title: A Weather-based Farming Model for Communities (WFMC)

overview.feedback: With the objective of building local level capacities of the farming communities to cope with agro-meteorological crop production risks, the M. S. Swaminathan Research Foundation experimented with the establishment of village level mini agro-met observatories in selected project villages namely, Kothur and Srirangapur in Andhra Pradesh and Kundai and Amda in Rajasthan on a pilot scale. The underlying hypothesis was that the data collected from the meteorological instruments by the community over a period of time would help the community to develop weather based thumb rules for taking appropriate farm decisions based on simple weather parameters like rainfall, wind speed, temperature and relative humidity.About 10 farmers, considered to be ‘Agro-met Farmers’ who used the agro-met data extensively for their farm operations and a set of ‘Control Farmers’ played a key role in demonstrating the utility value of the locally generated information besides providing useful insights on the how the enhanced capacity of the local communities, well managed local institutions help broadening the understanding of climate risks and in providing in-situ solutions. A variety of information was gathered from both the ‘Agro-met’ and ‘Control’ farmers practicing cropping system of maize (Kharif)-wheat (Rabi) through a pre-tested questionnaire and personal interviews at various stages of the crop production process.

responsibilities.initiating_agent: Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation (SDC)
responsibilities.executing_agent: NGOs and technical institutes
responsibilities.funding_source: Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation (SDC)

evaluative_information.success_factors: not specified
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: Time frames to assess the effectiveness of adaptation strategies at field level should perhaps be longer than the four year span of the V&A project. It will be important to monitor and quantify impacts over a longer period so that the lessons and insights drawn could be extrapolated for wider implications at the national and international levels.
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: not specified
evaluative_information.project_evaluation:
Analysis of data revealed that by adhering to farm decisions based on data generated from the mini observatory, the ‘Agro-met’ farmer group did record a benefit cost ratio of 1.2, from the cropping system of maize-wheat, while it was 0.96 for the ‘Control’ farmers. The partial budgeting analysis also indicated that there is an estimated positive change for the ‘Agro-met’ farmer group.
The agro-met experiment proved to be an example of a new knowledge based community empowerment that enhances its coping capacity. Thus the knowledge developed is useful to understand the role of both simple technological improvements that the local communities could relate to with appropriate training and the significance of sensitizing people to adverse impacts of climate change will help manage climate risks more prudently at the local level.

additional_information: This project is one part oft the "Vulnerability and Adaptation experiences from Rajasthan and Andhra Pradesh" by the SDC.

title: Adaptation for small farmers of coffee and tea

overview.feedback: The main part of this project is Capacity Building and Implementation of Integrated Coffee Management Practices. Around 872 coffee producers from 4 districts (Canchaque, Montero, San Miguel del Faique, Yamango) were involved.Those farmers not only contributed through their local and traditional knowledge to design the adaptation strategy, but were also sensitized to the needs and solutions to confront climate risks.10 technical advisors were trained to train 50 environmental promoters and 200 promoter farmers in climate change adaptation on coffee plantations at community level.To reduce the risk of landslides and prevent erosion on community land, the four districts were reforested. Hence, 4 communal nurseries with around 45,000 seedlings were installed in the four districts.Following the good practices in Nicaragua and Chiapas, CEPICAFE started the installation of 10 solar driers in Montero to assure the coffee drying process under changing precipitation patterns. More often unforeseeable rainfalls interrupt the sun drying process during harvest season, thus negatively affecting the quality of the green coffee beans.Furthermore CEPICAFE supported sustainable coffee practices, like soil conservation, irrigation, fertilization, pest control or shadow management.

responsibilities.executing_agent: Cafédirect (United Kingdom), Cepicafe and German Technical Cooperation Agency (GTZ)
responsibilities.funding_source: Cafedirect, German Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development (BMZ) and GTZ

evaluative_information.success_factors: Family empowerment. Environmental education at all levels. Sustaining income levels of families with activities that cushion the negative effects of climate change. Inter-agency partnerships to develop proposals.
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: The project was aimed directly by the headquarters and there was poor coordination with the PDRS.
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: No-regret
evaluative_information.project_evaluation:
Prolonged drought periods and water scarcity for communities and agriculture were identified as climate related risk threatening the coffee farmers.
During the process a comprehensive study on water management and measures to implement in order to improve water use and efficiency has been elaborated. As the identified measures require huge investments at the regional and public level, those measures could not be implemented during the AdapCC lifetime. CEPICAFE focused on trainings and advisory services for farmers to improve irrigation systems and water management at the community and farm level. It is recommended to further support improved water management techniques and involves the local and regional political institutions to access additional financing.

additional_information:
Another part of this project is Reforestation and Carbon Sequestration:
+ Reforestation project on 285 ha community land is planned
+ Nursery with 50.000 seedlings of native trees and pines installed
+ After 25 years carbon sequestration of 560.5 tCO2/ha on 285 ha, corresponding to 159,742.5 t CO2 in reforested areas expected
+ pre-sell of 5,092 carbon credits for approximately €60,000 by 2015

title: Adaptation measures as part of the Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Act (MNREGA) and Scheme

overview.feedback: “The Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Act (MNREGA) is an Indian job guarantee scheme, that came into effect on February 2, 2006 in 200 of India’s most backward districts. However, from April 1, 2008 the Act covers all of rural India. It provides a legal guarantee of 100 days of wage employment in a financial year to every rural household whose adult members volunteer to do unskilled manual work at the minimum wage rate notified for agricultural labour prescribed in the state or else an unemployment allowance. The main objective of the Act is to supplement wage employment opportunities in rural areas. Some of the key features of the Act are : -100 days of employment to a local rural household if it demands it and is willing to do unskilled manual work -A Job Card is necessary for demanding employment under NREGA. -A written application by a Job Card holding family to the Gram Panchayat or Programme Officer is necessary for demanding employment -All adult members whose names are on the Job Card can apply for employment. The entitlement of 100 days of employment in a financial year is for a household as an aggregate. Creation of durable assets and strengthening the livelihood resource base of the rural poor is one of the main objectives of the Scheme. The permissible works under this Scheme are: -Water Conservation -Drought proofing (including plantation and afforestation)-Flood control and protection works including drainage in water logged areas-Land development-Minor irrigation, horticulture and land development on the land of SC / ST / BPL / Indira Awas Yojana and land reform beneficiaries. -Rural connectivity to provide all-weather access The most important aspect of this Scheme is ensuring that there are a sufficient number of works that are available to respond to the demand for employment within 15 days of demand. The role of Gram Sabha and Gram Panchayat in the planning process is that the Gram Sabha should identify and recommend works and the Gram Panchayat should consolidate and send the recommendations of Gram Sabha to the Programme Officer. The Central government outlay for scheme is 401 billion or Rs. 40,100 crores in FY 2010-11. '

responsibilities.initiating_agent: National and State Govt.: Rural development
responsibilities.executing_agent: Panchayats

evaluative_information.success_factors: transparency of gram panchayats, regular disbursement of wages, social audit
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: corruption in releasing funds, elite capture and exclusion of weaker communities,only employment focus, activities not implemented according to a plan, spatially or time-wise, disconnected and scattered implementation of activities which may require broad scale planning
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: win win (ensures employment despite climate change impacts)
evaluative_information.project_evaluation:
National:NREGA commenced on February 2, 2006 in 200 districts, was expanded to cover another 130 districts in 2007-2008 and eventually covered all 593 districts in India by April 1, 2008. The outlay was Rs. 110 billion in 2006-2007, and rose steeply to Rs. 391 billion (140% increase in amount with respect to previous 2008-2009 budget) in 2009-2010. As of 30th June,2010 a total of 179,43,189 families in the country have been provided employment under MGNREGS. A specific study carried out in selected villages in Chitradurga district, Karnataka to examine the impact of the NREGA activities from the perspective of providing environmental services and reducing the vulnerability show :
• increased ground water recharge,
• increased water percolation,
• enhanced water storage in tanks,
• increase in soil fertility,
• reclamation of degraded lands and
• carbon sequestration.
2. These NREGA activities and the resulting environmental services contributed to increased crop and livestock production.
3. There was no example of any significant scale negative impacts from any of the NREGA activities implemented.
4. NREGA activities also reduced the vulnerability of crop production, water availability and livelihoods to uncertain and low rainfall, low water availability and poor soil fertility.
5. The field studies in Chitradurga have clearly demonstrated the potential of NREGA activities to provide environmental services as well as to reduce vulnerability, despite the short period of only 1 to 3 years to deliver the services. Longer period of 5-10 years is needed to realize the full environmental services or vulnerability reduction potential, due to the gestation period involved (e.g., ground water recharge, soil fertility improvement and forest growth).
6. NREGA activities were not implemented in the villages according to any micro-plan or watershed plan or in any sequential manner. Despite this limitation, many NREGA activities have the potential to provide guaranteed benefits. Examples of such activities for Chitradurga district are:
• Desilting of water bodies accompanied by silt removal and application to crop fields
• Land development leading to land leveling and cropping
• Afforestation (as a drought proofing activity) with appropriate species choice
• Construction of percolation tanks.

additional_information: Several impact assessment studies have been carried out on NREGA. (1) Independent surveys by economists such as Jean Dreze, found  that NREGA workers had to put up with numerous infringements of their rights without being able to do much about it: lack of work, delays in wage payment, non-payment of minimum wages, absence of worksite facilities, were common. Most of these irregularities remain unaddressed, often even unnoticed. The persistence of corruption is another aspect of this lack of accountability. Three related problems that have contributed to this state of affairs are: confusion about the operational requirements of the Act; absence of any grievance redress system; and lack of independent monitoring.     (2) Winrock India carried out a study of district level convergence between MG-NREGS & ongoing schemes of different Departments/ Ministries to ensure effective convergence for durable asset creation and promote strengthening of the livelihood resource base of the rural poor in the districts of Betul and Sehore in the central Indian state of Madhya Pradesh in India. It was found that at the district level, convergence is primarily limited to the planning stage itself, with elaborate discussions at the district level meetings amongst the concerned departments. Meanwhile, with inputs from the project team of Winrock, a few plans were developed in the two pilot districts for convergence between MG-NREGS and some line departments’ schemes such as those of Water Resource Department, Forest Department, Agriculture/Horticulture Department through involvement of KVKs for training & extension activities, Sports Department and Fisheries Department.                     (3) Another impact assessment was carried out by the Professional Institutional Networking (PIN) of Ministry of Rural Development, sanctioned by United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) in the three districts namely Sirsa in Haryana, Sirmaur in Himachal Pradesh and Hoshiarpur in Punjab. Some of the main finding's main findings of Panchayat perception, worksite verification, workers and non workers assessment of NREGS are: Role of Gram Panchayats is becoming extremely crucial in planning and implementation of the rural development scheme. Elected Panchayats in districts of Sirsa and Sirmaur reported that they received training, whereas only one fifth of the Panchayats in Hoshiarpur district received training on NREGA. Regarding the Panchayati Awareness about Measurement Book (MB), it was seen that Panchayats awareness with regard to measurement Book among Panchayat members is very good in Sirsa as compared to Hoshiarpur and Sirmaur District GPs. On the impact of NREGA on employment genaration, all the Panchayats reported that economic condition of the wage earners has improved and moreover the workers need not to go outside the village to seek work. The common problem areas quoted were: lack of Proper trained staff, delay in receiving funds and lack of awareness on different aspect of NREGA guidelines and convergence with other department etc.

title: Adaptation of Water Management

overview.feedback: The initial objective of the effort was to evaluate current and future vulnerability of water resources to climate change.  Three case study reports were produced that summarized current and future livelihood systems and hydrology in each of the 5 ecological zones. To assess future vulnerability, the researchers developed a scenario-driven dataset for a water balance model using the WEAP water planning model for each case study area. The second objective was to identify a comprehensive set of adaptation strategies that address water scarcity and build resiliency in vulnerable communities. Based on the outcome of these adaptation strategy scenarios, recommendations for national policies are being formulated for national adaptation to water stress.

title: Adaptation to Climate Change and Insurance (ACCI)

overview.feedback: Adaptation to Climate Change and Insurance (ACCI) is a bilateral project between the Kenyan and German Governments, funded by the German Federal Ministry for the Environment, Nature Conservation and Nuclear Safety (BMU) and the Government of Kenya. It is implemented by the Kenyan Ministry of Agriculture and GIZ – Deutsche Gesellschaft für Internationale Zusammenarbeit.The goal of the ACCI project is to enable farmers and small-scale enterprises to increase their capacity to adapt to climate change in Homa Bay and Busia County.ACCI through its partners supports	? Systematic collection, analysis and dissemination of information about climate change and related risks	? Dissemination of adapted site specific good agricultural practices	? Promotion of insurance products as measures to mitigate climate risks	? Monitoring of local adaptation capacity to climate changeACCI collaborates with public and private sectors to provide these services to farmers. The extension structure of the Ministry of Agriculture is the main implementing partner. In addition, local NGOs, CBOs, insurance companies and financial institutions are involved in implementation. The project started at the beginning of 2011 and will run until the end of 2013.

responsibilities.funding_source: German Federal Ministry of the Environment, Nature Conservation and Nuclear Safety (BMU)

title: Adaptation to Climate Change in the Nile Delta through Integrated Coastal Zone Management

overview.feedback: The goal of the project is to enhance Egypt’s resilience and reduce vulnerability to Climate Change impacts. The objective of the proposed project is to integrate the management of SLR risks into the development of Egypt’s Low Elevation Coastal Zone (LECZ) in the Nile Delta. To minimize the likelihood of coastal disasters, the most effective adaptation policy options include a combination of(1) Upgraded protection, (2) managing subsidence, and (3) land use planning, focusing new development away from the floodplain, and (worst case) (4) selective relocation away from vulnerable, existing city areas. The proposed project includes upgrading protection through the introduction of Environmentally-friendly ‘soft’ shoreline protection, as well as modifications in regulatory framework and institutional capacity to ensure land use planning, zoning, to account for climate risks.

responsibilities.executing_agent: Ministry of Water Resources and Irrigation, Coastal Research Institute, the Egyptian Shore Protection Authority
responsibilities.funding_source: GEF The Special Climate Change Fund (SCCF)

evaluative_information.success_factors:
Four main barriers for the institutionalization of climate change related adaptation policies and
measures in Egypt :
1. Legal framework for coastal protection and management is incomplete and suffers from number of critical gaps
2. A comprehensive institutional framework for coastal protection and management that addresses climate change risks is not in place
3. Agencies responsible for coastal zone management do not have the technical capacity of necessary knowledge to address adaptation concerns
4. Limited or no public involvement in the IZCM process
evaluative_information.limiting_factors:
Local stakeholders are not committed to implement
adaptation measures on the ground; precluding systematic tracking of development and adaptation benefits
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: The on-the ground measures designed under the project will also be scrutinized with cost-benefit analysis for identifying the low and no regret adaptation actions.
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: not specified

title: Adaptation to Climate change of coastal cities

overview.feedback: The project has 2 objectives : - Carry out an overall problem assessment in order to ensure the long term; sustainability of investments through an integrated planning implementation.- Clarify the competence attribution between stakeholders.To reach these objectives four main axes have been, defined :1. Data collection: use all existing studies (causes of observed phenomena) and tested solutions (in the field of sand dune stabilization) and set up a data management system in order to produce, for decision makers, information for planning, monitoring and evaluation of ACC options.2. Support for the adoption of in integrated action plan: promote an adapted institutional and legal framework to implement and consolidate sustainable adaptation options to combat climate change impacts. 3. Capacity building: Advice, training and skill perfection of different actors (Ministry of Environment (MDEDD), technical departments, Nouakchott municipalities)  to develop their capacities on the organizational and technical levels for a transparent planning and implementation.4. Networking: Promote inter-sectoral dialogue and cooperation processes to ensure a large integration of concerned stakeholders on the state and local level as well as involvement of civil society.

title: Adaptation to Climate Change Program (PACC)

overview.feedback: The project aims to contribute to knowledge, identifying and implementing adaptation measures from the population, public and private institutions and governments at the regions of Cusco and Apurimac, having an impact on policies at national and international level. The program has emphasis on water resources, reducing the risk of natural disasters and food security.A website will promote knowledge management around adaptation to climate change in Peru and work as a tool to inform and sensitize local, regional and national actors.

responsibilities.executing_agent: Predes, Intercooperation, Libélula, Ministry of Environment, Apurimac Regional Government and Cusco Regional Government , National Service of Meteorology and Hydrology of Peru (SENAMHI)
responsibilities.funding_source: Swiss Agency for Development and Cooperation (SDC)

evaluative_information.success_factors: The direct impacts of climate change occur at the local level, affecting mainly the livelihood of the most vulnerable. PACC promotes that the adaptation measures at the watershed-level have a solid base of knowledge and also an effect on the reduction of the vulnerabilities at both "community" and "family" level, and therefore have a transforming dimension. Hence, adaptation, will also be constituted into a strategy that contributes to the improvement of the quality of life, and in the development of local communities.
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: (i) Lack of hydrological and meteorological data, which can provide a historic perspective to allow making a distinction between effects and impacts of climate change, from climate variability; (ii) lack of data concerning other climate variables (in addition to temperature and precipitation) such as wind, humidity and radiation; (iii) scarce interdisciplinary investigation tradition and experience, which demands special efforts to coordinate through various spaces (meetings, workshops, online platforms, etc).
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: not specified
evaluative_information.project_evaluation:
The results achieved at the time are: diagnostics, monitoring and reporting (with the Regional Information System), application of adaptation measures and policies.
Information are available via www.paccperu.org.pe

additional_information:
The program will promote from its second year after the organization of local, pilot adaptation priority watersheds.
These pilot projects will be agreed with the municipalities and social organizations of these watersheds, and prioritize adaptation measures around water management, food security and reducing risks, underpinned by knowledge and experiences related to these 3 axes.

title: Adaptation to Climate Change Project

overview.feedback: The Project Adaptation to Climate Change (ACC) aims to reduce climate risks by coordinating actors in the region of Souss-Massa-Draa promoting effective communication, enhancement of existing knowledge and a system of monitoring, reporting and support of the regional observatory of the environment and sustainable developmentThe project targets in the first phase five specific objectives:1.	Introduction of climate effects in a system of risk management and development planning at regional and municipal levels,2.	Implementation of sectoral and territorial plans and strategies in concrete measures and projects3.	Consideration of vulnerable groups (women, elderly and poor) in risk reduction measures on the economic and social levels,4.	Integrating climate risks into sectoral planning and promoting inter-sectoral synergy5.	Establishing an information and advice system on ACC in the region.

title: Adaptation to Climate Change through sustainable management in watersheds

overview.feedback: This project includes: (a) diversification of agriculture (Promotion of salt tolerant rice varieties and other crops); (b) homestead-based forestry, horticulture and vegetable cultivation; (c) promotion of integrated rice, shrimp and fish culture; (d) pro-poor brackish water aquaculture; (e) identifcation of livelihood options and activities for women and marginal groups; (f) small entrepreneurship development based on local resources such as bee-keeping; (g) rainwater harvest and sweet water conservation for drinking and domestic; (h) sweet water conservation and efficient use for irrigation to agriculture; (i) preparedness for disaster risk (cyclone, tidal surge and sea level rise) reduction to save lives, properties and household assets; and (j) promotion of coastal afforestation for protection river bank erosion, prevent cyclone damages, etc.

title: Adaptation to Coastal Erosion - bulkheads and revetments

overview.feedback: The planned adaptation strategy involves the building of bulkheads and revetments complemented by bio-engineering. Revetments and vegetation are desirable adaptation measures for portions of the coast where there is recreational or docking use for the beach and it will also allow easier access to the sea. The revetments should be constructed from boulders and concrete. Bulkheads, on the other hand, are upright structures that form a wall. These are recommended only in limited portions of the coast due to their negative impacts leading to undesirable changes in the beach and due to their prohibitive cost.

title: Adaptation to Coastal Erosion - relocation

overview.feedback: San Fernando Bay is a densely populated area and it is a place where coastal erosion is already prevalent. Coastal erosion scale and impact are both expected to become more widespread due to climate change and sea level rise. A relocation facility for poor coastal dwellers, called the Fisherman’s Village, was constructed by the city local government. The village has 87 housing units which can be availed by fishermen. The dwelling units in the village are not immediately habitable and would require an initial outlay from the occupants for the construction of the bathroom and kitchen, and for the installation of doors and windows.

responsibilities.executing_agent: Worldbank, government

evaluative_information.success_factors: not specified
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: not specified
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: not specified
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: Only 20 units are reported to be occupied as of March 2008. It was found that this low number was because most of the fishermen found the cost of relocating to the facility unaffordable. The dwelling units in the village are not immediately habitable and would require an estimated Php 140,000 initial outlay from the occupants. It will also cost them about Php 700 per month, amortized over 25 years, to pay for the whole value of the house.

title: Adaptation to the Impact of Expedited Glacial Retreat in the Tropical Andes Project (PRAA)

title: Adapting to and reducing the risk of Future Extreme Rainfall on Urban Flooding

overview.feedback: The focus is to design a user-friendly climate- change guideline document for municipal decision makers. This guideline is meant to assist decision makers in improved management of the risks that currently arise with climate variability and those that may occur with future climate change. In this project, high resolution regional climate modelling will be applied to improve understanding of the effects that anthropogenic warming may have on thunderstorm formation over the Highveld. These modelled inputs will then be considered in a range of scenarios for planning purposes. These outputs will be workshopped with city managers so that a set of realistic scenarios can be developed. The critical dimension of this work will be the co-adaptive management and design of guidelines.

responsibilities.executing_agent: ReVAMP, The School of Geography, Archaeology and Environmental Studies , Wits University

evaluative_information.success_factors: The extent to which we believe the project would be most effective does exceed the budget given by the Water Resource Comission (WRC). Any resistance from the Municipality will delay the project and have great effect on its success.
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: The effectiveness of the project is directly dependent on the municipality taking it into consideration and implementing the guidelines and recommendations.
evaluative_information.synergies_to_mitigation: No, the focus is on adaptation.
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: Many municipalities are already having issues with flooding and strained capacity to deal with the effects of thunderstorms. Infrastructure needs to be improved and planning needs to be done in any case. At this point it is relatively inexpensive to include climate change projections into planning now compared to retrofitting in the future.
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: We are still in the initial phases of the project but we have had positive feedback from the municipality and they are willing to work with us on the project. The individuals in the team show positivity towards being able to merge the information and modeled data.

additional_information:
a) How has climate change information or climate science been considered in the design and implementation of the project?
Intrinsically – we are working directly with climate change models (from the CSIR) and finding how climate change will affect flooding and then adapting to that.
We are working mainly with SAWS data for OR Tambo airport and Ekurhuleni Municipality. Downscaled Climate Models from the CSIR are used and these data are used in hydrological model to improve flood prediction and vulnerability. We are working directly with the municipality and we are using their reports and policy documents to attain baseline information.

title: Adapting to climate change in China (ACCC)

overview.feedback: This project run by UK DIFD aims at improving development of climate change science in China and raise awareness of the need to factor in climate change to broader government policy.Risk assessments, based upon vulnerability and impacts are produced at national and provincial level and climate risks are integrated into planning and management within the three project provinces. Chinese policymakers and key stakeholders are informed and made aware of the ways to address climate change adaptation within China’s development process.Communication and information sharing is an important component of the project which is implemented mainly through: publications and trainings. China, UK and other countries in Asia and Africa share knowledge to further develop climate change adaptation approaches.

title: Adaptive capacities of communities to cope with flood situations

overview.feedback: Local communities adapt spontaneously to deal with problems of flood, water-logging and climate change.This booklet, collectively brought together by voluntary organizations working with the poor in the flood and water-log affected regions of Eastern Uttar Pradesh documents 45 indigenous adaptation practices. The broad objective of this compilation is to share these various local and traditional flood responsive ways and measures, with people over a larger area in order to build and strengthen their adaptive capabilities and capacities in tackling disasters like floods and thereby mitigating their impacts.

responsibilities.executing_agent: NGO:Gorakhpur Environmental Action Group (GEAG), Gorakhpur

evaluative_information.success_factors: Established networks and trust with local NGOs, CBOs and communities and interaction over time to be able to observe directly as well as to elicit accurate information on adaptation  practices.
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: Limitations to adaptation to flood situations by the community are: state of natural resources, basic physical infrastructure, livelihood systems, gender sensitivity and access to information
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: no regret:The documentation of these measures is dependent on the occurrence of floods
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: In terms of the practices followed by the community to adapt to floods, the review shows that it helps them in bearing their losses and that they are able to return to their normal lives as soon as possible with whatever resources they are left with. Remarkably, there is no wide scale migration and people continue to inhabit these regions and learn to live with floods. The documentation of these practices has itself been widely circulated to multiple NGOs, organisations and donors working on climate change adaptation int he country.

additional_information:
The review found that a community's adaptive capacities are affected mainly by
· The state of natural resources in the area.
· The livelihood system and opportunities at the local level.
· Income generating opportunities outside, in the nearby areas.
· Basic physical infrastructures, services and facilities like roads, housing, drinking water, etc. at the local level.
· The area's socio-economic and gender sensitivities.
· People's accessibility to information and know-how.
· Social capital in the community

title: Adaptive water management at a local scale

overview.feedback: The project is part of a larger transnational ADAPTS project named Adaptive Local Water Management which comprising 6 countries (Brazil, Peru, Botswana, Ghana, Ethiopia and Vietnam). The goal of the ADAPTS project is to increase countries’ adaptive capacities by achieving the inclusion of climate change and adaptation considerations in (local-regional) water policies, planning and investment decisions.  The project main objective is to enable the local counterpart – The Centre for Social Research and Development (CSRD) in Vietnam, to take climate change and adaptation into account when working with local communities, to support selected local adaptation measures and to play a leading role in facilitating a dialogue between communities, researchers and government authorities on climate change and adaptation in the Thua Thien-Hue river basin.

responsibilities.initiating_agent: The Provincial People’s Committee of Thua Thien-Hue and The Ministry for Development Cooperation of Netherlands.
responsibilities.executing_agent: CSRD of Hue-Thua Thien,IVM/VU University and Both ENDS
responsibilities.funding_source: The Ministry for Development Cooperation of the Netherlands

evaluative_information.success_factors:
-Participate of communities and local government.
-Partnership of people/ communities and government to ensure sustainability of project activities.
-Engage local and scientific knowledge
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: -Short time scale
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: not specified
evaluative_information.project_evaluation:
-The CSRD developed a good capacity on the issue of climate change and adaptation in their work with local communities, provincial and local authorities through a training course and an extensive survey on adaptation priorities of local communities and existing initiatives.
-The project assisted the Environmental Protection Branch (DONRE) of Thua Thien-Hue to draft part of the provincial action plan on climate change adaptation. This action plan was officially approved by the Province People Committee on the 28th of August 2010.
-The option of mangroves planting has been identified, analyzed and chosen as a specific adaptation measure to be supported. It serves as a buffer against floods and related erosion and providing other beneficial functions such as habitat for species in the basin.
-The project’s findings and outcomes has been disseminated at the national and international workshops, conferences which has contributed to drawing attention and resources mobilization to those who are interested in climate change issue in the region.

additional_information: -The project’s main approach: i/ Knowledge development: developing climate change information and studying how local water management can be made “climate-proof”. The Participatory Rural Appraisal (PRA) methods used for collecting information and identifying local adaptation measures in the study. ii/ Dialogues: establishing policy dialogues between local and national stakeholders on the issues of sustainable water management, climate change and adaptation. iii/ Local action:  the identification, support, documentation, analysis and dissemination of innovative, locally-based interventions to assure that local knowledge and visions are included in basin and national policy dialogues.

title: Adjusting to Floods on the Brahmaputra Plains

overview.feedback: The ICIMOD supported study in Assam documents the ways and means through which the local communities of the study sites have so far coped with and adapted to changing nature of climate and water induced hazards like floods, flash floods, sand casting, river bank erosion, rainstorms etc. Changing nature of the water induced hazards in the study area is a manifestation of the impacts of climate change in the Himalayan region.  The perceptions, practices and strategies developed by communities utilising mainly their traditional knowledge systems have been documented and analysed. These include – raised houses, alternate livelihoods, food storage, water resistant paddy, shifting of village site. Factors influencing the community’s adaptive capacity have also been highlighted.

responsibilities.initiating_agent: ICIMOD (International Centre for Integrated Mountain Development)
responsibilities.executing_agent: Aaranyak
responsibilities.funding_source: ICIMOD (International Centre for Integrated Mountain Development)

evaluative_information.success_factors: established rapport and familiarity with the community, willingness to share traditional coping practices
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: dependent on recall
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: best practices and documentation can help in policy development and dissemination to other flood affected regions
evaluative_information.project_evaluation:
Five case studies were carried out under the ‘Too Much and Too Little Water’ project of ICIMOD, one each in Nepal, China and Pakistan and two in India (Assam and Bihar). The synthesis report contains the abstracts of all the five country case studies. The full reports are published separately for each case study. A short documentary film (11 minutes) titled ‘Living with flood’ has also been made as a supplement to the case study in Assam.
ICIMOD is complementing the field study with a comprehensive study on the policy aspects of adaptation to climate and water induced hazards in the Greater Himalayan Region. In India the study is being carried out by the National Institute of Disaster Management (NIDM), Ministry of Home Affairs, Government of India, New Delhi.

title: Advancing Capacity to support Climate Change Adaptation (ACCCA): five pilot projects

overview.feedback: This project seeks to reduce the vulnerability of poor populations in sub-Saharan Africa to climate change by mobilizing scientists and all the other actors concerned to inform political decision-making. It will do so by means of five pilot projects in rural and urban populations. The project will emphasize the generation, organization and communication of information on the risks resulting from climate change, climate variability and extreme climatic events, as well as preparation for their effects on food security (Cameroon, Ethiopia, Kenya) and water supply (South Africa, Burkina Faso). The lessons drawn from the five experiments can then be applied in larger scale projects.The ACCCA project is currently supporting 19 adaptation pilot actions in 17 countries across Africa and Asia. The pilot projects selected for funding under ACCCA each aim to achieve the following objectives: •	Identify and prioritize climate risks to stakeholders and the climate influenced decisions that they face; •	Assess available knowledge about risks and adaptation opportunities, as well as synthesize the knowledge in terms that are directly relevant to stakeholder concerns and decision-making needs; •	Develop, test and disseminate risk communication materials that are designed to assist adaptation decisions; •	Use the risk communication materials in stakeholder forums to develop recommendations for climate change adaptation and promote their adoption; and •	Identify critical knowledge gaps that impede effective adaptation decisions and design assessment activities that would generate new knowledge to fill them.

responsibilities.executing_agent: * UNITAR  * ENDA-TM  * SEI Oxford Office * CSAG-UCT* START * START SE ASIA * START Temperate East Asia

evaluative_information.success_factors:
• Understanding the local decision making context for climate risk management and the baseline status of climate-related knowledge is essential for determining information needs and tailoring communication strategies

• Social learning between project implementers and stakeholders, based on early and active stakeholder engagement, such as through participatory development and testing of risk communication material, is key to producing information that is relevant to stakeholders and that can empower them to act.
evaluative_information.limiting_factors:
• Difficulties were encountered in relaying technical and scientific information in an easy-to-understand manner because of the complexities of the subject and the tendency for the nature of the scientific information to become transformed during translation.

• Developing clear and relevant climate risk communication messages requires collating large and often complex sets of information and knowledge from diverse sources
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: The need for appropriate communication of climate risks is particularly great in the developing world where vulnerability to climate change and variability is extensive and adaptation planning is lagging, stemming from poor understanding and awareness of the long-term impacts and implications of climate change on livelihoods and development, low institutional capacities to relay information, and lack of access to resources to support adaptation planning
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: Through this process, teams within the pilot projects improved their capacity to integrate climate information and communicate risk to local communities and policy makers, while the climate change c=science and risk communication support teams gained familiarity of and appreciation for the complexities and challenges involved in promoting improved understanding of climate change science and the development of climate risk communication tools and methods to support robust decision making  for adaptation

title: Advancing the Micronesia Challenge through New Protected Areas

overview.feedback: Island states such as the Republic of the Marshall Islands, the Republic of Palau and the Federated States of Micronesia are particularly vulnerable to the effects of climate change. In its Fourth Assessment Report, the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) has identified with great certainty island states’ vulnerability to sea level rise, deterioration of coastal conditions, diminution of fresh-water resources and increased invasion by non-native species. The project will assist the implementation of the Micronesia Challenge in designating areas for conservation, in order to build resilience to the effects of climate change and address the four threats as described by the IPCC. To achieve this, target sites are identified such as the Yela Swamp Forest in the Federated States of Micronesia, threatened by retreating coastline and advancing land development, the Northern Reefs of Palau affected by coral bleaching, and the island home of the Woja community on Majuro Atoll, which faces freshwater scarcity due to poorly planned water extraction and management. Measures undertaken are mostly conservation activities through collaborative agreements with the local stakeholders.

responsibilities.executing_agent: Micronesia Conservation Trust, Palau Conservation Society; provincial governments of Kayangel and Ngarchelong Federated States of Micronesia; Environment Landowners Association; Chuuk Conservation Society; Marshall Islands: Marine Resources Authority

title: Affordable Drip Irrigation Technology Intervention Program (ADITI)

overview.feedback: Low cost, modular, protective drip irrigation can help save and diversify crops for small rainfed farmers.  IDEI’s micro irrigation program for water scarce states in India includes the Affordable Drip Irrigation Technology Intervention (ADITI) program  which promotes the use of low cost drip irrigation kits. These kits are applicable in a wide range of plot sizes varying from 20 square meters to 1000 square meters, with prices ranging from Rs.250 to Rs.4000. These kits are manufactured and supplied by private agencies supported by IDEI. The ADITI kits reduce the limitations of rain fed farming, enabling a farmer to grow a wider variety of crops, cultivate all the year round, reduce the water use by 30-60%, and increase crop yields by 20-40%.

responsibilities.executing_agent: IDEI, local NGOs, private manufacturers and distributors
responsibilities.funding_source: multiple sources and user financing for the product

evaluative_information.success_factors: Research and development, technical aspects:  Research and development (The program has effectively addressed the issue of affordability by reducing costs through R & D and offering modular systems), technical aspects (There is backup service support available for addressing technical problems that ensures a user).
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: Labor: some low cost drip systems require more labor than conventional systems which may not be easily available
evaluative_information.synergies_to_mitigation: Reduce energy consumption: Drip systems operated with gravity pressure or with low-pressure low horsepower pump reduce energy consumption
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: Win-win: water conservation
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: Large number of drip irrigation kits have been sold so far (2,95,000). . Studies have been conducted to evaluate the use of these kits and also their impact on the farmers income and their consumption pattern that show a positive impact of the drip irrigation kits.  The kits are seen to reduce water use by over 50%, increase yields by 20% -40%, and can double the amount of irrigated area in situations of low water availability

additional_information: The low cost drip irrigation system is designed to be incremental, ranging from US$ 5.6 to $ 88.9 for plot sizes of 20 square meters to 1000 square meters and can be expanded with profits derived from crop. The kits have been designed so that they can address the irrigation issues of different farmers with varying plot sizes.

title: Agroforestry

overview.feedback: The wide range of traditional agroforestry (planting crops among trees) practices in Sri Lanka offers a promising solution to the ever-declining per capita availability of agricultural land and protects the land from degradation. On most coconut estates a variety of different crops are cultivated including food crops, spices and condiments, and cash crops. On some plantations pasture grass is grown in between coconut trees to allow cattle to graze.  Bananas, black pepper, coffee, ginger, turmeric, betel, vegetables and pineapple are the preferred species because they can grow in shade and provide a good income. The most common crop mixtures in mature coconut plantations are coffee and banana; coffee and pineapple; pineapple and papaya; and banana, coffee and cacao.  When farmers intercrop, the coconut trees benefit from the manure and fertilizers, weeds are eliminated, and the land is more productive.

title: Ajeevika - Livelihoods Improvement Project for the Himalayas

overview.feedback: The overall project objectives are to assess the impacts of climate change and socioeconomic changes on the poor in mountain areas of Hindu Kush Himalaya region, identify adaptation/coping mechanisms and enhance livelihood opportunities. The project is targeted at mountain communities (poor households and women) living in the western and eastern Himalayas. In the state of Uttaranchal the project aims to enhance livelihood opportunities, access required financial resources, manage new technology and institutions, establish non-farm enterprises, increase income through more sustainable cultivation systems.The project works by supporting local entrepreneurship and SHGs and demonstrations covering diverse activities related to agriculture, horticulture, livestock, forestry, soil and water conservation and ecotourism. The project is expected to have the following results: promote approximately 2846 community institutions, capacity building of target population with special emphasis on women and landless labourers, effective savings and credit operation with SHGs, business plan development for establishing enterprise and identification of policy issues affecting livelihoods of poor. The project has set up a company to support small entrepreneurs and help access and interface with financial and credit systems.

title: Alternate Cropping Pattern for Tamil Nadu

overview.feedback: The state of Tamil Nadu experienced four continous years of drought from 2000-2004.  During this period some experience was gained in promoting alternate crops with lower water requirements.  Building on that, this research study  has identified alternate cropping patterns for the state of Tamil Nadu based on soil, climatic resources,  surface water availability and social requirements.  Alternate crop combinations are suggested based on the amount of rainfall and specific crop varieties identified for seven different agro-climatic zones.  Crop combinations are developed for three rainfall and drought scenarios - normal rainfall (+-19% of average rainfall), moderate drought (-19-59%) and severe drought (>-59%) situations, and keeping in mind the water availability context  - specifically for  command areas, tank fed areas, well irrigated and dryland areas.  Efforts have been made  to propose cropping pattern that are economically viable.  Farmers may choose the appropriate cropping pattern, based on the seasonal rainfall forecast given by Department of Agricultural Meteorology, fifteen days before the start of the season.

responsibilities.executing_agent: Tamil Nadu Agricultural University, district joint directors of agriculture

evaluative_information.success_factors: technical feasibility and advancement (the study should be accurate so that it can be implemented on the field)
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: biological, farm and community compatibility; agronomic adoptability; economic viability and socio-cultural acceptability. The communication of the seasonal forecasts, and cropping patterns needs to happen in a small window of a fortnight when farmers decide on the cropping pattern at the start of the season. Also seeds need to be available in adequate quantity for the proposed cropping combinations.
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: win win: the system is being developed to reduce the impacts of climate change
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: Evaluation information was not available.

additional_information:
"For example for Tank-irrigated areas in Kancheepuram district in the North Eastern Zone, the normal combination is of rice-rice. lab / cluster bean / bhendi) (Nov.-Feb.) for servere drought years."

title: An evaluation of the sensitivity of socio-economic activities to climate change in climatically divergent South African catchments

overview.feedback: To increase the ability to respond to change is crucial in light of projected climate change and enhanced climate variability for South Africa. The country is faced with stressed water resources already and does not have a high level of capacity to cope and adapt. Consequently, a transition into a pro-active, adaptive management approach is imperative. It calls for a highly integrated management concept at catchment level, based on sound understanding of the interdependence of different key factors, such as economic and human needs, environmental requirements and management capacity under CC conditions. One starting point is a detailed analysis of the biophysical baseline and environmental as well as social-economic responses, in order equitably allocate water to all sectors. Knowledge of levels of vulnerability and policy driven opportunities of adaptability within selected catchments will bring comprehensive awareness of alternative strategies, for all of which adequate information management is also critical.

responsibilities.executing_agent: University of KwaZulu-Natal, School of Bioresources Engineering and Environmental Hydrology

evaluative_information.success_factors: Implementation has to be done by governmental bodies and stakeholders in the water sector.
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: Project designs actions through participatory processes in order to recommend actions that are feasible
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: The proposed research outcomes will provide greater security for SOCIETAL and ECONOMIC ACTIVITIES under CC by decreasing vulnerability in each of the selected catchments. Pro-active management will assure any decision-taking momentum to be on a reasonable time and space scale and hence early adaptation to the different stresses initiated by projected CV/CC and associated land use and demographic changes can be introduced, taking into account uncertainties.
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: Only to be stated after project completion.

title: Artificial Recharge to Ground Water through dugwells

overview.feedback: The Central Ground Water Board (CGWB), under the Ministry of Water Resources, had implemented a study on Ground Water in the IX plan in which recharge structures were constructed in areas where water scarcity existed. The performance evaluation studies indicated increased availability of ground water especially in lean months. In the X plan a rain water harvesting and artifial recharge to ground water was taken up in over-exploied blocks of four states. In the XI plan, the scheme of Artificial Recharge to Groundwater through dugwells has been taken up under the mandate of the Overall Master Plan for Artificial Recharge to Groundwater, prepared in 2002 by the Central Ground Water Board. This scheme promotes ground water recharge by promoting and financing the construction of dug well recharge structures for the 4.455 million existinging irrigation wells.  This includes a filter pit for simple filteration of rainwater that is then diverted into existing wells for groundwater recharge.This scheme is implemented in 1180 blocks of seven states namely, Andhra Pradesh, Maharashtra, Karnataka, Rajasthan, Tamil Nadu, Gujarat & Madhya Pradesh at an estimated cost of Rs. 1798.71 crores given by the Ministry of Finance through NABARD. The scheme provides 100% subsidy to marginal and small farmers and 50% subsidy to other farmers. An increase in ground water recharge will improve agricultural production (irrigation) and drinking water supply, enhance drought mitigation and benefit economic development. It will also mitigate ground water quality problems such as that of floride.

responsibilities.initiating_agent: Central Ground Water Board(CGWB), NABARD, Ministry of Water Resources
responsibilities.executing_agent: NABARD. State Government, Panchayati Raj Institutions, CGWB, NGOs

evaluative_information.success_factors: financial  (A huge cost is incurred in installing these structures and is a pre-requisite for the scheme to be successful), Quality of construction and maintenance, and monitoring
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: Limited monitoring
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: win-win (environmental benefits: improved water quality, recharge of ground water; socio-economic benefits: improved water availability for domestic and agricultural purposes.)
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: Earlier performance evaluation studies in the IX plan show increased availability of ground water especially in lean months.

title: ASEAN-German Programme on Response to Climate Change (GAP-CC)

overview.feedback: GAP-CC supports ASEAN in advancing the implementationof regionally coordinated strategies and policies forfood security and climate protection within its MemberStates. It aims to channel lessons and experience from individualcountry action into the work of the regional organisation,and vice versa. 	GAP-CC runs on two tracks which are linked in an integratedapproach involving both the ASEAN Secretariat andMember States and supports the- “Adaptation and Mitigation Strategies in Support of theASEAN Multi-Sectoral Framework on Climate Change:Agriculture, and Forestry toward Food Security” (AFCC)which is steered from Jakarta

responsibilities.initiating_agent: ASEAN Secretariat and ASEAN Member States
responsibilities.executing_agent: Deutsche Gesellschaft für internationale Zusammenarbeit (GIZ) GmbH
responsibilities.funding_source: German Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development (BMZ)

evaluative_information.success_factors: The cooperation and initiative of the project partner (ASEAN) is crucial. Highly dependent on individual, motivated people in the ASEAN and to identify champions among member states to lead the policy discussion on a regional level. Also cooperation with bilateral GIZ programs is crucial in order to find implementation examples and showcases and have on the ground linkages.
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: “The ASEAN way” with the principles of non-interference, and unanimity and very long decision processes. Institutional set up of ASEAN with strict divisions without much exchange (environment vs economy including agriculture). Lastly, there is not implementation power of ASEAN, member countries implement regional policies based on individual capacities and needs
evaluative_information.synergies_to_mitigation: No. However mitigation can also be looked at in the climate proofing process which is promoted through GAP-CC.
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: General capacity building in Climate Change and specific workshop methodologies (e.g. climate proofing training to ASEAN Member states in the agricultural sector).

title: Asian Cities Climate Change Resilience Network (ACCCRN) in Viet Nam

overview.feedback: The project is part of a larger transnational project named Asian Cities Climate Change Resilience Network (ACCCRN) which comprising 4 countries (India, Indonesia, Thailand and Vietnam). Three cities has been selected in Vietnam are Da Nang, Can Tho and Quy Nhon. The goal of project is to develop collaborative action plans for adaptation to climate change to benefit poor and vulnerable residents, which is build capacity for city governments, city-level organizations to enable them to reduce climate vulnerability, and to prepare funding proposals for donor support to adaptation plans. In each city, the project will working with city technical Agencies to help the integration of climate change issues into their planning and to raise awareness of future climate impacts and to build up capacity and responses of local organizations.It is composed four phase:1/. City scoping and selection2/. City – level engagement and capacity development3/. Implementation of effective urban resilience building projects4/. Replication

responsibilities.executing_agent: Institute for Social and Environmental Transition (U.S.A), National Institute for Science and Technology Policy and Strategy Studies, Challenge to Change

evaluative_information.success_factors:
- The response of the people involved and the local government
- The project must be in line with the strategic directions of “National Target Program to Respond to Climate Change” and “National Strategy for Natural Disaster Prevention, Response and Mitigation to 2020” which issued by Government.
evaluative_information.limiting_factors:
- The awareness of staff in the local organizations on the impacts of climate change is low.
- Lack of information sharing and management across sectors
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: not specified
evaluative_information.project_evaluation:
The project is under running.
-The expected results are:
+ The report of “Responding to urban Climate change” to be edited and published
+ Organize training courses on building design climate change adaptation plan for the cities ACCCRN member.
+ Support planting mangrove forest in Thi Nai Lagoon, Quy Nhon.
+ Organized National Workshop is to training and introduction to the principles, methods, tools and planning processes to adapt to climate change for focal point staff in each city.

additional_information:
- The most vulnerable populations in the ACCCRN cities are: Recent migrants who lack residential registration; At-risk communities in coastal or floodplain sites that are resettle to new locations; Women, children, parents, and poor.
- A combination of methods and tools centered on Shared Learning Dialogues and climate vulnerability analyses that they have adapted to their specific city contexts to use in the project.
- A climate change scenario carried out by Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment (MONRE) will be used to this project.

title: Assessment of regions affected by tropical glacier retreat

overview.feedback: The project has two major components: research of Mururata retreat and evaluation of adaptation measures to climate change for planning, prioritization and implementation in the future. The project is developed in rural communities whose livelihood is mainly based on agricultural activities. It aims at developing of a strategy for climate change adaptation and establishing mechanisms trough agreements and dialogues for efficient use and management of water resources in regions affected by the retreat of glaciers. This should ensure the provision of urban drinking water without compromising surrounding rural production systems. The project focuces on a scientific research of Murata and Illimani glacier retreat and its influence on water availability in the Choquecota watershed through incorporating hydrometic stations for monitoring as well as on identifying of climate change impacts on natural and social systems through the work with community members.

responsibilities.initiating_agent: Project funded by the Embassy of Denmark. Prior approval
responsibilities.executing_agent: Technical equipment Sustainable Water NGO
responsibilities.funding_source: Project funded by the Embassy of Denmark

evaluative_information.success_factors: Not appear during the implementation of the project, but institutional changes (municipality) can now perform critical situations for the implementation of measures.
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: No single factor limiting the application of the adaptation strategy in place.
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: No regret
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: Baseline information about the case study related to climate change impacts as well as strategic document on climate change adaptation are developed. The communities of the Palca watershed were trained on the topic of climate change adaptation. Such training was participatory and proactive, as community members recognize the current and future effects of climate change and are able to propose solutions to the problem.

additional_information: Strengthening the ability to identify natural resource problems and involvement of community members in solving them.

title: Assessment of small and medium scale hydropower plants: synergies and trade offs with rural development

overview.feedback: Lao Cai is a mountainous Vietnamese province with a large potential for development of small and medium scale hydropower plants and a poor population. An innovative possibility would be to explore the scope for small and medium scale hydropower to generate win-win benefits, i.e. both rural development and climate change adaptation advantages in addition to the climate change mitigation ones. There are several potential climate chaneg adaptation and human well-being benefits from small and medium scale hydropower plants. The present project has therefore been launched to analyze the effect of small and medium sized hydropower plants on the adaptation to a changed climate and the possible symbioses and trade offs with the rural development.The project’s objectives are:1. To understand the benefits of small and medium scale hydropower plants in climate change adaptation as well as rural development; 2. To recommend mitigation measures to minimize impacts from small and medium scale hydropower plants on environment and human well-being, especially to poor communities.

responsibilities.initiating_agent: Vietnam Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment
responsibilities.executing_agent: Vietnam Institute of Meteorology, Hydrology and Environment

evaluative_information.success_factors: Local government needs to implement and mainstream accordingly
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: Lack of public awareness on climate change in communities
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: Besides the benefits to climate change adaptation and mitigation, the project’s results had many recommendations related to the rural development
evaluative_information.project_evaluation:
Project provided good understand of the benefits of small and medium scale hydropower in climate change adaptation and mitigation include the changes of the hydrological pattern with storage capacities in hydropower reservoirs so that can decrease flash-flood and releasing of water stored in hydropower reservoirs give positive effects on downstream water supply and irrigation.
Furthermore, the project had some recommendations about the rural development that synergy to climate change mitigation and adaptation. With dissemination workshop, these recommendations were communicated to policy makers in local authorities, and they will be use as a scientific basis in development plan of Lao Cai province.

title: Babassu palms - Harvesting the fruits for oil and protein

overview.feedback: The Guajá of the eastern Amazon, constitute one of the few remaining hunter-gatherer cultures on earth.  They occupy a region in the eastern Amazon which is generally characterized as a seasonally dry tropical forest with a dry season from June to December. The palms support regional peasants and indigenous groups with a reliable source of food.  Few predators can access these kernels, as the fruits are very hard and it takes 5 tons of pressure to break them. Babassu kernels are good sources of oil and protein, which are often not readily available to the native populations of Amazonia. Other uses of the babassu palm include construction material, woven containers, mats, fuel and ritual applications. The palm is fire-resistant, juveniles (pindovas) can remain in the forest under-story for as long as 50 years, ultimately yielding an accumulation of up to 6,000 plants/ha.

responsibilities.executing_agent: not specified

evaluative_information.success_factors: palm seeds and seedlings, labour
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: not specified
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: not specified
evaluative_information.project_evaluation:
While there are a host of other non-timber forest products used and managed by the Guajá, the use of one species, babassu, demonstrates the intimate balance they have forged with natural resources. In many cases, the presence of babassu palms is an indication of past habitation and cultivation by indigenous groups and peasants.
The Guajá provide a example of the sustainable use and management of natural resources. Indeed, Guajá management practices may serve as a model within rural development. The integration of these practices would, of course, require further studies, partnerships with NGOs, entrepreneurial cooperation, and the formulation of government policy. Essential in facilitating the use of non-timber forest products is respecting indigenous autonomy, in the interest of a successful and ongoing project.

additional_information: In pre-colonial Brazil, stands of babassu palms served as a dietary supplement.  Such stands were an important source of fuel and fibre, and formed a hedge against starvation.  Today, the Guajá eat mainly the kernels (nuts) of the babassu fruit.

title: Biodiversity and Red meat initiative

overview.feedback: This project is part of the larger Namaqualand Wilderness Initiative (NWI) and focuses on the implementation of conservation stewardship. The project works with livestock farmers to find sustainable climate change adaptation solutions, and will encourage and enable farmers to derive tangible income benefits from implementing holistic farming practices. These practices include improved catchment management of wetlands and rivers to increase stream flows ground water recharge and water quantities, the removal of alien vegetation, ensuring appropriate livestock numbers and grazing rotations for herd and veld health, soil management including erosion control, fire management as well as setting aside portions of land for erosion buffers, biodiversity corridors, etc. CI staff provide the support function to the farmers which would normally provided by agricultural extension services, which is not available due to limited resources. The area is under threat  from un-sustainable farming activities, such as overgrazing, ploughing up of wetlands and indiscriminate burning.  These threats are addressed through the agreements, in which farmers undertake to implement certain conservation actions, like stock reduction, cooperation with wetland restoration and the formation of a fire management plan and alternative predator control methods.  In return, CI implements enabling actions that will support farmers in adopting these better land management practices. Currently the BRI has 22 members, 2 of which are private farmers and the rest communal farmers.  The area thus under better management at present, on which these 22 members farm, is roughly 9000 ha.

responsibilities.executing_agent: Conservation International
responsibilities.funding_source: Critical Ecosystem Profile Fund, United Way international, Citi Group

evaluative_information.success_factors: •Incentive structures for farmers: people need to feel that they benefit form the stewardship agreements
evaluative_information.limiting_factors:
• The buy in of commercial farmers: Unlike communal farmers who have better access to water and farming techniques through the project the commercial farmers may nor depend on those incentives as they already have sufficient access to water and farming techniques
•History of agonism between conservation sector and the farming community
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option:
Project addresses other stressors such as water scarcity, land degradation through overstocking of animals. The project contribute to better water access, healthier livestock and has created new business opportunities for the farmers i.e. meat supply contract with the supermarket Woolworth.
The project engages with landowners to secure areas under conservation and implement sustainable best practices on their farms while at the same time creating opportunities for local people to engage in alternative sustainable livelihood options as a means of adapting to climate change.
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: not specified

additional_information:
a) How has climate change information or climate science been considered in the design and implementation of the project?
Climate change information for the region was provided by Guy Midgley SANBI and the Climate Systems Analysis Group.
The area has been identified as important to protect to ensure resilience against climate change, both in terms of species, which will be able to use the Kamiesberg as refugia because of its higher rainfall and cooler climate and in terms of human livelihoods, especially water security. The reason for the latter is that the Kamiesberg is the catchment for two important non-perennial rivers in the area, the Groen River and the Buffels River and is also home to a network of wetlands, important for catching water in the rainy season and slowly releasing it in the dry summer months.

title: Biodiversity and Watershed Conservation and Restoration

overview.feedback: The objective is to support the adoption of environmentally friendly land use practices on 3,400 hectares in two Atlantic forest watersheds in Espírito Santo State, thereby contributing to improved biodiversity conservation. The components of the project are:1. Strengthening watershed management: the activities include (a) establish and strength watershed management committees, (b) prepare economic-ecological zoning plans, and (c) develop a communication strategy.2. Biodiversity protection and protected area (PA) management: interventions to restore and enhance the protection of critical areas for biodiversity conservation, and support the Pedra Azul State Park, including the elaboration of management plans and assisting landowners in the creation of private nature reserves. 3. Integrating biodiversity in production landscapes. The component requires the adaptation of measures to (a) remove obstacles to the adoption of land use practices that would be beneficial both to farmers and the environment - inducing adoption of sustainable land use practices; and (b) stimulate the adoption of practices that generate positive externalities, particularly in biodiversity conservation and water services protection - establishing payments for environmental services.
