title: Building Community Resilience to Disasters in Upland Areas

overview.feedback: The project aimed to pilot and to develop a better understanding of the impact of disasters in mountain areas whilst also recognizing the capacities and coping adaptation strategies of the mountainous and ethnic minority communities for reducing their vulnerability to natural disasters. It was one of the first projects in Vietnam to develop strategies for disaster preparedness that are adapted to the unique needs of ethnic minority people. This project supported 6 communes of Lao Cai (Northern Mountain) and Kon Tum (Central Highlands) provinces where are highly prone to flash floods and landslides in Vietnam.The project also focused on developing systems for risk assessment and planning through the use of hazard mapping. It also set out to pilot a system that would enable early warning and response at commune level.Based on information gathered through participatory Hazard Vulnerability, and Capacity Assessments (HVCA), the project designed a Community Based Disaster Risk Management training program to raise awareness of the local communities and authorities in these regions to Disaster Risk Reduction issues.

responsibilities.initiating_agent: Canadian Centre for International Studies and Cooperation (CECI), Provincial People’s Committees of Lao Cai and Kon Tum.
responsibilities.executing_agent: CECI, Agency for Technical Cooperation and Development(ACTED) in collaboration with The People’s Committees of Lao Cai and Kon Tum.
responsibilities.funding_source: The European Commission's Directorate General of Humanitarian Aid and Civil Protection (DIPECHO)

evaluative_information.success_factors:
Participate of communities and local government.
-Partnership of people/ communities and government to ensure sustainability of project activities.
In line with Governmental Strategy for Natural Disaster Prevention, Response and Mitigation.
evaluative_information.limiting_factors:
The high cost and not easy to operate, manage and maintain of rain gauges warning system.
Time and location of landslides and flash floods difficult to forecast.
- Communities did not always understand the digital GIS hazard maps.
-The lack of public awareness on climate change issues
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: Increase of livelihood opportunities and resilience
evaluative_information.project_evaluation:
Community-Based Disaster Risk Management Plan developed and implemented in two mountainous provinces.
Typhoon Ketsana struck mountainous Kon Tum Province in September 29 2009; Landslides killed 52 people, destroyed 2000 homes, and completely blocked the transportation system. But families in high risk areas of project’s communes (Tu Mo Rong and Mang Ry Communes of Kon Tum province) were ready to evacuate out of unsafe places, no one died in these communes during Typhoon Ketsana.
-After Training of Trainers course and a series of refresher training programs for 40 local trainers who speak the local ethnic language as well as understand local cultural habits, many training courses has been carried out by trainers in the target communes. This has been raising awareness of the local communities and authorities in disaster risk reduction issues.
-The Information, Education and Communication (IEC) materials on disaster preparedness and risk reduction as well as flipcharts ,VCD, TV/radios, the loudspeaker systems, leaflets , metal signboards, posters, warning signboards, information panels have been disseminated and provided to communities.
- Three pilot systems consisted of an automatic rain gauge for collecting rainfall information, a SIM card communication system designed to alert commune leaders and a wireless broadcast system for commune leaders to alert other villages were installed in Tu Mo Rong Commune of Kon Tum Province, Ban Ho and Phin Ngan Communes of Lao Cai Province for the disaster warning of flash flood.
- The digital GIS hazard maps (1/10.000) for six project communes were made available to Commune People’s Committee which used by government agencies on disaster risk management activities and helped to establish an early warning system and an evacuation system as well as helped communities recognize and understand potential dangers within the area in which they live.
-.Community Resilience to Disaster’s approaches is shared at the national level by workshops, meetings, and conferences to give examples of how to prepare for disasters in mountain areas that can be applied across the whole country.

additional_information:
-The project worked in six communes in total. They were Ban Ho, Trung Chai, Phin Ngan and Sang Ma Sao Communes in Lao Cai Province; and Tu Mo Rong and Mang Ry Communes in Kon Tum Province.
- The project enlisted a reiterative approach: piloting, testing, monitoring, improving, conducting refresher courses, repeating events, and only expanding those activities that proved to reduce the impact of disasters due to the lack of existing background knowledge on how to best build ethnic minority community resilience to disasters in upland areas.
-The digital GIS hazard map was produced with the accurate Global Positioning System (GPS) and HVCA information collected.

title: Building equitable resilience to the impacts of climate change and disasters.

overview.feedback: The project is focused in  one of the coastal districts of Ben Tre Province- Binh Dai district where is prone-ness to sea level intrusion, impacting on agriculture, shrimp farming, forestation, water and other livelihoods. The project tried two adaptive livelihood models to support poor communities to apply new techniques and cultivation practices to improve productivity and income. Project’s goal is to improve livelihoods through increased access to climate risk management capacity building and crop tolerant diversification.The project have three components:i) Livelihood groups have contributed to natural resource management through conducting research, involvement in farmers’ field schools, and employing livelihoods adaptation options such as extension training, saline tolerant crops, adjusted seasonal calendar, land use management, cultivation practices for rice farmers, shrimp farmers, fishermen, salt producers, aquaculture collectives. Through these activities the resilience of livelihoods in Binh Dai district will be significantly increased.ii) Integration climate risk analysis and adaptation activities into commune action plans through advocacy efforts.iii) Local authorities and poor communities have improved knowledge in identifying climate risks, hazards and disasters, and have the necessary skills to employ traditional coping strategies, adaptive options and action planning.

responsibilities.executing_agent: Oxfam Vietnam and Department of Agriculture and Rural Development of Ben Tre Province

The project is under implementing.

title: Building Mangrove Greenbelts

overview.feedback: Sea levels on the coast of Bangladesh are expected to rise up to 23cm, directly affecting the lives of 38 million Bangladeshis living in coastal areas. More land is being affected by increasing salinity, also threatening food security, and livelihood options. Char Kukri-Mukri, with a population of around 20,000, is already experiencing a marked increase in both the frequency and intensity of cyclones and accompanying tidal surges, disrupting agriculture and fishing, and also causing massive erosion.Char Kukri-Mukri was one of four sites chosen for this project which is establishing 6,100 hectares of mangrove plantations and 935 hectares of timber species and fruit trees. Women have been trained to grow mangrove saplings, as well as trees used for timber, such as bamboo, and in forest management. Mangrove saplings will soon be planted along the coastline to create mangrove forests containing over 2.5 million trees over the four sites.

responsibilities.executing_agent: UNDP, Ministry of Environment and Forest , local communities

evaluative_information.success_factors: It’s very important to pick the right varieties, the right species and also to involve the communities in the plantations and the maintenance and the management of the plantations.
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: not specified
evaluative_information.synergies_to_mitigation: Yes, Mangrove forests act as extremely effective carbon sinks, able to absorb 97.57 tons of carbon per hectare, or more than three times the absorptive capacity of non-mangrove forests.
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: Win-Win option
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: The programme is doing the Natural Resource Managment by training local people to run mangrove nurseries and manage forests and then paying them, a move that will have benefited 5,000 families by the end of 2010.

additional_information: Mangroves provide physical protection, trapping sediment in their intricate root structure at such a high rate that they can potentially reverse the effects of sea level rise.

title: Capacity building for adaptation to Climate Change in Vietnam (CACC project)

overview.feedback: The project aims to reduce vulnerability from the adverse effects of climate change in flood-prone areas of Central Vietnam, by improving capacity at the national and local level to develop adaptation strategies. The focused of the project was to ‘strengthen capacity to plan and implement community-based anticipatory adaptation strategies through disaster preparedness and integration of risk reduction and mitigation into local development planning’. Major activities of the project include strengthening disaster preparedness, capacity development on best practices for disaster resistant housing and public buildings, technical support, information sharing, and awareness, policy feedback and coordination with provincial priorities, a study on relocation and alternatives for highly vulnerable populations, national workshops on the impact of climate change and community-based adaptation strategies.

responsibilities.initiating_agent: Canadian Centre for International Studies and Cooperation (CECI), Provincial People’s Committee of Thua Thien-Hue.
responsibilities.executing_agent: Canadian Centre for International Studies and Cooperation (CECI) in collaboration with The Provincial People’s Committee of Thua Thien-Hue.

evaluative_information.success_factors:
-Participate of communities and local government.
-Partnership of people/ communities and government to ensure sustainability of project activities.
-Incorporation of the community-based issues in the policy level.
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: -Resource constrains of implementation of technological solutions/ measures
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: Increase of livelihood opportunities and resilience
evaluative_information.project_evaluation:
-The project demonstrates a unique way of vulnerability reduction through enhancing capacities of local people and communities.
-The project assisted communities in the two Districts to plan and implement adaptation strategies to reduce vulnerability to the adverse impacts of climate change. 37 sub-projects of Safer Village Plan (SVP), 8 sub-projects of Save Production Plan (SPP) were implemented. It covers 8 villages located in 4 communes.
-276 local officials, 800 local people were trained on Community-Based Disaster Management; 320 people were trained on agriculture, aquaculture, forestry extension service; 52 participants including engineers, technical, local builders were trained on disaster resistant constructions. Such trainings supported the implementation of the SVP and SPP.
-One study on relocation and settlement in Thua Thien Hue published and disseminated which provide better models of safer resettled villages, improve conditions for those villagers and draw more voluntary resettlement in these areas
-2 workshops at national and provincial level to introduce viable options for community-based adaptation strategies which contributed to increased awareness of developing comprehensive adaptation strategies that are integrated with social and economic development planning.

additional_information: The Province of Thua Thien Hue is in the central region, which is one of the most disaster-prone areas of Vietnam. This project supported communities in the Two Districts of Thua Thien-Hue Province to plan and implement adaptation strategies to reduce vulnerability to the adverse impacts of climate change. Ten villages in five communes, Quang Thai, Quang Phu, Phu Ho and Phu My and Phu Xuan participated in the project.

title: China?s National Climate Change Programme

overview.feedback: Observed climate trends in China are outlined and impacts of climate change on agriculture and livestock industry, forest and other natural ecosystems, water resources and coastal zone are analyzed. For enhancing the capacity of adaptation to climate change, the following countermeasures are put forward:1, Strengthen farmland infrastructure, adjusting cropping systems, selecting and breeding stress-resistant varieties and developing bio-technologies to increase the improved grassland,restore the grassland suffering from degradation, desertification, and salinity and increase the efficient utilization of agricultural irrigation water.2, Strengthen the natural forest conservation and nature reserve management, establish key ecological protection area, implement key ecological restoration programs, and enhance natural ecological restoration. 3, By rational exploitation and optimized allocation of water resources, building-up of new mechanism for infrastructure construction (anti-flood engineering systems in the large rivers), popularization of water-saving (high standard for drought relief technique inthe farmland), etc, to reduce the vulnerability of water resources to climate change.4, To reduce the losses from sea level rise through scientific monitoring of sealevel change, regulation of the ecosystem of marine and coastal zone areas, rationallyexploiting the coastline and coastal wetland, construction of coastal shelterbeltsystem (such as construction and expansion of mangroves) etc.

title: Cities Component, Policy Advice for Environment and Climate Change (PAKLIM)

overview.feedback: This project is to assist Indonesian cities to develop and implement action plans on climate change. It provides policy advice for mainstreaming environment and climate change into Indonesian cities’ development plans. The project developed a systematic participatory process for an integrated climate action planning, which includes both mitigation and adaptation. The project was piloted in 8 cities in Java.The whole project can be divided into four phases: (i) context establishment; (ii) prioritized areas assessment and goals setting; (iii) development if Integrated Climate Action; and (iv) monitoring and evaluation. The context establishment phase covers activities of steering committee establishment, GHG emission inventory, climate change impact mapping and identification of risks and opportunities for GHG emission reduction and for adaptation. The second phase covers activities of identification of prioritized areas for actions and goals setting such as emission reduction targets and targets for enhancing adaptive capacity and resilience. The third phase is to develop an integrated climate action plan and implement the actions,  that is a process to agree on key sectors to be addressed and related joint strategies for mitigation and adaptation, and to set realistic targets for both mitigation and adaptation actions within defined time frames. The last phase, monitoring and evaluation, includes assessment of target achievement and systematically reconsidering strategy and actions when necessary.

responsibilities.executing_agent: Deutsche Gesellschaft für Internationale Zusammenarbeit (GIZ) GmbH

evaluative_information.success_factors: The process requires good local knowledge and commitment by the local bodies: an effective steering function by the lead agency and pro-active involvement of all relevant sector agencies. A well-organized process, expert resources and local commitment are key for a successful implementation.
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: In many cities, data is lacking due to poor documentation and / or reliability of data. A hand-tailoring to specific city conditions might be necessary.
evaluative_information.synergies_to_mitigation: The project promotes Integrated Climate Action planning, which includes both mitigation and adaptation. It identifies mitigation actions after analysing risks and opportunities for GHG emission reduction.
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: This project promotes a participatory process in the integrated climate action planning. It increases the quality of the city's decission making process and in the city development planning in general.
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: The proposed climate change actions have been included in the formulation of the RPJMD, in in some cases affected the city existing development plan.

title: Climate Adaptation Centre

overview.feedback: WWF India in collaboration with other WWF Netherlands, Hewlett Packard and GTZ recently inaugurated a Climate Adaptation Centre on the Sundarban island, which aims to help Mousuni villagers better handle climate change by providing integral services such as an electronic early warning system, disaster preparedness kits, knowledge, resources and skills for adapting to climate impacts and educational materials for students. Disaster Management Teams and 6 task forces within each team have been made and trained within the 4 Mouzas in Mousuni. The task forces comprise of the early warning team, evacuation and rescue team, primary health team, water and sanitation team, disaster relief management team and advisory team. The leaders for each of the team are selected unanimously by the other members and in the event of any disaster the leaders of the early warning team hear the warning on the radio or receive an sms and inform the rest. The Climate Adaptation Centre provides rice seeds to the farmers and also holds information about the various varieties of rice, their market values and benefits of government schemes and programmes.

responsibilities.executing_agent: WWF India, Netherlands, HP and GTZ

evaluative_information.success_factors: reliability of early warning information, dissemination of climate information, forming disaster mangement groups
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: reduced coping capacity, delayed weather information, warning in vernacular language, low uptake for climate proofing activities
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: win win (Apparatus for early warning and agro met services is essential for vulnerable regions such as the Sundarbans)
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: The centre has only been set up last year so impacts are not visible yet. However, other adaptation strategies introduced by WWF have included the re-introduction of indigenous salt-tolerant rice plants to farmers on the island. Information on adaptation seems to be reaching the people as is evident from the fact that now almost 40 farmers use salt-tolerant paddy in Mousuni Island since last year when the centre had started. As the market value of this variety (tal mugur) is not far behind other high-yielding varieties, farmers on the island have been successful in maintaining their livelihoods without having to worry about losing crops to salt water incursion. Also, the number of volunteers in disaster response teams has significantly gone up.  At present a community elected institution runs the centre with support from WWF.

additional_information: The early warning system has been linked to Jadavpur University in Kolkata and will receive messages whenever there is an oncoming disaster. The Centre also houses relief material such as stretchers, torches and medical aid.

title: Climate adaptation modeling and capacity building in project conservation

overview.feedback: The project is to identify options to increase communities’ resilience to climate variability, in particular prolonged high precipitation event. Their livelihoods are very dependent on normal and predictable climate. They have difficulty to plant rice, which endanger their food stock for living, when prolonged high precipitation occurs. They may expand their agricultural and hunting activities to the migration corridor which puts orangutan, a protected animal, in danger. The method is designed to be applicable at village or local community level. It adapts the framework of the Center for International Forestry Research (CIFOR) for vulnerability assessment of inter-linked societal-and-environmental systems. The procedure includes preparation, primary data collection through field observation and in-depth interviews, a qualitative analysis to portrait people’s vulnerability using a score-card table, and adaptation options identification. Vulnerability is defined in a broad way and includes non-climatic causes such as socio-ecnomic factors. Good local knowledge and experiences helped in validating the vulnerability analysis and in identifying adaptation options.

responsibilities.executing_agent: World Wild Fund (WWF) - Indonesia

evaluative_information.success_factors: Support of people with strong local knowledge and local experiences  in the working team is important to interpret or clarify information from local people, and to analysis the infomation / data, and to validate the results.
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: Help from local non-governmnet organizations working on human development activities and local government is necessary to implement the measure.
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: This project addresses capacity building to local people. Therefore, it benefits to human developement in addition to increased resilience to climate variability, i.e. adaptation.
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: The method was tested at village or local community level where a link between climate dependent ecosystem / ecosystem services and the society exists. It can be easily transferred to other communities of this type.

title: Climate and Energy in a complex Transition Process towards Sustainable Hyderabad

overview.feedback: Hyderabad is an emerging megacity in Southern India. Rapid increase of population and fast economic growth cause expanding energy and resource consumption and constantly increasing greenhouse gas emissions. Climate change will lead to extreme weather events, disastrous floods, strong heat waves, extreme droughts and increasing water scarcity. One third of the population is living below poverty line and suffers from severe food and health problems. In this particular environment, responding to the anticipated climate change impact requires exploring greenhouse gas mitigation and adaptation strategies and ways towards increased energy efficiency and renewable energy. The core hypothesis of the Project is that “getting the institutions right” is one main key to solve the problems of sustainable resource use and to achieve a sustainable development of the Hyderabad region.

title: Climate Change Adaptation in the Swartland

overview.feedback: The project focused on increasing resilience of small scale farmers in the Swartland to climate change through offering a range of activities and climate change preparedness workshops to farmers. With the use of historical time-lines, small scale farmers related their experiences of changes in weather over the past few years and shared with members of other farming communities in the region how they were able to respond to these changes.Follow up workshops were continually evaluated and reformatted to respond to the needs expressed by the small-scale farmers. They generally included the sharing of scientific and local information, outings to see local examples of farming practice, and discussions on how farmers might plan their farming activities given the most up to date weather forecasts available on the South African Weather Service’s website. Seasonal weather forecasts were integrated into appropriate livelihood strategies including the choice of crop, timing of cropping and technological options. Farmers expressed a desire to record their own rainfall and temperature data, and were supplied by the project with the necessary and appropriate devices to do so. The information was recorded in climate diaries and discussed at the subsequent workshops.

responsibilities.executing_agent: Indigo development & change and Environmental Monitoring Group
responsibilities.funding_source: CCAA (Climate Change Adaptation in Africa) supported by IDRC (International Development Research Centre) and DFID (UK Department for International Development)

evaluative_information.success_factors:
•Engaging local and scientific knowledge
•Participatory action research process
evaluative_information.limiting_factors:
•Short time scale
•Learning processes take a long time and require long term commitment
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: Economic empowerment and improvement of livelihoods
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: Farmers are very eager to learn and like to engage with scientific knowledge. Participants have expressed that the interactions with each other and with researchers around Climate Change issues and livelihoods were necessary and useful. Many of the farmers have expressed a desire to continue with the workshops and data collection activities. Unfortunately funding issues and time for facilitation were not sufficient for sustaining the process.

additional_information:
a) How has climate change information or climate science been considered in the design and implementation of the project?
The Climate Systems Analysis Group (CSAG) at UCT produced a brief report outlining a preliminary analysis of climate data from weather stations in the Swartland region. Given the limited size of the geographic area, together with the use of incomplete historical data from only 5 weather stations, CSAG emphasized that the results are not conclusive, and require further investigation and research. However, the report concludes that an increase in maximum and minimum temperatures is likely, with warming particularly in autumn. Furthermore, an increase of up to 2.5 degrees Celcius is projected for the end of the 21st century, based on the SRESA2 (Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, Special Report on Emissions Scenario) emissions scenario. Precipitation, given the complex nature of its drivers, was less easy to predict. Generally, precipitation is likely to stay the same, or otherwise decrease slightly. It is predicted that rainfall events will be fewer, but more intense. The report concludes that agricultural activities and livelihoods are likely to be negatively impacted by the projected changes.

title: Climate Change adaptation strategies in Jiangxi province

overview.feedback: Summarize the observed climatic trends in the last half century and predict the possible trends in the future 50 years in Jiangxi Province. By analyzing the impacts of climate change on economy and society, the following adaptation strategies are put forward:1, adjust the industrial structure (promote the Machinery, information, electronics, telecommunications, tourism, and other high-tech, high value-added industries) to make sure the increment of energy efficiency.2, Strengthen the agricultural infrastructure (irrigation and drainage system, water storage system), adjust the cropping systems (increase the greenhouse vegetables, fruits and fish facilities, raise the multiple cropping index) and develop the anti-drought , anti-water logging, anti-pests/diseases, anti-frozen species and high temperature resistant varieties to improve the agricultural adaptability of severe weather.3, Controlling of soil erosion will be done bycombination of the engineering measures, biological measures and the ecological self-repair, take into account the development of the rural economy, Promote the Lake and the Rivers shelterbelt project, along the highway and rail Green Corridor project, the East River source Shelterbelt project.4, Consolidate the return fields to lake, convert the land for pasture project results, enhance the natural protected areas, forest home parks and wild animal protection project, the lake wetland restoration project, establish the main ecological effect area to promote the conservation of biological diversity.5, Complete flood control and drought hazard warning/commanding system, establish a more comprehensive hydro-biological safety system, improve the standards of  flood controlling levees to enhance the adaptation to climate change.

title: Climate change adaptation through climate-sensitive flood water management

overview.feedback: Natural floods are important contributors to the Mekong river system. They are improving the livelihood and productivity of local farmers and riverside dwellers by providing additional fertile soil for agriculture by sediment deposition. At the same time, extreme flood events threaten people’s lives and their income sources by destroying harvests and infrastructure. In recent decades, the Mekong Basin has endured a significant increase in extreme floods. This is due to man-made alterations in the river system and also due to changes in rainfall patterns. International climate change studies have projected a continuation if not an acceleration of this trend. The increased probability and severity of floods are a danger for the population, particularly in the Mekong floodplain, but also those near tributaries prone to flash flooding. Additionally, sea level rises of up to one meter are projected, thus making the Mekong Delta one of the five deltas in the world most vulnerable to climate change impacts.One of the key tasks of the Mekong River Commission (MRC) is to tackle flood events in a coordinated manner. The MRC has begun assessing likely impacts of possible future climate change on flood generation and propagation as well as flood risk in the Lower Mekong Basin. The MRC’s Flood Management and Mitigation Programme (FMMP) is supported in improving flood forecasting and management capacities of the relevant line agencies of the MRC Member Countries. The Regional Flood Management and Mitigation Centre (RFMMC) receives support in adjusting its current flood forecasting system to incorporate climate change scenarios.In the long run, these efforts will help protect the poorest and most vulnerable parts of the population in the four countries.

responsibilities.initiating_agent: Mekong River Commission (MRC), Federal Ministry for the Environment, Nature Conservation and Nuclear Safety (BMU)
responsibilities.executing_agent: Gesellschaft für Internationale Zusammenarbeit (GIZ) GmbH, Mekong River Commission (MRC) – Flood Management and Mitigation Programme (FMMP)
responsibilities.funding_source: Federal Ministry for the Environment, Nature Conservation and Nuclear Safety (BMU)

evaluative_information.success_factors: not specified
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: not specified
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: The overall resilience to flooding is increased as well as the general planning capacity on the national level.
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: Mainstreaming of the climate change adaptation topic within MRC was strengthened through a joint appraisal of flood forecasting and climate change modelling capacities in the Member Countries. The results of this appraisal were used to define the changes and improvements that need to be made to the flood forecasting system at RFMMC. These improvements are currently being implemented. Based on the results, MRC will be in a position to forecast floods even under a changing climate. Also, MRC can advise Member Countries in which regions to focus their flood preparedness, mitigation and management efforts. Using the flood forecasting system of MRC, national institutions can design, plan and implement climate change adaptation measures related to flooding. In order to gather practical experiences in this field, flood protection measures are being implemented in areas prone to suffer from increased flooding in the future.

title: Climate change adaptation to protect water and soil resources

overview.feedback: Burundi’s population is mostly poor, suffering from recurring food shortages and famines. Most people depend on agriculture and thus, on soil and water resources. These resources are endangered by inadequate water resource management and intensive farming on steep slopes. Climate change is further aggravating existing environmental problems and endangering Burundi’s socio-economic development. Resource dependence, lack of adaptive capacity, and state institutions underprepared for climate change lead to high vulnerability overall. Currently, Burundi is losing 5-17% (estimate) to extreme weather events.On the national, provincial, and local levels, decision-makers are supported in developing climate aware policies and integrating climate change into their strategies and investment plans. On the local level in selected catchment areas, user groups, municipalities and state facilities are enabled to independently plan, implement, and monitor adaptation measures.The project has a three-pronged strategy to reduce the vulnerability of the population of Burundi:1.	Mainstreaming climate change and adaptation into the political framework. Relevant decision-makers in Burundi are scattered across institutions and levels, making effective planning difficult and hampering implementation of Burundi’s national adaptation programme in everyday planning. Inter-sectoral user groups as well as public education and training of civil servants, will help improve coordination and efficiency.2.	Implementing specific adaptation measures in particularly vulnerable catchment areas. This includes places with rapid degradation of national resources and marginalised groups such as women, girls, and internal refugees. This part involves public education, training user groups as facilitators, agricultural extension, and set-up of local pilot projects in infrastructure.3.	Supporting the set-up of a country-wide early warning and information system for daily and seasonal weather forecasts and extreme events. This entails improving coordination between IGEBU and PNPRGC, and training both information providers and users in disseminating and using weather and climate information. Existing disaster management infrastructure is either included and improved upon or built from scratch together with local colline authorities (smallest administration unit).

responsibilities.initiating_agent: Ministry for water, environment, spatial planning, and cities (Ministère de l’Eau, de l’Environnement, de l‘Aménagement du Territoire et de l’Urbanisme, MEEATU), Ministry of agriculture and livestock (Ministère de l’Agriculture et de l’Elevage, MINAGRIE)
responsibilities.executing_agent: GIZ, MEEATU, MINAGRIE
responsibilities.funding_source: German Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development (BMZ)

evaluative_information.success_factors: not specified
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: Fragile state conditions. Low financial and staff capacity across institutions may hinder implementation. Specifically, a lack of capacity on the local level may impede advice and coordination for working with local user groups in catchment areas. At the same time, there is lingering conflict about land access if tenure reform is not carried out carefully.
evaluative_information.synergies_to_mitigation: Climate protection by energy-wood afforestation and modernisation of the energy wood value chain
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: The project also entails improvements in gender equality, development of participatory institutions and good governance, protection of the environment and natural resources including biodiversity. Additionally, the project can improve the human rights situation with regard to internal refugees.

title: Climate change and water ? risks, impacts and options for poor urban households

overview.feedback: The study will look at the current drought in the southern coastal region of the Western Cape Province (southern Cape) to try to understand these dynamics between water scarcity, the responses by local authorities and the impact of those responses on urban poor communities. The overall aim is to contribute to building climate change resilience of poor urban communities by identifying risks, vulnerabilities and knowledge gaps associated with their access to water under climate change conditions. The project includes the following objectives:1.	Investigate and critically assess how each of the Municipalities in the declared southern Cape disaster areas has responded to the drought with respect to domestic water provision and how it is financed. 2.	Pilot a consultative process with an affected community in the southern Cape to build an understanding of knowledge gaps and obstacles, share information, strengthen community structures and facilitate engagement with local authorities.3.	Develop resource materials which will assist vulnerable urban communities and municipalities in South Africa adapt to climate change and associated water scarcity.4.	Influence policy, practice and financing relating to water services in a climate-constrained world.

title: Climate change impact and adaptation in the Mekong Delta

overview.feedback: Vietnam is one of the nations most at risk from climate change, and the Mekong Delta -the main producer of rice, is the most vulnerable region in the country.A number of development agencies are providing climate-change linked assistance to Vietnam , but there has been no comprehensive study of the potential effects of climate change has been undertaken on the Mekong region. The project main objective is to develop the capacity of sectors and provincial authorities in the Mekong Delta to increase climate-resilience of programs, plans, policies, and/or projects to guide future development planning. This will result in increased climate change resilience and contribute to poverty reduction.This project have two parts: i/ modeling and assessment work to determine the likely future climate conditions in the region and their impact; ii/ identifying appropriate climate change adaptation measures for targeted areas (Ca Mau, Kien Giang Provinces) and sectors (agriculture, energy, transport) as well as development of pilot projects for scaling up and replication of project outcomes and support to collaborative mechanisms for information sharing and coordinated action on climate change.

responsibilities.initiating_agent: The Government of Vietnam and Asian Development Bank
responsibilities.executing_agent: International Centre for Environmental Management  in collaboration with the  People’s Committee of Ca Mau, Kien Giang, An Giang, Bac Lieu, Ben Tre, Can Tho, Dong Thap, Long An, Soc Trang, Tien Giang, Tra Vinh and Vinh Long provinces.
responsibilities.funding_source: Asian Development Bank, Australian Grant and The Government of Vietnam

Successful upscaling and replication of project outcomes.
Government needs to implement and mainstream on adaptation plan accordingly.
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: Lack of awareness on climate change
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: no
evaluative_information.project_evaluation:
The project is under implementing.
The expected outputs is
1. Climate change scenarios 2030, 2050 and the effects of future climate conditions on natural, social and economic systems to be documented
2. The appropriate climate change adaptation measures in two targeted provinces and three targeted sectors programs, plans, projects and/or policies to be documented
3. Pilot projects to allow upscaling and replication of project outcomes to be developed
4. The collaborative mechanisms for information sharing and coordinated action on climate change in the Mekong Delta region to be developed.
5. Institutional arrangement to fulfill their development responsibilities in future climate conditions and community awareness of climate change issues and adaptation measures to be increased.

additional_information:

title: Climate change impacts in Huong river basin and adaptation

overview.feedback: This project is one of the important projects of the Netherlands Climate Assistance Program (NCAP), in 15 developing countries. The Vietnam project is a pilot study of climate change impacts on the natural environment, including water systems and flows, of the most vulnerable people and adaptation policies and measures in Viet Nam.The project regards the Huong river basin in Thua Thien Hue Province in general and its lagoon population in particular. Future impacts of climate change on the water system and flows of the entire river basin will be projected in an integrated way. The social-economic focus is on the coastal district of Phu Vang in order to involve vulnerable stakeholders in preparing detailed measures to adapt to the projected climate change impacts in their local area.

responsibilities.initiating_agent: Vietnam Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment
responsibilities.executing_agent: Vietnam Institute of Meteorology, Hydrology and Environment

evaluative_information.success_factors:
- The adaptation measures of project are referred to different local and external stakeholders by interviews to make them suitable with the local conditions;

evaluative_information.limiting_factors: - The project was finished before the establishment of Vietnam National Target Program to Respond to Climate change and there are some adaptation measures become not suitable.

evaluative_information.project_evaluation:
The project provided adaptation measures for Thua Thien – Hue province in general and Phu Vang district in particular, especially the adaptation solutions for water resources in Phu Vang district:
- Review the planning of irrigation and drainage and gradually consolidate and repair canals to ensure the efficiency of reasonable irrigation and drainage;
- Build new sea dyke Thuan An–Tu Hien according to provincial strategy of adaptation to climate change
- Consolidate the system of boundary dyke to prevent flood and saline flood according to provincial strategy of adaptation to climate change
- Step by step perfect the mechanism of water resources integrated management in
the district area.
Besides, there are some lessons learned in the adaptation in local that was concluded by project: cost-effective use, use both top-down and bottom-up styles in participatory approach, need for translation of the scientific studies results to the language of the end-users, wise use of indigenous knowledge and expert opinion;

title: Climate Change Proofing Water Services

overview.feedback: The program aims is to contribute to the building of resilience of  communities and government in the larger Cape Town area, in order to respond to the impacts of climate change on water, in just and developmental ways. Through a seminar series that brings representatives from civil society, academia and  government together, the links between water and climate change, how we respond and the consequences of not responding, are explored.  The program`s focus is on the impact of climate change on water services for urban poor communities. In this context the program has several key activities:•	Action research on specific topics e.g. on Water Management Devices, which are being rolled out in Cape Town with little thought to the problems they present to many households. •Dialogue with local authorities and lobbying •Network building: work with urban and rural communities affiliated with the Western Cape Water Caucus (which brings together a wide range of NGOs and CBOs working on water issues in the city of Cape Town and surrounds)•Awareness raising and education: e.g. rainwater harvesting and water leaks repair

evaluative_information.limiting_factors:
•Lack of political will
•Structural changes that need to take place in the national and global economy
•Distributional effects
evaluative_information.synergies_to_mitigation: All activities around water conversation promote the usage of devices that are energy efficient and reduce the carbon foot printing (e.g. lobbying for biogas digesters at wastewater treatment plants)
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: Most activities focus on empowerment of previously disadvantaged communities at the political and individual level. Civil society is strengthened through democratic and participatory approach.
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: Impact of the program cannot yet be measured. However, the various activities have led to greater awareness among affected communities and local decision makers. The activities have also helped to connect and mobilize various citizen groups.

additional_information:
a)How has climate change information or climate science been considered in the design and implementation of the project?
The program is based on a literature review of existing climate science on future climate change trend in the greater Cape Town area.

What information about other adaptation projects should a web portal like ci:grasp contain?
•Project that use an integrated approach (i.e. considers the existing local governance system and processes and do not just focus on a single climate stimuli)
•Lessons learned
•Innovative strategies and solutions

title: Climate Change Scenarios for the Congo Basin

overview.feedback: The COMIFAC region with its vast forest cover has a great potential in forest-related mitigation, but appears to be highly vulnerable (economically and ecologically) to climate change, combined with low adaptation capacities. The project aims thus at informing national and regional decision makers about the potential impacts of climate change on natural resources in their region. They are enabled to better adapt their strategies of natural resource management in the light of climate change and to better stand their ground in the post-Kyoto negotiations. Projected changes in climate variables (temp. and prec.) available from various global and regional models (77 data-sets) have been used to project the changes along two scenarios (RCP 8.5 and RCP 4.5) with a higher resolution (50km) for the Congo Basin. Based on these results, an assessment of the related changes in the hydrology of the Congo Basin has been conducted and the potential impacts of those changes on the agriculture-, energy- and forest-sector have been projected for mid- and end of the century. After an additional analysis of the correlation between precipitation and GDP, propositions are made for potential adaptation strategies. In a nutshell, the results show a significant increase in temperature, independent of the models and scenarios used, while the total precipitation is unlikely to change dramatically. It is foremost the variability in precipitation and the frequency of extreme meteorological events which will increase and ask for tailored solutions. The carbon storage and extension of the forests is projected to slightly increase while the agricultural sector will be confronted to droughts and inundations, especially in the northern and southern parts of the region, close to or already within the Sahel-zone. Linux-Computers to continue working with the results have been handed over to five research institutions in the region and capacity development measures for the researchers and the decision makers have been implemented.Results of the project are available at http://www.climate-service-center.de/congo-project , where you can find the final report, fact sheets, and interactive maps and figures.

responsibilities.initiating_agent: Commission des Forêts d’Afrique Centrale (COMIFAC) for forest-related aspects ; Commission Internationale du Bassin Congo-Oubangui-Sangha (CICOS) for water-related aspects
responsibilities.executing_agent: GTZ/GIZ
responsibilities.funding_source: International Climate Initiative of the German Federal Ministry for the Environment, Nature Conservation, and Nuclear Safety (BMU-IKI)

evaluative_information.success_factors: Political interest in using the data for management strategies, adaptation strategies and for the international negotiations. A critical mass of local climate change scientists supporting the decision makers in the further utilization of the project results.
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: none
evaluative_information.synergies_to_mitigation: Development of the region’s capacity as a CO2 sink, sustainable economic development to avoid emissions. No direct emission reductions through the project.
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: Networking between the directors of hydrological and meteorological departments/stations in the region. Network of scientists and their respective Institutions working on climate change and its impacts.
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: Yes, it does provide the expected effects and the project results are highly appreciated by the local and regional decision makers and scientists.  It is strongly desired by the partners to continue this kind of work to break down the results on a local adaptation level, which can only be done with strong ownership and input from local scientists. This is beyond the scope of this regional project and could thus be attacked in possible follow-up projects.

additional_information: The next logical step appears to be the in depth training of and collaboration with local scientists in order to create a significant pool of climate change expertise in the region. This should help to close the gap between science and policy makers and to meet the growing demands of climate expertise in the fields of politics, consultancies and project implementation.

title: Climate Insurance Systems

overview.feedback: 'The growing frequency and severity of extreme weather events such as typhoons, droughts, floods, and snow storms due to climate change have resulted in an increase in financial losses, and thus threaten the economic basis of households and enterprises – especially those in rural areas and at the lower end of the income spectrum – in many developing countries. The project applies an integrated approach by addressing legal and regulatory issues that might hamper the market launch of index-based insurances, and by supporting re- and primary insurance companies and other financial service providers to develop demand-oriented weather insurance products for the respective target groups in the pilot regions. To this end, GTZ cooperates with the insurance regulator (CIRC), the Chinese Meteorological Administration (CMA), Chinese and foreign insurance and re-insurance companies and financial intermediaries.The project identifies and analyses weather perils in all provinces of China. Through a thorough analysis of past weather events and the economic and social losses resulting from those weather events, the exposure of different households and enterprises to weather perils are analyzed. Through household surveys and client studies the potential demand for weather insurance products is assessed. All this extensive research will then result in the development of suitable weather insurance products, possibly on the basis of parametric triggers, meaning that e.g. farmers will receive insurance payouts once a certain trigger (such as a certain precipitation or water levels  for a flood insurance) is reached.'

responsibilities.executing_agent: Deutsche Gesellschaft für Technische Zusammenarbeit (GTZ), China Insurance Regulatory Commission (CIRC)
responsibilities.funding_source: German Federal Ministry for the Environment, Nature Conservation and Nuclear Safety (BMU)

evaluative_information.success_factors: Institutional pre-conditions
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: Lack of willingness of the local partners such as CIRC to implement the project
evaluative_information.synergies_to_mitigation: No synergy to the mitigation of climate change
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: win-win option
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: "Despite the great interest in weather insurance worldwide, the emerging economies and developing countries still have very little experience with this type of scheme. Each new pilot project thus contributes to a better understanding of this complex issue. The project will also help to boost the professionalism of the Chinese insurance sector and promote underdeveloped rural regions."

title: Climate Risk Adaptation and Insurance

overview.feedback: The Climate Risk Adaptation and Insurance in the Caribbean project seeks to address climate change, adaptation and vulnerability by promoting weather-index based insurance as a risk management instrument in the Caribbean (target countries: Saint Lucia, Grenada, Jamaica). The project has developed two parametric weather-index based risk insurance products aimed at low-income individuals and lending institutions exposed to climate stressors. The objective of the project is to help target countries increase social resilience and incentivize sustainable adaptation measures by incorporating climate risk insurance within a broader framework of disaster risk reduction strategies. The overarching goals of the project are:•	To support the development of weather-related risk management solutions, including insurance;•	To support the development of public-private insurance solutions so that financial support is extended to the most vulnerable groups;•	To demonstrate the value of a regional risk pooling instrument in climate change adaptation and risk management.Central to the project’s agenda is its role in the transfer of learning and experience to further North-South, as well as South-South exchange by:•	Informing policymakers on approaches to loss avoidance and reduction;•	Highlighting the role of international organizations in promoting regional approaches to adaptation; and•	Deepening the debate within the international climate policy negotiations on addressing loss and damage and the role of insurance in this regard

responsibilities.initiating_agent: German Federal Ministry for the Environment, Nature Conservation and Nuclear Safety
responsibilities.executing_agent: Munich Climate Insurance Initiative (MCII), Caribbean Catastrophe Risk Insurance Facility (CCRIF), MicroEnsure, Munich Re
responsibilities.funding_source: The International Climate Initiative (ICI) of the German Federal Ministry for the Environment, Nature Conservation and Nuclear Safety

evaluative_information.success_factors:
• Awareness of risk exposure and willingness to explore alternative coping mechanisms by high-level stakeholders;
• Demand for weather insurance products to enhance risk management portfolio of exposed parts of the population;
• Weather and loss data to establish a parametric index;
• Sufficient back-up mechanisms in place (i.e. reinsurance)
• Education and capacity development of final beneficiaries and all other stakeholders involved;
• Strong partnerships between actors involved with a view to long-term sustainability.
evaluative_information.limiting_factors:
• After project funding ceases, an ongoing support with local stakeholders should be sought to assure security of all Parties involved.
• If the products are not maintained and updated as best as possible, clients will lose interest and might abandon the approach altogether
evaluative_information.synergies_to_mitigation: No direct linkage to emissions reduction or other mitigation-related topics
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option:
• Stakeholders are willing to explore other avenues to enhance their risk management portfolio
• Other countries in the region are interested to take up the approach
evaluative_information.project_evaluation:
Too early to say – the buy-in by as well as the cooperation with local stakeholders is very positive, but there has not yet been any weather event that triggered the insurance.

Real effects of the approach are long-term as they relate to resilience against weather risks and the true positive effects of the insurance can only be shown when the approach went through 2-3 hurricane seasons

additional_information: The project is led by the Munich Climate Insurance Initiative (MCII) - hosted at the United Nations University Institute for Environment and Human Security (UNU-EHS).

title: CLIMATE, WATER AND AGRICULTURE: IMPACTS AND ADAPTATION OF AGRO-ECOLOGICAL SYSTEMS IN AFRICA

overview.feedback: In many parts of Africa, agro-ecological systems are characterized by recurring drought events, soil degradation and water supply shortages. Presently, public infrastructure such as roads, long-term weather forecasts, and agricultural research and extension are inadequate to secure adequate adaptation.This project will assess quantitatively how climate affects current agricultural systems and will predict how these systems may be affected in the future by climate change under various global warming scenarios, and suggest what role adaptation could play.Therefore the project will implement a series of annual workshops over a three year period to provide country teams with tools necessary to conduct. Furthermore the project will culminate with an international conference aimed at high-level economists, scientists and policy makers from the region, to disseminate regional knowledge on the vulnerability of the agricultural sector to climate variability and climate.

responsibilities.executing_agent: Centre for Environmental Economics and policy in Africa(CEEPA) – Univ of Pretoria

evaluative_information.success_factors:
• Adaptation options need to be suggested to the partners in water management, agriculture and municipal planning
• Role players need to be informed about the project’s outcomes
evaluative_information.limiting_factors:
• The capacity of managers and farmers to respond is unknown.
• The difficulty in communication technical climate information in a balanced and skilful way.
• A further problem is that in the developing country context farms may face financial or informational constraints which serve to delay efficient adaptation.
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: Yes, there is a significant capacity building component. Many public meetings and talks have been held and presented to raise awareness of climate change and the riskd facing the sectors in the study area
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: not specified

additional_information: The project aims to improve national and regional assessments of the economic impact of climate change on the agricultural sector of eleven African countries, and to determine the economic value of various adaptation options. The eleven Countries are: Burkina Faso, Cameroon, Egypt, Ethiopia, Ghana, Kenya, Niger, Senegal, South Africa, Zambia and Zimbabwe.

title: ClimateAdaptationSantiago (CAS): Development of a Climate Change Adaptation Plan for the Metropolitan Region of Santiago de Chile

overview.feedback: BackgroundThe CAS project acted in close international cooperation at the intersection of science and practice/policy. Therefore, the interchange of knowledge between scientists and local actors was a central part of the project. Based on a participatory process with a wide range of actors coming from different levels and sectors (public, private, academia, civil society) in Santiago de Chile, the project contributed to the development of competences and capacities. The Regional Climate Adaptation Plan with the developed measures has been handed over to the Regional Government and the Regional Secretary of the Ministry of the Environment who are currently planning the implementation of the plan. The establishment of a Regional Learning Network between six megacities in Latin America: Mexico-City, Bogotá, Sao Paulo, Buenos Aires, Santiago de Chile and Lima allowed for exchange and mutual learning between scientists and decision-makers of these cities evolved with regard to climate change and response activities.Objective and activitiesThe main objective of the ClimateAdaptationSantiago (CAS) project was the development of climate change adaptation measures for the Metropolitan Region of Santiago de Chile in the most highly affected sectors: energy, water, and land use. Scientists from two research centers within the Helmholtz Association worked in close collaboration with partners in Latin America in order to develop a Regional Climate Change Adaptation Plan which includes the developed adaptation measures.The activities included the downscaling of global climate change models to the Metropolitan Region of Santiago de Chile, an estimation of the related impacts on energy and water supply and demand as well as on the generation of flood and heat hazards. Vulnerabilities were analyzed and suitable adaptation measures developed in a participatory round table process (10 roundtables over a 2,5-year time period).For the establishment of the Regional Learning Network three international workshops were organized in order to exchange knowledge and practical experiences regarding climate change adaptation. State of implementation/resultsThe Regional Climate Change Adaptation Plan with the developed measures has been handed over to the Regional Government and the Regional Secretary of the Ministry of the Environment who are currently planning the implementation. This final plan was accompanied by a manual for its implementation. Furthermore, a manual for the broader public was developed as well as context-specific information material for three selected municipalities. The overall results of the Regional Learning Network have been published.

title: Coastal Climate Change and Adaptation - A Sea-Level Rise Risk Assessment for Cape Town

overview.feedback: This project assessmented sea- level rise risk for the City of Cape Town by identifying and priortising risk reduction options including institutional, biological, physical and infrastructure options. Both direct and indirect risks were considered, focusing on the storm damage and what happens as a result of storm damage. The last phase identified particularly vulnerable locations and distinguished between different aspects of sea- level rise including wave run up, wave set up and eustatic sea- level rise.  The findings supported the implementation of a coastal buffer zone in the City of Cape Town that is currently being planned.Research findings were communicated at stakeholder workshops and the project received extensive media coverage.

title: Coastal Management

overview.feedback: The purpose of this technical cooperation is to establish a coastal zone management program for the area between Tamandaré (PE) and Paripueira (AL) which responds to the need of local fishermen and other stakeholders. The long-term aim is to enable rural communities along approximately 120 km of coast to improve their livelihood by opening new economic opportunities made possible through management of marine and coastal ecosystems and improved municipal land use planning.     The specific objectives are: 1. build consensus on development policy or the coastal region by integrating the local entities responsible for land and marine resource management; 2.strengthen local coastal management capacity; 3. improve understanding of the effects of coastal development on the area’s marine ecosystems, particularly the coral reefs upon which artisanal fisheries and tourism depend; and 4. increase economic opportunities through the creation of employment alternatives in ecotourism, maintenance of fisheries yields and habitat conservation, and strengthened land use planning.

title: Coastal vulnerability assessment and strategies for better preparedness towards impact of climate change and SLR along the West Bengal coast

overview.feedback: The study seeks to describe the current and projected vulnerabilities to climate change in the study area. The Sundarbans have been chosen as the proposed area to study the dependence of the communities on coastal ecosystems and the impacts on livelihoods that might arise due to future climate change. The key vulnerabilities that the study focused on were: coastal vulnerability to climatic hazards, SLR (Sea Level Rise) and saltwater intrusion and deriving a vulnerability range determining climatic hazard risk zones along the coast. The vulnerabilities will be assessed using a mix of secondary literature to understand the nature of occurrence of climatic hazards, hazard mapping, genarating an analytical model to indicate area under inundation under different levels of SLR and bio physical and socio economic impact assessment. Based on the vulenrability and impact assessments, the study would bring out policy recommendations. These will feed into identifying areas for interventions for the development of suitable adaptation strategies and developing the state Disaster Management Plans.

title: Collaborative governance: Managing the risks associated with flooding and sea-level rise

overview.feedback: The project aims to establish a collaborative governance system required for better decision making processes in the face of climate change risks in the City of Cape Town, South Africa. It will achieve this by strengthening institutional partnerships between civil society and government, increasing human and institutional capacity with regards to flooding and sea-level rise; and facilitating access to relevant knowledge at all scales.The focus will be on the governance system around decisions concerning economic planning and legislation, and formal and informal sector decisions involving investment and risk.  Specific components of the governance system, that will receive attention, include:•	the alignment and contradictions of local policies, •	better coordination between government, civil society and private stakeholders, •	a two-way flow of knowledge between scales,•	balancing competing needs; and•	the implications of social and gender inequalities.

title: Community Based Adaptation in Africa ? The South African component

overview.feedback: The project is part of a larger transnational project comprising eight African counties (Sudan, Tanzania, Uganda, Kenja, Malawi, Zimbabwe, Zambia).  It focuses on developing robust methodology on community based climate adaptation processes including monitoring and evaluation systems for adaptation projects. Indigo development & change is implementing the South African component and focuses much of its efforts on supporting small?scale farmers of the Suid Bokkeveld that decided to explore ways to increase the robustness of their livelihood strategies. Activities include quarterly climate preparedness workshops in which farmers are introduced to  climate science and share their own climate knowledge and the identification and actualizing resilient adaption strategies such as the cultivation of wild roiboos and  the use of sustainable farming practices.Furthermore Indigo development & change focuses on policy strengthening  through the establishment of an adaptation network through which it intends to  monitor and influence sectoral and  national climate change policies and through the communication of project findings to different levels of decision making.

responsibilities.executing_agent: Indigo development & change (for the south African component) in collaboration with Associate Adele Arendse.

evaluative_information.success_factors:
•A participatory action research process: A Participatory Action Research approach ensured that the scientific predictions and findings contributed to the adoption of innovative strategies whilst the by the farmers. At the same time farmers were also able to make valuable contributions to research development and implementation.
•Facilitation of active learning
•Community ownership of the research and learning process
evaluative_information.limiting_factors:
•Resource constrains of implementation of technological solutions/ measures
•Fact that learning is a ongoing process
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option:
Increase of livelihood opportunities and resilience
New economic possibilities e.g. fair trade market, organic market
evaluative_information.project_evaluation:
Project has a high commitment to the learning process
Farmers actively using seasonal forecasts and measure temperatures on a regular basis
Farmers benefit directly from the project measures.
The project has demonstrated that livelihoods are not only dependent on climate but a host of other factors which determine whether a particular livelihood strategy is successful. The methods used in the project where therefore aimed at unlocking the adaptive capacity of vulnerable groups by fostering problem solving capacity and stimulating a positive and empowered attitude using a participatory action research approach.

additional_information:
a) How has climate change information or climate science been considered in the design and implementation of the project?
Core component of the project is climate science and how to create a shared interface between local knowledge and science

title: Community Based Mangrove Reforestation and Management

overview.feedback: Seeing the important role of the mangroves in sustaining local residents' livelihoods and contributing to a reduction in natural disasters and the growing threat from climate change, particularly projected sea level rise disaster vulnerability, there is new interest in regenerating mangroves and taking advantage of the safety, livelihood and biodiversity benefits they produce. The project supports Da Loc Commune of Hau Loc coastal District in Thanh Hoa province to planting new mangroves and developing systems for sustainable management of a total of 350ha of mangroves.The project had two overarching aims: i/ Mangroves reforestation and ii/ Community management and protecting of mangroves.

responsibilities.initiating_agent: The People Committee of Thanh Hoa Province and CARE Vietnam
responsibilities.executing_agent: CARE Viet Nam

evaluative_information.success_factors: Mobilizing all of local people's participation in planting mangroves and maintaining the trees, particularly with the active participation of the women.
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: Not specified
evaluative_information.synergies_to_mitigation: Yes, carbon sequestration by the mangroves
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: Livelihood benefits from sustainable use of the mangrove
evaluative_information.project_evaluation:
-The replanting of 200ha mangroves was successful, with very high survival rates (70-90%).
- A mangrove nursery garden with 15,000 seedlings of the Sonneratia (Cay Ban Chua) has been established and is fully managed by the community.
- The project established Farmer Groups with clear institutional structures in place to manage the mangrove. So, the community had an improved awareness on climate change adaptation and capacity to collectively manage the mangrove forest.
-The project has had a positive impact on the institutional processes and linkages at the site. The development of the Community Management Boards (CMB) – a successful attempt at collaborative management – demonstrates that full and open participation and empowerment can be successful in driving forward institutional developments.

additional_information:
-Community based approach using traditional knowledge is a good approach in forest plantation and management.
-There is a need to expand the scope of the project, with particular attention to awareness rising in other, nearby villages, ensuring that there is no ‘outside’ damage to the mangrove from unsustainable collection of firewood, timber or marine resources. At present the protection teams appear successful in deterring or stopping this impact but the pressure may increase as these resources increase with the development of the mangroves.

title: COMMUNITY GENE FUND

overview.feedback: This project includes: (a) diversification of agriculture (Promotion of salt tolerant rice varieties and other crops); (b) homestead-based forestry, horticulture and vegetable cultivation; (c) promotion of integrated rice, shrimp and fish culture; (d) pro-poor brackish water aquaculture; (e) identifcation of livelihood options and activities for women and marginal groups; (f) small entrepreneurship development based on local resources such as bee-keeping; (g) rainwater harvest and sweet water conservation for drinking and domestic; (h) sweet water conservation and efficient use for irrigation to agriculture; (i) preparedness for disaster risk (cyclone, tidal surge and sea level rise) reduction to save lives, properties and household assets; and (j) promotion of coastal afforestation for protection river bank erosion, prevent cyclone damages, etc.

responsibilities.executing_agent: NGO with women's groups
responsibilities.funding_source: Government: Ministry of Rural Development, Government of India.

evaluative_information.success_factors: Institutional: availability of land and willingness of community to grow traditional seeds and appropriate pricing policy
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: improper seed distribution network
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: win win since the gene fund will be helpful in restoring traditional land races even in a no climate change context
evaluative_information.project_evaluation:
Crop varieties in cultivation have increased. Over 60 varieties are under active cultivation now as against 25-30 varieties when the programme began in 1996. Diverse cropping which was becoming an exception is now increasing again.
• Marginal lands have become productive. Lands which used to produce crops worth Rs.250-300 per acre have started producing crops worth over Rs.4000.
• Seeds that can crop about 1000 ha have been stored in villages within a span of two years and three cropping seasons.
• Traditional varieties add diversity and nutritive value to the women's household menu. Forgotten foods from the past like Korra, Aargulu, Bailodlu are being consumed again.
• A rethinking on the harmful effects of the new agricultural practices has started. People are shifting back, from tractor ploughing to bullocks. { Deep plough through tractor upturns the fine and fertile top soil and brings up the hard subsoil while shallow ploughing through bullocks keeps the fine soil on the upper layers itself }
• Many people have started approaching the sangham women for traditional seeds, thus helping promote a local self reliant seed economy.

additional_information: The community seed banks and other agricultural programs have strengthened the internal input cycle. Mulching, earthworks, use of farmyard manure has reduced erosion and degradation. A cumulative impact of all these efforts can be seen in the fact that no member of DDS sanghams need to suffer hunger since her own access to food has multiplied at least four times. In times of distress members can bank upon the grain support that these programmes can bring together.

title: Community Grain Bank

overview.feedback: Agragamee (an NGO working in rural Orissa) helped in setting up grain banks by mobilising rural tribal communities to address the issue of food security and to reverse the situation of debt trap and bondage. Tribals were encouraged to make collective savings of grain soon after the harvests and Agragamee helped by matching the amount of grain collected for the first 2-3 years. They can borrow grains at a  nominal rate of interest set by the community institution, which they can repay the following year after the crop is harvested. The village communities used the established traditional method of storing in grain bins and polished bamboo baskets  once the grains were dried on bamboo mats, plastered with cow dung. On an average 1 basket holds 4-5 quintals of grain which can be kept for one year.

responsibilities.executing_agent: NGO:Agragamee

evaluative_information.success_factors: record keeping, training for the management committee, transparency and continuity, high rates of return of grain, active participation of village committee members, low interest rates
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: non participation, high rate of default, lack of proper storage
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: No-regret: it provides a safety net even if climate change does not occur
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: The extensive coverage of this programme over the two blocks in Rayagada and Koraput districts, helped establish grain banks in 700 villages, with wholehearted support from the community. Out of this, grain banks in 500 villages are functioning successfully, and have made substantial contributions in helping the tribal community climb out of the debt trap. Agragamee’s model of grain bank has gained wide recognization and is being taken up for replication by Government as well as other development agencies.

additional_information: A good practice case is that of Hailiasahi a hamlet of Mandibisi village. Each family here was bonded to the local zamindar (landlord), or the brahmins (priests) of the village. The terms of bondage were inhuman and compelling. The 16 tribal families in this hamlet could not even claim ownership over their homestead land. Agragamee intervened, in 1982, in this village to help the members access the government programme of rehabilitation of bonded labourers, along with providing them employment for a short period.The village continued saving in the grain bank. Now, the hamlet of Haliasahi is able to dictate terms to the villagers of Mandibist with a substantial savings of more that 100 quintals of grain in their bank. They now have a surplus, which they also lend to other tribal villages.
