title: Community Grain Fund (CGF)

overview.feedback: Groups of women in rural AP have formed sanghams (voluntary associations) and, with the help of local NGOs and DDS, regenerate fallow land within the village, and grow, store and distributetraditional varieties of grain through their own Community Grain Fund which functions as a local public distribution system. With the assistance of DDS, the women lobbied with the government to change their policy and loans were made available, allowing them to prepare village fallows and sow the first crops. Loans were repaid at market rates over five years in the form of grain to village committees who store it and manage  the Community Grain Funds (CGF). The establishment of these funds required a one-time expenditure on the part of the government after which the CGF have operated independently. Grain from the CGF is sold at subsidized prices to the poorest and most vulnerable in the village. The amount that people can purchase was established according to need as determined by the villagers themselves in a participatory process. '

responsibilities.initiating_agent: women's collectives (sangams) and DDS (Deccan Development Society)
responsibilities.executing_agent: sangams (women's collectives)

evaluative_information.success_factors: strong institution, low default, storage facilities, availability and access to land
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: breakdown of the sangham linkages, higher default rates and willingness of farmers to participate
evaluative_information.synergies_to_mitigation: yes: The seeds grown using organic farming techniques which are less enrgy intensive
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: no-regret: reviving back traditional seeds and establishing a grain bank are useful irrespective of climate change
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: Through this alternative PDS the women brought over 1000 hectares of fallows under the plough. They produced an extra 800,000 kilograms of sorghum in their villages in the very first year of the project. This meant that they were able to produce nearly three million extra meals in 30 villages. Or 1000 extra meals per family. The fodder provided by the newly cultivated fields sustained over 6000 heads of cattle in 30 villages. Finally and more importantly in each village 2500 extra wage days were created. 500 towards ploughing, sowing and manuring and 2000 wages in weeding. In all 75000 extra wage days were earned in 30 villages.

additional_information: The amount of grain that villagers could purchase was established according to need as determined by the villagers themselves, in public participatory processes. The money earned from the sales was deposited in an interest-bearing bank account in the name of the Community Grain Fund, and used to fund loans to bring additional fallow land under cultivation. The initial bank deposit was for a five year term and the interest subsidized the reduced price the villagers paid when they bought the grain in lean times. Therefore, after the initial investment by DDS in providing small loans to bring land under cultivation, the Community Grain Fund did not require outside assistance, and continues to fund new cultivation, increasing the amount of food produced and consumed locally, as well as local employment possibilities.

title: Community Managed Sustainable Agriculture (CMSA)

overview.feedback: The CMSA approach replaces the use of chemical pesticides with a combination of physical and biological measures including eco-friendly biopesticides and complements it by adopting biological and agronomic soil fertility improvement measures leading to reduced use of chemical fertilizers. This has significantly reduced the cost of cultivation, the need for large amounts of credit and indebtedness that results. CMSA uses an institutional platform of community organizations and their federations to plan, implement, manage, and monitor the program and provide a single window approach for delivery of livelihood improvement services and enterprises, exclusively for small-farm holders.

responsibilities.initiating_agent: Resource organisation: Centre for Sustainable Agriculture
responsibilities.executing_agent: Non profit entity: Society for Elimination of Rural Poverty (SERP)

evaluative_information.success_factors:
Institutional:
leadership and participation of strong community institutions and their federations that own and manage the program
- farmer field schools that deliver extension services
- a menu of technologies options developed with farmer participation and experimentation
- scaling up with practicing farmers as community resource persons [CRPs] who serve as community extensionists
- developing ‘value chain’ investments from inputs to equipment, post harvest and marketing arrangements of produce for development of sustainable agriculture. Convergence with other government programs
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: availability of technical support, labor intensive
evaluative_information.synergies_to_mitigation: yes: reduced use of inorganic fertilisers
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: win win
evaluative_information.project_evaluation:
Over 300,000 farmers have adopted CMSA in Andhra Pradesh alone, covering 1.36 million acres of farmland—5.1 per cent of the net cropped area in the state—in just over four years. According to estimates by CSA, 2 million acres (10 % of cultivated area) in AP is covered under CMSA. In 2004, CMSA started on 400acres of land in 12 villages and by January 2009 it had grown to cover 1.3million acres (over 552,000 ha). Currently, over 318,000 farmers in 3,171villages (about 12 per cent of the all villages in the state) are practicing CMSA. The program covers 18 of the 23 districts of the state.During 2008-09, the project covered about 13.81 lakh acres with 3.18 lakh farmers across 3171 villages in 18 districts of Andhra Pradesh.
Mainstream agricultural research and extension institutions and other programs providing subsidies to farmers for usage of chemical fertilizers and pesticides are still skeptic and more dialogue is needed between the farmers and scientific community practicing sustainable agriculture. The current dialogue on role of agriculture in adaptation to climate change and reduction of carbon footprint through reduction in usage of chemical fertilizershas also started. This augurs for a possible second ‘green’ revolution, particularly for rain fed areas.

additional_information: The model of NPM approach [Non Pesticidal Management] was developed by the Centre for Sustainable Agriculture and later taken up by SERP for scaling up in other districts with World Bank support.CMSA approach is currently under scrutiny and observation by many agencies. National Mission on Sustainable Agriculture being set up by Government of India is looking at the CMSA approach as one of the key strategies to be replicated at the national level. Many farmer organizations in Andhra Pradesh and other states of India who are facing similar issues and had similar experiences on smaller scale are interested in how to convert CMSA into a people’s movement.

title: Community model of rural water and climate risk management

overview.feedback: The objective of the project is to improve the availability of water for irrigation and human consumption among rural families in communities located in areas vulnerable to climate change in the Municipality of Vallegrande. The project will implement the Natural Heritage Reserves (Repano) which consists in the protection of water sources with closures to human and animal activity and which will be managed by local communities. It will also be implemented multi-irrigation systems that will allow water accumulation from low-flow water springs for supplemental irrigation during long periods without rainfalls saving agricultural production. This implicates the construction of 15 irrigation systems in 5 communities in the area of Alto Seco. Each system will store 1500 m3 of water, which will cover the water needs for irrigation purposes. These measures will be designed to allow for more intensive agriculture, reduce land degradation, and help to even-out annual patterns of water availability as rainfall declines and becomes more erratic.

responsibilities.executing_agent: Oriental Training Institute (ICO)

evaluative_information.success_factors: Ensure adequate financial resources for the normal development of multifamilial irrigation system measures.
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: Limiting factor of the project will be to not achieve the designation as Natural Heritage Reserve (Repana) of the areas around local water sources.
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: No regret
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: Local water catchment areas are protected and the vulnerability of local agriculture to current climate variability is reduced. The adaptive capacity of the community and local government is improved. Resilience of local water sources (through associated ecosystems) is improved in order to be able to resist pressures driven by climate change.

additional_information: For the effective implementation of the project, active participation of involved communities is needed. This will be reached through the assessment of the perceptions of climate change from the perspective of community members.

title: Community Reforestation

overview.feedback: The project aims to (i) control erosion and reduce the associated landslide and flood risks through the reforestation of erosion-prone areas of the city, particularly where favelas are located, and (ii) employ local residents and re-introduce native tree species to the hillsides. The individual reforestation projects are carried out on relatively small areas of land, ranging from plots of one hectare to larger parcels of 18 to 30 hectares. In each area to be reforested, the project is implemented undertaken in three stages 1. Site Selection based on social (community association in existence, community desire, viability, potential for favela expansion) and environmental (severity of slopes, presence of water sources and springs, drainage basin areas, size of site) criteria; 2. Site Preparation The site is cleared, drainage canals and roads built, and the soil plowed, with fertilizer made from composted municipal waste worked into the soil to improve nutrient content and overall soil quality. In areas with very steep slopes, terraces are built to stabilize the soil, increasing water retention and reducing erosion. At the same time, seedlings cultivated from a municipally-owned model farm forest nursery are selected by forest engineers to best suit the nature of the site being reforested. 3. Planting and Maintenance The prepared sites are planted using forest succession principles involving primary and secondary species.Resources required  labour, tools, tree seedlings

title: Community Resilience with Natural Disaster in Mekong Delta

overview.feedback: Project goal is to empower flood-prone communities in the Mekong to reduce the impact of natural disasters and secure and enhance their livelihoods. Main project’s objective is to build sustainable community and household resilience to floods in highly flood-prone, inland areas of the Mekong Delta by reducing the vulnerability to flooding of household and communes in Long An, Dong Thap and An Giang provinces.In the past two decades flooding in the Mekong that impacts by climate change has become unpredictable, increasing in frequency, duration and intensity. The three targeted provinces suffer the most frequent and persistent flooding in the Mekong. In 2002, large-scale flooding lead to the death of 163 people, destruction of houses and the spread of water-related diseases.Project has three main components:1. Community-based disaster management: Facilitating changes in the way communities prepare for, adaptation, respond to and recover from disasters implemented at both village and commune level.2. Institutional capacity building: Building the capacity of CARE’s implementing partner Department of Agriculture and Rural Development (DARD) by raising the understanding of and skills to apply participatory approaches and methodologies as well as adaptation and preparedness measures amongst DARD members.3. Livelihood diversification and alternative income generation: Assisting poor and marginalized individuals and families in diversifying their income sources during non-disaster periods as well as securing alternative income generation opportunities in times of disaster.

responsibilities.initiating_agent: Australian Agency for International Development (AusAid) and Provincial People’s Committees of An Giang, Long An, Dong Thap
responsibilities.executing_agent: CARE in collaboration with The Departments of Agriculture and Rural Development of An Giang, Long An, Dong Thap Provinces.

evaluative_information.success_factors:
-Participate of communities and local government.
-Partnership of people/ communities and government to ensure sustainability of project activities.
- In line with Governmental Strategy for Natural Disaster Prevention, Response and Mitigation.
evaluative_information.limiting_factors:
- The lack of financial resources in the practices of disaster preparedness.
-The lack of public awareness on climate change issues.
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option:
- Yes, empowerment of the communities through training and awareness raising on DRR and income generation.
- Socio-economic development, environment conservation.
evaluative_information.project_evaluation:
The project is under implementing, the main expected outcomes are:
-19,000 households (HHS) benefit from improved village or commune-wide preparedness, adaptation or response infrastructure or services.
-3,800 HHS benefit from improved household physical assets (home, boats etc.) through sub-grants or relief assistance.
-3,250 HHS benefit from employment in newly-established or expanded businesses within project-targeted sub-sectors.
-3,900 HHS benefit from training in more efficient agriculture or other technical areas for self-employment.
-6,500 HHS benefit from using newly-introduced financial products provided by People’s Credit Funds that assist to smooth income and expenditure flows.
-Integration of Disaster Risk Reduction into the social-economic development plan at province, district, village, commune level.
-HHS have a high sense on disaster preparedness and mitigation:
(i) 88 –92% HHSs of 3 provinces having high awareness of living in disaster areas. (ii) Number of drowning’s & house damage strongly reduced. (iii) Better income for poor households in the flood seasons.
The initial results of the project is that there was no reported damages houses as well as no death recorded in the last couple of years.

additional_information:
-The project carry out in twelve communes in six districts of Long An, Dong Thap and An Giang provinces.
- In each village, a Village Development Group (VDG) is established
VDGs take a leading role in designing, implementing the Village Development Plan (VDP), monitoring and evaluation. The activities of VDP focus on three following sectors: (i) disaster risk reduction (DRR); (ii) capacity building for households in DRR; (iii) Income generation/ livelihood activities for households.
-Community Participatory Planning Approach is adopted and highly appreciated by villagers and local authorities due to its relevance, effectiveness and positive impacts on the community.

title: Community Seed Bank Project

overview.feedback: The community seed bank project helps in conserving traditional seed varieties by encouraging farmers to form sangams and grow indigenous varieties organically and by setting up farmer community seed banks for seed exchange, distribution and utilization. The marketing of the seeds is done by CIKS’s (Centre for Indian Knowledge Systems) own outlet – Arogyam to sustain the practice of conserving and growing. About 130 paddy and 50 vegetable varieties have been conserved in four districts, 125 villages with 37 farmer sangams benefitting 3000 farmers. The varieties conserved have specific characteristics including drought, water logging, salinity, disease and pest and flood tolerance.

responsibilities.executing_agent: CIKS

evaluative_information.success_factors: institution for management of sangams and for creating revolving funds, marketing
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: awareness, forming local institutions: lack of awareness about conserving traditional seed varieties
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: environmental conservation and social welfare
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: About 130 paddy and 50 vegetable varieties have been conserved in four districts, 125 villages with 37 farmer sangams benefitting 3000 farmers as most of the species have drought, water logging, salinity, disease and pest and flood tolerance.

additional_information: Farmers who cultivate traditional varieties are given technical assistance of manuring their field organically, treating pests by natural control methods etc. At the end of the season the farmer then returns twice the quantity of seeds that he had taken from the seed bank, these seeds are then distributed further which has a multiplying effect, creating a revolving fund. Some sangams also run biopesticide units as an additional source of income.

title: Community water project

overview.feedback: A community water project providing paid access and clean filtered drinking water to poor families in 25 villages in the the coastal area of Andhra Pradesh (AP), via community taps and jerry cans. Naandi foundation (NGO) and Water Health International (disinfection technology provider) implemented an output based aid project to improve rural water services in 3 districts of coastal AP in a public-private partnership. The project aims to create community safe water schemes (CSWS) in 25 villages that lack access to clean drinking water benefitting around 12,500 poor households. Nandi Foundation undertook the mobilisationand collects user fees, and in return gets a performance based subsidy linked to the delivery of pre-agreed outputs including three months of billed water services. This  output-based subsidy approach requires that tariffs paid by users for consumption cover the costs of operation and maintenance, user-fee collection, and education and communication activities with key stakeholders and vulnerable groups.Each scheme included a water treatment plant connected to a water distribution point from which users obtain water in jerry cans. This scheme involves the panchayat, Naandi Foundation and WHI with Global Partnership on Output based AID (GPOBA) subsidising the cost of setting up the water treatment plants.

responsibilities.executing_agent: Naandi Foundation and Water Health International
responsibilities.funding_source: Global Partnership on Output based AID

evaluative_information.success_factors: delivery of the pre agreed outputs, provision of reliable water services, payment of subscription fees
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: non payment of user fee, non functioning water treatment plant, high cost of drinking water
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: no regret: the financially viable arrangement for provision of clean drinking water to poor communities will work inspite of climate change
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: As of September 2008, four CSWSs have been constructed and verified, three in Krishna and one in West Godavari. The remaining 21 villages have been selected.   The aid disbursement is made after meeting clearly defined three outputs, and the last payment is made after the project has worked and water charges are recovered for at least three months.  Thus short term evaluation is in-built in the disbursement mechanism of the project.

additional_information:
GPOBA is subsidizing the cost of setting up the water treatment plants in 25 villages through a US$800,000 grant. The subsidy is paid to Naandi in installments after independent verification of three pre-agreed outputs which Naandi pre-finances through commercial borrowing. Notably, a significant part of
the subsidy is payable only after each CSWS proves it has provided reliable water services for at least three contiguous months after becoming operational.

title: Community-based Afforestation

overview.feedback: The project based on four parts: Community-based adaptation interventions, Capacity building, Policy analysis and Learning. As first a climate-resilient and community-based coastal afforestation measure (6,700 ha and 1,000 km of coastal afforestation, 12,200 people trained) and a warning communications for Extreme Climate Events will be implemented. Climate Risk Reduction Measures incorporated into Coastal Area Management Frameworks, which includes training of National Planners and Policymakers on Climate -Resilient Coastal Development and District Officials in Facilitating Community-based Adaptation. Furthermore a Community Awareness Campaign and a coordination mechanism for Climate-Resilient Policy Development and Coastal Planning will be established. Last part is a knowledge-transfer with Other Regions and Countries Facing Climate-Induced Coastal Hazards.

title: Community-Based Disaster Management Project in Priority Environmentally Critical Areas in the Davao River Watershed

overview.feedback: Project components include: a) Information, Education and Advocacy which involves development and carrying out community-based information and education drive to disseminate results of the relevant technical and scientific studies such as the Terrain Analysis Study and other relevant information in order to raise the level of awareness of local people especially the most vulnerable groups and mobilize their support for the disaster prevention activities.It is also generated support from policy-makers, economic actors and least vulnerable sectors on the need to unify and harmonize efforts towards disaster preparedness through the Community Disaster Response Committee. The Barangay Health Workers and Barangay Nutrition scholars composed basically of women will be mobilized in information and education activities; b) Capacity Building focused on disaster preparedness climate  change adaptation, vulnerability and risk assessment, disaster planning and management. Formal structures like that of community disaster response committees were established that engaged the participation of various stakeholders. Collaboration with mandated agencies such City Disaster Coordinating Council/City Disaster Response Centre, Philippine National Red Cross and other relevant agencies in the field of disaster preparedness is part of the strategies.Training topics: Community-based primary health care, Emergency Health and Welfare Training, Provision of medical and first aid kits for emergency  responses; c) Preventive and Mitigating Measures.

title: Conservation and development of local grape-fruit varieties in the flooding area of Day River

overview.feedback: At Red River Delta of Vietnam, Day River originates from Red River and flows to Tonkin Gulf. Day River has been for flood diversion as part of flood control in Red River Delta. Frequent floods diverted to Day River have greatly affected the way the local residents live and produce agricultural products including the effect to grapefruit production – one of the main incomes of Day River (Hoai Duc district) community.The project aims to contribute to conserving and improving agricultural biodiversity as a coping strategy to climate change scenario at Red River Delta through developing  models for conserving and developing grapefruit varieties which have advantages of fast fruits maturity, good commercial quality, and being high resistant to the flood-prone conditions in Day river, Hoai Duc district. The main objective is (i) To identify negative impacts of climate change on grapefruit genetic biodiversity at the flood-diverted area of Day River. (ii) To assess and select the best grapefruit variety with desirable characteristics including high rate of fruit maturation, high commercial quality, resistance to flood, drought and diseases for commercial production. (iii) To develop demonstration models for selected grapefruit variety with suitable cultivation techniques.(iv) To enhance the local residents’ awareness about the impact of climate change and adaptation on agricultural production of Red River Delta.The major activities are:- Surveys and collection of weather data from Ha Noi Meteological station during the last 10 years- Organize participatory discussion and workshops on impacts of climate change- Survey (interviewing local people) to decide the suitable grapefruit varieties for selection for use- Selecting the best varieties with participation of various stakeholders (experts, producers, consumers, local officers and households)- Tag the lead grapefruit tree and map the grapefruit gene pool as basis for future conservation and multiplication- Provide technical and financial funding to households participating in conserving the selected varieties- Develop 2 nursing sites (100 m2 each) to multiply grapefruits- Rapid multiplication of Que Duong grapefruit variety using VietGap-oriented techniques- Develop models on Que Duong grapefruit plantations using 2 varieties for commecial production purpose- Training on market access for participating households.- Document traditional knowledge to produce a publication on techniques on nursing and cultivation of Que Duong grapefruit varieties

responsibilities.executing_agent: SGP VIET NAM and Farmers' Union of Hoai Duc District

evaluative_information.success_factors: -Active participation of communities and local government.
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: not specified
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: Increase of livelihood opportunities and resilience

-A report on the extreme weathers (temperature, rainfall, flooding, and drought) on degree and distribution of grapefruit genetic biodiversity at the project target site to be produced.
- Grapefruit varieties with desirable qualifications to be selected and multiplied
- A model for community conservation of grapefruit genetic biodiversity at Cat Que Commune of Hoai Duc District at 5-7 genes and 100 individuals/gene to be developed

title: Conservation and Development of the Kien Giang Biosphere Reserve

overview.feedback: Kien Giang is a coastal province in the western portion of the Mekong Delta where is extremely vulnerable to the effects of global climate change such as sea level rise, flood, king tides, drought and fire. The project objective is sustainable management of the natural resources of Kien Giang Province and improved management of the protected areas. Through effective management of the protected areas and of the coastal mangrove   forests, the natural resources of Kien Giang Province are being used in a sustainable way.The project will focus in three key areas of the Kien Giang Man and the Biosphere (MAB) Reserve that was recognised by UNESCO in 2006. They are U Minh Thuong National Park, Phu Quoc National Park and the Kien Luong Hon Chong Coastal Area.At the same time, the economic situation of coastal populations is being improved. In addition, local government staffs are being trained and relevant institutions are being strengthened.

-Development of management plans for biodiversity conservation in the Biosphere Reserve

title: Conserving Biological Diversity

overview.feedback: With 7100 islands and 36,000 km coastline, the Philippines is affected particularly by climate change impacts, and especially by sea-level rise. The increase in extreme weather events is leading to increased flooding and landslides, and to erosion and land loss along the coasts. This is also jeopardising the unique species diversity of the country. Policy-makers and the wider public have become aware of climate change impacts but a lack of consistent adaptation strategies remains. The project aims to develop strategies for adaptation to climate change and conservation of biodiversity and to implement these in specific cases. Existing structures such as the secretariat of the climate change committee will be strengthened by providing intensive consultancy and training. The development of national adaptation strategies will be supported in processes involving close cooperation with relevant government bodies, local authorities, the private sector and civil society. Moreover, tangible measures to conserve biodiversity will be financed within the context of small-scale projects. The project will also raise awareness among authorities and the population of the issues surrounding climate protection and climate change.

title: Conserving grazing and fodder lands through reforestation

overview.feedback: The project reviving the Sukuma people's traditional practice of conservation called ngitili - a Sukuma word meaning enclosure. The traditional practice of ngitili was used by people in response to serious fodder shortages caused by the frequent droughts typical in semi-arid areas. It provides animal fodder for animals unable to follow other animals to grazing lands. Involving the conservation of grazing and fodder lands by encouraging vegetation regeneration and tree planting, ngitili has proven to help protect the environment and improve the livelihoods of communities in the region.

responsibilities.executing_agent: Ministry of Natural Resources and Tourism

evaluative_information.success_factors:
•Site selection:
Individual ngitilis are usually established on degraded croplands and rangelands but site selection is also determined by land availability, proximity to homesteads, production potentials and ease of protection.
•Responsibility:
For individual ngitilis, the responsibility lies with the family heads. For communal ngitilis the responsibility lies with the group of elders.
•Conservation:
Once selected, degraded areas are closed off to protect them from animals for a period of five years to allow regeneration.
•Management:
Mapping and demarcation of village grazing and cropping areas, together with issuing title deeds, ensures the protection and management of the ngitili.
•Protection:
Traditional village guards are used to protect the ngitilis, and the community assemblies to formulate sanctions, laws and punishments for misuse.
•Order of usage:
Farmers prefer to use the communal ngitili first and save private ones until communal feed sources are exhausted. Where an individual ngitili usually covers an area of less than 5 ha (12 acres), a communal ngitili can cover up to 50 ha (124 acres).
•Seasonal variations:
In the wet season areas are closed off to animals in order to allow vegetation to regenerate. During the dry season, once grazing areas are depleted, the ngitili is opened bit by bit to allow animals to feed.

title: Construction and management of multipurpose lakes

overview.feedback: The objective of the project is the preservation of water storage capacity of reservoirs, in order to ensure food security and income generation of small agricultural producers. This will be achieved through construction of lagoons for rain water harvesting and management, which will capture and store surface runoff water in the rainy season.The stored water will be used during the dry season for domestic, mainly drinking and crop irrigation. This results to a reduced dependence on precipitation and its variability in time, distribution and quantity. Furthermore the project will reduce the accumulation of sediments in the lagoons through the implementation of biomechanical constructions and afforestation of infiltration trenches.

title: Construction technique of the Qingzang railway

overview.feedback: A new way (by controlling the conduction, radiation and convection to cool the roadbed and lower the temperature of permafrost) to keep the frozen soil embankment stable was put forward by the project. Various techniques named the rock embankment structure, the rock and gravel slope protection structure, the ventilated embankment structure, the sun visor structure and the hot rod plus insulation materials were developed. Experiments on the air convection effect of the block-stone embankment, chimney effects of the rock slope protection, heat shield effects of the gravel slope protection, forced convection mechanism of the ventilated embankment structure, enhanced heat transfer mechanism of hot rod were conducted to establish a series of theories, techniques and methodology to evaluate the cooling of roadbed engineering.

title: Coral gardening

overview.feedback: Restoration of coral ecosystems will reduce coastal erosion and sand loss. Restoration includes “coral gardening”, which seeks to rescue temperature tolerant and slow-growing massive corals from situations of overgrowth, extreme shallows, and severe bleaching events. The first step has been to reduce pollution stress on the corals, the community engaged in planting mangroves and improving waste management. Next steps were to plant fast-growing corals and remove the coral-eating crown of thorn starfish. The community also engaged in constructing fish-houses, stone and cement structures that serve as shelter for coral and fish and also absorbing wave energy. A decisive element was to plant the corals in large colonies to promote resistance and survival.

responsibilities.initiating_agent: Foundation for the Peoples of the South Pacific International
responsibilities.executing_agent: local community, a national NGO, and a holiday resort

evaluative_information.success_factors: "Staghorn" Acropora corals worked well in sites were reefs had been destructed into shifting rubble.  Porites corals were best suited for silty areas or areas with periodic freshwater runoff. Inconsiderate use of different species may have negative implications to biodiversity. Test plantings are highly recommended.

title: Coral Triangle Initiative

overview.feedback: The Coral Triangle region in the Indo-Pacific Ocean is a global hotspot of marine life abundance and diversity. Destructive fishing practices, overexploitation of coastal and marine fisheries for local and export markets as well as the weakening of the adaptation capacity of the local flora and fauna as a result of climate change are leading to a loss of marine resources affecting the welfare of the population heavily dependent on the sea and its resources for livelihoods, food security and income. Covering the Economic Zones of Indonesia, Papua New Guinea, Malaysia, Philippines, Timor Leste and the Solomon Islands, the loss of biodiversity in the region could affect more than 200 million people. In response, the governments of the six countries have launched a 'Coral Triangle Initiative on Coral Reefs, Fisheries and Food Security'. The project aims at establishing two large Marine Protection Areas respectively in the Savu Sea, Indonesia, and in the Kimbe Bay-Bismarck Sea area of Papua New Guinea to increase the regions' resilience to climate change. A network of smaller Marine Protected Areas will combine science-based marine protection with community-based measures matching the socio-economic needs of the local population, in order to maintain a robust ecosystem which still allows for sustainable development.

responsibilities.executing_agent: The Nature Conservancy, South Brisbane, Australia, Ministry of Marine Affairs and Fisheries (DKP); WWF Indonesia; Provincial and district governments, local universities and community groups; Mama Graun Conservation Trust, Papua New Guinea
responsibilities.funding_source: German Federal Ministry for the Environment, Nature Conservation and Nuclear Safety (BMU)

evaluative_information.success_factors: not specified

evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: Win-Win option, long-term it will improve food security and create additional income(tourism).
evaluative_information.project_evaluation:
The lessons learned in the process of designing and implementing the resilient network of protected sites within the project are applicable to other areas across the Coral Triangle region. The project is therefore expected to have impacts which will increase the sustainability and impact beyond the core sites.
The Savu Sea Marine National Park development activities, got a good appreciation from Anambas Regencies, where in the event at workshop in Jakarta, they also said it would develop a conservation area where the process will learn from Savu Sea Marine National Park.

additional_information: When compared with countries around Indonesia such as Australia and New Zeland, Fiji and the Cock Island already have fisheries conservation area, the other part is willing to declare such as Papua New Guinea. The absence of marine conservation area for marine mammals, particularly whales in Indonesia, causing the vacuum region as a liaison between the south pacific ocean and the Indian Ocean for the species. Waters of the Savu Sea is an important corridor for both oceans for marine mammals and turtles. It is feared that the lack of marine conservation areas for the purpose of protection of marine mammals and sea turtles would threaten the species from commercial fishing.

title: Dam and irrigation system Ch?iyara Qhochi

overview.feedback: The main components of this project are the construction of a community reservoir and the provision of an irrigation system. The reservoir has a capacity of 540,000 m3 to store rainwater during the months of October – March, which can be used from June – November. This reduces the vulnerability of the population to climate variability and climate change. The project will provide access to irrigation to secure and increase productivity, diversify production, with positive effects on diet and cash income. It also increases the available agricultural work and involvement throughout the year in reducing production’s migration. Beside the provison of reservoir and irrigation system, additionally technology to optimize spray irrigation was introduced.

title: Database for the management of information and data on climate change adaptation (DATACLIM)

overview.feedback: The web-based Climate Information System (CIS) aims to support Indonesia in adapting to climate change by making the relevant climate information and data available to the stakeholders.The project is creating a web-based climate information service for accessing, managing and sharing climate related data and information. In doing so, it addresses Indonesia’s demand for scientific and planning capacity to cope with climate change, thus increasing the country’s adaptive capacity to climate change and overall resilience. Additionally, it will further co-ordinate and improve the knowledge management between the national and local (data gathering) level. The long term goal is to increase Indonesias| adaptability to the impacts of climate change in general, and in the agriculture, water and health sectors specificallyThe climate information service itself aims at supporting Indonesia in the adaptation to climate change by providing useful products in usable ways for Indonesian stakeholders. These products were developed based on dialogs with the sectors to identify needs and availability and data from Indonesian weather stations. This strengthens the national weather service BMKG in its mandate to provide the essential climate change data and information as described in the goals of the Indonesian mid-term development plan 2010-2014. The current version contains observed historical climate data. Future projections of climate information from climate models are planned to be included in the future. The key products of the CIS are:•	The provision of climate heritage of Indonesia from rescued and archived historical climate data•	The toolbox IKI-DATACLIM, which provides Indonesian officials and stakeholders with sound and actionable climate information•	The linkage of standard climate indices in ICI-DATACLIM to sectors based on identified and potential sectoral demand

title: Deficit Rainfall Insurance (DFRI)

overview.feedback: The DFRI is an index based insurance where the loss in yield on rain-fed crop is assessed using weighted and capped rainfall data during different stages of the crop period. There are two kinds of products available (1) a single phase product, cheaper and covering one critical crop period, like the flowering and (2) a multi phase product with a higher payout frequency, dividing the growing process in different phases taking into account the minimum and maximum rainfall required for a minimal harvest. The scheme is beneficial for farmers who cultivate rain-fed crops in the 30 Km radius of an IMD station having minimum past data of 20 to 30 years.

responsibilities.executing_agent: DHAN (Development of Humane Action) Foundation

evaluative_information.success_factors: presence of a IMD (Indian Meteorological Department) station, availability of historical data, financial (Without adequate sum of money a farmer cannot get his crops insured)
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: Financial, rainfall variation between field and station (Lack of money by the farmer, reciept of payment after initial year of insurance from the bank on the occurrence of a calamity)
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: No regret
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: The project can be evaluated based on the increase in the sum insured from the first to the second year from $14,100 to $47,326

title: Demarcation and erection of stone pillars on the HTL (High Tide Line) on the Tamil Nadu coast

overview.feedback: High tide line is the highest level of water that is reached during spring tides on the land. The project aims to delineate and mark the HTL along the coasts of Tamil Nadu by erection of stone pillars. The delineation work will be done using remote sensing and the pillars will be fixed along the coast for identification of the HTL on ground for the coastal community. The HTL will also be superimposed on the village cadastral maps to identify setback lines as prescribed by the CRZ notification. This will identify the HTL on the ground and help in implementation of the coastal zone regulation more effectively. The likely impacts would be (1) less pressure on vegetation in the setback areas as they will be clearly identified, thus maintaining storm buffers, and (1) reduce the risk of loss of property by preventing building near the coast, especially if the HTL may shift with sea level rise in the next 50-100 years.

responsibilities.executing_agent: Institute of Remote Sensing, Anna University and Forest Department

evaluative_information.success_factors: reliability of information: If the delineation line is not reliable or accurate the coastal zone regulation implementation will not be effective
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: Financial: cost of procurement of data for delineation and also for pillars, Technical: knowledge of remote sensing techniques
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: Helps in raising awareness and also reducing impacts due to climate change
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: 3 coastal districts have been covered and about 10 are left. The impacts will depend on how this affects the Coast Regulation Zone (CRZ) implementation and will only be known after a separate evaluation.

additional_information: Maps are given to the District collector, the District town and country planning department and the District Coastal Zone Management Authority (DCZMA) as well as the State CZMA.. The chair is the DC.

title: Developing a model in applying technologies addressing flash floods and droughts

overview.feedback: Cam Tam Commune of Cam Thuy District is a poor and typical commune of the midland mountainous area of Thanh Hoa province in terms of topography, soil conditions, social custom, culture and agricultural practices. This area is regular suffered from effects of droughts and flash flood which threatened directly to property and people life.The project aims to strengthen the preservation and sustainable use of natural resources to reduce impacts of droughts and flash flood on agricultural production at Cam Tam Commune.The main objectives are i/ To build  models for applying scientific-technological advances so as to limit damages caused by droughts and flash floods through reinforced protection and sustainable use of water resources, land and agricultural biodiversity; ii/ To promote the awareness and understanding of the local government authorities and inhabitants on the impacts of climate change on local sustainable development;

responsibilities.executing_agent: SGP VIET NAM

evaluative_information.success_factors:
-Participate of communities and local government.
-In-line with the National Strategy and Action Plan for Disaster Mitigation and Management.
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: Not specified
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: Increase of livelihood opportunities and resilience
evaluative_information.project_evaluation:
The project is under implementing.
The expected outcomes are
i/ The model of protecting and using sustainably water resources (harvesting and storage of surface water and rainwater) successfully established, with 30 households provided the support to build (or improve) water-harvesting 50 m3 tank to store and supply water.
ii/ The model of conserving and using land resources and biodiversity sustainably successfully established, with 20 ha of rice-planting land established ( with drought-resistant varieties and an appropriate rotating scheme ), 1-2 endemic mountainous rice varieties restored and developed; 8 hectares of flash flood-limiting model tested;
iii/ 10-12 training courses and workshops organized with 500 participants therefore the awareness and understanding on the impacts of climate change and adaptation measures enhanced;

additional_information: Developing a model in applying technologies to reduce vulnerabilities and to increase adaptive capacity in addressing flash flood and droughts

title: Developing water related climate change adaptation options to support implementation of policy and strategies for Water for Growth and Development

overview.feedback: The aims of the project are:> to develop an adaptive integrated management approach in order to take vulnerabilities into account for policy implementation, specifically focused on the governmental strategy “Water for Growth and Development”> to provide updated knowledge through multiple GCMs on the impacts of climate change in SA;> to provide guidelines for the reduction of uncertainties through improved monitoring and modelling;> to identify a suitable toolkit for vulnerability assessments and adaptation activities, taking ongoing, and future WRC (Water Research Commission) projects into account; and> to develop procedures and methodologies to mainstream climate change into governmental organisations, institutions and rules, specifically for the South African Department of Water and Environmental Affairs.

responsibilities.executing_agent: University of KwaZulu-Natal, School of Bioresources Engineering and Environmental Hydrology

evaluative_information.success_factors: Government needs to implement and mainstream accordingly.
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: not known
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option:
Economy:
Creating awareness for water as a crucial and limiting resource to the country’s sustainable development
- Reduction of vulnerabilities to CC through appropriate adaptation options
- Ensure open and transparent dialogue on risks and needs for the economy to develop sustainability
- Create stable point of departure for economic activities, hence growth and development
Health:
Improved management of water resources will lead to better water quality as well as its availability in the long-term. These are the two main issues stressed in the MDGs within the context of water.
Environment:
- Good understanding of the environment and potential impacts of CC, as well as more certainty in monitoring and modelling
- Foster sustainable development by realising that water is a key resource for an environment which services society and the economy equitably with integrity in equal terms. This should lead to appropriate action with environmental issues being incorporated and receiving reasonable credit in the equation of sustainable and adaptive development.

title: Development of a Risk Management Strategy against SLR

overview.feedback: This Study from the Inter-American Development Bank (IADB) is a technical cooperation to support the management of sea-level rise (SLR) in Valparaiso. The activities planned in this study are (i) compile all relevant existing information in the Municipality; (ii) evaluate the institutional and operative capacity to respond to risks; (iii) carry out a study of vulnerability to natural risks--seismic, tsunami, coastal erosion; (iv) carry out a study of vulnerability to man-made risks--fires, buildings in risk areas; (v) identify interventions that could mitigate the effects of disasters both natural and man-made; (vi) prepare a strategy for risk management for the short and medium terms; (vii) make recommendations and prepare guidelines regarding these risks for the Patrimony Master Plan of Valparaíso; (viii) prepare specific measures that could be financed by the Program of Revitalization and Development of Valparaíso (CH-L1004); and (ix) draft terms of reference for a project which could be financed by this Program. With these TC products, plans can be developed for the growth of the City, current vulnerabilities can be reduced, and future occurrences can be mitigated.

title: Development of Regional Flood Formula Using L-Moments for North Brahmaputra River System

overview.feedback: This is a study to develop a regional flood frequency estimates for gauged catchments relationship using L-moment (statistics used to summarize the shape of a probability distribution) based robust frequency distribution for the North Brahmaputra river system to provide rational flood frequency estimates for gauged catchments. It may also serve as a useful alternative for estimation of floods of desired return periods for the ungauged catchments of the study area. Estimation of flood magnitudes and frequency is required for planning and designing of various types of water resources projects. 10 data sites for this study was selected after testing data from 12 data sites as the 10 data sites comprised of homogeneous data sets.

responsibilities.executing_agent: National Institute of Hydrology

evaluative_information.success_factors: technical: the method followed to collect data, data analysis and interpretation
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: lack of data, need based
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: not specified
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: not specified

additional_information: Flood frequency estimates are made using historical data but the climate change impacts are felt in recent pasts. This study takes into consideration data from multiple catchment (gauged and un-gauged) considering impacts of recent pasts thus providing estimates of flood frequency that are more in-tuned to recent changes. For future changes a small factor (above or below the estimate) must be considered.

title: Development of salinised and drought tolerant rice varieties

overview.feedback: The project aims to minimize vulnerability and strengthening local adaptive capacity in order to reduce the impacts from droughts and salt water intrusion in rice production.The project will build a model for applying technological advances in conservation and sustainable use of local rice varieties which are tolerant to droughts and salinity. Therefore 100-105 ha of 2-3 drought and salinity tolerant rice varieties will be planted.  2-3 groups of farmers will be established, to meet the demand of the province and other neighboring provinces.Furthermore the project enhances the awareness and understanding of the local authorities and people on the impacts of climate change on socio-economic development. Therefore 10 technical training workshops and one study tour for the participating farmers will be organized.

responsibilities.executing_agent: SGP VIET NAM

evaluative_information.limiting_factors: not specified
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: not specified

Income of rice farmers will be secured and increased by 10-12%. title: Documentation of traditional knowledge about early warning indicators for weather change

overview.feedback: This is a documentation of the traditional knowledge and practices in the state of Rajasthan. The proverbs and sayings have been recorded as told by the vilage communities. These traditional practices rely heavily on repeated observation of nature and natural processes and surroundings and help predict future trends and events, some of which could be threats. These warnings range from changes about the weather conditions, cloud movement, wind direction and speed, activities of animals and birds and any specific changes occurring in the development of plants. These practices can be used by the communities to rely on their own indigenous warning system about the changing weather and thus reduce the heavy losses that are incurred due to unexpected weather changes.

responsibilities.executing_agent: CECOEDECON

evaluative_information.success_factors: strong belief in traditional practices amongst communities, experiences of the elderly members of the community, realisation of threats posed by weather and climate change
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: negative experiences of the older generation, disregard and lack of belief for traditional knowledge and practices. Actual change in weather patterns due to climate change may actually make some of the saying redundant ?
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: win-win (social welfare, revival of traditional knowledge systems, warnings can be used to reduce damages or avert them completely)
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: not specified

additional_information: The book contains several sayings a few of them are (a) Rains seldom come if the friuts on the neem tree (Azadirachta indica) do not ripen and fall to the ground, (b) there is no produce if the ripened fruits of the neem (Indian lilac) tree remain attached to the tree branches, (c) chances of rain reduce if the clouds have a yellowish tinge in the evening, (d) good rains can be expected in the year when a higher number of black spiders are observed, (e) clouds that have the shape of francolin's (teetar) feathers give rains, (f) It is believed that if rains in December occur only for half the time then the crop production is also reduced to half, (g) Transplanting time for barley and wheat is right when the germinated plant is yellow in colour and not green and (h) Storms or hot summer winds starting from the Northern direction is considered a good sign and give a good crop, etc.

title: Domestic use of sea water

overview.feedback: Qingdao is located in the coastal region (west of Yellow Sea) and belongs to one of the urban areas facing severe problems of fresh water shortage in China. The project will construct demonstration samples in Qingdao city to show how the fresh water can be replaced by sea water in domestic usage (especially, water used to flush toilet).The project applies the main techniques developed by the Institute of Seawater Desalination and Multipurpose Utilization to reach the provision of 0.85 million m3 water per year to a community with about 33 thousand residencies.1, When pumping water from the sea, the beach caisson means (use submarine sands to conduct the depth filtration to sea water) are adopted in the project. In this way, it is sure less suspended materials and pollutants enter into container.2, Smells of sea water mainly resulted from alga, bacteria and microbe etc. Experiments show that both the sodium hypochlorite and chlorine dioxide can be used as a disinfector to remove the odor.3, A storage pool for treated sea water is constructed in the community water station. The frequency conversion water supply system, which was designed to regulate water flow according to the real time water consumption and make sure the constant pressure at the pipe end, is used to provide water to the household.

responsibilities.initiating_agent: The Institute of Seawater Desalination and Multipurpose Utilization, SOA
responsibilities.executing_agent: The Institute of Seawater Desalination and Multipurpose Utilization, SOA

evaluative_information.success_factors: not specified
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: Sea water treatment technique is still in its trial stage.
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: no-regret option
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: The project can provide the anticipated effects.

additional_information: The project is expected to save fresh water of about 0.276 million Ton per year.The cost of fresh water is 1.618 Yuan/T, while the cost of toilet using sea water is 0.33 Yuan/T

title: Drought-Management Considerations for Climate Change Adaptation: Focus on the Mekong Region

overview.feedback: During recent years, drought has become a common occurrence in most areas in the Mekong River Delta of the Mekong region, including nine provinces in the South of Vietnam. Ninh Thuan province is one of them that are most severely affected by drought. Droughts have been increasing in number, duration, and intensity. Prolonged dry periods have caused significant damage to agriculture and changed the salinity of groundwater thus damaging aquaculture.The project’s main objectives are:1.  To assess the climate vulnerability of rural communities in the most drought-prone areas of Ninh Thuan province. As part of this study, perception surveys were conducted to identify the degree to which the perceptions of communities limited the efficacy of the activities of various intervening agencies.  2. To identify possible adaptation measures to mitigate the impacts on rural communities of ever-increasing climate variability and change, in terms of droughts, with an emphasis on identification of adaptation measures.

responsibilities.initiating_agent: The People’s Committee of Ninh Thuan province
responsibilities.executing_agent: Graduate School of Global Environmental Studies of Kyoto University, Japan
responsibilities.funding_source: Oxfam in Viet Nam and The Kyoto University, Japan

evaluative_information.success_factors:
-Mainstreaming the results findings to the drought management plans.
-Participating of stakeholders
evaluative_information.limiting_factors:
-Lack of mechanism to co-operation on identifying and implementing drought management and mitigation programmes
-The constrain of financial resources
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: none
evaluative_information.project_evaluation:
-This project provided an in-depth assessment of drought impacts on production and life in the driest areas of Ninh Thuan province (particularly the villages of An Hai, Ninh Phuoc District, and Phuoc Thanh, Bac Ai District) by analyzing the impact of drought on cultivation, stock breeding and aquaculture
- Several adaptation measures have been analyzed and proposed such as developing drought-resistant crop seeds, setting up groundwater irrigation systems with high–efficiency, providing new seed species and vaccines at preferential prices, and offering low-interest loans for drought control.
- Analyzed and assigned drought control responsibilities and missions at both central and provincial levels (including civil society organizations and NGOs).
- Proposed to building upon social institutions like village Self-Help Groups (SHGs), women’s groups, and village water sub-committees, and to promote better forest management for the avoidance of forest fires.

additional_information: The project used a mix of vulnerability-assessment  methodologies, in response to the interdisciplinary nature of the problem. A combination of participatory rural appraisal techniques was used in the study.

title: Earthen dams - A Community Based Watershed Development Approach

overview.feedback: Improving water availability in semi-arid areas is a key adaptation action.  The community based approach of watershed development involved facilitating the formation of village development committees (VDCs). CECOEDECON and the VDCs constructed an 800 m long earthen dam with anicut in the pasture land to harvest monsoon flows and raise ground water recharge rates and levels. The intervention has resulted in increased availability of water, reduced soil erosion, improved water quality, increased livestock population and agricultural yields. It has directly beneffited 344 families and a cattle population of 5000. There has been land quality improvement of 2900 ha. The VDCs are responsible for management, operation and co-ordination of the dam, the VDCs have taken initiative in community mobilization and repair of dam (retro-fitting of top, stone pitching of slope to control erosion).

responsibilities.executing_agent: CECOEDECON, Gram Panchayat, Village Development Committee, Panchayat Samiti
responsibilities.funding_source: CECOEDECON, Village Development Committee, Panchayat Samiti

evaluative_information.success_factors: Technical: Without technical support from the NGO the intervention would not have been possible
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: not specified
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: win win: soil and water conservation, social welfare and economic development
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: An impact assessment of the work was done in the year 2000 which showed the positive results of the intervention on crop yields in the village Bapugaon (wheat increased from 4.5 -9 Q/ha to 48-60 Q/ha, and for the three crops of mustard (4.5-7.5Q/ha), Bajra (12-15Q/ha) and Groundnut (7.5-9Q/ha) the yield increased to 24-30 Q/ha. It has also resulted in improving the water and land quality of the local region.

additional_information: The contribution for the earthen dam and anicut at Bapugaon was Rs. 2,39,000 out of which CECOEDECON contributed Rs 76400, Panchayat Samiti contributed Rs 125,000 and the contribution of the Village Development Committee was Rs 37,600. Since 2000 onwards, (1) most of the farmers started taking three crops a year (Rabi, Kharif and Jayad) and growing vegetables like Tomato, Chilly, Arbi and watermelon in the Zayad season; (2) water became available throughout the year in all the wells. The most profound effect of the storage has been seen in the quality of water (showed increased hardness and salinity content due to decreasing water quantity) that has reached potable standards. The other beneficial are seen in the improved social status of villagers and reduced migration.

title: East Kolkata Wetlands

overview.feedback: The EKW are a complex of natural wetlands and extensive man-made fishponds that absorb the stormwater runoff during monsoon events and reduce flooding risks for Calcutta.   In normal times they effectively use nutrient rich sewage flows for profitable pisciculture and vegetable cultivation, thus providing a natural sewage treatment service as well.  Much EKW area has been lost to real estate pressures, and the East Kolkota Wetland Management Act of 2006 implemented by the EKW Management Authority controls further landuse change and support conservation of the wetlands in about 12500 ha.

responsibilities.executing_agent: EKWMA (East Kolkata Wetlands Management Authority)

evaluative_information.success_factors: enabling legislation, non interference of political interests,repair of sewage channels and treatment
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: increasing land value and real estate pressures
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: win-win: The wetlands will contine to provide services and livelihoods even during non flood season
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: The project has three major benefits – regular sewage treatement through a natural process, livelihood through fishery and vegetables for locals, and the storm water runoff function.  The value of the sewage function can be guaged from the fact that the recurring cost for a small treatment facility of 500 mgd capacity is about Rs 1 billion, and the EKW absorb about 3000 mgd thus saving about Rs 6 billion of operation costs annually.  The flooding damage avoided is extra.

title: Economics of Adaptation to Climate Change

overview.feedback: The project is part of a larger transnational project named Economics of Adaptation to Climate Change (EACC) which comprising 6 countries (Bangladesh, Bolivia, Ethiopia, Ghana, Mozambique and Vietnam). The goal of the EACC project is to develop cost estimates for adaptation responses based on climate simulations of future impacts combined with sectorial analysis of agriculture, water, fisheries, and forests, among others, which aim at identifying social vulnerability and adaptive capacity in particularly climate-impacted geographic regions and among particularly vulnerable.The project’s main objectives: - To identify key socioeconomic and biophysical zones and develop a typology and livelihood profile of areas and communities that are climate vulnerable in Vietnam.- To assess the policy and institutional framework for adaptation – at the national, regional and local levels – through interactions with policy makers and other stakeholders in Vietnam.- To classify different types of local social vulnerability to climate change through targeted fieldwork in selected vulnerable areas of the country from which livelihood typologies are developed. - To work with local affected communities, policy makers, scientists, and other interested stakeholders to develop participatory scenarios of adaptation pathways that might be chosen in the future.- To produce data, analysis, and advice for the overall EACC study on where the social assessment can help clarify questions of vulnerability, adaptation, and economic costs.

responsibilities.executing_agent: The World Bank Team in cooperation with The Center for Natural Resources and Environmental Studies, Challenge to Change and Dragon Institute

evaluative_information.success_factors: not specified
evaluative_information.limiting_factors:
- Community awareness of climate change is low. Therefore, to implement the recommendations that make sure the report is limited.
- The information and data used to analysis is limited.
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: not specified
evaluative_information.project_evaluation:
- Identified impacts of climate change and vulnerability and adaptation options
- Identified key socioeconomic and biophysical zones of vulnerability to climate change, and typologies of livelihood profiles of areas and communities that are climate vulnerable
- Assessed the policy and and institutional framework for adaptation at the national, regional, and local levels Vietnam, through analyzing the “National Target Program respond to Climate Change ” issued by Government in 2008.
- Assessed local existing and potential adaptation options and measures
- Organized Participatory Scenario Development (PSD) workshops to identify and categorize adaptation pathways suitable for different livelihood groups.
- Provided recommendations on: i/ Respond to direct and indirect impacts of climate change (disaster needed to transition to long-term adaptation, developing the warming system and weather forecast as well as incorporation in economic and social planning), ii/ Social risk management asset development and social protection (livelihood resilience, safety net programs, strategies for adaptation plans); iii/ Policy design and implementation (Role of government, overlapping mandates, climate change adaptation mainstreamed into plans, investment needed)

additional_information:
The project has four components:
- Climate projections and assessment of exposure, climate sensitivity, and potential impact through use of forecasted climate models
- Assessment of adaptive capacity, adaptation deficit, and mal adaptation through study of past climate adaptation
- Estimation of the costs of future adaptations that will be necessary
- National assessment of adaptation to climate change
The methodologies used were:
- Community Risk Mapping
- Focus groups to gather information regarding climate hazards, impacts, and adaptation practices and to address the role of community formation and group identity on adaptation choices, the teams conducted targeted focus groups.
- Key stakeholder interviews.

title: Ecosystem-based adaptation for smallholder subsistence and coffee farming communities in Central America

overview.feedback: Conservation International (CI) and the Tropical Agricultural Research and Higher Education Center (CATIE) are working together to identify and test Ecosystem-based Adaptation strategies that can help smallholder farming communities adapt to climate change in Central America. The joint research project, referred as CASCADE, is taking place in Costa Rica, Guatemala and Honduras.The overall goal of the CASCADE project is to help vulnerable smallholder farming systems adapt to climate change by identifying and testing Ecosystem-based Adaptation (EbA) strategies that can help farmers, and building local capacity to support the implementation of these strategies in smallholder farming communities. The project started in 2012, and most of the activities conducted at the moment are related to the first three topics below:1. Research on climate change impacts to understand the vulnerability of Central American ecosystems and smallholder farmers (both subsistence and coffee) to climate change, taking into account the interests and needs of key stakeholders and to select the smallholder farming communities where the household surveys will take place.2. Vulnerability assessment to identify which smallholder (both subsistence and coffee-producing) farming communities, ecosystems and ecosystem services in the target countries are most vulnerable to climate change.3. Ecosystem-based Adaptation strategies identification to document household livelihood strategies used to cope with past climatic variability and local knowledge about expected impacts of climate change across a range of different smallholder communities, at both household and community level.4. Ecosystem-based Adaptation evaluation to test the effectiveness of existing on-farm activities that are relevant for EbA in a subset of communities by collecting detailed information on the characteristics, management, and implementation of those activities, and their performance in the face of climate change. 5. Institutional Analysis to identify the local and national institutions (both formal and informal) that could promote EbA approaches among vulnerable smallholder farming communities (both subsistence and coffee-producing) and define strategies for strengthening these institutions role in promoting EbA and smallholder resilience to climate change.6. Capacity Building for Ecosystem based adaptation to strengthen capacity of key organizations and institutions to support implementation of Ecosystem-based adaptation approaches with smallholder farming communities (at both household and community levels) by developing and delivering targeted training courses and extension materials.7. Multiplication and amplification to promote the incorporation of EbA approaches in national and regional adaptation strategies and other relevant policies through dissemination of project results to a wide set of stakeholders and decision-makers (e.g., government, civil society, academic) at national, regional and international levels.

title: Ecosystem-based Adaptation in marine, terrestrial and coastal regions in Brazil, Philippines and South Africa

overview.feedback: Ecosystem-based adaptation is a new concept, which capitalizes on the ability of natural systems to assist in human adaptation to climate change. In many cases, because natural systems provide multiple adaptation benefits, they are potentially much more cost effective than hard-engineered solutions. However, experience in both identifying and implementing ecosystem-based adaptation activities are in their infancy. Here we propose to identify and implement ecosystem-based adaptation activities in three very diverse settings, which will serve as models for amplification of ecosystem-based adaptation in other areas.To increase the resilience and adaptive capacity of vulnerable people to climate change, CI will assess the potential for Ecosystem-based Adaptation (EbA) solutions in the Philippines, South Africa and Brazil; implement pilot EbA solutions; and provide capacity building, linking lessons learned to local, national and international climate adaptation planning and policy.The identification and implementation of these ecosystem-based adaptation activities will help inform other EbA activities around the world. This work will provide examples from marine and terrestrial settings, including fisheries dependent on coral reefs, coastal protection by mangroves, livestock grazing in semi-arid systems, agriculture in tropical forests and freshwater use. The project will work with regional and national authorities to capitalize on these examples in other settings within the three countries, and will work with international policy bodies to create conditions which will allow replication of these results in other countries.The project is generously funded by the German Federal Ministry of the Environment, Nature Conservation and Nuclear Safety under the framework of the International Climate Initiative (IKI) and will run until July 2015.

title: Ecosystem-based Adaptation in Mountain Ecosystems

overview.feedback: The project “Ecosystem Based Adaptation in Mountain Ecosystems”, looks at the impacts of climate change on the integrity and functioning of mountain ecosystems in three countries, namely Nepal, Peru and Uganda. The project will propose sources of alternative livelihoods that build ecosystem management In many cases, there are some initial experiences, and it is particularly important to diversify income bases under changing climate, and have a portfolio of livelihood options. The project is a joint and complementary effort of UNEP, UNDP and IUCN. All three partners have a strong background in EBA and related fields. UNEP provides overall coordination for the project, while UNDP and IUCN are responsible for country level coordination through the UN country teams. As the programme develops, other countries and other ecosystems will be added.The objective of the project is to strengthen the capacities of Nepal, Peru and Uganda to strengthen ecosystem resilience for promoting ecosystem based adaptation (EBA) options and to reduce the vulnerability of communities, with particular emphasis on mountain ecosystems. The project consists of four components: 1.	the development of methodologies and tools for mountain ecosystems;2.	the application of the above tools and methodologies at the national level;3.	the implementation of EBA pilots at the ecosystem level; and4.	the formulation of national policies and building an economic case for EBA at the national level.The project aims to create new opportunities for experimental learning between regions and among countries within the same region. Through parallel and cooperative development and application of methodologies and tools, and the implementation of pilot projects, the project will shorten the learning curve of local and national institutions and fast track the transfer of knowledge and experience for building ecosystem resilience.

title: Ecosystem-based Adaptation through Mangrove Restoration and Sustainable Use

overview.feedback: The project will promote ecosystem-based adaptation (EBA) by providing incentives for mangrove conservation that link climate change adaptation, mitigation, and sustainable aquaculture. The result will be integrated into national policies. It will achieve this objective through three measures: it will demonstrate the economic and environmental benefits of EBA vs. hard engineering solutions; it will introduce innovative financing mechanisms that promote EBA through carbon financing and shrimp certification; and it will integrate EBA in mangrove ecosystems into national and provincial laws and regulations. The project will work with GIZ and other donors to support the drafting of a national policy in Vietnam that provides the legal basis for mangrove PES systems, it will also work with major European shrimp importers to expand certification in Vietnam to support market access and consequently jobs and it will take advantage of experience in Thailand to accelerate learning and innovation.

responsibilities.executing_agent: not specified
responsibilities.funding_source: German Federal Ministry for the Environment, Nature Conservation and Nuclear Safety

evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: Recovery of the area’s mangrove cover is good for farming and climate.
