title: Ecosystems Protecting Infrastructure and Communities (EPIC)
country: Nepal; Thailand; China; Chile; Burkina Faso; Senegal

overview.feedback: EPIC aims to help protect communities and selected ecosystems and ecosystem services from disasters and tackle the adverse effects of climate change. Through quantitative and scientific evidence, the project will demonstrate how healthy ecosystems can help reduce impacts and risks of specific hazards and make livelihoods more resilient.Avalanches and landslides threaten human settlements, transportation and other infrastructure in mountainous regions of countries such as Nepal, Chile and China. Coastal communities in Thailand are becoming more exposed to tropical storms, with the loss of traditional livelihoods due to the conversion of mangrove forests to short-lived shrimp farms. Unpredictable rainfall, droughts, floods and other extremes seriously affect communities in Burkina Faso and Senegal, where declining agricultural productivity is already linked with climate change.Around the world, environmental degradation reduces the capacity of ecosystems such as forests and wetlands to meet people’s need for food and fresh water and to protect them from hazards by providing a natural, physical buffer, by helping regulate floods and by stabilizing slopes. Healthy and diverse ecosystems can prove to be not only robust in the face of extreme weather but are also important given the services and benefits they provide immediately following a disaster and during recovery. The Ecosystems Protecting Infrastructure and Communities (EPIC) project will be implemented in six countries, led by IUCN in collaboration with ProAct Network, a Swiss NGO.The goal of the project is to document evidence that highlights the need for promoting and conserving ecosystem services for both climate change adaptation and in planning for disaster risk reduction.In addition to tangible interventions on the ground, EPIC will also work with policy-makers at national and local levels to promote policies that link sectors such as environment, disaster management, land-use planning and public finance, and help in co-ordinated planning through providing lessons learned and best practices.Empirical and applied scientific information will be compiled from case studies addressing different scenarios in Chile (snow avalanches), China and Nepal (landslides), Burkina Faso and Senegal (droughts and floods) and Thailand (coastal hazards). Based on lessons learned from the case studies, and building on resources available through the PEDRR (Partnerships for Environment and Disaster Risk Reduction) EPIC workshops will be held to improve awareness and technical capacities on ecosystem-based risk management in the selected countries.It is hoped that longer term ecosystem-based adaptation strategies will be built upon the results shown from managing ecosystems for disaster risk reduction.

responsibilities.executing_agent: IUCN and ProAct Network
responsibilities.funding_source: International Climate Initiative (ICI) of the German Federal Ministry for the Environment, Nature Conservation and Nuclear Safety, BMU

evaluative_information.success_factors: The success of this initiative will, to quite a high degree, depend on the lessons learned from the respective interventions, the ability to co-ordinate and share these among partners (where relevant) and other organisations working on similar themes, and on the ability to scale these up for larger and more diverse applications in due course. Such activities will require a longer timeframe than others before results are clearly demonstrable. Engaging the local to national policy makers as well as communicating results in global policy/decision-making fora is therefore key to immediate recognition, uptake and further investment in the good practices, beyond this project.
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: Disaster events, political unrest/conflicts
evaluative_information.synergies_to_mitigation: The nature of EPIC’s design lends some of the planned activities to supporting mitigation, e.g. reforestation, agricultural security through improved and more appropriate tree/cropping mixtures, mangrove restoration and so forth.
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: Not yet but many can be anticipated, e.g. livelihood security enhancement.
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: While it’s too early to validate the expected effects, EPIC ensures that the interventions and priorities align with local community priorities, with regards to climate change impacts and disaster risks. The vulnerability assessments focused on local strengthens and capacities that can be used for adaptation.

additional_information: IUCN has been promoting the potential of ecosystem services for addressing disaster risks and climate change, JOINTLY. BMU is the first donor to fund such a project and this project has the potential to become a flagship for ICI.

title: Effective Conservation and Sustainable Use of Mangrove Ecosystems

overview.feedback: The Objective is the conservation and sustainable use of mangrove ecosystems in Brazil to conserve globally significant biodiversity and key environmental services and functions important for national development and the well-being of traditional and marginalized coastal communities. The following Outputs are envisaged.OUTCOME 1: •	Regulatory framework and corresponding operational guidelines developed for improved mangrove management. •	Institutional procedures and capacities aligned to new regulatory framework for mangrove management and coordinated with sectoral policies. •	Financial strategies for mangrove PA management tested and supported by the regulatory framework. •	A representative network of mangrove UCs designed within the existing PA system.•	National Plan for the Conservation and Sustainable Use of Mangroves designed and formalized. OUTCOME 2•	Resource management plan for fisheries developed at the ecosystem level in the UC cluster of Pará. •	Resource management plan for the Uçá Crab developed and tested in the Parnaíba Delta. •	Value-added mangrove products are identified and potential market opportunities are explored. •	Capacity building program delivered to facilitate implementation and replication of sustainable use approaches to mangrove PA resources. OUTCOME 3•	Land planning guidelines tailored to mangrove conservation developed and tested in a large APA and coordinated with state and regional planning processes. •	Water resources management processes developed and tested to include mangrove conservation needs.•	Capacity building program designed and under implementation for relevant planning institutions, sectoral stakeholders and UC management.

title: Enhanced strategies for climate-proofed and environmentally sound agricultural production (C-PESAP): Agricultural development

overview.feedback: This project is one component of a much bigger project “The China Climate Change Partnership Framework”. This component aims at designing and developing strategies and actions to adapt to climate change for selected provinces in the Yellow River Basin. This will be done through the development of a multi-sector Information System (IS) and of suitable agricultural practices to address C-PESAP (Climate-Proofed & Environmentally Sound Agricultural Production). An operational plan will be developed which will be fed into the IS to share with stakeholders. Trainings of field technicians and farmer associations in selected agro-ecosystems, and development of pilot suitable agricultural practices with farmers/farmers associations will be organized. The authorities will be involved to develop a roadmap for communities.The strategies generated will serve as examples for replication in other areas.

title: Enhancing Carbon Credit for Greater Resilience to Vulnerability

overview.feedback: This is a pilot intervention initiated by World Food Programme and the Government of Uttar Pradesh to control negative impacts of climate change on the food security of households by enhancing carbon stock of the selected villages. The measure adopted is promotion of usage of energy efficient agri and household equipments like solar lightning, bio-gas, energy efficient cooking stove, irrigation pump, etc. The use of crops that are more suited to arid regions like millets, pulsesand other cash crops. Paddy varieties better suited to dry conditions (gives lower yields but improved food security).It also includes promotion of farming practices that lower water use i.e. System of Rice Intensification (SRI), Organic farming to increase soil moisture holding capacity, mulching, bio-gas slurry to increase soil carbon and agro-forestry for carbon credits, drip and sprinkler irrigation and adopting measures for rain water harvesting. It would result in increasing the local food security, reduce the need for food aid, increased carbon stock and reduced green house gas emissions, awareness and capacity building of the village communities.

title: Enhancing Coping and Adaptation Capacity of the Community to Reduce Vulnerability to Climate Change

overview.feedback: This project includes: (a) diversification of agriculture (Promotion of salt tolerant rice varieties and other crops); (b) homestead-based forestry, horticulture and vegetable cultivation; (c) promotion of integrated rice, shrimp and fish culture; (d) pro-poor brackish water aquaculture; (e) identifcation of livelihood options and activities for women and marginal groups; (f) small entrepreneurship development based on local resources such as bee-keeping; (g) rainwater harvest and sweet water conservation for drinking and domestic; (h) sweet water conservation and efficient use for irrigation to agriculture; (i) preparedness for disaster risk (cyclone, tidal surge and sea level rise) reduction to save lives, properties and household assets; and (j) promotion of coastal afforestation for protection river bank erosion, prevent cyclone damages, etc.

title: Enhancing Human Security through Environment and Disaster Management

overview.feedback: The project aim is to develop a Community Based Climate Change Adaptation Model, which can be applied to different socio-economic condition. The goal of the project is to enhance human security in Central Viet Nam to cope with the climate change impacts in the form of natural disasters like flood and cyclone. The objectives are as follows: 1)  To study and analyze climate change impacts on communities and its livelihoods in the  case study of Phu Loc district in Thua Thien Hue province in Central Viet Nam,  2)  To undertake training and awareness raising programs in the village, commune and district  3)  To initiate participatory planning process in the village, commune and district level, 4)  To implement demonstration sub-projects under the safer village/ commune/ district plans, and 5)  To monitor and analyze the implementation  process, and development of Community based Climate Change Adaptation Model.

title: ENSO index insurance

overview.feedback: From 2004 to 2006 GlobalAgRisk performed a feasibility assessment and preliminary product development work for an insurance product that would reduce constraints to agricultural lending in the microfinance sector.That early work identified the consequences of El Niño as a major constraint to lending in northern Peru. El Niño is a recurring threat in Peru that can bring catastrophic rainfall and flooding along its northern coast. That assessment led to a focus on the region of Piura and the design of an innovative index insurance product that utilizes measures of Pacific sea surface temperatures obtained from NOAA as the basis of payment. These values are highly predictive and correlated with the extreme El Niño events and their consequences in Piura. The unique aspect of this index is that the sea surface temperatures can signal a severe El Niño months in advance of its impact on land, enabling an insurance payment to be made several months before the onset of catastrophic weather. The advance payment can then be used for risk mitigation and adaptation strategies to reduce losses and disruptions from the impending disaster.

evaluative_information.project_evaluation: In 2009, GlobalAgRisk received support from the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation (Full Press Release) to conduct educational outreach and advance product development and pilot testing of El Niño Index Insurance for risk aggregators (financial institutions, business, members of the agricultural value chain) in Piura. The UNDP provided additional support to develop applications of El Niño Index Insurance to rural households, farmers associations, and local and regional government agencies in Piura to facilitate adaptation to climate risks and disaster risk management. El Niño Index Insurance for risk aggregators has been approved by the Peruvian regulator and is being offered by the Peruvian insurance company La Positiva, with reinsurance from PartnerRE. Other applications of El Niño insurance (e.g., for the public sector) will be offered in early 2011.

additional_information: The original product was designed to transfer the portfolio risks of rural lenders and thereby improve access to credit for smallholder farmers. However, the potential benefits of El Niño Index Insurance extend to many sectors due to the widespread damage and loss that can occur.

title: Evaluation of tendencies in water balance as an indicator of climate change

overview.feedback: The weather conditions that can be expected for mid-21st century are generated by General Circulation Models. However, these models have a thick resolution so the local variation is poorly simulated. Although this problem is global, the situation in Bolivia is more critical because of the physiographic features of the country that are generated by the many areas of life and unique ecosystems.With the information generated from the project, maps of highly vulnerable zones can be generated. This is an important step for planning Adaptation.

title: Experience in promoting micro irrigation technologies

overview.feedback: Aga Khan Rural Support Programme (AKRSP) introduced water saving irrigation devices such as drip and sprinkler kits in the groundwater stressed Saurashtra region in Gujarat to help farmers shift to protective irrigation and reduce agriculture input cost. They also promoted crops that use less amount of water and appropriate agronomic practices in addition to the drip and sprinklers.In Junagadh district, where groundwater overuse was very high AKRSP decided to pilot groundwater management with two interrelated objectives of 1) reviving the Meghal river and 2) arresting salinity ingress along the coast in Mangrol Block, where groundwater overuse was leading to increased ingress annually.

title: Farm-Dike Establishment

overview.feedback: Building farm-dikes with flap-gates would be a cost efficient strategy to protect farmland from rising sea levels. It is thought that in South Kalimantan over 150,000 ha of re-claimed coastal swampland, which is currently being farmed for rice and other food crops, are at risk. Farm-dikes with flap-gates have been shown to be successful in draining off excess surface and groundwater, providing flood protection, preventing salt intrusion, and controlling water quality. Each farm-dike can be used for 50 years, after which it should be replaced with a new one while the lifespan of a gate is 15 years.

responsibilities.executing_agent: not specified

evaluative_information.success_factors: not specified
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: not specified
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: No-regret option. The dikes and gates can be used during the rainy season to protect the agricultural land.
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: not specified

additional_information: This research focused on adaptation strategies for a 1.0-m SLR. Based on the data that SLR in this area was 15 mm per year and assuming the rate to be constant, we estimated that a 1.0-m SLR would be reached in the 66th year. Therefore, the lifespan of the project was set at 66 years.

title: Financing Adaptation by carbon credits for air travel

overview.feedback: The initiative offers air travelers the option of offsetting the CO2 emission that they would undertake during their upcoming flight, by donating towards the planting of trees. This tree donation option is integrated with the flight booking process on the MakeMyTrip website itself; wherein an air traveler can voluntarily choose to be part of the project by selecting the number of trees he/she wants to plant.  A travelers CO2 emission is calculated on the distance that s/he would undertake and the average CO2 emission by an aircraft /mile therein. The project is carried out on filed by the NGO based in Rajasthan SevaMandir. Though this project is primarily a mitigation project it helps the local communities of the Udaipur and Rajsamand Districts of Rajasthan to adapt to the changing climate by increasing their resource base. The activities under the initiative involve tree plantations, boundary wall erection around plantations and water harvesting (digging trenches, gully plugging and construction of check dams).  The plantations ensure fodder and shade for cattle, reduce soil erosion and increased agricultural productivity due to improved moisture retention.

title: Five Percent Technique - On farm pond using five percent of the field area to store run off water

overview.feedback: Five percent technology is a risk reducing technique implemented on farm where a pit covering  5% of the total area of a field is dug at the most upstream spot of the plot, to store water for protective irrigation of crops during the dry season. These pits collect runoff water and store it for use during dry spells. These pits are usually about 1.5 meters deep and water is manually lifted and applied to fields. Five percent is the minimum area for supplying the required irrigation to upland paddy during its critical growth periods immediately after monsoon. Farmers can make bigger or deeper pits depending on land availability and soil type. This technique is promoted by an NGO Professional Assistance for Development Action (PRADAN) and its local partners especially in the dry South West Bengal region.

responsibilities.executing_agent: PRADAN

evaluative_information.success_factors: availability of 5% area, willingness of the farmer
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: scattered landholding
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: Win-Win: it is an effective and low cost strategy for assured irrigation especially during dry season
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: The cost of treatment for making a farm pond is around Rs 25,000 per ha and can be financed through the NREG scheme. It can save rain fed crops during low rainfall periods and improve productivity of barren uplands.

title: Flood and Watershed Management

overview.feedback: The development objective of the Project for China is to improve the protection of property and safety of people from flood events and bring about sustainable utilization of land and water resources within Xining Municipality. There are six components to the project. The first component of the project is flood control and management. This component will include both structural and non-structural activities including dikes strengthening, access roads, cross dike structures and water level control structures, an integrated flood warning system, and riverbank landscaping works. This component will also improve the level of flood protection in selected areas of Xining Municipality and in a comprehensive flood warning system. The second component of the project is wastewater collection. This component will support the construction of about 72.5 km of both wastewater and urban storm water collection pipelines to intercept an estimated 33 million tons of wastewater and storm water drainage, which at present flows freely to the river systems in the Municipality, to deliver to existing or proposed wastewater treatment facilities. The third component of the project is participatory watershed management. This component will involve three integrated sets of sub-activities to allow communities to respond to varying soil and water conservation, land use, socio-economic conditions in the 17 individual highest priority sub-watersheds within the municipality. The fourth component of the project is institutional strengthening and capacity building. This component will support construction of a flood warning center, provision of office equipment, consulting services, technical study and research, and training and study tours. The fifth component of the project is resettlement and environmental management. This component will support resettlement and rehabilitation of displaced persons in connection with the implementation of the project, and managing the adverse environmental impacts resulting from the implementation of the project through establishment and operation of environmental management offices, provision of consulting services, and carrying out monitoring and supervision. The six component of the project is project management. This component will support development and operation of a management information system and strengthening the capacity of Xining Municipality to carry out procurement, construction, supervision, quality control, financial management, and monitoring and evaluation with respect to the project.

title: Freshwater / Marine Modelling

overview.feedback: Current predictions suggest that Cape Town will experience an increase in the intensity and frequency of coastal storms combined with a mean sea level marginal increase over the next two decades.  This City has completed a sea level rise risk assessment.  However as a coastal City, the marine environment provides a key service to the City as a receiving environment for freshwater run-off and stormwater discharge.  Burgeoning development and the attendant increases in the built environment within the City has resulted in an increase in run-off which places increased pressure on the City’s stormwater systems as well as its catchments.  The City must begin to investigate and understand the potential combined effects of coastal storm surges, mean sea level rise and increased freshwater and stormwater flow.  It is highly likely that these events would coincide given that the storms responsible for extreme rainfall events would often result in coastal wave surges. The combined effect of intense rainfall, high winds and storm surges has the potential to increase flood risk and infrastructure damage.

title: Future Climate Scenarios and Water Resource Availability - PROCLIM

overview.feedback: This project includes: (a) diversification of agriculture (Promotion of salt tolerant rice varieties and other crops); (b) homestead-based forestry, horticulture and vegetable cultivation; (c) promotion of integrated rice, shrimp and fish culture; (d) pro-poor brackish water aquaculture; (e) identifcation of livelihood options and activities for women and marginal groups; (f) small entrepreneurship development based on local resources such as bee-keeping; (g) rainwater harvest and sweet water conservation for drinking and domestic; (h) sweet water conservation and efficient use for irrigation to agriculture; (i) preparedness for disaster risk (cyclone, tidal surge and sea level rise) reduction to save lives, properties and household assets; and (j) promotion of coastal afforestation for protection river bank erosion, prevent cyclone damages, etc.

evaluative_information.limiting_factors: An obstacle to carry out the study was the lack of integrated information on the River basin (e.g. availability of future global climate scenarios, adaptability of the regional numeric model and calculation capacity). title: Gender and adaptation to climate change in watershed areas

overview.feedback: The GTZ Project, PROAGRO, works in two communities, Kuyoj Qhocha and Tapera, where residents are largely dependent on irrigation-fed agriculture for their livelihoods. Changes in precipitation patterns and rising temperatures in both communities have already begun to impact agricultural outputs and family incomes.In many instances, men have been forced to migrate away from their homes to seek work to supplement family incomes, placing an additional burden on women to care for the homes, children, livestock and family agricultural plots. As a response measure, PROAGRO has partnered with the GTZ’s Climate Protection Program to design an adaptation to climate change pilot project that targets the special needs of women in the two affected communities. The project seeks to stabilize livelihoods and diversify incomes, without increasing the work load for women. A further goal of the pilot is to increase awareness and improve information about climate change.The pilot’s activities focus on capacity building, natural resource protection and production of new crop varieties. Weather stations have been installed in both communities to provide information about temperature and precipitation that can be communicated to the national meteorological service. Community members have participated in workshops to improve their knowledge about climate change. Trainings have been carried out to adapt forest, water and soil management practices to changing climatic conditions. New crop varieties have been introduced to diversify both family nutrition and incomes, as well as improve food security. In all cases, emphasis has been placed on giving women a leadership role in managing the new activities.

responsibilities.initiating_agent: PROAGRO in conjunction with regional governments of Cochabamba, Sacaba and Aiquile, authorities of watersheds Tapera and Kuyoq Qhocha
responsibilities.executing_agent: Women's groups supported by PROAGRO
responsibilities.funding_source: Government of Germany and the counterpart of women

evaluative_information.success_factors: Permanent accomplishment of the project’s designed activities.
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: Weak organization of women, extreme events, aspects of climate.
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: No regret
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: Initial results of the pilot point to improved understanding within the two communities with regard to climate change.  Women have gained valuable experience in improving their family’s incomes via the production of flowers, berries, vegetables, eggs and fish, which can be used for the family’s consumption or sold in the local markets.  The pilot has also introduced methods to improve soil-quality, concepts of land-use planning to maximize returns and irrigation technology to help use water more efficiently.

title: Global Climate Change and Water Resources in Southern Africa: Potential Impacts of Climate Change and Mitigation Strategies

overview.feedback: Taking the view that water is South Africa’s key resource, this implies the need to adapt the management of this resource progressively as global climate change progresses, in order to maintain optimal levels of both resource protection and beneficial use of water for society. To better plan for the future, the following objectives are therefore proposed:+> to develop plausible climate change scenarios for Southern Africa+> to investigate the potential impacts of climate change on hydrological responses and associated water resources+> to investigate possible water related socio-economic impacts in a designated Water Management Area+> to recommend appropriate strategies to adapt to, and cope with , water related impacts of potential climate change and +> to determine whether effects of climate change can already be detected and to recommend appropriate monitoring systems for its detection.Furthermore, two case studies identified vulnerabilities and adaptive capacities of, first, a small scale community of irrigation farmers at Mueden and second, large-scale commercial farmers both in the Midlands of KwaZulu-Natal.

title: Guangxi Nanning Urban Environmental Upgrading (Guangxi Nanning Urban Infrastructure Development)

overview.feedback: The Guangxi Nanning Urban Environmental Upgrading Project is a key urban environmental improvement initiative of the Nanning municipal government (NMG) which aims to enhance the urban environment and public health in Nanning City. The incidence of waterborne and vector-borne diseases is expected to be reduced by 10% from the 2004 level. The Project comprises four subprojects:(i) Xinxujiang River environmental upgrading, which will reduce flood risk, improve wastewater management, andexpand the green environment in the area along Xinxujiang River;(ii) Kelijiang River environmental upgrading, which will reduce flood risk, improve wastewater management, and expand the green environment in the area along Kelijiang River within Xiangsihu New District;(iii) solid waste management, which will strengthen the domestic solid waste management capacity and improve cleanliness of the streets;(iv) Qingxiushan Park ecological upgrading, which will improve the environmental conditions and facilities of the park, a major tourism and recreational amenity in Nanning City, and thereby contribute to improvement of the city’s air quality, promote tourism, and increase people’s awareness of environmental protection. The Project will provide institutional capacity building and training on project management, operation and maintenance (O&M) of project facilities, and sustainable financial management of the implementing agencies (IAs).

title: Haryana Community Forestry Project

overview.feedback: The Haryana Community Forestry Project aimed to build the capacity of rural communities to improve the natural environment and maintain land fertility through sustainable management of natural resources. It supported formation of village organisations (Village Resource Management Committees-VRMCs, Hill Resource Management Societies-HRMS, Farm Forestry Associations-FFA), rehabilitation of sand dune and wind erosion affected areas, wastelands and  community lands. In addition, the project facilitated poplar plantations, multi-species agroforestry introduction, improved kitchen gardens, alternative energy efficient cooking stoves and generation of income by micro-enterprise development. The project also focuses on soil and water conservation measures and nineteen water harvesting structures have been built, in drier regions johads (traditional water bodies) have been renovated to capture runoff. The project was implemented in 338 villages in Haryana.

title: Hydrological Mangrove Rehabilitation

overview.feedback: The work in this region began in 2002, creating a mangrove atlas with partners which first proposed community based mangrove management areas in the Jangkang and Kembung rivers.Natural hydrology was restored in the area as four tidal creeks reconnected to their inland freshwater sources and raised mounds of Acrostichum aureum. Ten of the 36.5 hectares were planted while the remaining two thirds of the area were left unplanted in order to compare growth rates between reforested seedlings and natural re vegetation. Future monitoring of the restoration is being carried out by MAP-Indonesia, Yayasan Laksana Samudera, University of Riau and the local community.An illustrated manual delineating the process of hydrological mangrove rehabilitation was produced as part of the project.

title: ICICI-BASIX  weather indexed insurance

overview.feedback: The introduction of rainfall insurance by BASIX was the first weather insurance initiative launched in India and the first farmer-level weather insurance offered in the developing world. BASIX, in collaboration with ICICI Lombard and with technical assistance from the Commodity Risk Management Group (CRMG) of the World Bank, piloted the sale of weather insurance to 230 farmers in the Mahahbubnagar district of Andhra Pradesh (A.P.) during the 2003 monsoon season.  During the 2005 monsoon season, BASIX sold 7,685 policies to 6,703 customers in 36 locations in 6 states. This product insures the farmers against the possibility of crop loss in moisture stress conditions thereby lowering risk and ensuring sustenance.

responsibilities.executing_agent: BASIX

evaluative_information.success_factors: (1) the presence of customers (2) preferably 200 to 300 acres of groundnut and/or castor bean in the village to ensure a market for the weather insurance; (3) a reasonable number of small- and medium-size farms with 2 to 10 acres of land each; and (4) a village location less than 20 kilometers away from the nearest rainfall reference station, to reduce the basis risk born by the buyer.
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: willingness to pay for insurance, building trust
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: No regret: This is especially helpful when there is crop loss as a result of drought, in normal years it will not be very helpful
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: Within only three years, the small pilot program graduated into a large weather insurance operation. During the 2005 monsoon season, BASIX sold 7,685 policies to 6,703 customers in 36 locations in 6 states.The best evidence that the product is attractive comes from the fact that most farmers in treatment villages reported that they would like to purchase the insurance for the next kharif season in June 2006.

additional_information: Once the benefits of the product are fully understood, farmers will be able to alter their production strategies towards maximizing output, rather than diversifying risk, and to shift their demand for credit from consumption loans to investment loans. This shift is likely to result in increased specialization and investment, and to contribute to increased profits and the well-being of the rural population.

title: Impact of Climate Change and food insecurity on poverty

overview.feedback: By affecting the length of the growing season and variation in precipitation, climate change is likely to affect the agricultural productivity and food security of small farmers.Farmers along the coastline may loose their lands with rise in sea level. The scoping study assesses stakeholder perceptions, especially of small and marginal farmers about the impacts of climate change and the measures needed for mitigating the adverse impact of climate change on food security. The study is being done in four countries-– Afghanistan, Bangladesh, India and Pakistan. The study would help assess current perceptions of stakeholders who are likely to be amongst the worst hit by climate change, on impacts and adaptation steps, such as change in cultivation practices and appropriate measures to facilitate food banks.

title: Impacts of climate change on water resources and adaptation measures

overview.feedback: In Vietnam, lack of water due to insufficient supplies together with climate change will result in water scarcity in dry season and more flooding in wet season in 21st century. Therefore, it is necessary to have adequate and appropriate research and quantitative assessment about impacts of climate change on water resources basing on scenarios for climate change in Vietnam. This will be useful to give adaptive measures to change of water resources in the future. The development objectives of the project is to strengthen the capacity of the sectors, organizations and Vietnamese people to adapt and response to climate change impacts on water resources in order to minimize the negative impacts and losses and effectively recovery from their effects, or by taking advantage of positive impacts.

responsibilities.initiating_agent: Vietnam Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment
responsibilities.executing_agent: Vietnam Institute of Meteorology, Hydrology and Environment

evaluative_information.success_factors:
Mainstreaming adaptation measures in water management policy;
Communicating the project’s results in an easily understanding ways.
evaluative_information.limiting_factors:
The awareness of stakeholders is quite low;
The adaptation measures are quite expensive to take;
The co-ordination in water resources management is not really good to implementing the results proposed by project.
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: not specified
evaluative_information.project_evaluation:
The project is running and the immediate objectives of it are:
1. To assess impacts of climate change on water resources in some main river basins of Vietnam with the climate change scenario-driven approach;
2. To propose measures adapting to water resources changing due to climate change. Especially, specific solutions for each main river basin in Vietnam will be brought out such as modification the operation rules of reservoir system due to inflow change to ensure amount of water for hydropower, irrigation, domestic supply and environment… for Red river basin; or management of inundation caused by sea level rise; planning infrastructure under circumstance of climate change for Mekong river basin…
The project has had some workshops to disseminate the primary results to all stakeholders.

additional_information: The project uses PRECIS model (Hadley Centre: http://precis.metoffice.com/) to develop climate change scenarios for each basin, MIKE model systems to assess the flows trend, Penman method to calculate the potential evapotranspiration, and some other models...

title: Implementation of pilot adaptation measures in selected wetlands highly vulnerable to the effects of climate change

overview.feedback: As part of the 'Adaptation to Climate Change Impacts on the Coastal Wetlands in the Gulf of Mexico through Improved Water Resource Management Project' several pilot adaptation measures in selected areas will be implemented. To address the impacts of an expected increase in the frequency of more intense hurricanes, the project would: (i) increasing the extension of the protected area status for wetlands, implementing wetlands conservation strategies; (ii) building  protection barriers, strengthening river beds and the cleaning river mouths; (iii) improving existing health services anticipating CC impacts and conducting biological control of diseases; (iv) improving infrastructure (embankments); and (v) modification of building norms, application of land use plans. Furthermore buffer zones and of biological corridors between vulnerable wetlands an early warning systems based on hydro-meteorological models will be established. Expansion of civil protection system and restitution of vulnerable ecosystems through conservation, reforestation and restoration of wetlands are also planed.

title: Improving Agricultural Productivity through Photovoltaic Water Pumping

overview.feedback: This project seeks to improve agricultural productivity in this increasingly drought-prone region through the implementation of a more efficient system of irrigation which uses a photo-voltaic. The project consists of the installation of an electric water pump powered by solar photovoltaic energy and connected to a drip-irrigation system on a family farm. Furthermore the project aims: Capacity building of small farmers to improve agricultural productivity using water-efficient and affordable technologies that are easy to implement and to use renewable energy for irrigation and to use water efficiently, to actively engage the local community, especially women, in the use of this technology, through participatory processes and to develop a regional replication and dissemination strategy.

responsibilities.executing_agent: NGO , local communities

evaluative_information.success_factors: Such pilot solutions needed to be carefully analyzed and their weak points identified to be monitored for a period of time long enough to understand their overall performance. Such performance needed also to be described and monitored through accurate social, economical, technological and environmental factors and indicators.
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: not specified
evaluative_information.synergies_to_mitigation: Emission reduction through photo voltaic power generation.
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: Win-Win-option
evaluative_information.project_evaluation:
Replication is a key aspect of the project as it was conceived as a model to understand those factors that allow self-replication of technological systems within the semi-arid region.
Since the beginning, the project put at its core the sustainability of small-scale technological solutions carried out in communities that have a low degree of mechanization. The challenge was to have a consistent process to be able to promote mutual learnings and understand how best to share the information among the project partners.
Depending on the type of irrigation system and water pump, the payback time for the system showed to be in the order of 1.5 to 6 years.

additional_information: The financing is based on a revolving fund, where each farmer that meet specific eligibility criteria is entitled to receive up to 4,000 Euros to buy technology equipments. The peculiarity of this revolving fund is that the farmer does not receive cash but technology through a direct commercialization channel with some technology providers in Brazil for irrigation equipments.

title: Improving Water Management and Irrigation Productivity

overview.feedback: Climate change has been threatening the progress made in agricultural production by sustainable management techniques such as integrated watershed development and soil and water protection. Most of Ethiopia relies no rainfed agriculture. As drought and flooding increases, Ethiopia’s food security is in jeopardy.The project is a three-way cooperation between Ethiopia, Israel, and Germany in order to improve small and medium farmers’ adaptive capacity. This is done via two main strategies: (1) advising and supporting water user groups in sustainable water use and monitoring hydrological parameters, (2) increasing water productivity through modern infrastructure and adapted use of fertilizer as well as supporting distribution of products.

responsibilities.initiating_agent: Federal Ministry for the Environment, nature conservation and nuclear safety (BMU), Agricultural Ministry of Ethiopia
responsibilities.executing_agent: GIZ

evaluative_information.success_factors: not specified
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: The limiting factors in implementing the project are: weak alignment and loose integration of project activities with other regular activities, lack of credit facilities for smallholders to ensure access of irrigation inputs, weak organizational set up and limited role of water user associations. Absence of legal framework for establishing and encouraging irrigation beneficiaries to be organized as water user associations and functioning properly to ensure equitable and fair distribution of irrigation water.
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: Overall income security of farmers and food security is improved
evaluative_information.project_evaluation:
As of the end of 2011, the project has had good success. 2,055 households have been reached, of which 735 benefit from improved irrigation infrastructure. Incomes have risen more than 40% on average; productivity is estimated to increase 20%. Households who received training in management only have improved their incomes, albeit not as much. Total irrigated area has increased from 175 to 320 ha.

Water management capacities of the water users in the project site improved through training and experience sharing from other project sites. The water user groups were able to solve conflicts over distribution and use of water, which helps them to use the water in equal proportion.

additional_information: Financing of the project was split between GIZ (1.5 million EUR) and Mashav (1 million USD)

title: INCA - Adaptation and Mitigation Strategies of Andean People

overview.feedback: Countries like Peru and Bolivia are bearing the consequences of climate change, such as extreme weather events, which are directly affecting crops, livestock, biodiversity, and, last but not least, increasing levels of poverty. Livelihood strategies of the Andean region are based on principles of risk management, contributing to the resilience of family livelihood development. Vulnerable mountain farmers are nowadays applying these ancient strategies in a combination of homegrown experimentation and scientific know-how to adapt to climate change. Understanding these adaptations has become one of the most important focuses of research into climate change impacts and vulnerability.

responsibilities.executing_agent: TU Dresden (Germany), UNALM (Peru), Instituto de Ecologia (Bolivia)

evaluative_information.success_factors: not specified
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: not specified
evaluative_information.synergies_to_mitigation: Scientific exchange of adaptation and mitigation strategies on climate change among local users, scientific community, state authorities, NGOs, as well as other relevant stakeholders in the tropical Andean region by communicative networking, elaboration of extension packages for farmers, scientific qualification on B.Sc., M.Sc., doctoral and postdoctoral level
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: The development of the INCA follows a long term strategy. Sustainable network management after the end of funding by DAAD will be assured by the following integrated activities: (1) Establishment of a cross-border education cooperation at master or doctoral level with the partner universities; (2) Use of the extensive alumni network as a basis for further external funding; (3) Creation of synergies with existing EU master and doctoral programs (SUTROFOR, FONASO); (4) Integration into other networks like UNEP/UNESCO course of the TU Dresden, Humboldt Foundation; (5) Initiation of R&D cooperation between GIZ and consultancies.
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: The endogenously determined strategies, which are based on the experience of the farmers, are to be complemented by knowledge and experiences coming from outside farm-household systems and communities. In a collaborative way, this exogenous knowledge is to placed at the disposal of the local actors. Through this a participative network on climate change contributes to bridge the gap between the global discourse on climate change and local action. The necessary network approach leads to a far reaching involvement of the local actors.

additional_information: International Network on Climate Change "INCA" - Understanding Adaptation and Mitigation Strategies of Tropical Andean People.

title: Incorporation of climate change risks into national level policies

overview.feedback: The Project would take action at the national level to provide the essential capacities and strategies to advance national frameworks for incorporating climate change considerations into systems that govern land-use and coastal management practices that affect coastal ecosystems. The focus here would be on response systems that would enable stresses to be kept within the coping range of ecosystems under future climate change, thus increasing resilience and the conservation of key biodiversity. Existing policy systems regarding coastal areas would be adjusted over time to the changing conditions expected under different climate scenarios. Specific guidelines and measures would be included in these procedures to ensure that climate change scenarios are adequately addressed and that those responsible for their application and evaluation are fully trained to implement new approaches and standards. It will address as well specific activities to enhance regulations related to the National Protected Area System as a particular land planning policy with a high potential for coastal ecosystems protection from surrounding environmental stresses.For these purposes, the project will develop communication strategies aimed at reaching specific target groups whose decisions and behaviours affect coastal biodiversity and/or who are affected by climate change. Among them, policy and decision makers, natural resource managers, the media, and stakeholders from key economic sectors related to coastal resources (e.g. fisheries, tourism, and agriculture).

evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: Yes, although risk management is primarily focused on the population, the benefits will affect biodiversity as well, as the coastal ecosystems would be protected by the national strategy of risk management emphasizing climate risk.

title: Increased Water Harvesting and Diminished Desertification

overview.feedback: The project aims at increasing irrigation water availability through formation of water user associations (WUA) for tank rehabilitation and management in the drought prone coastal areas of Tamil Nadu. WUAs restore tank structureslike tank storage capacity, bunds, sluice outlets, and surplus weirs to their original design standards. Women SHGs (self-help groups) also dig farm level ponds. These steps increase water retention/holding capacity of the tanks and farm ponds, providing water for drinking and domestic purposes and also for irrigation to reduce crop damage. Groundwater levels are also improved. The community based organizations formed would be responsible for future maintenance of the tanks. The project is expected to benefit approximately 12500 families with a total population of 75000.

responsibilities.executing_agent: DHAN foundation, European Commission and Oxfam Novib, the Netherlands

evaluative_information.success_factors: Institutional: the formation of new water harvesting structures and their maintenanace depends upon community institutions
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: alternate supply of water and no shortage in supply: the need to restore the structures arose only because of shortage of water
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: ground water recharge, reduced salinity ingress, irrigation water for crop production leading to economic benefits
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: 25 community-level tank management associations have been organised since the beginning of the project to rehabilitate village tanks, and 40 women’s self-help groups have been organised in order to excavate 250 new farm ponds.   In the Seranthai hamlet in Kothankulam Panchayat of Ramnad district agriculture is the primary source of income and food. Due to degraded tank condition and fluctuating monsoons the total area under irrigation reduced and the community members were forced to migrate. The Seranthai Tank Farmers Association in cooperation with the families restored a tank increasing water holding capacity to 7500m3. Approximately 80 households with an average of 0.3 hectares of paddy fields are assured with single crop yield and the water is also provided for livestock. In Shanmuga Kumarapuram there was a chronic water shortage both for drinking and domestic use, the villagers formed an association and dug up a new pond with a water holding capacity of 7000m3 supplying drinking water for about 11 months a year to 430 inhabitants.

title: Increasing climate change resilience of vulnerable communities

title: Increasing Resilience of Coastal areas and Community Settlements to Climate Change

overview.feedback: The project will implement effective community based adaptation measures in coastal areas thatreduce vulnerability and improve adaptive capacity to climate change and sea level rise. The project will use demonstration measures aligned with local conditions, which will encompass community-based systems for the management of protective ecosystems, sustainable use of climate-sensitive natural resources and diversification of vulnerable livelihoods. Envisaged demonstration projects will focus on opportunities for community-based afforestation, mangrove regeneration and plantation management, erosion prevention and participative protection of coastal sediment barriers, reduction of man-made stresses on coral reefs and protective ecosystems, diversification of crops and agricultural practices, optimization of freshwater and irrigation management, and improved information flows in climate information and early warning systems. The project will also enable a strategic revision of national and sub-national policies and programs to incorporate climate change risk considerations and adaptation strategies into financial decision processes.

responsibilities.executing_agent: Government, Local community

title: Increasing the resilience of small-scale tea farmers in responding to climate change

overview.feedback: This project was designed to provide concrete recommendations and to develop strategies to build resilience to climate change amongst small-scale tea growers, and mainstreaming adaptation to projected increasing climate risk. The following measures were undertaken to improve the resilience of the small-scale farmers:Through quarterly climate preparedness workshops farmers together with scientists discussed climate change projections and trends in the Suid Bokkeveld region, including adaptation options and long term strategies.  In the workshops farmers learned to integrate seasonal weather forecast into their decision making.Mentor farmers trained their fellow farmers in soil erosion control and the removal of alien species.As a result of the training farmers created wind breaks and retention buffers in their tea production areas. Through the learning process initiated by the project farmers changed to more sustainable agricultural practices e.g. mulching as a method to conserve moisture and increase plant nutrients.Finally, farmers learned to monitor the growth of wild and cultivated rooibos stands, and were able to enhance their management abilities according to findings. In the participatory research farmers discovered that wild rooibos has a greater resilience to severe climatic events than cultivated varieties. Two communities of small-scale rooibos farmers, currently organised as the Heiveld Co-operative and the Wupperthal Tea Association, have been harvesting wild and cultivated rooibos, and have become the de facto guardians of the wild rooibos genetic stock.

responsibilities.initiating_agent: World Wide Fund for Nature (WWF) South Africa
responsibilities.executing_agent: Environmental Monitoring Group, Climate Systems Analysis Group (UCT)

evaluative_information.success_factors:
•Access to latest scientific findings which provide info about seasonal trends and the level of confidence
•Excellent relations with farmers (which built upon previous work in the community)
•Continuity
evaluative_information.limiting_factors:
Farmers are resource poor, implementation of technical measures is often too costly. Many actions require investments that most of these farmers to not have.
Drought conditions persisted in the Suid Bokkeveld for most of the project period. This was both a constraint to the project (because of the limited resources of farmers to participate in learning processes) and an incentive (as farmers are stimulated to learn more about the situation and how best to respond to it).
One significant gap in adaptation support is the lack of engagement by the Department of Agriculture in the area.
evaluative_information.synergies_to_mitigation: At a small scale there are synergies to mitigation created through more sustainable land use and farming practices.
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: The project has significantly contributed to the empowerment of farmers through the promotion of sustainable farming practices and better decision making based on the farmers enhanced climate and crop knowledge. They also have now better access to market and other resources through marketing of their climate proofing activities. Wild rooibos, for example , is much in demand by European markets and attracts a high price. Through the project farmers were able to develop a successful harvesting and marketing strategy that gave them access to those markets (e.g. fair trade and organic markets).
evaluative_information.project_evaluation:
In order to be successful all project activities needed to be linked to local institutions (e.g. working with a particular rooibos farming co-operative, the Heiveld Cooperative).
Project has been successful because farmers are more resilient and were able to improve their livelihoods. Here are some of the findings from the project:
• There is a real enthusiasm amongst farmers in isolated communities to gain more understanding of global climatic patterns, and how these affect their livelihoods and their lifestyles.
• A learning process that supports the sharing of information and experiences at both global and local scales breaks people’s sense of isolation and helplessness, and creates new capacities for positive action to mitigate the effects of climate change.
• Adaptations are most effective when based on existing knowledge.
• The role of formal and informal institutions at a range of scales is critical for supporting adaptation.
• The project has shown that positive synergies may be found between rural livelihoods, conservation of biodiversity and successful adaptation to climate change.

Finally, the learning approach adopted in the project has enhanced local knowledge and broadened farmers’ capacities to respond in a proactive manner. The project used indigenous adaptive capacity as a starting point, combined with relevant external knowledge, rather than imposing adaptation plans in a top-down manner. This allowed the development of adaptation strategies to current and future climate change in a more realistic and participatory way.

additional_information:
CONSIDERATION OF CLIMATE CHANGE INFORMATION OR CLIMATE SCIENCE IN THE DESIGN AND IMPLEMENTATION OF THE PROJECT:
*Project design and implementations was based on the findings from downscaling data provided by the Climate Systems Analysis Group (UCT).
*Farmers have access to quarterly weather forecasts (which is provided by the South African Weather Bureau) and learned about relevant climate information through climate preparedness workshops.

title: Information and Communication Technology (e-choupal)

overview.feedback: E-choupal comprises of three main elements (1) providing a web enabled computer (with power backup), (2) a trained farmer – the e-choupal shanchalak, and (3) providing access to agricultural oriented information –  on weather, scientific farming practices, input supply, financial services, market prices, at the village in the local language.  Farmers can take informed decisions, align their farm output with market demand, secure quality and productivity, and reduce uncertainties.  Transaction costs are reduced. The e-choupal is a web based initiative of ITC’s International Business Division

responsibilities.executing_agent: ITC

evaluative_information.success_factors: Service providing efficiency, reliability of the information, dissemination of information (information must be provided timely and should be reliable so as to not cause any loss to the farmers, the information should be provided in the local language and should be easily understood)
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: internet kiosks management(internet kiosks management)
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: No-regret (economic development, social welfare)
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: The initiative has been widely accepted amongst the farmers and the service which was initially started in five states is being given in ten states and will soon cover fifteen states. It is presently operating in ten states, 40,000 villages, 6500 kiosks with four milion people.The e-Choupal has been specially cited in the Government of India’s Economic Survey of 2006-07, for its transformational impact on rural lives.

additional_information: The sanchalak bears some operating cost but in return earns a service fee for the e-transactions done through his e-Choupal. Farmers can get real-time information despite their physical distance from the mandis. The system saves procurement costs for ITC Limited. The farmers do not pay for the information and knowledge they get from e-Choupals; the principle is to inform, empower and compete. As per the Memorandum of Understanding (MOU), Nokia and ITC will collaborate to offer Nokia Life Tools consumers enriched content available in ITC’s e-Choupal network in the areas of commodity prices as well as updated information on the agriculture sector.

title: Information and Communication Technology (iKisan)

overview.feedback: iKisan was set up with two components, the iKisan.com website, to provide agricultural information online, and technical centres at village level (operated by agricultural graduates who act as the interface between the computer networks and the farmers) providing both on- and off-line information services. Their online services include information on 20 crops and market information about products and services of the companies in the Nagarjuna group, weather forecasting and current events. The offline services include crop diagnostics, disease and pest management, soil testing, sampling and fertility; information about agricultural equipment and other inputs and their availability; market information; crop insurance information; information regarding cropping patterns and systems; poultry- and animal husbandry-related information.

overview.feedback: This project includes: (a) diversification of agriculture (Promotion of salt tolerant rice varieties and other crops); (b) homestead-based forestry, horticulture and vegetable cultivation; (c) promotion of integrated rice, shrimp and fish culture; (d) pro-poor brackish water aquaculture; (e) identifcation of livelihood options and activities for women and marginal groups; (f) small entrepreneurship development based on local resources such as bee-keeping; (g) rainwater harvest and sweet water conservation for drinking and domestic; (h) sweet water conservation and efficient use for irrigation to agriculture; (i) preparedness for disaster risk (cyclone, tidal surge and sea level rise) reduction to save lives, properties and household assets; and (j) promotion of coastal afforestation for protection river bank erosion, prevent cyclone damages, etc.

responsibilities.executing_agent: Practical Solutions-ITDG

evaluative_information.success_factors: The stage of awareness  and involvement of the authorities and population (awareness of the problem of climate change, importance of a climate information system, project presentation and the involvement in activities).
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: One of the main difficulties in the implementation of a regional GIS was to convince the various institutions to share information, personnel, procedures, resources and adopt common data sources. In addition, rural families have access and make use of climate information through ethno-climatic booklets, radio and concerted predictions of Senamhi. This information is used for various agricultural activities.

additional_information: This project is part of the Macroproject. The aim was to protect the livelihoods of the rural poor by developing actions that would reduce their risk. title: Innovative insurance products for adaptation to climate change

overview.feedback: In order to build resilience against changing precipitation patterns, decreased predictability of weather conditions and increasing frequency of extreme events, the emergence of index-based crop insurance products is fostered in Ghana. Such insurance products can stabilize income and food security for the rural population. Furthermore, a more developed insurance marked can attract national and foreign direct investment, particularly in a then more resilient agricultural sector, and makes international markets more easily accessible for Ghanaian enterprises. Thus, the project contributes to Ghana’s overall economic development and food security and sets an example that can have positive effects for other African countries.

responsibilities.initiating_agent: Collaboration of the National Insurance Commission of Ghana, the Ghana Insurers Association, the Ministry of Finance of Ghana and others
responsibilities.executing_agent: GIZ
responsibilities.funding_source: Federal Ministry for the Environment, Nature Conservation and Nuclear Safety, Germany (BMU)

evaluative_information.success_factors: In order to scale up the crop insurance programme both in terms of sums insured and product portfolio, continued financial support is required either from donors, the national government or the involved insurance companies.
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: Index-insurance products rely on accurate data and research (weather data, agricultural data) that are not yet available for every location; low standards of education, agricultural management expertise and financial literacy of farmers require high education and awareness raising investments and threaten economic viability; uncertainties like basis risk and poor agricultural management may lead to ineffective risk abatement.
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: Improving food security, attracting national and foreign direct investment into the agricultural sector, opening international markets.
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: Studies and surveys suggest that insured farmers feel more at ease when it comes to drought and changing weather patterns and are willing to invest more in their crops; noticeable effects on FDI’s or market access however presuppose an up-scaling of the crop insurance programme. Crop insurance as an adaptation measure for climate change appears to be a valid option if the obstacle of high investments in product development, data management and research can be managed. Moreover, if coupled with other adaptation measures (e.g. SLM), its effectiveness may be improved.

title: Institutional Strengthening for Integrated Water Resources Management (CITARUM)

overview.feedback: The main goal of the project is to integrate climate change adaptation (CCA) and climate change mitigation (CCM) options in the catchment management and local development planning. The project supports a resilient and less carbon intensive development strategy in the catchment area. It was conducted as part of a 15 years Integrated Citarum Water Resources Management Investment Programme that began in 2010. It consists of three parts. Part 1 is the identification of adaptation options based on vulnerability and risk analyses. Part 2 is the integration of adaptation and mitigation options into regional water resources management development plans. In addition to outputs of Part 1, it takes inputs from local stakeholders, identified actions already pursued by local communities, and to be synergised with local development policies. Part 3 is monitoring and evaluating plan implementation. This part has not been conducted.

responsibilities.initiating_agent: Asian Development Bank through the Indonesian National Planning Agency (BAPPENAS)
responsibilities.executing_agent: Centre for Climate Risk and Opportunity Management, Bogor Agricultural University (CCROM-IPB), under the supervision of the Ministry of Environment

evaluative_information.success_factors:
The project requires a large amount of data that may not always be available or accessible. Support from institutions that hold data is necessary.
Experts and resources for climate and land use projections and analyses may be uneasy when replicating the approach beyond a well-supported basin.
Participation of local communities and local government are crucial during primary data collection, identification of existing adaptation and mitigation options, and mainstreaming process
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: Not known
evaluative_information.synergies_to_mitigation: The project supports a resilient and less carbon intensive development strategy in the catchment area, and therefore aims at both climate change adaptation and climate change mitigation.
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: This project is part of a 15 years Integarted Citarum Water Resources Management Investment Programme. Therefore, it supports the integrated water resource management and better catchment management.
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: The project is relevant and transferable to any river basin with a similar importance as Citarum River with its relevance to water supply for Jakarta. Funds may be made available from central government and other institutions for such priority catchments. Expertise are possible from university and other institutions of excellence.

additional_information: Climate proofing method was used in the project, a case study on this application is recommended.

title: Insurance for climate change adaptation

overview.feedback: Reducing risks associated to natural hazards through risk management and prevention strategies is a priority need in Peru. On behalf of the German Federal Ministry for the Environment, Nature Conservation and Nuclear Safety (BMU), Deutsche Gesellschaft für Internationale Zusammenarbeit (GIZ) GmbH has developed a project that offers an innovative choice for risk reduction and climate change adaptation. The project is part of the BMU’s International Climate Initiative (ICI).Objectives The project’s overall objective is to give small businesses, producer organizations, and sub-national governmental institutions on Peru’s north coast the possibility of insurance coverage against extreme natural hazards by way of new, innovative insurance products.The secondary objectives are:-	Analysis and strengthening of the regional demand for insurance products associated to natural hazards.-	Develop innovative insurance products associated to natural hazards.-	Create a legal and institutional framework suitable for developing innovative insurance products associated to natural hazards.-	Contribute to scaling up a replicated model by creating national and international visibility. Create national and international visibility.

responsibilities.initiating_agent: Insurance Company La Positiva Seguros and Superintendence of Banking, insurance and private pension funds.
responsibilities.executing_agent: Deutsche Gesellschaft für internationale Zusammenarbeit GmBH (GIZ). German Development Agency.
responsibilities.funding_source: German Federal Ministry for the Environment, Nature Conservation, and Nuclear Safety (BMU).

evaluative_information.success_factors: The development of insurance markets for agriculture and climate risks needs the support of the government and an enabling policy environment, especially the Ministry of Agriculture. A strong cooperation between the public and private sectors is essential for the project’s success.
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: The main challenge for developing insurance products against climate risks is the lack of information and data on climate events and agricultural production that is trustable and can be used for insurance products.
evaluative_information.synergies_to_mitigation: There are no synergies to mitigation.
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: The project has positive side-effects regarding a general culture of preventive measures, as it is difficult to develop insurance products without thinking of possible risk reduction and prevention measures.
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: Building a market for insurance against climate risks will still take time. Important initial products have been developed on behalf of the public and private sectors. It is necessary to strengthen this cooperation for the sustainability of climate insurance products and risk transfer mechanisms.

title: Integrated Climate Change Management in Communal Reserves

overview.feedback: The overarching goal of this Project is to reduce the vulnerability of indigenous communities to climate change by increasing their resilience through the integration of Ecosystem (EBA) and Community Based (CBA) Adaptation Strategies in the management of Communal Reserves in the Peruvian Amazon, thereby contributing to the sustainable livelihoods of such communities and guaranteeing the conservation of approximately 500,000 hectares of high conservation value areas. By involving different levels of government and civil society through a highly participatory approach, the management capacities, agreements, communication and tools will be developed to enable the execution of a portfolio of income-generating EBA and CBA measures with indigenous communities.

responsibilities.initiating_agent: Ministry of Environment, National Protected Areas Service
responsibilities.executing_agent: United Nations Development Programme (UNDP), National Protected Areas Service (SERNANP)
responsibilities.funding_source: German Federal Ministry for the Environment, Nature Conservation and Nuclear Safety

evaluative_information.success_factors:
Active participation of national counterparts as well as local indigenous organizations in all aspects of project implementation.
Successful realization of parallel funding from local and regional governments for adaptation measures.
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: Lack of long term, quality climatic data for intervention areas.  Low levels of continuity in technical roles in regional authorities and in indigenous leadership is a structural weakness widespread across Peru, that often precludes work on activities that need to be long term to produce meaningful results. As Law enforcement of illegal mining operations are outside the scope of this project, the economic viability  of all proposed income-generating activities is at risk in areas where illegal mining is widespread.
evaluative_information.synergies_to_mitigation: In Peru, 47.5% of green house gases generated annually come from land use, land-use change and forestry. This occurs in part because of the conversion of forests into grasslands and agricultural lands as a result of unplanned land use and lack of control by the state. The project will contribute to climate change mitigation by providing indigenous communities and partner institutions with the capacities, tools and information to reduce deforestation and degradation and engage with forest restoration EBA activities on Communal Reserves and their adjoining titled lands.
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: The project will empower indigenous people and their organizations to lead and define their own development path through the adoption of Life Plans. The development of these Life Plans will respect traditional governance structures and decision making processes, integrating local land use decisions with regional-level plans. The project will promote market-oriented, income-generating EBA and CBA activities such as Sustainable Forest Management and sustainable agroforestry (such as cocoa or coffee), complementing them with food security practices that reduce climate change vulnerability, for example local aquaculture with native species. Indigenous community members will be given training in a variety of skills (communication, internet, accounting, team leadership) will which allow them to explore new development opportunities and improve their climate risk management capacities.
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: not specified

Indigenous community members will be given training in a variety of skills (communication, internet, accounting, team leadership) will which allow them to explore new development opportunities and improve their climate risk management capacities.
