title: Integrated Coastal Zone Management (ICZM)

overview.feedback: The ICZM’s development objective  is to assist the Government of India in building national capacity for implementation of comprehensive coastal management approach in the country, and piloting the integrated coastal zone management approach in states of Gujarat, Orissa and West Bengal.The  Project will help build the appropriate institutional arrangements, capacity and advanced knowledge systems needed to implement the national program.  In West Bengal, the project will support capacity building of the state level agencies and institutions, preparation of an ICZM plan for the coastal sediment cell for the coastal region, and piloting of ICZM approaches include mangrove plantation. The pilot investments in West Bengal will complement the ICZM plan and the capacity building sub-components to address the major coastal zone management issues in the two targeted coastal stretches of (i) Digha-Shankarpur, and (ii) Sagar Island in theSundarban, covering about 13 percent of West Bengal’s coasts.                                  The investments will include (a) conservation and protection of coastal resources including mangrove and coastal shelterbelt plantation; pilot works in shoreline protection for Digha beach and the southern end of Sagar Island; and rehabilitation of the marine aquarium at Digha; (b) environment and pollution management by completing the sewerage system for Digha to prevent flow of sewage onto the sandy beach; cleaning and environmental improvement of the Digha beach, and solid waste management in Digha; improvement of the fish auction centre at Digha; and distribution of grid electricity on Sagar Island to replace diesel generation and prevent soil and water pollution; and (c) livelihood security of coastal communities in Sagar Island including support to CBO coordinated livelihood improvement activities; afforestation-based livelihood improvement; promotion of local small-scale tourism and ecotourism activities; and provision of cyclone shelters in the coastal villages.

responsibilities.executing_agent: Ministry of Environment and Forest, GOI, national and state project management units (PMUs)

evaluative_information.success_factors: political will, research and studies to establish the hazard parameters, allocation of resources
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: weak institutional structure to implement ICZM, lack of end users of knowledge and capacity building services
evaluative_information.synergies_to_mitigation: yes (Carbon finance opportunities will be explored to enhance financial attractiveness of interventions such as improved sewerage systems and the mangrove plantations. )
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: win win (Irrespective of climate change it is important to have an ICZM structure in place because of India’s long coastline)
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: It is a fairly recent project, and according to pre-calculations, the state level pilot investments are likely to directly benefit 1.1 million people, while the state and national capacity building activities will benefit 7.65 million people directly, and 35 million people indirectly in the medium term, and eventually all 63 million people living in the low elevation coastal areas in India.

additional_information: The description for the project has been given specifically for the state of West Bengal."The initial set of three states have been selected on various grounds including pressure on coast, presence of critical ecosystems, risks of natural hazards, etc. The Asian Development Bank is supporting a less comprehensive shoreline management project in Karnataka, Maharashtra and Goa. It is envisaged that the second phase of the ICZM would take up the other coastal states with project preparation in all remaining coastal states commencing immediately."

title: Integrated farming of coffee plants for adaptation and reduction of greenhouse gas emissions

overview.feedback: The coffee tree is one of the most important and traditional activites in the Brazilian agriculture. And might be appreciably affected by the climate changes, mainly with the temperature increase.There are already some researches that show promising techniques to minimize the climatic extreme effect, such as coffee crop grown shaded. Besides the adaptation of coffee crop in warmer environments using management techniques, some agroforestal systems are being adopted for carbon mitigation. The aim of the present study is (i) evaluate the potencial of shade coffee crop using different fruit trees and forestry in order to decrease the temperature in the full sun coffee crop, promoting the coffee adaptation in climate change effects; (ii) quantify the carbon balance in the system soil-plant-atmospher to assess the potencial for carbon sequestration in different shading system; (iii) evaluate the biomass production through of the more advanced remote sensing methods.

responsibilities.executing_agent: Cepagri/Unicamp and Embrapa
responsibilities.funding_source: Brazilian Coffee Research and Development Consortium/Embrapa Coffee

evaluative_information.success_factors: A critical factor for the success of this project is a temperature. If the temperature during the experiment does not reach at least 32 degrees Celsius is not possible to observe a difference between the experiment.
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: The limiting factors of the project are the samples used to quantify the carbon stock, since that is necessary destroy a great number of coffee tree.
evaluative_information.synergies_to_mitigation: This project besides promotes the coffee adaptation in climate change effects, it also mitigates the greenhouse gases emissions by carbon sequestration
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: This project is another positive side effect that is related to social development, since there is no migration of the crop due to climate change and adaptation practices can add value to coffee.
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: So far, it is possible to observe an increase of biomass in shaded coffee

title: Integrated Land Use Management to Combat Land Degradation and Deforestation in Madhya Pradesh

overview.feedback: Sustainable land and Ecosystem management is the use of land resources (soild, forests, rangelands, water, animals and plants) for the production of goods to meet human needs while assuring the long term productive potential. The project component involves (1) enabling adoption of SLEM (Sustainable Land and Ecosystem Management) in Madhya Pradesh, (2) demonstrating and upscaling of innovative approaches for sustainable land and ecosystem management, (3) developing adaptive capacity. The expected outcomes of the project are to integrate SLEM in the land use planning at the state level, management of natural resources and conservation of biodiversity led by respective community groups, reduced vulnerability of communities and increased resilience of land and ecosystems to climate change and variability.

title: Integrated Local Assessment  of the Santa River Basin - SNC

overview.feedback: Vulnerability and adaptation to climate change assessment to identify and evaluate natural hazards, and the vulnerability and risk of socioeconomic activities and local affected infrastructure; the results are incorporated into the land use planning process.  It evaluates the territory of ecosystems and natural resources of the Santa River Basin related to hydrometeorological anomalies, natural and anthropogenic processes that enable to design and implement adaptation measures  in a participatory manner.The Integrated Local Assessment allow to know the vulnerability and the adaptation processes to climate change of the different systems, at a micro level.

responsibilities.executing_agent: Ancash Regional Government with the Ministry of the Environment  and Senamhi

evaluative_information.success_factors: Institutionalize climate change in the Regional Government of Ancash, to be considered in the execution of all type of sustainable development projects. Fortify the local institutional capacities for the implementation of the adaptation measures like a permanent process.
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: Scattered, outdated and limited access to information. There is no territorial information. Data  is not comparable at spatial scales and generalized.
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: not specified
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: From the Integrated Local Assessment  of the Santa River Basin the intrinsic vulnerability, as well as the current and future vulnerabilities were obtained, which set the basis to determine the proposals for the adaptation measures considering the current and future climate scenarios developed by SENAMHI.

additional_information: This assessment is part of the Second National Communication (SNC) on Climate Change to the UNFCCC. The aim was to develop and improve national capabilities to facilitate the integration of climate change in the national development and poverty reduction processes, establishing an adaptation strategy for priority areas and sectors.

title: Integrated local assessment and adaptation strategy to CC - PROCLIM

overview.feedback: This project includes: (a) diversification of agriculture (Promotion of salt tolerant rice varieties and other crops); (b) homestead-based forestry, horticulture and vegetable cultivation; (c) promotion of integrated rice, shrimp and fish culture; (d) pro-poor brackish water aquaculture; (e) identifcation of livelihood options and activities for women and marginal groups; (f) small entrepreneurship development based on local resources such as bee-keeping; (g) rainwater harvest and sweet water conservation for drinking and domestic; (h) sweet water conservation and efficient use for irrigation to agriculture; (i) preparedness for disaster risk (cyclone, tidal surge and sea level rise) reduction to save lives, properties and household assets; and (j) promotion of coastal afforestation for protection river bank erosion, prevent cyclone damages, etc.

responsibilities.executing_agent: Ministry of Environment, Autonomous Authority of the Chira-Piura Basin (AACHCP), National Natural Resources Institute (Inrena)

evaluative_information.success_factors: The Local Integrated Evaluation was developed under an innovative work-scheme that coordinated the joint effort of several governmental institutions and the population, concatenating political processes, investigation platforms and participatory mechanisms, involving the local and regional organizations as part of this effort.
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: An obstacle to carry out the study was the lack of integrated information on the River basin (e.g. availability of future global climate scenarios, adaptability of the regional numeric model and calculation capacity). In addition, there was moderate uncertainty in the construction of climate scenarios. Two methodologies were applied (statistic and dynamic), and two emissions scenarios for a period close to 2035.
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: not specified
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: Detailed studies were developed at the Piura river basin level and 4 sub-watersheds, as a result of a joint process of six institutions that combined scientific, professional and local actors’ efforts to elaborate the Local Integrated Evaluation and the Climate Change Adaptation Strategy. Piura’s river basin climatic characterization and climate scenarios up to the year 2050, with a 20 × 20 km resolution, were also developed.

additional_information:
This assessment is part of PROCLIM, a project to strengthen national capabilities for an effective performance of the human, institutional, and financial resources in order to face
Climate Change and manage Air Quality in prioritized geographic areas and cities.

title: Integrated Watershed Management

overview.feedback: The project aims to be the national reference center in the integrated watershed management in the watersheds of the Tunari Mountain range and the Central Valley of Cochabamba.It involves as an initial stage the socioeconomic and biophysical diagnostic, in order to evaluate the areas of influence for appropriate planning. title: Integration of climate change into existing disaster preparedness programs

overview.feedback: This project is involved in “Disaster Preparedness and Climate Change programmes” which implemented in Nicaragua, Mozambique and Vietnam supported by Red Cross/ Red Crescent Centre based in Netherlands.Vietnam is one of the most disaster-prone countries in the world. Each year typhoons, floods and droughts cause death, injury, loss of property and infrastructural damages. The projects goal is to contribute to the significant reduction in human suffering and negative effects of natural disasters.The project objective is to reduce human suffering and negative effects of natural disasters on the most vulnerable people of Vietnam by strengthening Vietnamese capacities to adapt and respond to natural disasters that are enhanced by climate change.Basic idea was awareness-raising about the impacts of climate change on livelihoods and the need to be prepared to adapt. So NGOs make climate change impacts part of their focus. Furthermore The Red Cross produced two documentaries that were broadcast on national television.Also the theme of climate change impacts was integrated into participatory community assessments, which resulted in the identification of community-specific vulnerabilities and solutions (e.g., loud speaker systems for early warning, construction of dams and tree barriers as defense for agricultural land against winds and salt water intrusion).The project focused on 30 disaster prone coastal communes in 5 provinces ( Nghe An, Ha Tinh, Quang Binh, Ninh Thuan and Binh Thuan) which are most vulnerable areas.

responsibilities.initiating_agent: Red Cross, Red Crescent Climate Centre
responsibilities.executing_agent: Vietnam Red Cross Society and Netherlands Red Cross Society
responsibilities.funding_source: The Netherlands Ministry of Foreign Affairs

evaluative_information.success_factors:
- Cooperation between Red Cross and scientists, relevant institutions and organizations;
- The project had the cooperation with many other organizations in 5 pilot provinces;
- The climate change messages were communicated to local people in simple ways.
evaluative_information.limiting_factors:
- Lack of CC knowledge of Red Cross key staff.
- Insufficient practical experiences with community based disaster preparedness and the step from Hazard Vulnerability, and Capacity Assessments (HVCA) to project implementation.
- Difficult for Vietnam Red Cross to reach out to policy makers
evaluative_information.synergies_to_mitigation: No direct, but indirect. (e.g. afforestation reduces global CO2)
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: The project is nothing of both. However, it creates further projects, which could be a No-regret or a Win-Win option.
evaluative_information.project_evaluation:
This is an appreciated project, recognized by several stakeholders in Vietnam (and abroad) as an example for climate change adaptation, and having created a willingness among the Vietnam Red Cross and the Netherlands Red Cross to continue.
-Various training and dissemination materials were developed and distributed. VNRC staff, national decision makers, local authorities and inhabitants of the 30 project communities were reached by various dissemination activities on the relationship between climate change and disasters and the need to be prepared.
-30 coastal communities were increasing their resilience to storms, floods and drought by implementing small-scale adaptation measures such as building dams, search and rescue centres, planting trees(http://cigrasp.pik-potsdam.de/adaptations/27) and improving loudspeaker systems for early warning.
Based on this pilot projects, the Red Cross has decided to focus efforts on mangrove restoration and afforestation as a strategy to both ameliorate climate change impact and simultaneously generate funds through the UNFCCC Clean Development Mechanism to finance disaster preparedness.
- The Red Cross is now engaged in a more systematic consultation with the national meteorological office and climate change experts, and using that knowledge for more effective risk management activities.

additional_information:
The project’s approach is to consider a disaster preparedness related to climate change project is the same as “normal” disaster preparedness project but:
- Integrated climate change-component;
- More emphasis on advocacy at national level;
- More cooperation and exchange with technical institutions and NGO’s.
-The project’s approach is based on a triple A principle: (i) Awareness with information and educational activities; (ii) Action with supporting the development of concrete adaptation activities within the existing context of disaster preparedness programmes by implementing 30 community sub-projects; (iii) Advocacy with raising concerns about the impacts of CC on vulnerable people to policy makers and offering practical examples of CC adaptation and disaster preparedness programmes.

title: Integration of Gender into climate change adaptation and low carbon development: raising awareness, building capacity, supporting national and international policy processes

overview.feedback: The overarching approach is bringing to the fore the connection and importance of gender in climate change. Climate change affects different regions, generations, income groups and genders differently. Developing countries, such as Bangladesh and the Pacific Region have already been highly affected. Poor people, a disproportionate amount of which are female are particularly vulnerable, and at the same time key actors. All too often, gender issues have been neglected so far in local and national climate policy-making. Women and communities have their own visions and knowledge on how to build and strengthen their resilience to climate change. And such visions are tied to the broader realities of power relationships that are informed by class, gender, ethnicity and citizenship. The initiative will further harness the capacities of communities, primarily women on adaptation and low carbon development in Bangladesh and parts of the Pacific Region (Kiribati, Nauru, Republic of Marshall Islands). This likewise provides opportunities for women to engage in local and national climate change policies. In this context, the project partners will develop training material, as well as indicators and methods for selecting and monitoring of ‘gender sensitive adaptations measures’, and policy proposals. Global exchange and multiplication of the project’s content and results will be provided by a Global Learning Platform, which will be organised by GenderCC’s International Secretariat. The platform will involve and connect practitioners from around the world working in these fields. While in the inchoate phase the International Secretariat and the two project partners will provide the bulk of the content, the circle of participants will widen, involving the wider GenderCC network and in the long run, the global women, gender, climate change and environmental community.

responsibilities.executing_agent: Center for Global Change (Bangladesh) Secretariat for the Pacific Community (Pacific)
responsibilities.funding_source: Federal Ministry for the Environment, Nature Conversation and Nuclear Safety (BMU), GERMANY

evaluative_information.success_factors: Already climate change is recognised in both countries as an urgent issue. Additionally in both countries acknowledgment of gender as an important issue and the need for gender sensitive approaches has started. The project addresses the lack of actual practical experiences and approaches with its pilot projects and training.
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: If stakeholders are unwilling or fail to become gender aware. Non participation by relevant actors. Lack of gender disaggregated data.
evaluative_information.synergies_to_mitigation: The project aims at an integrated approach in which mitigation and adaptation are no separate and exclusive measures. Thus the promotion of low carbon development (energy efficiency, alternative energy sources) is an expression of this approach.
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: Greater gender Awareness in regard to climate change policies and low carbon development, as well as gender awareness within governmental bodies. NGO sector and communities will have positive effects in other areas. The project will also contribute to women’s empowerment in general by improved participation of, and alternative economic opportunities for, women.
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: not specified

title: Jal Abhishek Abhiyaan

overview.feedback: Jal Abhishek Abhiyaan is a convergence program launched by the Government of Madhya Pradesh in 2006 that aimed at promoting community awareness and self initiative towards water conservation and augmentation and converges existing departmental schemes for the same. The program disseminates information about techniques, and facilitates community action for implementing an action plan with funds from different sovernment schemes and public contribution. The stated aims are: (1) To construct water conservation structures through convergence of funds from different line departments.(2) To conserve water through these structures thereby contributing towards ground water recharge.(3) Equitable distribution, usage and saving of the existing water resources.

responsibilities.executing_agent: Rajiv Gandhi Watershed Mission in the Department of Panchayati Raj and Rural Development
responsibilities.funding_source: Convergence of funds from different line departments

evaluative_information.success_factors: The success of this program depends on institutional and financial factors such as awareness genaration, community mobilisation and available of funds for construction of water harvesting structures, and sustaining the works over time
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: JAA is not a scheme and depends on convergence with multiple government schemes for fund availability, and successful community implementation, and requires leadership and high amounts of administrative effort. This may limit the program in the long run if ways of reducing the coordination effort are not found.
evaluative_information.synergies_to_mitigation: Some impacts possible - e.g. improved soil organic carbon in fields through field bunding, increased ground water levels can potentially reduce energy consumption for irrigation,but are often offset by increased use.
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: Win Win. This program will help in conservation, augmentation and maintenance of water resources in the state with community involvement
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: Activities supported include dugwells, farm bunding, farm ponds, percolation tanks, plantation, check dams, ground water recharge pits along with dugwells. The quality of work varies across districts and leadership in districts is key. The program promotes adaptation to climate change by focussing on community and individual water conservation practices and introducing climate reseilient cropping practices

title: Jessour to collect water runoff

overview.feedback: Building earthen dikes to collect water runoff is a widely used technique. In the mountains regions of North Africa people used the jessour, an ancient system of collecting run-off from long slopes. Farmers build earthen dams (tabias) across the valley floors to trap the run-off water and silt. Small terraces are created for growing crops and fruit trees that would normally struggle to survive in this arid climate. The Institut des Régions Aride (IRA) together with local farmers developed technologies to improve the jessour and to avoid destruction of the spillways trough heavy rain. Other improvements include the ‘buried stone pocket’ for the localized, underground irrigation of fruit trees to increase the efficiency of water use.

title: Johads - Rainwater harvesting

overview.feedback: To harvest the monsoon waters, people in Rajasthan construct small earthen check dams (johads) across seasonally flooded gullies (nalas) which also improve percolation and groundwater recharge.  Starting 1984, the last sixteen years have seen the revival of some 3000 johads spread across more than 650 villages in Alwar district.  This has resulted in a general rise of the groundwater level by almost 6 m and a 33% increase in the forest cover in the area.  Five rivers that used to go dry immediately following the monsoon have now become perennial.

responsibilities.executing_agent: Tarun Bharat Sangh

evaluative_information.success_factors: not specified
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: not specified
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: The construction of these johads not only allow for the harvesting of rain water, but they also increase groundwater recharge and stabilize the runoff levels of rivers. Also human activities benefit from these structures as crop yields may increase and also the area covered by forests.
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: For the last 16 years the construction of these small scale infrastructures has spread all over the region with very positive results.

title: Joint Climate Change Risk Management Program (CCRM)

overview.feedback: The aim of the proposed joint programme is to help Egypt align its climate risk management and human development efforts in pursuing the achievement of MDGs in the face of climate change and the predicted serious threats to the country. In this context, the project will serve to reduce poverty and mitigate risk by combining mitigation and adaptation under one integrated Climate Risk Management (CRM) banner with a special attention given to the vulnerable poorest populations of Egypt through two complementary approaches: - Main-streaming GHG mitigation into national policy and investment frameworks, including increased CDM financing opportunities; enhancing the country’s capacity to - Adapt to climate change. The joint programme will build awareness and capacity of key decision makers and development actors to support the systematic integration of climate change as a new variable in key policy, regulatory, institutional and operational frameworks and implement pilot projects.

title: Joint Forest Management (JFM)

overview.feedback: Where functional, Joint Forest Management committees undertake protection and management of local forests that meets their needs and provides substantial benefits to the local communities, with support from the Forest departments.  JFMCs protection forests from fire, grazing and control fuelwood and timber harvesting, and communities can benefit by sustaining local forests over time  for flows of environmental services including water recharge, increased biodiversity and improved micro climate, as well as improved flows of fuelwood, fodder and other NTFP’s (non-timber forest products). However, tenurial insecurity and excessive governmental control, and low community interest can lead to sub-optimal outcomes.  Increasing share in timber revenue will help. By increasing the resource availability it diversifies people’s livelihood options, improves water availability by increasing percolation, and sequesters carbon. India has about 100,000 JFMCs.

responsibilities.executing_agent: Forest department of states and the JFM committees

evaluative_information.success_factors: institutional, legal recognition
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: prior existence of forest management committees
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: Win win: provides economic, social and environmental benefits
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: The project success varied with the region where it is implemented. There has been an increase in the number of JFMC’s over the past decades showing a decrease in the extent of degraded forest area but there has not been a considerable increase in the forest area. A firm legal basis for JFM is the biggest issue facing the programe which has created several problems in states where JFM has been implemented . Issues of conflicts among communities, presence of a traditional institution, transparency in management, marketing of products should be sorted out to make JFM a complete success.  Options within the Forest Rights Act can help strengthen community tenure and control for existing JFM groups as well.

additional_information: JFM has also been tried in Sundarbans in West Bengal where the forests act as a buffer against climate extremes of cyclones and storm surges. Forests provide subsistence food and subsistence income in case of failure of crop due to drought, provides more fodder, fuelwood, etc. Improves soil moisture condition especially in hilly areas. The Existence of JFMs also makes harvest (sustainable) easy. In the Udaipur District, JFM committee allows open grazing in the second year of drought.

title: Khazan technology

overview.feedback: The Khazan technology is based on the traditional knowledge. Low-lying coastal land, which has been reclaimed from marshy mangroves by construction of dikes, bunds and sluice gates (which regulate water movement – both inflow and outflow – during high and low tides). It is based on the principle of a tidal clock and salinity regulation. The sluice gate is strategically located depending on the contours and relief of the land.  The wooden shutters open and close with the pressure of the tidal flow and thereby protect the agriculture fields from tidal effects. There are three components which are independent and need to be conserved as one Khazan ecosystem: agricultural fields, fisheries, and sluice gates.

title: Kisan Credit Card Scheme (KCC)

overview.feedback: Kisan Credit Card Scheme (KCC) aims at providing adequate and timely support from the banking system to the farmers for their short-term credit needs for cultivation of crops. This mainly helps farmer for purchase of inputs etc., during the cropping season. Repayment can be rescheduled if there is a bad crop season, and extensions are offered for up to 4 years. The card is valid for 3 years and subject to annual renewals. Banks in India that lend for agricultural purposes usually offer the KCC. Withdrawals are made using slips, cards, and a passbook.

responsibilities.initiating_agent: Reserve Bank of India, GOI and NABARD
responsibilities.executing_agent: Banks

evaluative_information.success_factors: Financial: farmer willingness to enter into an agreement with the bank, ability to pay back loans, Institutional: Average land holding size as limit to be fixed on the basis of operational land holding, cropping pattern and scale of finance.
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: Maintenance of pass and cheque book, inability to repay, crop loss due to repeated drought
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: win win: The credit card can be used whether or not the crop is affected due to climate change impacts for improved productivity
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: Since its launch in August 1998, around 2.38 crore Kisan Credit Cards were issued upto 31 March 2002 by Cooperative Banks, Regional Rural Banks and Commercial Banks put together. Conversion/reschedulement of loans also permissible in case of damage to crops due to natural calamities.

additional_information:
Card valid for 3 years subject to annual review. As incentive for good performance, credit limits could be enhanced to take care of increase in costs, change in cropping pattern, etc.
Full year's credit requirement of the borrower taken care of.

title: Kutch Drought Proofing Project

overview.feedback: Kutch Drought Proofing Project was initiated to establish self sufficiency in food, fodder and water in the villages of Kutch and thus to increase the capacity of the villagers to withstand calamities. The activities included in the project are earthen farm bunds, stone outlets, grass seeding on bunds, grassland development, Check dams, percolation tanks, bore-well recharging, contour bunding of fields, renovation of existing water harvesting structures and construction of new structures. Use of drip irrigation systems is being promoted for water management. This will result in increasing groundwater levels, reduce salinity ingress and will make communities resilient to drought conditions.

responsibilities.executing_agent: Kutch Nav Nirman Abhiyan, NABARD
responsibilities.funding_source: Prime Minister's National Relief Fund, Ministry of Rural Development

evaluative_information.success_factors: effective local institutions
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: need basic funds to implement
evaluative_information.synergies_to_mitigation: soil carbon benefits would need to be evaluated
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: fulfills water needs, environmental conservation by groundwater recharge and reducing salinity ingress.
evaluative_information.project_evaluation:
26 villages have been made drought proofed for more than 2 years, 4 villages for more than 1 year; grassland development in 13 villages covering 353 ha; farm bunding in 492 ha, fodder bank in 10 villages with 1112 cattle population; 785 ha of farm land has been treated; 1850 ha of land contributes to soil and loisture conservation.
To evaluate the efficiency and success of the project in fulfilling the water needs of the people a rapid assessment of the structures was undertaken. This also helped in understanding the future line of action in the project villages.

additional_information: The Kutch Drought Proofing project was initially planned for the year 2001 but had to be postponed due to the earthquake in that year.Training and capacity building of the project implementing NGOs was done with the support of Aga Khan Rural Support Programme (AKRSP). The programme is presently focusing on strengthening the forward linkages of the producers of milk in Kutch through the collaborative approach of Abhiyan and Saurashtra Kutch Dairy Project (a wing of National Dairy Development Board). Under this a fodder bank programme was started in 10 villages to make them self-reliant in terms of fodder availability in drought years. The initiatives of the pprogramme are compiled in a quaterly published magazine (ChatAchat).

title: KwaZulu Natal Forest Restoration Project

overview.feedback: This project is a livelihoods program that helps poor and vulnerable members of our township and rural communities to grow a future for themselves. Wildlands Conservation Trust facilitators teach individuals in these communities how to grow indigenous trees from seed and care for the plants until they reach a certain height. These individuals are referred to as ‘tree-preneurs’. The trees are then traded back to Wildlands for food, clothes, bicycles, agricultural goods and tools, school and university fees. The trees are then either planted back into the communities or planted out in Wildlands’ forest restoration projects. The project supports the ongoing establishment of the Jobe, Ongoye and Buffelsdraai Carbon sinks and the identification and development of new sinks in southern KwaZulu-Natal and the Eastern Cape, using pro-poor development methodologies in pursuit of this overall objective. Wildlands calculates that for every hectare of the 1000 hectares being re-forested on the three sites, 3 to 41/2 tonnes of CO2 will be sequestered per year over a 20-year period. This amounts to 60 000-90 000 tones of CO2 removed from the atmosphere over the project’s lifespanSpecific measures:1.Support the growing, planting and care of 40 000 seedlings per annum, using the Indigenous Trees for Life pro-poor methodology, across the existing (and new) sinks.2.The management of this process, with emphasis on the training and capacity building of the tree-preneurs and planting and caring SMME’s.3.The ongoing development of the Wildlands Carbon Sink scientific process, to underwrite the medium – long term sustainability of the sinks. 4.The formal evaluation and development of new sink opportunities in the southern KZN and Eastern Cape regions.5.Small sclale land owners plant trees on the boundaries of their properties which increases flood protection

responsibilities.executing_agent: Wildlands Conservation Trust

evaluative_information.success_factors:
Projects is a pro-poor and consultative process engaging the local communities and ensuring that they benefit from the tree planning (e.g. trading for credit scheme where ‘tree-preneurs’ get building materials, school fee credit etc. in exchange for seed collection and planting)
Importance of Incentive structure for seed collection and planting
Important role of local facilitator
Required buy in by local community leaders
evaluative_information.limiting_factors:
Recent drought has limited the tree survival of plant seeds
Low education levels in the communities
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: Yes as the trading scheme improves the livelihoods of participating communities.
evaluative_information.project_evaluation:

•Socio-economic study

title: Land shaping promotes crop irrigation and prevents water stagnation

overview.feedback: The low-lying area of the Sundarbans in West Bengal is well-known for frequent floods and cyclones. Water stagnates from June-July and remains muddy upto December making it impossible to grow any crop except the low yielding variety. Ramakrishna Mission Lokasiksha Parishad (RKMLSP) undertook a unique project of Land Shaping wherein a part of a field is raised artificially under its rural livelihoods program. The idea of digging ponds to raise the low land with the help of excavated earth provided sufficient rain water for crop irrigation as well as prevented water stagnation. The available land for crop cultivation for marginal farmers was about 0.2 to 0.6 hectare each. One-fifth (20 per cent) of the land selected for LS is dug up to a depth of 2.4 meters. The excavation could be in the center of the plot or on the side – according to the shape and size of the plot. With the excavated earth, a raised bund of 75 cm, along the boundary of the area is made, to stop water from entering the area. This made it suitable for the cultivation of High Yielding variety (HYV) rice, vegetables etc. On the original low land traditional varieties of rice is grown during monsoon season and chillies, sunflower or water melon is grown during winter season using the pond water. Land Shaping (LS) combined with the Integrated Farming Systems Approach is one of the main factors for enhancing productivity in a sustainable way in the Sundarban.The Ramkrishna Mission Loka-Siksha Parishad (RKMLSP), Narendrapur works in 4 blocks in Sundarban where it has so far completed around 1,600 LS projects in small and marginal farmers’ fields in the Sunderbans area in which the low-lying flood-prone land (plots of 1 to 4 bighas) has been raised by excavating a pond, covering 20-25% area of the plot, at an appropriate position for rain water harvesting and using the excavated soil for making bunds and uplands and lifting the said pond water for irrigating the rabi crops.

responsibilities.executing_agent: Ramakrishna Mission Lokasiksha Parishad (RKMLSP)

evaluative_information.success_factors: stagnant water, inability to raise HYV crops, saline water, medium landholding
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: willingness to dig a pond in individual farmland
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: no regret: In a flood prone area such as Sundarbans this practice will help farmers cope and ensure higher economic returns
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: The Ramkrishna Mission Loka-Siksha Parishad (RKMLSP), Narendrapur in the outskirts of Kolkata has so far completed around 1,600 LS projects in small and marginal farmers’ fields in the Sunderbans area in which the low-lying flood-prone land (plots of 1 to 4 bighas) has been raised by excavating a pond, covering 20-25% area of the plot, at an appropriate position for rain water harvesting and using the excavated soil for making bunds and uplands and lifting the said pond water for irrigating the rabi crops. The pond is used besides irrigation for fish and duck rearing. A small part of the raised land would also accommodate a cattle shed for 3-4 cows and a small poultry-cum-duck near the farmer’s house for about 15-20 poultry birds and 10-15 ducks. The cattle dung and bird excreata are used for compost making along with crop residues and farm wastes; also most farmers produce vermicomposts for raising vegetables and other high value crops. The integration of crop farming with livestock usually cattle, duckery and poultry has resulted in a high level of synergy giving the farmers a 3-4 fold increase in income.

additional_information: In the last 15 years, RKM in collaboration with other organisations like Ford Foundation, German Agro Action, CAPART, has successfully developed more than 600 individual LS sites and motivated about 1000 families to develop LS for sustainable production and socio-economic development.

title: Learning about Adaptation in Eco Schools

overview.feedback: The aim of the Eco-School Climate Change project is to facilitate and empower schools as drivers of community action, learning and social change toward reducing and offsetting greenhouse gas emissions. This is being achieved by encouraging climate-friendly behaviour through lessons and action projects that link with the curriculum. In the process biodiversity conservation and healthy ecosystems are promoted as part of climate change mitigation and adaptation. The framework of the current WESSA/WWF Eco-Schools programme forms the basis through which this is achieved, as it has a well researched and peer reviewed process framework that fosters whole school learning and education for sustainable living. Although there is no requirement to expand on the number of schools in the six climate change nodes, the number of schools has increased in 2010 from 144 to 240 and this is growing in number in all nodes, in almost all cases. Specific measures include:39 lessons on the curicculum relating to climate change, development of a climate change cartoon and theme specific educational puzzle, vegetable gardens and wetland rehabilitation activities.The project is located in the following provinces of South Africa: Western Cape, Mpumalanga, Eastern Cape, Free State and KwaZulu-Natal.

responsibilities.initiating_agent: Wildlife & Environment Society of South Africa (WESSA), WWF South Africa
responsibilities.executing_agent: Wildlife & Environment Society of South Africa (WESSA), WWF South Africa
responsibilities.funding_source: Wildlands Conservation Trust and the Climate Change Action Partnership

evaluative_information.success_factors:
•Training of educators, teaching of learners (Capacity development)
•Supply of theme specific resource support learning materials to schools
evaluative_information.limiting_factors:
•Funding
•Lack of Integration into the national curriculum through the National Department of Education
•Limited support time through coordinators to school
•Limited conceptual depth and capacity of educators
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: • Yes as it teaches students to conserve their environment and contribute towards sustainable development through developing attitudes, lifestyles and values that are harmonious with the environment (understanding of interrelationships of eco-system services and resources)
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: Although quantitative values cannot effectively record the effective of impact, there are many qualitative assessments that have given a positive indication of the progress and impact being had in schools.

additional_information:
a) How has climate change information or climate science been considered in the design and implementation of the project?
Through teaching and learning in the classroom and action projects identified by schools. This has been in response to global concerns and developments but has been integrated into curricular learning through a cross-cutting approach supporting learning in the classroom. The resource materials that have been designed around climate change and related issues has been broadranging to show the complexity and implications of this issue, and how it impacts on every sphere of existence today and the future.

title: Legislation

overview.feedback: Climate change potentially threatens much of what may be broadly interpreted as legislated government service delivery or delegations (provision of water, transport, waste management, living environments) – within this legislated context little clarity exists on the legal framework of national, provincial and local government in terms of clear and actual roles and responsibilities in addressing climate change within this issue of service provision.  With the completion of a range of climate change risk assessments and an increase in knowledge of future vulnerabilities, local government must consider its own liability and governance in terms of its delegations in approving plans and developments. One of the key drivers for change in the future will be legal accountability and liability for future impacts on private property and commercial developments.  The City is often constrained in taking proactive action through layers of bureaucracy and legislation.  Does the urgency of climate change create a new policy environment that will allow faster more directed action that is not slowed through bureaucratic means?

title: Local Authority Partnerships

overview.feedback: Facilitate adaptation discussions between the five major coastal metro areas in South Africa with a view to collate, unpack and understand areas of common interest, concern and relevance with relation to adaptation.  From the common areas, to refine and identify key themes and issues that would represent a collective position by the metro’s on adaptation areas:                                           a.  where assistance by national government is needed,                                          b.  where a shift in national policy would facilitate improved or more effective resilience/adaptation at local level,                                           c.  where a change in national frameworks or funding mechanisms would enhance adaptation/resilience at local level,                                           d. where a change in legislation would promote/facilitate adaptation/resilience at local level. Identify and refine key areas that should form a basis for ongoing engagement and discussion between the local authorities as well as collectively with national government.

title: Mainstreaming climate change adaptation in irrigated agriculture project

overview.feedback: The objectives are to enhance adaptation to climate change in agriculture and irrigation water management practices through awareness-raising, institutional and capacity strengthening, and demonstration activities in the Huang-Huai-Hai Basin (3H Basin) in China. This aims to help mainstream climate change adaptation measures, techniques, and activities into the national Comprehensive Agricultural Development (CAD) Program which is China’s largest national investment program in irrigated agriculture. There are three components to the project. The first component is the identification and prioritization of adaptation options. The second component is the demonstration and implementation of adaptation measures. The purpose of this component is to introduce, demonstrate and implement the specific adaptation measures in selected demonstration areas, and adjust and integrate appropriate adaptation measures into the implementation of the Third Irrigated Agriculture Intensification Project (IAIL3), in order to reduce vulnerability to climate change in the 3H Basin. Finally, the third component is the mainstreaming adaptation into national CAD program and institutional strengthening. The component will aim at integrating and mainstreaming climate change adaptation into the national CAD program, including a series of capacity building, technical assistance, knowledge sharing, public awareness activities, and preparation of a national climate change adaptation plan for CAD by State Office of Comprehensive Agricultural Development (SOCAD), with the cooperation of Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS), the National Development and Reform Commission(NDRC) and Ministry of Finance (MOF) national climate change adaptation offices.

responsibilities.executing_agent: Ministry of Finance, State Office of Comprehensive Agricultural Development (SOCAD)
responsibilities.funding_source: World Bank GEF (Global Environment Facility) - SCCF (Special Climate Change Fund)

evaluative_information.success_factors: institutional and perhaps financial pre-conditions
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: Adaptation measures for agricultural development, such as the adjustment of crop structure, may be controversial initially
evaluative_information.synergies_to_mitigation: No synergy to the mitigation of climate change.
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: win-win option
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: The project seems to have reached good results up to now. Good government support and good cooperation with farmers (many trainings were organized with a significant participation of farmers).

additional_information:
The project is located in the whole Huang-Huai-Hai Basin in China: 2 counties in each of 6 provinces (Jiangsu, Anhui, Hebei, Shandong, Henan, Ningxia)

title: Maize initiative

overview.feedback: Maize is an important staple in Southern Africa. Droughts and poor soil often result in bad harvests or total harvest failure. The Seed Initiative for Maize in Southern Africa conducts research into drought-resistant varieties of maize which can generate bigger harvests than conventional varieties, even in less fertile soil, thus contributing to food security. At the same time, the project cooperates with government and private-sector players in the maize sector so as to foster production and the seed trade (also for small-scale producers).

title: Management of natural resources in the coastal zone

overview.feedback: The project aims at providing pilot solutions to solve the conflict between economic development and sustainable management of natural resources. In particular, shrimp production has led to rapid economic growth, and large areas are therefore being transformed into shrimp farms in Soc Trang coastal land. The ecological balance of these wetlands is endangered. It lead to the unsustainable exploitation of resources, hampering the protective function that mangrove forests have on coasts and detrimentally affecting the local population’s ability to earn income..The project objective is to protect and sustainably use the coastal wetlands of Soc Trang Province for the benefit of the local populationOne of the priority areas in this project is rehabilitation and manage of mangroves with emphasis on resilience to climate change which is part of the integrated management of the coastal zone.

responsibilities.initiating_agent: German Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development
responsibilities.executing_agent: Deutsche Gesellschaft für Technische Zusammenarbeit and People’s Committee of Soc Trang Province
responsibilities.funding_source: German Federal Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development

evaluative_information.success_factors: The participation of all local authorities and people in the project
evaluative_information.limiting_factors:
- The awareness of local people about natural resources and the linkage between natural resources management is quite low
- The lack of cooperation mechanism for integrating sustainable management and the use of natural resources, as well as overlapping competencies among various offices and economic interests (shrimp farms).
evaluative_information.synergies_to_mitigation: Yes, mangroves are plant communities established in coastal and estuarine areas influenced by the tide in tropical and subtropical zones. They provide important ecosystem services and goods that include sequestration of carbon dioxide
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: economic development
evaluative_information.project_evaluation:
The project is running and result archived so far are:
- Capacity development for counterpart staff and staff of collaborating local authorities has created the preconditions necessary for the acceptance and implementation of new and innovative concepts;
- The People’s Committee of Soc Trang Province is supporting the project with the implementation of the new concept of co-management and innovative approaches to mangrove rehabilitation, as well as the establishment of inter-sectoral steering committees for integrated coastal zone management at province, district and communal levels;
- All relevant stakeholders support the implementation of co-management in the pilot site of Au Tho B village. Although the pilot study has not been completed yet, local authorities, in collaboration with the district authorities, have started to extend the concept to the communal level

additional_information:
- The project approach are included (i) Different co-management methods allowing the stakeholders to learn how to reach agreements on the protection and sustainable use of coastal zone. (ii) Rehabilitation and manage of mangroves with emphasis on resilience to climate change as part of the integrated management of the coastal zone. (iii) Intermediaries such as staff from public authorities, women's organisations and communities take part in training courses on the management of the coastal zone. (iv) Development of the sustainable financing of ecosystem services provided by coastal wetlands. (v) Participatory environmental monitoring system.(vi) Establishment of a regional network for the coastal zone in the Mekong Delta.
- This is one of three GTZ projects related to adaptation to climate change in coastal areas in Vietnam. The project will generate synergies by using lessons learned and joint implementation of some activities in the Project "Conservation and Development of the Kien Giang Biosphere Reserve" that being implemented by GTZ in Vietnam.

title: Managing Escalating Wildfires

overview.feedback: Working on Fire is the South African Fire Management Programme, which is running very successfully, but there's a gap in addressing the increasing escalating hazardous effects of Climate Change on Wildfires  So this project is in place to develop and implement integrated disaster risk management strategies to address climate change-induced fire hazards.” The Project aims to play a catalytic role in bringing about a paradigm shift from conventional wildfire management approaches that are focused on reactive fire fighting, to a more proactive Integrated Fire Management (IFM) approach. This will serve to enhance the adaptive management capacity of the national/provincial/local government and local communities to cope with the increase wildfire risks associated with climate change.  The geographical area for this project is the Western Cape, parts of the Southern Cape, including Baviaanskloof and Tsitsikamma, because wildfires in this region has been escalating with increased intensity over the last few years. This areas falls within the Cape Floristic Region, which has been declared a hotspots with key endemic species and natural resources that needs adaptive management for long-term sustainability.

responsibilities.executing_agent: Working on Fire

evaluative_information.success_factors: It was importance that there were structures in place to take up the implementation of these  new projects. This body was found in the Fire Protections Assosications spread over the implementation area.
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: A limiting factor will be to find the right skill in local communities. But this will give the project the chance to build the capacity of local communities and leave them with specified skill that will benefit them forever.
evaluative_information.synergies_to_mitigation: In order to adapt, mitigation is going to be important as it will help us assess our decreasing ecological footprint.
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: It will contribute to training and educating communities and students on the importance of protecting our sensitive ecosystems.
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: The outcome should be a proactive approach to fighting Wildfires with skilled manpower in local areas who has access to key information necessary to manage their technologically enhanced stations. As this project is still in the planning phase we hope that it will have desired effects.

additional_information: Some of the Resources used; Guy Midgeley's Climate Change Scientific Research Data; Key information from the Initial National Communication (INC) 2003; CSRI on Weather Patterns and Fire Danger Rating Systems ; Department of Water Affairs and Forestry 2000 report on  - Review of the veld fires in the Western Cape 15-25 January 2000

title: Mangrove Forest Restoration in Andhra Pradesh

overview.feedback: The project was initiated to restore degraded mangroves and prevent further damage and entailed identifying degraded mangrove areas, floristic studies to determine the extent of damage and the species composition to help decide the species to be planted. Restoration works was being carried out by the forest department since 1991 but the technique of canal building to improve easy water flow was started after the intervention by MSSRF. Canals were designed in a fish bone pattern and a trapezoidal shape. The seedlings were planted at the mid level of the canal so that they recieve water at all times but do not submerge. This resulted in restoring 520 ha of mangroves by the Village Level Institution (Eco-development Committee) and Vana Samrakshana Samiti (VSS).

responsibilities.executing_agent: MSSRF, Eco-Development Committee (EDC) and Vana Samrakshana Samiti (VSS), Andhra Pradesh Forest Department

evaluative_information.success_factors: Local Institutions: Canal digging, planting and desilting, all these activities are carried out by community involvement
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: Financial (high initial cost)
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: social welfare (providing employment and also increasing fishery resources), environmental protection and conservation (buffer against climate extremes-coastal storms, tidal surges), reduced soil erosion
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: The project has successfully tested a process for restoring mangroves in multiple sites. 520 ha of area has been restored in 3 districts in the project. Capacity has been built of NGOs and labour. NGOs in the region who were trained  in mangrove restoration work have restored an additional area of 215 ha of degraded mangroves.  Villagers trained have become skilled in canal digging, planting and desilting can can further the cause of restoring 9442 ha of degraded mangrove forests (Eight village level Institutions).

additional_information: The species used for plantation were Avicennia marina, Avicennia officinalis and Excoecaria agallocha as these species can tolerate wide range of salinity. The members of the NGOs, namely Sravanthi, Action in Godavari area, Sangamithra Service Society and Coastal Community Development Program in Krishna, were trained in restoration techniques and in participatory approaches in community mobilization and mangrove management (increasing their income) because of the labour force required for such extensive work.

title: Mangrove plantation, Joint Forest Management and Revenue Sharing in Sundarban Reserve Forest

overview.feedback: The Forest Department undertakes Mangrove plantation in the reserve forest of the Sundarban Biosphere Reserve (SBR). The Mangroves are extremely important to the coastal ecosytstem as they act as soil binders and diffuse impacts of storms. They are a natural habitat for fish, prawns etc and support the fish and shrimp economy and are also habitat for the Royal Bengal Tiger and important for the biodiversity of the region. The WB Forest Department has issued Govt. Orders for formation of Forest Protection Committees (FPC) around the Reserved/ Protected Forests, and Eco-Development Committees (EDC) around the National Park and Sanctuaries of Sundarban region also. Till now, 52 FPCs and 14 EDCs have been registered. They get a 25% share of the entry fee receipts (Rs 10/day per person) from visitors to the SBR. After formation of FPCs/EDCs instances of felling, poaching, have reduced and tiger survival after village visits has increased. The user groups are involved in some of these plantations as well.

responsibilities.executing_agent: community, Forest Department

evaluative_information.success_factors: survival rate, suitable species, community support and involvement
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: inundation
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: win win
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: The FD does 1000 ha of plantations each year. Since 1989, 15000 ha of mangroves have been planted.

additional_information: The FD has promoted rainwater harvesting in the FPC villlages. Channels have been redug. There is need for long-term modelling of the bio-physical processes in the sundarbans that includes subsidence due to tectonic plate subsiding, accretion, dredging and deposited silt and hydrological processes in the delta.

title: Mangrove planting

overview.feedback: The mangroves planted by the Red Cross since 1994 protect 110 kilometers of the 3,000-kilometre sea dyke system that runs up and down Viet Nam’s coastline. They plant four different species, which reach a height of 1.5m after three years. The plants stabilized the dyke system and protect Viet Nam’s coastal inhabitants from the ravages of typhoons and storms and future sea level rise.The planning and protection of 12,000 hectares of mangroves has cost around US$ 1.1 million, but has helped reduce the cost of dyke maintenance by US$ 7.3 million per year.

responsibilities.executing_agent: Viet Nam Red Cross
responsibilities.funding_source: Viet Nam Red Cross,  Japanese Red Cross, Danish Red Cross

evaluative_information.success_factors: not specified
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: not specified
evaluative_information.synergies_to_mitigation: Yes, through carbon sequestration by the mangroves.
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: reduce the cost of dyke maintenance by US$ 7.3 million per year
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: In lives spared, one need only look to the dividend reaped during typhoon Wukong in October 2000. This typhoon pummeled three northern provinces, but left no damage to the dykes behind regenerated mangroves, and no deaths inland of the protected dykes. In the past, waves would breach the coastal dykes and flood the land of poor coastal families.

title: Mangrove Restoration at Lake Pulicat

overview.feedback: The mangrove restoration project at Lake Pulicat aims to improve the water quality of the lake to improve conditions for growth and multiplication of fish population and the overall goal of the project is to prevent over-fishing. Local communities planting mangroves which act as bio-filters, improving water quality by maintaining nutrient recovery, releasing excess nitrogen, deactivating phosphates, removing toxins such as heavy metals by adsorption and absorption. The restoration of mangroves  helps increase fish populations  helps maintain the economic activities of the farmers and also gives additional benefits by increasing biodiversity, carbon sequestration and acting as a buffer against coastal storms and cyclones, which will be more frequently through climate change.

responsibilities.executing_agent: Forest Department, CReNIO (Centre for Research on New International Economic Order)

title: Megacity Research Project ? Ho Chi Minh City - Integrative Urban and Environmental Planning Framework Adaptation to Climate Change

overview.feedback: The project is one of ten projects in megacities throughout the world developed by the Brandenburg University of Technology Cottbus (BTU) under the programme “Sustainable Development of the Megacities of Tomorrow – Energy and Climate Efficient Structures in Urban Growth Centres” (BMBF).The project focuses on mega-urban region of Ho Chi Minh City (HCMC) as one of Vietnamese regions most affected by climate change. The main project’s objective is to develop strategies for adapting urban land, urban structures and urban development concepts to climate changes and to minimize or avoid impacts of climate change in the context of the megacity-HCMC. It aims to increase the resilience and adaptive capacity of the urban system of HCMC.Two major topics constitute the project structure: Action Field 1 focuses on environmental research; Action Field 2 is concerned with urban development.

responsibilities.initiating_agent: German Federal Ministry of Education and Research
responsibilities.executing_agent: Brandenburg University of Technology Cottbus
responsibilities.funding_source: German Federal Ministry of Education and Research

evaluative_information.success_factors:
-In line with strategy orientation of the ‘National Target Programme to Respond to Climate Change’ (NTP) which issued by Government in 2008.
-Successful uptake of recommendations.
- The implementation of measures will be an outcome of scientific research and research will be undertaken on grounds of the implementation of measures.
evaluative_information.limiting_factors:
-Financial and human resource constrains of implementation of technological solutions/ measures.
-Insufficient of co-ordination mechanism for mainstreaming adaptation measures within local development planning.
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: The project outcomes will contribute in environmental conservation of Ho Chi Minh City
evaluative_information.project_evaluation:
The project is running and its expected outcomes objectives are:
- To compile flood hazard maps and climate function maps, grounding on GIS-based indicator mapping;
- To compile demand-oriented planning recommendation maps;
- To develop strategies and measures for climate change adaptation in Ho Chi Minh City
- To implement a planning study as a showcase for the adaptation of urban neighbourhoods;
- To develop and implement a Community Based Adaptation (CBA) Scheme to adapt low-income communities to climate change;
- To elaborate recommendations for institutional innovation in the Ho Chi Minh City Metropolitan Region to improve adaptive capacity;
- To support efforts regarding climate change adaptation and to integrate effective adaptation measures into urban planning in Ho Chi Minh City;
- To advance and disseminate climate change related knowledge, to inform decision makers and the general public about climate change risks;
- To increase capacity to implement necessary adaptation measures and to strengthen the resilience of the Ho Chi Minh City urban system.

additional_information:
-Two topics constitute the project structure: (i) the Action Field “Urban Environment” encompasses the work packages: Adaptation Planning Framework; Urban Flooding; Urban Climate; Urban Energy; Urban Transport. (ii) the Action Field “Urban Development” includes the four work packages: Precaution and Adaptation Strategies to Climate Change Impacts on the Regional and City Level; Integrative Planning Approach for New Energy and Climate-Efficient Neighborhoods; Livable City - Urban Regeneration and Community-Based Adaptation; Energy-Climate-Efficient Housing Typologies.
- A multi-layered typological approach to be utilized to assess the sustainability of urban settlement developments.
- With an interdisciplinary approach, the assessment criteria and methodology will be selected with the aim of assessing contents and objectives of the regional land-use planning system for their adequacy and ef?ciency in adaptation to climate change.
- One importance component of the project is climate science and how to create a shared interface between local knowledge and science.

title: Micro irrigation for Diversification of Agriculture

overview.feedback: The term “micro-irrigation” describes a family of irrigation systems that apply water through small devices. These devices deliver water onto the soil surface very near the plant or below the soil surface directly into the plant root zone. Topography of the State is highly variable comprising of lands having negligible slopes to slopes as high as 50 to 60% where crops are raised. For installation of micro-irrigation systems assistance to the extent of 80% of the project cost shall be provided to the beneficiaries as project share. The remaining 20% cost shall be borne by the beneficiaries. Under the project, 17310 micro-irrigation systems are proposed to be installed (17,262 sprinkler and 50 drip) and Command area of 20007 hectares would be covered under economical and efficient irrigation systems. Due to variation in altitude and topography, the soil types particularly texture and depth are highly variable. Objective of the project is to induce cultivation of cash crops i.e. vegetables in the proposed project area which at present are under cereals, pulses and oilseeds.

responsibilities.initiating_agent: Government of Himachal Pradesh, Department of Agriculture
responsibilities.executing_agent: Government of Himachal Pradesh, Department of Agriculture
responsibilities.funding_source: NABARD (National Bank for Agriculture and Rural Development)

evaluative_information.success_factors: financial assistance:Installation of these structures is expensive and thus for adoption by farmers they would have to be subsidized, quality material and followup support
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: High initial cost
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: economic development, water conservation, social welfare (employment)
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: The project monitoring and evaluation is to be conducted by the – State level committee constituted for the smooth implementation of the project. By the funding agency i.e. NABARD,  State level project implementation unit, D.N.O. (District Nodal Officer) and PIA (Project Implementation Agency, subject matter specialists) With the adoption of green house/poly house technology, farmers are growing high value cash crops like capsicum, tomato, cucumber, leafy vegetables etc. The productivity of crops is 4 to 10 times higher and quality of produce is better. The incidence of pests and diseases is very low with better management. The cost of production has reduced considerably and the production is of better quality.

additional_information: This project is one part of the "Pandit Deen Dyal Kisan Bagwan Samridhi Yojna" that has two main components: Production of cash crops through adoption of precision farming practices through poly house cultivation and Project on Diversification of Agriculture through Micro-Irrigation and other related infrastructure.

title: Micro irrigation technologies

overview.feedback: This study looks at micro-irrigation technologies, commonly in use in water scarce areas of developed countries which increase the ability to use water more efficiently in irrigated agriculture. These technologies can improve productivity; raise incomes through increased crop yields and outputs; and enhance food security of households. Low-cost systems include the Pepsee easy drip technology, bucket and drum kits, micro sprinklers, micro tube drip systems and others that have been designed by organizations such as the International Development Enterprises (IDE), along with innovative farmers. The more sophisticated, capital intensive systems are conventional drip and sprinkler systems.

responsibilities.executing_agent: NGO: IWMI

evaluative_information.success_factors: requires less capital when compared to conventional technologies, low level of skills required, suitable even for small land holdings
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: lack of access to groundwater, default on loan repayment, crop specificity of the available micro-irrigation technologies, lack of know-how, poor product quality and absence of adequate credit facilities
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: win win : reduces input cost while increasing productivity, and promotes sustainable agriculture
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: Increase in yields up to 100 , Saving in water by 50 – 60, Uniformity of water application. Precision Placement of Water and Fertilizers, Improvement in quality, Saving in fertilizers by 25 – 30 %, Saving in Electricity, labour and time, Undulating lands can be brought under cultivation, Salinity problems get minimized.

additional_information: Low-cost micro-irrigation technologies are largely promoted to poor farmers, hence their competitive pricing and compatibility with smallholder farming systems. Farmers can generally recover their initial investment capital between one and three years, although the extent of economic gains from investment depends on the type of crop. Subsidies and options for financing from organizations and government schemes like IDE, the Aga Khan Rural Support Programme (AKRSP) and the Gujarat state government in India canfurther increase the profitability of investing in microirrigation,which makes a crucial difference in adoption by poorer farmers.

title: Multiplying Best Practice in Adaptation to Climate Change

overview.feedback: “As a result of climate change impacts, the semiarid north of Brazil is threatened by increasing aridity. The rural, predominantly smallholder population relies mainly on traditional and highly inefficient irrigation technologies and depends greatly upon uncertain rainfall. The Federal Environment Agency (UBA) is coordinating a project of adaptation to climate change in Brazil, which is starting with a workshop in Rio de Janeiro for delegates from affected rural regions. The purpose of the project is to prepare the rural population to cope with increasing aridity. Tried and proven forms of local initiative for adapting to climate change will be disseminated and replicated by building networks. To this end, pilot projects on irrigation in the northeast of Brazil that are already under way will be expanded. In addition, support is being provided to establish a network of municipalities and organizations seeking to disseminate successful adaptation measures. In addition to training measures, a limited amount of technical equipment (such as pumps and irrigation equipment) is also being provided.The participatory approach enables the population in the affected regions to cope better with the impacts of climate change. It is envisaged that the results of the pilot projects will be taken up in regional development plans and other strategy papers and will also contribute to the debate on adaptation measures within the context of negotiations concerning the Framework Convention on Climate Change. Moreover, the project contributes to economic stabilization and to food and income security in the region.”

responsibilities.executing_agent: German Federal Environment Agency (Dessau), Centro Clima, Universidade Federal do Rio de Janeiro, Gesellschaft für Technische Zusammenarbeit (GTZ) GmbH, Brasilia Rede de Desenvolvimento Humano, Rio de Janeiro, German Development Service (DED)
responsibilities.funding_source: German Federal Ministry for the Environment, Nature Conservation and Nuclear Safety (BMU)

evaluative_information.success_factors: limited amount of technical equipment
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: not specified
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: Win-Win option; the project contributes to economic stabilization and to food and income security in the region.
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: “The UBA is supporting an agricultural irrigation project that already enjoys international recognition. A solar-powered water supply system is to be installed, and cultivation and sales of regional products are to be promoted. In the course of the project’s two-year duration, adaptation measures for other vulnerable regions in Brazil will be identified and communicated on location.”

additional_information: Based on experience gained by the project partners, further adaptation projects are to be selected and introduced in other areas, e.g. the Amazon. Local stakeholders and non-governmental organizations will be involved and vouch for the transfer to the local population. Besides setting up a regional and national communications network, the project is intended to support national policymakers in adapting to climate change.
