title: Municipal Climate Protection Programme (MCPP)

overview.feedback: The eThekwini Municipal Climate Protection Programme (MCPP) was initiated in 2004 as concern was increasing with regards to potential climate change impacts. The programme has been developed in a phased manner; Phase 1 focused on the assessment of local climate change impacts; Phase 2 focused on the development of an adaptation workstream with three focal areas of action: municipal level, community–level and urban management intervention. The Headline Climate Change Adaptation Strategy (HCCAS), was the fist of the municipal level interventions. This highlighted key interventions required by the municipality to adapt to climate change. Following the HCCAS of phase 2 it was recognised that sector specific adaptation plans needed to be developed in order to start mainstreaming adaptation planning into the municipality. To test this approach three pilot sectors, health, water and disaster management, where chosen, and sector specific adaptation needs identified. Work is also being pursued investigating the impacts of climate change on the city’s globally significant biodiversity and related open space system. Recognising that the resilience of local communities would also need to be increased, a parallel process of community – based adaptation was initiated, focused on livelihood analyses, food and water security issues and community reforestation projects. A third focal area has also been developed which focuses on a variety of urban management interventions, including: sea level rise modelling, a pilot green roof project and a variety of greening initiatives. The next phase of the project, phase 3, involves the development of a tool which will allow for the simulation, evaluation and comparison of strategic development in the city in the context of climate change, and Phase 4 will work towards mainstreaming climate change concerns into city planning and development.

responsibilities.initiating_agent: The Environmental  Planning and Climate Protection Department of the eThekwini Municipality
responsibilities.executing_agent: eThekwini Municipality
responsibilities.funding_source: eThekwini Municipality and various external donors

evaluative_information.success_factors: First of all, the complexity of impacts makes it difficult for the eThekwini Municipality to formulate appropriate adaptation interventions. Secondly, adequate institutional, human and financial resources, as well as political will, are critical for successful implementation of adaptation interventions in the Municipality.
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: The project has found that in order to deal with potential climate impacts some institutional restructuring of local government activities is required. At the same time, adaptation interventions should be implemented in a manner which embeds the current activities and processes in the day to day operations of the municipality. Various sectors within the municipality have different capacities and thus different abilities to integrate climate change adaptation into their activities. A limiting factor for the project is therefore the provision of adequate institutional, human and financial resources necessary for restructuring and for the mainstreaming of climate change adaptations.
evaluative_information.synergies_to_mitigation: Some of the projects that have been initiated under the MCPP act to reduce emissions, namely the Community reforestation project (carbon sequestration), Green Roof pilot project (natural cooling, thereby reducing the need for electrical cooling and the use of electricity) and 2010 FIFA Soccer World Cup (creating awareness around energy efficiency and influencing new developments, making them more energy efficient).
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: Focus on and prioritization of climate change adaptation can make the eThekwini Municipality climate smart, and thus more able to deal with climate impacts and projected climate changes. At the same time, the assessment of municipal sector activities and the work towards finding suitable adaptation interventions can also work to highlight shortcomings in municipal structures and activities, and thus trigger necessary improvements in the Municipality. What is more, the strengthening of institutional, human and financial resources necessary to integrate climate change adaptation into municipal structures and activities also work to strengthen the general capacity of the Municipality. Positive side-effects can also be seen more directly in for example the socio-economic and catchment management benefits of the community reforestation projects.
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: The first two phases of the project have provided a good insight into local climate impacts, and have brought about an understanding of the necessity of developing sector specific adaptation plans. The last two phases are already well advanced, but at a point where it is still too early to evaluate the full outcome. The initiation of several community projects show that the MCPP goes beyond report writing and top down analysis.

additional_information: Climate science has been the basis for all the adaptation projects.

title: Nagaland Environment Protection and Economic Development

overview.feedback: Nagaland Environment Protection and Economic Development (NEPED) Project was initiated to find solutions to the practice of shifting cultivation by altering the practice to make it more sustainable rather than try to stop it. To make the practice more sustainable a tree component (agro-forestry) was included with annual crops along with enriched fallow management systems (leaving stumps of Alnus nepalensis, a nitrogen fixing tree, to enhance regeneration and soil fertility) with soil erosion control measures. This helped in soil moisture and nutrient retention, reduction in erosion and diversifying the income base of tribals.

responsibilities.executing_agent: Government: Project Operation Unit (State level), Local NGOs (village level)
responsibilities.funding_source: Government of India and India Canada Environment Facility (ICEF)

evaluative_information.success_factors: awareness: Making the communities aware about the negative impacts of conventional shifting cultivation will make adoption of the altered way of shifting cultivation easy
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: responsiveness of the communities to adopt to the changed practices, returns: If the returns to the communities are lower than that by the conventional process then the community will not adopt the practice
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: economic returns from agroforestry, environmental benefits by reduced use of Jhum, social welfare
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: The project was surveyed in the year 1999 when it was found that the replication of the model in the villages is 1:6, i.e there was a six times increase in the area under use of the practice covering a total area of about 33,000 ha from an initial 5500ha. A total of 7.8 million trees were planted. The project success made it possible to go into the second phase for empowerment and economic development. The project success can be attributed to the wide scale acceptance of alternate jhum, continuation of the project from the first phase focusing on environment protection to the second phase focusing on economic empowerment (looks at activities related to additional farming systems over and above the subsistence jhum farming and is more market oriented) and the third one focusing on energy empowerment (to meet the need for energy, upscale power generation to augment energy requirements which is cheap, green and clean .

additional_information: NEPED has been implemented in two phases and the third one is currently being implemented. In the first two phases the project activities were carried out by the funds made available by ICEF, in the third phase NEPED has been registered as an autonomous institution catering to plantations, micro-credits and several other developmental activities to make it independent of external funding.

title: National Mission for Green India

overview.feedback: The National Mission for a Green India is one of the eight Missions under the National Action Plan on Climate Change (NAPCC), recognizes that climate change phenomena will affect and alter the distribution, type and quality of natural resources of the country and the associated livelihoods of the people. To reduce the negative impacts of climate change the forestry sector will be promoted and enhanced because of its environmental amelioration through climate mitigation, food security, water security, biodiversity conservation and livelihood security of forest dependant communities. The activties such as afforestation, reforestation on open, degraded urban and peri-urban forest lands, restoration of mangroves and wetlands, adoption of agroforestry in fallow and degraded agricultural lands, enhancing biomass/NTFP (Non timber forest products) based livelihood will be taken up.

title: National strategy for agriculture, ecosystems and water resources

overview.feedback: The final product of the project is a National Adaptation Strategy containing detailed proposals and criteria for the authorities on adaptation to climate change and the specific measures which must now be implemented. Some of the measures the Strategy recommends are appointment of an interministerial National Climate Council to improve the coordination of measures for adaptation to climate change; promotion of interdisciplinary climate research and development of appropriate training programmes; broader-based collection of climate and water resource data to improve the quality of forecasting; better enforcement of existing water and agricultural ordinances; introduction of insurance services for climate-related damage in agriculture, with a particular focus on small farmers; assistance with the restructuring of farms that are affected by climate change; and development of a climate label for agricultural products which are particularly resilient to the impacts of climate change.

title: Natural Resource Management Program (ProGRN)

overview.feedback: The Natural Resources Management Program (ProGRN) aims for the sustainable use of natural resources and the conservation of biodiversity by the local people and the government, taking into account the impacts of climate change. The program is based on experiences and results of previous interventions by the German cooperation in the environmental sector and seeks primarily to strengthen the capacity of key actors at national, regional and local level. The program focuses on three priority topics: (1) Environmental policy and climate, (2) decentralized management of natural resources and (3) Conservation of marine and coastal biodiversity.

title: Netherlands Integrated Coastal Zone Management (ICZM)

overview.feedback: The project focused on the goal of advising the Vietnamese Government in planning and development of the Vietnamese coastal zone, its communities and its resources in a sustainable way, for which ICZM is introduced and accepted as the suitable and effective approach. More particularly, the Project aimed to provide capacity, technical and operational support for the first 3 years of a desired longer term Vietnam ICZM Programme.  The work was conducted in Hanoi and in three pilot provinces including Nam Dinh (north), Thua Thien – Hue (central) and Ba ria – Vung tau (south) with participation of various national relevant ministries and agencies as well as provincial authorities.The Project had main objectives: • Assist in establishing the required institutional structures and functional linkages between provincial, national and international institutions and stimulate dialogue and exchange of information on Coastal Zone Management across ministerial, institutional and provincial boundaries;• Produce a practical guide, raise the awareness and enhance the capabilities of relevant decision takers and professional staff at national and provincial levels to prepare, review, approve and implement Strategy and Action Plans for ICZM• Initiate short term application of ICZM in three provinces through practical problem solving approaches;• Identify, provide and co-ordinate techniques, data and tools and train suitable staff and personnel for ICZM in Vietnam.

responsibilities.initiating_agent: Ministry of Natural Resource and Environment (MONRE), the Royal Netherlands Embassy (RNE) in Hanoi
responsibilities.executing_agent: Royal Haskoning, DHV Consultants, WL|Delft Hydraulics and Vietnam Environment Protection Agency of MONRE

evaluative_information.success_factors:
-The active participation of stakeholders.
-Engaging local and scientific knowledge.
-The implementation has to be done by governmental bodies and stakeholders in the coastal zone sectors
evaluative_information.limiting_factors:
Difficult to identify National level Authority to provide the integrated process ICZM to Socio-Economic Development Planning
-Insufficient of Management and Institutional capacities in the Coastal zones.
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: none
evaluative_information.project_evaluation:
- Inventoried projects and plans relating ICZM activities.
- Three case studies for three provinces were completed: (i) Thua Thien-Hue province – Lagoon management to prevent flood impacts, overfishing and water quality problems; (ii) Ba Ria Vung Tau province – Management of planning conflicting pressures of tourism and industrial developments plus coastal erosion; (iii) Nam Dinh province – Sea dike erosion threatens coastal villages.
Three studies contributed on producing a “Integrated Coastal Zone Management Strategy and Action Plan-ICZM SAP” at three provinces. One of the ICZM SAP for Thua Thien Hue has been approved by Province People Committee. Two others has been drafted.
- A training programme has provided that focused on introduction of ICZM principles, tools and techniques. It is conducted at national and provincial level.
-Research findings were communicated at stakeholder workshops.

additional_information: The project design and implementations is based on the findings of the Coastal Zone Vulnerability Assessment Project completed and used ICZM methods and techniques to further introduce and develop ICZM  which support the formulation of a national ICZM policy.

title: North Eastern Region Community Resource Management Project for Upland Areas

overview.feedback: NERCORMP is a livelihood and rural development project initiated to improve the livelihood of the communities by setting up community based Institutions (CBIs) at the grassroots level called – Natural Resources Management Groups (NaRM-Gs) and Self Help Groups (SHG) to  provide resilience to local communities by diversifying and increasing income levels, enhancing sustainable use of resources through improving village infrastructure, shifting cultivation practices, biodiversity conservation, grants for enterprise development. It has benefited people by increasing drinking water facility, increasing crop production, increased Non Timber Forest Product (NTFP) collection, etc.

responsibilities.executing_agent: North Eastern Region Community Resource Management Society and partner NGOs
responsibilities.funding_source: International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD), North Eastern Council, Ministry of DoNER

evaluative_information.success_factors: Institutional:for proper functioning of all the activities; Financial:initial cost for enterprise development
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: community participation, capacity and institution building (without community mobilisation and capacity building the project would not be effective)
evaluative_information.synergies_to_mitigation: reduced carbon emissions (abandonment of shifting cultivation practice)
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: No-regret: economic development (increase in income and agricultural practices), environmental benefits (reduced practice of shifting cultivation)
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: An evaluation of the Project was carried out by the Office of Evaluation of the IFAD in 2005 concluding that the Project’s overall impact on poverty deserved a ranking of 5 out of a maximum 6. A wealth ranking exercise conducted by the Project at the completion (PCR) showed that, out of the 86 per cent of the participating households who were below the poverty line at the commencement of the Project, only 18 per cent continued in poverty and the rest 68 per cent had moved up. Jointly, Ministry of Development of North Eastern Region, through the Department of Economic Affairs (DEA) of Government of India approached the World Bank to replicate the ‘IFAD model’ in all the 8 NER states. A post project sustainability evaluation has been recommended. An endline evaluation was conducted in May, in 2008 The review after project completion states that the project covered 860 villages against the proposed 1000 villages.The project has formed 1012 NaRM-Gs, 3168 SHGs, 103 Narm-g Cluster Associations and 103 SHG Federations. Socio-economically the number of households having easy access to water increased by 42%, abandonment of jhum by 15% of the households, increase in other cultivation practices such as terrace, orchard and home garden/vegetable cultivation and an increase in NTFP collection (31%), the area under plantation increased by 2716.37 ha. The project resulted in biodiversity and forest conservation of 1835.89 km square area. The increase in overall household income as per base line and endline survey for the six districts was 66%.

additional_information: In the year 2009 a proposal for expansion of the project to the entire North Eastern region was proposed (NERCORMP-II)

title: NREGA (Soil and Water Conservation)

overview.feedback: The Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee Act (MG-NREGA)  provides a employment based safety net on demand in all rural districts of the country. The scheme operates by giving the families of the rural communties a job card that makes them eligible to work. Each rural family is eligible for a maximum of hundred days of wage employment, annually in their own panchayat. Under the  scheme soil and water conservation works are carried out by the community including ditch-cum-bund fencing, staggered trenches, forest plantation and V-ditch construction. This work benefits the community by increasing water retention capacity, fodder availability and conserving soil.  With frequent and extensive droughts – Rajasthan is a major utiliser of this program.

responsibilities.executing_agent: Rural Development and Panchayati Raj Department
responsibilities.funding_source: Government of India, some share from state government

evaluative_information.success_factors: Institutional (For effective implementation of the scheme it is essential to have pre-established rules and guidelines (MNREGA, 2005))
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: financial status of the rural community (If the village community is not poor and have a secure and sufficient flow of income they would not take up the work. )
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: no-regret (It is a source of income for the people along with other benefits and would be helpful even in the absence of anthropogenic climate change impacts)
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: A study conducted by Institute of Development Studies has evaluated NREGA in Rajasthan giving the following results and conclusion. There has been an increase in employment especially to women members of the society, reduced migration, reduced incidence of debt, improved environmental conditions, reduced erosion, increased agricultural production. In Jhalawar the water level increased upto 10-15%. The problems of administration at different levels, delayed payment of wages, lack of technical assistance for field work improvisation still exist. There is a need for regular monitoring of projects. People’s capacity for implementation of project has to be build up, greater responsibility to the panchayats with regard to fiscal disbursement of wages at the village level.

additional_information: According to the study conducted by Institute of Development Studies in the districts of Dungarpur, Jhalawar, Banswara, Jalore and Karauli majority of the schemes under NREGA were for drought proofing and water harvesting and thus only the soil and water conservation scheme has been focussed on in this description.

title: NTFP (Non Timber Forest Products) Enterprises

overview.feedback: NTFPs constitute an important part of the livelihood of the poor in some of the most backward and tribal regions of Orissa. The work undertaken by Vasundhara involves advocating local primary gatherers’ rights over the products and their markets and they have also set up a Community Enterprise Revolving Fund (CERF). NTFP cooperatives are established to improve the negotiating capacity of collectors, reduce imperfections in the market, so that a larger share of the benefit is accrued by the poor. At present, there are 35 women’s primary cooperatives which have networked to form two unions, which are secondary level cooperatives.

responsibilities.executing_agent: Vasundhra

evaluative_information.success_factors: Institutional and policy support (Odisha Self-help Cooperative Act 2001) for easy formation of cooperatives, access to finance
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: community participation, hard to sustain over time
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: economic benefits, social benefits
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: The project intervention has shown 42-54% incremental gains to the members (economic  gains); members increased by 80%, number of cooperatives has increased to 38 (2010). There has also been an increase in the influx of the female members in the cooperatives particularly from the Tribals in the region. Success of the cooperatives in the Kuchinda, Bamra and Jamankira blocks of Sambalpur district, Tilaibani and Barkote block of Deogarh district and Pallahara block of Angul districts led to the demand in other areas of Koraput,Sundargarh(Lahunipada)and Phulbani.

additional_information:
For the project to have greater success it is necessary to integrate the following; (1) Skill Up-gradation,
(2) Development and extension of Appropriate Technology for NTFP processing,
(3) Compilation and Dissemination of Market Information,
(4) Finding alternatives for better and more profitable uses of NTFPs'
(5) There needs to be shift in focus from timber to NTFP, and this shift needs to be supported by research in the direction of NTFP based forest management systems.

title: Pacific Mangroves Initiative (PMI)

overview.feedback: 'Pacific islanders are considered to be among the people most vulnerable to climate change and climate variability. Conserving mangroves and associated habitats is regarded as a key natural adaptation strategy and also serves to mitigate climate change.The conservation and restoration of these habitats thus has both national and local dimensions. Better legislation and policy, improved knowledge and information about the anticipated impacts of climate change as well as improved capacities of local communities for wetland management have been identified as priority needs by the Pacific Island Countries.The objective of this project is to increase the resilience of the people of the Pacific Islands to climate change and improve their livelihoods. To this end, data will be collected and analyzed in order to enhance the national baseline information feeding into climate change scenarios. National and local policies and tools for the management and restoration of mangroves and associated ecosystems will be reviewed or developed in each country. Specific mangrove management measures will be applied in selected pilot sites. A comprehensive awareness raising and capacity development programme will complement the activities.'

responsibilities.executing_agent: The International Union for the Conservation of Nature (IUCN), Institute of Applied Science at the University of the South Pacific (USP), Secretariat for the Pacific Regional Environmental Programme (SPREP), Worldfish Solomon Islands
responsibilities.funding_source: German Federal Ministry for the Environment, Nature Conservation and Nuclear Safety (BMU)

evaluative_information.success_factors: planting the right species is very important
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: not specified
evaluative_information.synergies_to_mitigation: Yes, through carbon sequestration by the mangroves.
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: Win-Win option, if the project is successful it will furthermore reduce poverty and rural-uban mitigation.
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: "The implementation is still ongoing, but the project will enhance the resilience of communities and improve and sustain their livelihoods by conserving and restoring mangroves and associated wetlands. In-country capacity to engage in evidence-based adaptive management will be increased. Broader effects will include a reduction in rural-urban migration, a boost in rural employment and poverty reduction."

additional_information:
"Mangroves throughout the whole Pacific are being degraded or destroyed due to their use as rubbish dumps, overharvesting, reclamation to make way for tourist resorts, urban development, housing, and even due to the proliferation of squatter or informal settlements in the ‘no-mans’ mangrove areas.
So other project locations are Vanuatu, Solomon Islands, Samoa and Tonga."

title: Package of Organic Practices for Arecanut, Ginger, Large Cardamom, Passion fruit and Pineapple

overview.feedback: Horticultural crops like pineapple, passion fruit, large cardamom, arecanut and ginger have been promoted in North Eastern states of India to stabilize cultivation in shifting cultivation areas. These are traditionally organic practices and the study documents the organic practices – crop growing methods, input supplies and harvesting procedure, and can help with certification, thus helping maintain them as organic. The crops have been selected based on the knowledge of cultivation and farming, the economic returns, nutritional value and also because these crops are being promoted for the rehabilitation and resettlement of shifting cultivators as they can address the livelihood and food security needs of the people. Organic agriculture systems enhance biological diversity, increase soil biological activity, maintain long term soil fertility and recycle wastes of animal and plant origin thus minimizing the use of non-renewable resources. They also improve soil moisture retention. All these characteristics of organic practices in horticultural crops will give sustained production with minimum inputs thus reducing the need for shifting cultivation for livelihood. Because the organic agricultural systems are more diverse they have greater flexibility to cope with adverse effects of climate change leading to higher economic and ecological stability and also because they have low input costs, the risk of partial or total crop failure will be lowered.

responsibilities.initiating_agent: NERCORMP (North Eastern Region Community Resource Management Project)
responsibilities.executing_agent: NERCORMP
responsibilities.funding_source: FAO (Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations), New Delhi

evaluative_information.limiting_factors: None
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: it improves social, economic and environmental benefits
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: not specified

title: Pani Panchayats (Water Council)

overview.feedback: Pani Panchayats are councils set up for management and distribution of water resources equitable in Maharashtra. They have been set up by Vilasrao Salunkhe and the Gram Gaurav Pratisthan Trust in order to address the issues of water scarcity in drought prone Maharashtra. Pani Panchayats have worked out technological and social innovations that help repair and restore degraded watersheds (thereby increasing water harvests), and by guaranteeing each family within the community an equal share of the water harvested, meets goals of equity as well. Every family member is typically allowed water for cultivation at the rate of half an acre per head subject to a maximum of 2.5 acres per family. In other words 1000 m3 of water per head per year subject to maximum 5000m3 per family per year.

responsibilities.executing_agent: Individual and Gram Gourav Pratisthan Trust
responsibilities.funding_source: State government line departments and other sources

evaluative_information.success_factors: guaranteeing water share to each farmer, soil conservation, water harvesting
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: social conflicts, subsidy, electricity supply, availability of land
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: win win: In both drought and non drought years assured irrigation and access to water help farmers to cope
evaluative_information.project_evaluation:
Barren lands that had produced little or no food were gradually producing one good seasonal crop, which helped farmers survive the year with dignity. In some areas, as water availability increased, farmers could go on for two crops. The 50-odd schemes co-sponsored by the GGP eventually enabled 3,000 acres to be brought under protective irrigation, benefitting a population of some 10,000 people from 1,500 families. The availability of water made possible through conservation schemes and percolation tanks meant that drinking water for the village population was accessible and close at hand and villagers, women especially, did not have to trudge across long distances for water in the hot sun any longer.

Out of the 30 odd water councils set up in Maharshtra, few of them are still functioning and have expanded their work to lift irrigation in some tribal districts in Maharashtra.

additional_information: Several of the principles behind the organisation of the Pani Panchayat ought to be made part of public policy. First, the principle that people should have equal shares in common resources, if adopted, would revolutionise society in far-reaching ways. Today, a landless person in the village is seen as a person who has no right to resources just because he has no land. Because of this, he often also does not have political power since it is assumed he is poor and therefore his views need not be taken into account when decisions concerning his survival or that of the community are being made.

title: Participatory learning and community adaptation to climate change for food insecurity

overview.feedback: The project aims to create an integrated and participatory learning capability and community adaptation strategies to climate change to reduce food insecurity in three communities in the municipality of Ancoraimes. It aims at generating an evaluation methodology on local damages, at revaluing the use of local or traditional knowledge of bio-indicators in agricultural and livestock production, and to scientifically bolster this information with data gathered in a local meteorological station. With this data, local decisions and agreements will be reached. The productive diversification will enable the families to have a more diverse alimentation, to conserve and sustainably manage soils through a system of integrated management of crops (MIC), using techniques such as rotation of crops, incorporation of solid and liquid fertilizers, handling of covers (alive and dead), all of this is harmony with agroforestry systems. Practices inspired in individual and communal experiences will be implemented, and results will be diffused through consciousness-raising sessions, peer to peer training among farmers and “learning by doing”, fairs and sharing of experiences.

responsibilities.executing_agent: Plan Internacional Inc.

evaluative_information.success_factors: Local strategies and biomarkers to manage communities should be compared with systematic information to anticipate likely damage to production systems, events exacerbated by climate change.
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: Not have sufficient financial resources.
evaluative_information.synergies_to_mitigation: Through the incorporation of agroforestry systems in integrated management and reforestation in degraded areas
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: No regret
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: The communities are able to manage local strategies and biomarkers compared with systematic information to anticipate likely damage to production systems events exacerbated by climate change. Families diversify agricultural production through the use of varieties and species that are adapted to local climatic conditions and practices of Integrated Crop Management (ICM) and agroforestry systems are applied. Children, adolescents and their families improve their knowledge and understanding on Adaptation to Climate Change, Resilience and Climate Risk.

title: Participatory modelling for assessment of climate change impacts on water resources

overview.feedback: The project aims to increase understanding and produce more relevant information for planning and adaptation to climate variability and change in relation to water resources through a participatory process. The project will adapt a catchment model after stakeholder requirements, use high-resolution regional climate change scenarios, assess the impact of participatory modelling on stakeholders’ perceptions of climate change related to water resources, explore how to increase stakeholder confidence and twin to a participatory modelling project in Sweden to assess similarities and differences. Results of the project will illuminate how stakeholder participation can be used in order to make climate change studies more relevant and useful to the local needs in developing countries. Co-operation will be in the form of exchange of personnel, joint planning and implementation of stakeholder interviews and workshops, sharing of experiences regarding climatological and hydrological modelling and stakeholder participation in the two HELP basins.

responsibilities.executing_agent: University of KwaZulu-Natal (School of Bioresources Engineering and Environmental Hydrology) and Swedish Meteorological and Hydrological Institute (FoUh Research Department – Hydrology)

This awareness can potentially lead to better informed decisions which in the context of the participants could lead to optimized environmental conservation, small farmers further economic development, community development.

title: Participatory Varietal Selection and Promotion (PVSP)

overview.feedback: The PVSP programme aims at introduction and validation of Participatory Varietal Selection and Promotion methodology for crop varieties. A pilot project was undertaken in selected districts in Bihar to enhance livelihoods condition through productivity enhancement and to establish farmers’ rights especially, enabling the farmers from resource poor areas in exerting their choice in selection of seeds and technologies that best suits their area. The main crop chosen was moong – grown in the summer months in between wheat and rice. Based on farmer preferences four new varieties of moong were tested through a process of mother and baby plots.  The primary focus is testing & validating PVSP through farmers’ participation and dissemination of the same in nearby villages about the technology as well as the varieties tested and ultimately, developing a varietal portfolio of that area.  The new varieties led to to 200-300% increase in yield.

responsibilities.executing_agent: NGO:ASA
responsibilities.funding_source: Govt.: Bihar Rural Livelihood Promotion Society (BRLPS

evaluative_information.success_factors: traditional growers of moong seed (familiar with crop) , minimum landholding of 400 sq mtrs, access to irrigation (essential at sowing time), member of SHG, small/medium farmers, better results in uplands which have better drainage, and if farmers are able to sow the seed in time which allows harvesting of moong pods 3-5 times before the monsoon
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: ability to rent pumps for irrigating and timely sowing, untimely monsoon, training network, availability of improved seed varieties
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: No regret: Increased productivity, taste, texture of crops leading to enhanced income
evaluative_information.project_evaluation:
In Bihar the World Bank funded Bihar Rural Livelihood Project (BRLP) is implementing PVS in three districts with technical support by ASA. In the initial phase trials were done with 4 new varieties of moong seed – leading to yields of 10-17 q/ha, as opposed to 2-5 q/ha with the local seeds. It plans to reach more than 48000 farmer households through PVS processes during 2008-2011, of which about 8000 have been covered already.
http://www.researchintouse.com/resources/riu09impact5india-crop.pdf

additional_information: Training camps helped orient farmers. Village resource persons were appointed by ASA during the entire pilot phase to oversee the implementation for the PVSP program

title: Pastoral Risk Management

overview.feedback: The project objective was to reduce the regular animal losses of pastoral herders in Qinghai due to recurrent natural disasters, and to build up their own capacities to prevent damage from natural calamities. The project also contributed to the overall improvement of herders’future livelihoods, reduced environmental degradation and an increased capacity for risk prevention and management at local and provincial levels.Immediate objectives were:• To develop a comprehensive pastoral risk management strategy, including annual risk management contingency plans for two counties in Qinghai Province as pilot areas for further replication;• To develop and field test in selected villages, together with herders, innovative risk management techniques and improved livestock production options to improve rational utilization of the family-based ranches so as to reduce losses when disasters occur. Some specific outputs were to develop annual over-winter risks management plans for the pilot villages and counties and consolidate them into a pastoral risk management agenda for Qinghai Province; to improved winter preparation and risk prevention capacities within pilot villages through institutionalized and implemented: A: Rangeland improvement measures, B: Increased forage production and storage in herders’ households, C: Methods and mechanisms developed for adjustment of herd and flock structures before winter; to develop a risk warning system for herders; to organise a training programme to increase stakeholder capabilities and skills in risk prevention and management.

responsibilities.executing_agent: FAO, Rural Institutions and Participation Service Ministry of Agriculture (MOA) Department of Agriculture and Animal Husbandry (DAAH), Qinghai

title: Pernambuco Sustainable Water

overview.feedback: The development objective of the Sustainable Water Project is to improve sustainable water supply and sanitation services for the population residing in the Capibaribe river basin. This will result in a reduction in the percentage of served population subject to water rationing in the area and a reduction of pollution load discharged by the municipalities targeted by the project’s wastewater investments. This program focuses on four lines of action, as follows: (a) Consolidation and strengthening of the state’s institutional framework to adequately manage water resources; (b) Optimization of existing water infrastructure and increasing operational and financial efficiency of water supply and sanitation services; (c) Investment in expanding water supply and sanitation service coverage in urban areas; and (d) Designing and implementing adequate water and sanitation programs in rural communities and small towns using adequate technologies, financing and management frameworks.

title: Piloting Climate Change Adaptation to Protect Human Health

overview.feedback: The objective of this global project on public health adaptation to climate change is to “increase adaptive capacity of national health system institutions, including field practitioners, to respond to climate-sensitive health risks”. This will contribute to the broader goal of ensuring that “Health sectors are able to cope with health risks resulting from climate change, including variability”.The project in China aims at promoting an integrated strategy to improve adaptation to climate change, with a focus on preventing increasing morbidity and mortality during heatwaves.The main objective is to strengthen the national capacity to respond to the increased health risks due to heatwaves in China.  It will focus on reducing the impacts of climate change on cerebro-cardiovascular diseases in the project regions through implementation of heatwave forecasting and early warning systems designed to protect human health.

responsibilities.initiating_agent: Environmental Health and Related Product Safety, China CDC, and the World Health Organization (WHO)

title: Polyhouses for Diversification of Agriculture

overview.feedback: The polyhouses are protective shades constructed with the help of ultraviolet plastic sheets. The structure is prepared with the bamboos or iron pipes. Iron pipe structure is costly but more durable than bamboo.The size of polyhouse may differ depending on the necessity. The direction of polyhouse is always East to West, so that the maximum sunshine is available. The house should not be constructed in shade. The polyhouses are kept cold or hot depending upon the season.Crops growing under the polyhouse are safe from unfavourable environment and hailstorm, heavy rains or scorching sunshine, etc. The humidity of polyhouse is not adversely affected by evaporation resulting in less requirement of water. In limited area of polyhouse, insects and pests control is also easy and less expensive.By adopting the modern technology of polyhouse, the difference in the demand and supply of off-season vegetables and fruits etc. can be minimised. This facilitates in maintaining the quality of the product also.

responsibilities.initiating_agent: Government of Himachal Pradesh, Department of Agriculture
responsibilities.executing_agent: Government of Himachal Pradesh, Department of Agriculture
responsibilities.funding_source: NABARD (National Bank for Agriculture and Rural Development)

evaluative_information.success_factors: financial assistance:Installation of these structures is expensive and thus for adoption by farmers they would have to be subsidized, quality material and followup support
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: High initial cost
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: economic development, water conservation, social welfare (employment)
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: The project monitoring and evaluation is to be conducted by the – State level committee constituted for the smooth implementation of the project. By the funding agency i.e. NABARD,  State level project implementation unit, D.N.O. (District Nodal Officer) and PIA (Project Implementation Agency, subject matter specialists) With the adoption of green house/poly house technology, farmers are growing high value cash crops like capsicum, tomato, cucumber, leafy vegetables etc. The productivity of crops is 4 to 10 times higher and quality of produce is better. The incidence of pests and diseases is very low with better management. The cost of production has reduced considerably and the production is of better quality.

additional_information: This project is one part of the "Pandit Deen Dyal Kisan Bagwan Samridhi Yojna" that has two main components: Production of cash crops through adoption of precision farming practices through poly house cultivation and Project on Diversification of Agriculture through Micro-Irrigation and other related infrastructure.

title: Preserving Biodiversity in the Nyungwe Forest (APRECO)

overview.feedback: The project is transforming agricultural land into agroforestry systems on at least 5000 ha along the border zone of the Nyungwe forest, East-Africa’s largest montane rain forest. Farmers, local authorities and key stakeholders are educated about agroforestry methods. Seedlings of well adapted tree and shrub species are produced and planted, applying a participatory approach.The transformation into agroforestry systems will reduce soil erosion and soil degradation and improve soil fertility, increase resilience and productivity of local farming systems and enhance their adaptation capacity to impacts of climate change. Furthermore, agroforestry contributes to additional carbon sequestration in tree biomass and soil, increases the availability of energy from renewable sources (firewood) and provides timber for farm income diversification. Finally, the Nyungwe forest with its exceptional biodiversity, its crucial function as carbon sink and its importance for the regional climate (evapotranspiration, small water cycle) can be preserved.

responsibilities.initiating_agent: University of Koblenz-Landau, Institut für Integrierte Naturwisssenschaften, Campus Koblenz, Germany
responsibilities.executing_agent: Verein zur Förderung nachhaltiger Entwicklung in Ruanda e.V. / Association for the Promotion of Sustainable Development in Ruanda
responsibilities.funding_source: German Federal Ministry for the Environment, Nature Conservation and Nuclear Safety (BMU) in the framework of the International Climate Initiative (ICI)

evaluative_information.success_factors:
- General acceptance towards a change of the agricultural production system on farmer level and therefore, high adoption rates
- support and acceptance from authorities on different political levels, good cooperation with local partners
- Production of high quality tree seedlings and technical correct planting
- Sufficient infrastructure to access the target area
evaluative_information.limiting_factors:
- Though assumed to be unlikely, political instability would endanger the implementation of the project
- Strong attitudes of targeted farmers towards the cultivation of fodder grasses (Pennisetum), which cause a high competition to the planted trees and impede the establishment of leguminous hedgerow shrubs and require increased sensitisation efforts
- Environmental conditions (very poor and acidic soils) make the establishment of trees difficult and extreme weather events (e.g. extreme rain or droughts) would endanger the measures
- Difficult recruitment of suitable staff, who is willing to work in a remote area
evaluative_information.synergies_to_mitigation: There will be a sequestration of carbon in the standing biomass of the trees planted. Furthermore, there is no more need to cut trees in the National Parc (Nyungwe forest) as agroforestry trees will provide fuelwood (renewable energy resource).
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: The project is at the same time one of the largest employers in the project area. The provision of additional cash income to the rural population increases their economic capacity and may have positive effects such as increased school attendance (school fees can be paid), improvements on housing and living conditions, better utilisation of health care facilities or even increased savings.
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: At the current point in time a positive prospect regarding the achievement of the outcome can be given due to a high degree of acceptance and appreciation of the project in the region and the high number of trees that have already been planted. However, the positive effects resulting from the shift towards agroforestry on farm level can only fully be evaluated and assed after a longer period of time.

title: Program for the Strengthening of National Capacities to Manage the Impact of Climate Change and Air Pollution (PROCLIM)

overview.feedback: It sought to create and reinforce the capacity for developing climate change scenarios and vulnerability assessments and develop proposals for adaptation and geographic areas prioritized.As a whole, PROCLIM allowed the strengthening of institutional capacities. PROCLIM not only strengthens a specific group of people and central institutions for the management of Climate Change, but also contributes to the development of capabilities to reach a larger group, working in a collaborative environment, where each one does what they have to and knows how to do it. PROCLIM has implemented processes, which can be applied to other issues of national importance; it developed a work-methodology which conception and design extrapolates to other National institutions. PROCLIM opened a path to generate climate information needed for decision making to face climate change.

responsibilities.executing_agent: National Environmental Council (CONAM)

evaluative_information.success_factors: Lack of knowledge about climate change at the community and local government level; First project of this type in Peru; Lack of clarity between key actors at the River Basin level on the relation between the environment, climate change, vulnerability and adaptation, and sustainable development;
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: Climate change is not yet institutionalized at the project’s scope; Public, private and family management fields are disarticulated and lack a shared vision; Little continuity of the priorities of the governmental management.
evaluative_information.synergies_to_mitigation: Yes, PROCLIM has generated and strengthened capacity to identify, analyze and estimate GHG emissions and other air pollutants at 5 institutions: Environmental Health Department (DIGESA), National Natural Resources Institute (INRENA), Ministry of Energy and Mines (MINEM), Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MTC) in 13 prioritized cities .
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: not specified
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: PROCLIM has generated and strengthened capacity for developing climate change scenarios and vulnerability assessments of 7 institutions: AACHCHP, CENTRO, CONCYTEC, IGP, INRENA, ITDG and SENAMHI. It also developed integrated local assessments and adaptation strategies at  2  prioritized River Basins (Piura and Mantaro). The information generated has been widespread, “closing the circle” with the inclusion of the climate variable in the planning process towards sustainable development. It generated the Integrated National Emissions Inventory for 2000, five local inventories and thirteen sectoral inventories as well as map of deforestation of the Peruvian Amazon.

title: Programme on Integrated Climate Change Adaptation Strategies

overview.feedback: As a small island, Grenada is particularly vulnerable to the adverse effects of projected climate changes. Extreme events such as hurricanes experienced in the recent past are likely to become more intense in the future. Two major droughts occurred in the past years with substantial adverse effects on the water and agriculture sectors. Projections indicate a strong likelihood of declining rainfall in all seasons in the future. Furthermore, Grenada is expected to suffer severe negative impacts as a consequence of sea level rise. 1 metre sea level rise – which can be expected even under strong mitigation globally – may inundate crucial infrastructure and other coastal assets along the coast.  Whilst Grenada has developed many policies and strategies over the years relating to adaptation there remain substantial gaps and challenges in a strategic approach to adaptation, implementation of measures and co-ordination across sectors and scales.  	Thus, the overarching project goal of the Programme is to increase resilience of vulnerable communities and ecosystems to climate change risks in Grenada through integrated adaptation approaches. The project will be implemented jointly by UNDP and GIZ. On the national level, strategic and coordination abilities in adaptation are to be strengthened and a systematic approach to climate risk assessments in various decision making and planning processes is developed (GIZ). At the sector level, support is provided to strengthen water resource management, and to develop a coastal zone management plan for the management of coastal resources in a climate sensitive and efficient manner (GIZ). At the local level, concrete adaptation and climate resilience measures with a strong connection to livelihoods are implemented (UNDP). Finally knowledge management is strengthened (UNDP) and capacity to enable access to international climate finance is built to increase the sustainability of resources for adaptation (GIZ).  This comprehensive and integrated approach can serve as a role model for other countries in the region and as a springboard for further work and funding in Grenada.

responsibilities.initiating_agent: The Ministry of Agriculture, Lands, Forestry, Fisheries & the Environment Grenada, German Federal Ministry for the Environment, Nature Conservation and Nuclear Safety (BMU)
responsibilities.executing_agent: The Grenadian Ministry of Agriculture, Lands, Forestry, Fisheries & the Environment GIZ, UNDP and other national agencies
responsibilities.funding_source: German Federal Ministry for the Environment, Nature Conservation and Nuclear Safety (BMU)

evaluative_information.success_factors: Political leadership, subsequent funding, ownership and strong capacities
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: Small size of national administration may lead to knowledge drain. Inter-sectoral/inter-ministerial coordination mechanisms for climate change adaptation need to be improved. Optimising water storage may require building artificial storage which might be difficult in Grenada’s land tenure regime. Funding of activities after project ends is not ensured.
evaluative_information.synergies_to_mitigation:
Climate change mitigation is not the key objective of the project. Nevertheless, several co-benefits for the mitigation of GHG emissions can be expected. First of all, improved inter-sectoral coordination mechanisms and policy and planning instruments are likely to have positive impacts on mitigation policies. The present strategies and policies show that Grenada seeks for an integrative policy approach covering both adaptation and mitigation.

Supporting Grenada in its watershed management (here mainly: conservation of vegetation cover) and increasing the efficiency of water use (less residual water, less treatment, etc.) may deliver co-benefits as well.
With regard to climate finance, although the focus will be on adaptation finance it will also seek to enable access to financial resources for mitigation (e.g. for the implementation of NAMAs and low carbon development plans).
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: Overall supply of freshwater will be more secure, ecosystems more resilient due to more adapted practices and removal of invasive species.
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: not specified

additional_information: The specified funding applies only to the part of the project implemented by GIZ.

title: Project of Management of  Natural Resources : phase 2

overview.feedback: The project management of natural resources (PGRN1) which was completed in 2004 confirmed that the participatory and integrated approach (API) could be implemented within the regional Offices for Agricultural Development (CRDA). The second phase of the project submitted by the Tunisian authorities to the World Bank aims to consolidate these gains. These three objectives are : (i) improving incomes and living conditions of rural populations of 72  Imadats of the Governorates of Jendouba, Kasserine and Medenine (ii) improve the sustainable management of natural resources, and (iii) institutionalize API within three CRDA concerned. Achieving these goals requires the adoption of a sustainable management of natural resources, greater participation of the rural population and institutional strengthening.

title: Project Sahyog (A Drought Proofing Initiative in The Thar Desert)

overview.feedback: The project is a drought proofing initiative in the Thar desert by community participation involving construction of groundwater recharge structures, desiltation of rivers, installation of 31 hand pumps, six open wells constructed, diversifying livelihood opportunities by improved agricultural practices like horticulture, dairy, mushroom farming, etc., drip irrigation, pasture development, enterprise development for women. The project has resulted in increasing the water table level by 20ft, increased wool, milk production and mobilizing women participation.

responsibilities.executing_agent: His Highness Maharaja Hanwant Singhji Charitable Trust, local communities

thereby giving economic, social and environmental benefits.
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: The project impacts were evaluated for the  ground water table that showed an average increase of 20 ft, the water level in the open wells remained constant despite monsoon failure, milk and wool production increased by 15% to 25%,  increased animal immunity, reduced mortality.  Evaluation was also conducted by the State Remote Sensing Application Centre and their study showed a prominent increase in intensity of vegetation cover in the area.

title: Promoting Resilient Coastal Development

overview.feedback: This project will promote the development of adaptation options in coasts of Tunisia that are cross-sectoral, thereby breaking with the traditional, sectoral and infrastructure-heavy approaches of the past.  The project will seek to demonstrate soft and innovative technologies to address the key coastal challenges (introducing vegetative buffers, wetland restorations, coastal dune stabilization and beach nourishment...), while building the capacity of local, regional and national stakeholders to undertake science-based adaptation planning.  Financial mechanisms and risk sharing schemes will also be explored in order to internalize the costs of adaptation in the long term.  Finally, the project will aim at generating a better understanding of climate impacts and adaptation options through targeted research, awareness raising, and knowledge sharing and dissemination

title: Promotion of Climate Change Adaptation in Semi-Arid and Rainfed Regions

overview.feedback: The project aims to build resilience and capacities of poor rural communities to adapt to climate change. The village communities will be organised into Village Development Communities (VDC) and the women members into Self Help Groups (SHGs). The project will focus on the following four measures: (1) Promotion of Climate Change Adaptive Behaviour and Disaster Risk Mitigation, (2) Promotion of Renewable Energy as a well-being and mitigation measure, (3) Capacity building, knowledge generation, dissemination and policy dialogue, & (4) Empowering, equipping and enabling WOTR (Watershed Organisation Trust) to serve as a national referal centre for climate change adaptation. The project is experimental in nature and will help to draw lessons and devise best practices that can be later widely replicated and scaled up to adapt to climate change.

title: Providing support to measures for adaptation to climate change in the Mekong region

overview.feedback: The expected impacts of climate change and the plans to develop the hydropower potential of the Lower Mekong Basin are the biggest challenges to the ecosystems of the region. Millions of livelihoods in the basin depend on the Mekong as a source of food, means of transport and provider of water for many purposes. Although individual MRC member countries are already implementing adaptation projects, the knowledge and expertise of a regional institution such as MRC will be crucial in managing climate change impacts. There is a clear benefit to plan for and manage potential climate impacts on a regional scale compared to the national of local level. Member Countries of MRC have therefore established the Climate Change and Adaptation Initiative (CCAI). The CCAI serves as a long-term collaborative regional initiative to assist the Member Countries to adapt at the regional, national, and community levels to serious impacts and challenges posed by climate change by building a systematic process of adaptation planning, implementation, and learning. With its emphasis on a basin-wide approach, the CCAI ensures that adaptation to climate change is harmonised with effective adaptation strategies and plans at various levels and is applied at priority locations throughout the basin.The programme’s aim is to support CCAI to improve its services as a knowledge and information hub regarding adaption to climate change in the Mekong region. The cooperation will yield increased expert capacities at MRC to give advice to its Member Countries and to support their planning for targeted and effective adaptation.Advice to specialist and management staff of the MRC and member state authorities on options for adapting to climate change is provided. Initially the Commission is supported in making data, information and reports on climate change available, such as regionalised climate projections for Member States. A regional expert committee (Mekong Panel on Climate Change) will be founded to advise member states. Adaptation options will be developed; progress made in adaptation will be documented using a suitable monitoring system.

title: Public Investment and Climate Change Adaptation ? IPACC

overview.feedback: The Public Investment and Climate Change Adaptation Project (IPACC) of the Deutsche Gesellschaft für Internationale Zusammenarbeit (GIZ) GmbH (German Development Cooperation), funded by the Federal Ministry for the Environment, Nature Conservation and Nuclear Safety (BMU) of Germany through the International Climate Initiative (ICI), aims to increase awareness amongst national and regional political decision makers and relevant technicians of the potential costs and benefits of climate change in priority sectors and regions. This is undertaken in order to guide public investment decisions employing adaptation to climate change (ACC) and reduction of climate related risk criteria.The project has four components:1. INFORMATIONThe project updates and systematizes existing information on the risks and positive effects of climate change for two priority regions and sectors, and prepares vulnerability and risk maps based on these studies. In the two regions and for two priority sectors, methodologies are validated and studies of cost-benefit analysis are carried out.2. GUIDELINES AND CRITERIABased on cost-benefit analysis, the project uses pilot cases to develop at least two instruments of criteria and guidelines that consider climate change and possible adaptation measures in the design of public investment projects in two prioritized sectors. Additionally, design of a budget incentive proposal for funding ofpublic investment for climate change adaptation, incorporating the guidelines and criteria, is underway.3. INSTITUTIONALIZATIONThe project supports planners and evaluators of public investment projects during the process of incorporating the instruments with climate change adaptation in the National Public Investment System. Professionals from national government entities and in two regional governments are trained in the application of the instruments.  In the priority regions, the project tests and validatestools for adaptation of climate change and risk reduction measures in the framework of planning public investment projects. The regions apply the incorporation of climate change adaptive measures on a pilot basis in at least one existing policy instrument. IPACC supports them in the formulation of political guidelines which promote the application of those tools. Also, the project develops a monitoring mechanism for the application of climate change adaptation in public investment.4. KNOWLEDGE MANAGEMENTA digital platform provides access to information on risk analysis as required for public investment that is better adapted to climate change. In addition, the project supports the formation of networks in the priority regions. Through knowledge management and the exchange of experiences, relevant stakeholders from other Latin American countries are sensitized and informed about climate change economics.

responsibilities.initiating_agent: Ministry of Economy and Finance of Peru
responsibilities.executing_agent: Deutsche Gesellschaft für Internationale Zusammenarbeit (GIZ) GmbH – German Development Agency
responsibilities.funding_source: German Federal Ministry for the Environment, Nature Conservation and Nuclear Safety (BMU)

evaluative_information.success_factors: Strong institutional support of the Ministry of Economy and Finance is essential. Project activities should be accompanied by permanent capacity building, especially at regional and local levels.
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: The project depends on the institutional framework in Peru, specifically, the National Public Investment System (SNIP) and its methodologies.
evaluative_information.synergies_to_mitigation: The project does not pursue any mitigation reduction goals. However, the methodologies developed by the project might also be adapted for mitigation purposes.
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option:
The climate-proofing of public investment projects helps to reduce government spending on reconstruction and recovery services because of damages caused by natural hazards. These “avoided costs”, that is, benefits, can be used for other purposes.
The project supports the incorporation of climate change criteria and analysis into the public investment project design process. As such, it contributes to economic and political stability in communities, regions and nationally.
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: Having finished its first phase (development of climate change adaptation criteria for public investment projects in priority sectors), the project has now started its second phase (institutionalization of criteria within the National System of Public Investment). Thus, it is still too soon to expect any immediate effects.

title: Rainfall collection works and water harvesting

overview.feedback: The following measure is part of the “Mainstreaming Climate Change Adaptation in Irrigated Agriculture Project” by the World Bank. It is located in the Huang-Huai-Hai River Basin, concerned provinces are Hebai, Jiangsu, Anhui, Shandong, Henan and Ningxia. The project identifies specific climate change adaptation measures and techniques, which are demonstrate at selected project sites. The construction of field rainfall collection and water harvesting works to increase storage and retention of surface runoff and rainfall and mitigate rainfall deficits or insufficient irrigation water resources, especially in dry seasons. Furthermore it helps to compensate for increasingly unbalanced natural rainfall between seasons expected as a result of climate change.

title: Rajasthan Water Sector Restructuring Project (RWSRP)

overview.feedback: The Rajasthan Water Restructuring Project involved formation of local farm level committes (Water Users Associations) to transfer some of the operations and management of minor systems to these groups. The project  rehabilitated 91 irrigation systems, improving surface and ground water resources, increasing productivity of agriculture by improving irrigation systems performance and agricultural practices. The activities included dam safety works, intensification of agricultural extension services, institutional and capacity buliding, ground water management and dissemination of information regarding state water policy. As of March 2010 546 Water User Associatios have been formed.

title: Recycling Scrap Tires into Retaining Walls

overview.feedback: Retaining walls made with scrap tires are helping to raise living standards in the favelas of Rio de Janeiro.A team of researchers has discovered that the tire walls, built for less than one-third of the cost of conventional anchored concrete retaining walls used elsewhere in the city, may be more effective at stopping landslides during the rainy seasons. First the project team built a test wall in an isolated area and embedded it with measuring instruments to measure its performance. The team used a specially designed saw to slice off one side wall in each tire, tied the tires together in a honeycomb pattern using polypropylene rope, and packed them full of compacted earth. The test walls were layered up to six meters high.These retaining walls are an economically viable and environmentally sustainable way of building low-cost structures. The walls could be constructed under engineering supervision, by the people themselves.

responsibilities.executing_agent: Pontifícia Universidade Católica (PUC) do Rio de Janeiro, Fundacao Instituto Geotecnica of the Municipality of Rio de Janeiro  (GEO-RIO )

evaluative_information.success_factors: technical expertise on designing and construction retaining walls, tires
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: It is not yet known how high the walls may be built, or how solid they will remain on very swampy or compressible ground over the long term.
evaluative_information.synergies_to_mitigation: Yes, regarding the fact that in Rio alone, more than three million tires are disposed of each year. Many of these tires are illegally burned.
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: Win-Win option, reduces injuries and deaths, reduces property losses and save the environment.
evaluative_information.project_evaluation:
Even before the test wall was finished, local authorities were so impressed that they constructed another wall in one of the hillside slum communities. After they constructed the wall, GEO-RIO cleaned up gullies and provided drainage. Shortly after, they had torrential rainfalls. The downpour caused several concrete walls to collapse and several poor housing to be washed away elsewhere in Rio but the tire structures held. Where there had initially been skepticism about the wall, some people felt that as residents of a low-income area they were being given a substandard replacement for concrete, there was now total acceptance.
After seeing the wall’s success on the hillsides, citizens’ groups are already adapting them for their own uses. One small fishing community on a swampy tidal inlet in northern Rio collected tires to build a jetty, and planted it with trees and shrubs to keep tidal water from washing into their homes.

additional_information: Many landslides begin when loose debris from illegal hillside garbage dumps becomes sodden and topples under its own weight. The heavy material crashes into the mainly plywood shack dwellings below, causing deaths and property damage every rainy season.

title: Reducing Disaster Risks from Wildfire Hazards Associated with Climate Change

overview.feedback: The project will counter the increased probability of fires from climate change. This will entail institutional strengthening, capacity building, and awareness raising, under a programmatic approach to climate change sensitive fire management. The adaptation strategy around integrated fire management will be implemented in selected pilot areas identified to be at particularly high risk due to climate change. The project will in particular address long term adaptation to climate change needs in the context of forecasting and early warning systems, and strengthening and establishing national and regional centers and information networks for rapid response to extreme weather related events. Improved fire management will have important adaptation benefits.

title: Reducing the impact of flooding caused by sea level rise to promote sustainable agriculture production and ensuring food security

overview.feedback: The project aims to develop community-based sustainable agricultural production models to minimize impacts of flooding and salt water intrusion caused by sea level rise, adapting to climate change and contributing to food security and stable incomes s in a Phuc Hoa commune of Tuy Phuoc District, Binh Dinh Province where rice production is the major source of food and income. The commune is located at the confluence of two branches of Kon river pouring into Thi Nai Coastal Lagoon. It is a low lying and narrow delta with elevations from sea level in the range of 0.5-1.2 m and therefore has been subject to salt water intrusion and frequent flooding during rainy seasons.The project is designed and implemented by testing demonstration models for solutions to adapt to increasingly severely flooding and salt intrusion. These models should use the research results of selecting and creating high yielding flood tolerant rice varieties (such as varieties named 24SS, SH2, BM207, PC6, H43, H30) carried out by IRRI (International Rice Research Institute) in-cooperation with national agriculture institutes. Local farmers’ experiences in coping with flooding and after-flooding conditions will be fully applied in the models.Furthermore the Project aims to strengthen awareness and local capacity to adapt to climate change. Public awareness raising activities will be conducted widely in the whole commune.

responsibilities.executing_agent: SGP VIET NAM

evaluative_information.success_factors:
-Active participation of communities and local government.
-In-line with the National Strategy and Action Plan for Disaster Mitigation and Management.
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: not specified
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: Increase of livelihood opportunities and resilience
evaluative_information.project_evaluation:
The project is under implementing.
Expected major outputs:
1. Enhanced understanding and knowledge on CC and its impacts, and adaptation measures
2. 2-4 rice varieties which cope better with flooding and salt water intrusion to be selected.
3. A model of 20ha of rice, 2 crops per year, for 2 years, with the participation of 50-60 households to be tested with the application of new rice varieties which cope better with flooding and salt water intrusion.
4. 2-3 groups of households or 10 households trains in rice seed production to meet the demand of the commune and other neighboring communes
5. A sustainable agricultural production model to be developed and replicated to other areas.
6. 8-10 technical training workshops organize.

additional_information: Lessons learnt from the models will serve as inputs for the local decision-makers to plan for upscaling them in bigger areas of rice cultivated land and to continue to seek other adaptation measures to address immediate and longer climate change impacts. Information on the models at Phuoc Hoa should be also made available to other neighboring communes with similar conditions for learning and possible replication (such as Phuoc Thang, Phuoc Thuan, Phuoc Son and Phuoc Nghia communes in Tuy Phuoc District) and Cat Chanh, Cat ien, Cat Tai, Cat Thang communes in Phu Cat District).

title: Reforestation of the recharge zones of fresh water sources and recovery of agrobiodiversity of tubers and cereals

overview.feedback: The project aims to protect freshwater sources through reforestation and recovery of native germplasm of agricultural biodiversity of cereals and tubers in the communities of the municipality of Colquechaca to ensure food security to people and to preserve the fertility of agricultural soils in a sustainable manner.For this purpose, it will be built and installed a forest nursery with a capacity of 10.000 production seedlings per year. Furthermore, it will be carried out the reforestation of 36 recharge zones of freshwater sources, with 12.000 forest species between native and exotic. The activities include an inventory and a registry of the agro-biodiversity of tubers and native cereals in different varieties.

evaluative_information.synergies_to_mitigation: The reforestation to protect freshwater sources contributes to mitigation through the capture of carbon from the atmosphere during the growth of forest trees.

evaluative_information.project_evaluation: Improvement of 38 hectares of agricultural soil with incorporation of leguminous green manure, crop rotation, application of reversible plows and agroforestry systems.

additional_information: The greates impact will be seen in the environmental field because the final purpose is to generate processes of adaptation to climate change, protecting thus the fresh water sources in the aquifer recharge areas of the five sub Mayorallty of Colquechaca. This will enable the recovering the agrobiodiversity of tubers, cereals and some native forest species to improve degraded soil fertility, eroded by monoculture systems and overgrazing.

title: Rehabilitation of Integrated Tank Management Systems in the Kalivelli Watershed

overview.feedback: The project aimed to increase the water storage capacity of tanks in the Kalivelli watershed. To rehabilitate and manage tanks, community based management institutions were formed and entrusted with the physical work and distribution of water in an equitable manner. The project cost was shared by Palmyra/ICEF and the landholders in a ratio of 7:3. 24 tanks and 4 ponds with a command area of 1687.47ha were worked on along with 2 large channels (‘maduvu’). A total of 2,97,256 m3 of soil excavated, 19,920 m of bund length strengthened, 8885 m of supply channels cleared, encroachments removed in two villages and storage capacities increased by 10.01 million cubic feet.

responsibilities.executing_agent: Palmyra

evaluative_information.success_factors: Institutional: formation of local water user associations and SHGs and their effective management; financial: contribution of 30% by the user group
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: without regular maintenance the tank will silt up and stop functioning effectively; functioning of the institutions is essential for maintaining records, user fee deposit and checking inequity in distribution of water (may create conflicts amongst the users)
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: increased irrigation capacity leads to increased agricultural outputs and income in the hands of local communities.
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: The total number of tanks rehabilitated were 31 as against the proposed 23,  there was increased water storage leading to a increase in crop production due to better irrigation. These factors reflect the success of the project in achieving the desired results.

additional_information: The project was monitored by FERAL (Foundation for Ecological Research, Advopcacy and Learning). The project site was monitored using GIS based techniques to see the change in cropping pattern, the area of water storage; vegetation cover and drainage pattern were mapped. A five year database for the soil, water quality and meteorological information was created. Indicators were idetified for monitoring with the help of the primary stakeholders; In the final year of the project staff gauges to measure water level and silt traps to measure sedimentation rates were set up.

title: Rescue and transfer of bioindicators of  interandean valleys from a cultural context
