It proposes the comprehensive development of mountain ecosystems with high vulnerability to degradation of biodiversity, water and soil as well as the identification of vulnerabilities and mechanisms coping with climate change.

title: Rice-wheat Consortium for the Indo-Gangetic Plains

overview.feedback: Zero tillage is the seeding of a crop in unplowed fields, To make the rice-wheat systems of the indo-gangetic plains more productive, tractor drawn zero-tillage drills with six to eleven inverted-T lines are used to seed wheat directly into unplowed fields in a sigle pass of the tractor. The system has reduced production costs (US$ 52/ha), increased crop yields by 5-7% and increased farm income from wheat production  by US$ 97/ha. The positive effects have also been realised by the savings in fossil fuel and water, and reducing green house gas emissions.Especially saving water will be more important with proceeding climate change.

responsibilities.executing_agent: Rice Wheat Consortium
responsibilities.funding_source: CGIAR (Consultative Group on International Agricultural Research)

evaluative_information.success_factors: local manufacturing capacity, involvement of several manufacturers, subsidy to lower investment cost, institutional support for a innovative technology to materialize
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: Has spread primarily for wheat crop, rice needs to be addressed, and technology needs to spread to smaller farmers.
evaluative_information.synergies_to_mitigation: reduces emission of green house gases
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: No-regret: the technology will give both economic and environmental returns even in the absence of anthropogenic climate change impacts
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: A comprehensive review of the impacts of zero tillage wheat in the rice wheat systems has been done by Erenstein and Laxmi (2008) giving the following, the practice is adopted on 1.76 million ha area,  has reduced production cost by $52/ha, crop yield increase by 5-7%, The farm income has increased by $97/ha from wheat production, increase household incomes has been between $180-340/farm and increase in food production has been 0.7% (343,000 tons). There is an 8% saving of diesel as compared to the conventional system.

additional_information: Also the primary reason is the monetary gain for the farmer and simplification of field preparation, but despite early expectations of water saving, significant water savings have not yet been achieved.

title: Riparian Habitat Rehabilitation project

overview.feedback: The Riparian Habitat Rehabilitation Project was established to develop and implement strategies to rehabilitate key degraded riparian corridors in the Karoo. The project aims to combine sustainable water and biodiversity conservation with job creation and skills development amongst members of the local rural communities, in order to promote resilience of ecosystems and communities to climate change. The project will also act as an adaptation mechanism through the restoration of riparian ecosystems which will help buffer the Karoo communities to the predicted impacts of climate change. The re-vegetating and restoring the soils as well as connecting fragmented pieces of vegetation together will increased capability of the ecosystem to provide its services such as water filtration, reducing sedimentation and flood impacts and build resilience to the impacts of climate change.Specific Measures:1.Develop and implement a strategy to regenerate degraded riparian zones on farms to create corridors of suitable habitat for Riverine Rabbit dispersal.2.The ongoing development and propagation of seedlings of indigenous riparian plants in the Karoo Indigenous Plant Nursery in Loxton.3.Training of nursery staff (i.e Seed collection, seed germination, seedling care, infrastructure management, trail maintenance, simple construction, etc.)4.The formal mapping and recording of the planting and restoration process into a database, thereby allowing for the restoration process to be formally tracked and quantified over time. This includes monitoring for climate change adaptation.5.Provide opportunities for members of the rural Loxton community to engage in conservation through skills training and providing employment opportunities, particularly for women and the previously disadvantaged.6.Develop guidelines for landowners to rehabilitate degraded riparian corridors to promote long term sustainability of natural resources (e.g  soil conservation techniques such as digging hollows, mashing)

responsibilities.executing_agent: The Endangered Wildlife Trust (EWT)
responsibilities.funding_source: CAP, CapeNature, Department of Environmental Affairs, Altron, Altech, Bytes, Powertech, Altech Netstar, MAZDA, National Lottery, SA National Parks, ZGAP, Rand Merchant Bank

title: Roof rain water harvesting Akash Ganga

overview.feedback: Akash Ganga is an innovative roofwater harvesting system that channels rooftop rainwater from every house in a community through gutters and pipes to a network of underground reservoirs with large enough capacity to store a year of drinking water. It depends on community partnership or social enterprise to provide drinking water to the people by renting roofs from home owners or acquiring rights to harvest their rooftop rainwater. One half of the harvested rooftop rainwater is stored in the reservoir attached to the house for the exclusive use of the home owner. The other half flows to the shared community reservoir. People who live under thatched roofs or who cannot afford to have their own reservoirs take water from the shared reservoir.

title: Scenario planning to assess the implications of climate change on land and water use within the agricultural sector

overview.feedback: The overarching aim of the project is to identify and promote logical, financially feasible alternatives that will encourage wise, and sustainable use of land and water resources within the agricultural sector of the Garden Route. A significant portion of the agricultural sector within the Garden Route is currently financially unstable and environmentally unsustainable. In these areas inappropriate cultivation and irrigation, overstocking, and illegal activities are causing significant damage to natural resources. The first phase of the project, included an assessment of current agricultural practices in the Garden Route, and an assessment of farmers’ attitudes towards changing rainfall patterns and other climatic variables. The second phase utilizes these findings and make recommendations relating to mitigation and adaptation strategies based on scenario planning exercise among farmers and experts. Recommendations to the farmers, Agricultural Unions, relevant government departments and politicians will be suggested , based on the outcomes projected by the models. The project includes the following components:•In depth study of  the perspectives and attitudes of farmers towards climate change•Workshop with farmers for development of existing and potential adaptation and mitigation options•Creating an environment for farmers that allows them to identify of adaptation and mitigation strategies•Scenario workshop with experts and farmers•Revisiting of adaptation and mitigation options and development of adaptation and mitigation strategies by the farmers

title: Sea water level rise scenarios and possible disaster risk reductions

overview.feedback: This project ultimately aims at mitigation of the impacts of the sea level rise due to climate change in Vietnam through propose adaptation measures. Its objectives are:- To increase the knowledge on the methods of dealing with natural hazards due to climate change and the problem of sea level rise in Vietnam;- To protect local communities, many of them belong to the poorest and most vulnerable to natural hazards as well as economic sectors in the coastal areas from adverse impacts of the sea level rise;- To propose to the Vietnam government the strategies towards reasonable utilization of the resources of the coastal zone for economic and social development while protect the natural and social environment of the area.

responsibilities.initiating_agent: Vietnam Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment
responsibilities.executing_agent: Vietnam Institute of Meteorology, Hydrology and Environment

evaluative_information.success_factors: The awareness of Vietnamese Government in marine problems is more and more increased and the project’s results will contribute in policy making processes of the country.
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: The project focus on some pilot study areas and it can make the adaptation measures may not be detail enough for all Vietnam country regions.
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: Contribute to coastal management problems
evaluative_information.project_evaluation:
The project studies the impacts of sea water level rise on many field include:
- Potential impacts of saline water in spatial scale in the Red and Mekong River deltas and pilot study area;
- The vulnerability of ecological system and marine protected area;
- The cost – benefit analysis of adaptation measures in the pilot study area;
- Risk analysis and management.
The project is running and it will propose:
- Potential measures to mitigate the negative impacts on ecological system and marine protected area;
- Approaches to manage the risks of sea water level rise.

additional_information: The project uses Morphologic Vulnerability Index to study the coastal erosion and mapping potential inundation areas; and Coastal Vulnerability Index to assess the risks of sea level rise.

title: Sedgefield Desalination Plant

overview.feedback: Sedgefield, a seaside town on the Garden Route in the southern Cape, situated within the Knysna local municipal area, effectively ran dry in January 2009 when the Karatara River stopped flowing.  While potable water was tankered in to Sedgefield, the Knysna Municipality sought an urgent solution, and alternatives were examined to implement rapid, short and medium term options. An innovative, demand-based approach was developed to address the water supply crisis  in Sedgefield, and this proved to be cost effective and achievable in the time scales required.  The approach included the construction of the Sedgefield desalination plant, a single-pass, reverse osmosis (RO) system that can produce potable water of 1. 5M?/day. Initially the plant will be operated by the supplier for one year – which will probably be extended to three or five years. The team is justifiably proud to have commissioned the plant within three months:  the contract award was signed on 1 October 2009 and the plant was functional on 18 December 2009, in time for the anticipated holiday peak in December 2009.

title: Small-scale wind power

overview.feedback: Small-scale wind power reduces water resource stress and contributes to climate change adaptation in two ways: (1) by providing energy for water pumping and (2) by reducing fuel wood consumption in households whose livelihood opportunities have expanded with electrification. Maintenance is done by local staff and spare parts are supplied by the machine manufacturer. It is based on a design by the Intermediate Technology Development Group, ITDG. The machine is a 300 watt multi-blade unit with a six meter rotor diameter. It cuts in at wind speed as low as one meter per second and is usually coupled to a lift pump or a bucket pump. Water from the pump is stored in a reservoir. The project is located in Temaruru, Mashonaland East.

responsibilities.executing_agent: ZERO (regional environment organization)

evaluative_information.success_factors: Define a wind map and develop test schemes at sites showing high potential is the fundamental  of success. Furthermore the project should be integrated into the rural development program.
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: No wind no power.
evaluative_information.synergies_to_mitigation: Emission reductions through windmills. In this study all windmills together generate about 600 kWh per month. A diesel genset would emit about 640 kg of CO2 in supplying 600 kWh of electricity.
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: It is a win-win option. The project reduces emissions, generates incomes and improves	living conditions of rural people.
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: The project was not conceived as a climate change project, however, it has displaced the use of kerosene for lighting and refrigeration at the site. In it’s current form the project supplies energy to a few shops and a rural health center. There is potential to expand the project to include energy supply for income generation projects.

additional_information: The wind machine used in this project was developed as part of the project.Local and foreign experts used local technical skills to construct the machines. The technology works well and is now exported to the U.S.

title: Social Forestry Plantation

overview.feedback: Community forests and plantations on common lands provide multiple biomass benefits to local communities, can improve the soil moisture and groundwater situation. In addition to fuelwood, they provide an additional source of fodder for livestock and act as a safety asset in times of crop failure. This becomes more important under Climate Change to reduce the impact on the forest. With a view to increase peoples participation in forest protection and management the Rajasthan Forest Department collaborated with the Barodiya Panchayat in Jaipur district, to plant a total of 73 acres in the years 1985, 1992 and 1993 with species like Acacia tortilis, Eucalyptus spp. and Dalbargia sissoo. The plantation provided the communities with fuel wood, fodder and timber benefits. A management plan was prepared to harvest the plantation after completion of its rotation period. Based on the harvest plan, an auction was held which led to high bids and the revenue was divided equally between the community and the forest department, as per the state government order S. F. (17) 11 Raj./8/82-A/ on June 5, 1982 regulations.

responsibilities.executing_agent: Forest Department, Gram panchayat

evaluative_information.success_factors: institutional, distribution of monetary benefits: to protect and manage the forests (forest department and the Gram Sabha), for continued forest plantation, protection and management by the community
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: not specified
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: no-regret: the plantation activity gives economic returns in the form of fuelwood and the final felling and also gives other benefits like increased availability of fodder and environmental benefits like soil binding and checking erosion, etc. These benefits will be obtained despite anthropogenic climate change impacts
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: The harvesting of the plantation resulted in a net income of Rs 8,000,000  which was equally divided amongst the community and forest department. The plantation also provided fodder and fuelwood to the local communities.

additional_information: Increased availability of fodder to the villagers led to an increase in livestock population by the community. The monetary income received from the final harvest was equally distributed amongst the forest department and the community. The community used their share of the money for improving rural infrastructure - building a village road and funded additional plantation work from NREGA - the social security employment guarantee funds

title: Soil and Water Conservation Programmes

overview.feedback: Himachal Pradesh has hilly terrain and high rainfall in the rainy season increasing erosion, while water scarcity is experienced in other seasons. The state department of Agriculture is implementing rain water harvesting including Individual, Community based tank and Head weirs etc, and soil conservation and soil erosion control schemes to increase agricultural production. Improved water availabillity improves productivity and reduces risk of crop failure while soil conservation helps preserve fertility in the longer run.

responsibilities.executing_agent: Government of Himachal Pradesh

evaluative_information.success_factors: institutional mechanisms, water users groups, financial resources, technical support
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: inadequate repair and maintenance, lack of funds
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: No-regret: SMC (Soil and Moisture Conservation) and watershed treatment undertaken by the Department is essential for water availability and groundwater recharge especially during dry spells
evaluative_information.project_evaluation:
The major interventions here are the structures built and the financial outlays for undertaking minor and major irrigation works. During the year 2007-08, The Department has executed 98 Minor irrigation Schemes / Water Harvesting Structures with an expenditure of Rs. 324.54 lakh . 29 projects of Minor Irrigation were executed with an expenditure of Rs. 350.61 lakh during the year 2008-09 and a provision of Rs. 327.24 is required to complete these 29 schemes during 2009-10.
Integrated Watershed Management: The Department of Agriculture is constructing Community Based Water Harvesting Structures, Silt retention structure in R.C.C. , Concrete, masonry and Check dams in wire crate mesh etc on 100% assistance to provide protective / life saving and assured irrigation.During the financial year, 2008-09, Rs 100 lakh have been provided under this scheme. The schemes are executed through participatory approach and cover engineering and vegetative measures. This is a State Plan Scheme.

title: Southern Voices Capacity Building

overview.feedback: The project is part of a large transnational programme which supports the strengthening of Southern civil society networks through the country offices and other support structures of the consortium members. 11 national networks, 6 regional and 3 thematic networks will be included in the programme.The project in Vietnam aimed a better support for climate change advocacy, lobbying and public awareness rising at fair pro-poor positions of governments and other stakeholders to their commitments related to climate issues. A key tool for advocacy will be written Country Assessment Report made by the NGO Climate Change Working Group (CCWG) networks.Furthermore capacity building and utilization will be prioritized, including organizational and technical strengthening of existing networks and skills at national levels in Organizational development (OD), policy analysis, advocacy, and media engagement.Focus on strengthening know-how within the Southern networks – brokering knowledge and facilitating linkages on selected themes: adaptation, REDD (Reducing Emissions from Deforestation and Forest Degradation in Developing Countries), renewable energy/ energy efficiency /low carbon development and gender.The programme’s objective is to increasing public awareness at national, regional and international levels in order to help implement and develop climate change policies which promote environmental integrity and sustainable development benefitting poor and vulnerable people.

responsibilities.executing_agent: CARE Vietnam  and Climate Change Working Group

title: Stakeholder?s engagement to inform and promote climate change community-based adaptation for the city of Johannesburg

overview.feedback: This project aims to provide some insight on how to situate vulnerability, disaster risk and climate change adaptation efforts within the city’s communities. More specifically, it aims to; provide a better understanding of the perceptions and comprehension of climate change amongst civil society; improve resilience to climate change at the community level in order to address the impacts of change; and to strengthen the capacity of the local authorities to integrate climate change concerns in local and city wide planning, as well as their ability to budget for cost-effective policy responses.

responsibilities.initiating_agent: The project is a Climate Change Adaptation Policy Fellowship, awarded by START (Systems for Analysis , Research and Training)
responsibilities.executing_agent: Executed by Linda Phalatse as a City of Johannesburg employee, with supervision from Coleen Vogel from Witwatersrand University
responsibilities.funding_source: START (Systems for Analysis , Research and Training)

evaluative_information.success_factors: The success can be measured by the understanding of the concepts on the side of the targeted stakeholders.
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: The short timeframe can be a limiting factor.
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: Social welfare, engagement of stakeholders strengthened capacity and understanding.
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: Adaptation can not be seen as an outcome but as a long term process to build resilience of communities to climate change

additional_information: Adaptation does not need a new development strategy. At the City of Johannesburg there are existing strategies that can include adaptation to make adjustments in  policies, cultures and attitudes that will establish enabling conditions accompanied by infrastructural changes.

title: Stewardship corridors for climate change adaptation

overview.feedback: The project aims to create ecological corridors by forging partnerships with private and communal landowners, allowing some level of human use, while protecting biodiversity and allowing ecosystems to function. These will connect core conservation areas in the landscape, while improving the ability of species to adapt to climate change and allowing for long-term mitigation. The KZN Biodiversity Stewardship Programme is focused on building rural community-based initiatives that have tangible climate change adaptation value, through the core focus on improving biodiversity protection through capacity building, training and mentorship. Through the project six stewardship corridors have been estabished: Dalton Private Reserve, Red Desert Nature Reserve, Umgano Community Project, Somkhanda Game Reserve, Usuthu Gorge and the Upper Thukela community site (incorporating Mweni)Major implementation measures include:a)Removal of alien plants i.e. establishment and initiation of an alien plant clearing plan on each of the sitesb)Improved grassland management on these sites, through the improved management of fire and livestock grazing trainingc)Training of field rangers to ensure improved biodiversity monitoring and patrolling in order to assist in understanding the role these areas play in climate change adaptationd)	Improved biodiversity management on these sites, by developing and providing financial support for the implementation of a Management Plan for each initiative.e)Provide mentoring of field rangers to these community-based initiatives to ensure viability of these initiatives

responsibilities.executing_agent: Ezemvelo KZN Wildlife
responsibilities.funding_source: DG Murray Trust, via the Climate Action Partnership

evaluative_information.success_factors:
• Important role of community offices
• Crucial that the needs of the communities are addressed
• Importance of ensuring community ownership
• By committing to a long-term Biodiversity Stewardship agreement, which will often restrict potential land-use activities to only those compatible with sound conservation management, the landowner / community must realize a benefit from the property, either through financial support or income-generation activities.
• mentorship to the field rangers extremely valuable and has added much value to the motivation of the field rangers, and their abilities to perform their duties.
• Community initiatives require significant support in building the capacity of middle management structures in order for them to take ownership of these projects, allowing long-term sustainability.
• Collective support by several partners, such as in this case Ezemvelo KZN Wildlife, Wildlands Conservation Trust, CAP, DGMT as funders, allows community initiatives to gain momentum
evaluative_information.limiting_factors:
• Not enough engagement of the broader community i.e. limited understanding and awareness of the community on the reserve and biodiversity agreement area and what implications and benefits the reserve has for them.
• The community structures still require significant support in terms of coordinating management meetings, implementing daily management activities
• The challenge is to ensure that middle management in these communities are capacitated and take ownership of the projects
evaluative_information.synergies_to_mitigation: Yes, restoration of healthy ecosystems, soil carbon in grasslands, protection of indigenous forest, catchment and wetland management.
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: Yes the project has contributed to local job creation, education, training of field rangers and the  improved access to water and other ecosystem services that support human well being.

additional_information:
How has climate change information or climate science been considered in the design and implementation of the project?
Climate change data was provided by SANBI (Guy Midgley), use of stress tests (e.g. 1 degree change, 2 degree change etc.) instead of scenarios
Identification of the corridors was done by Ezemvelo KZN Wildlife

title: Strategic Program for Climate Resilience (SPCR) - Bangladesh

overview.feedback: The most pressing climate threats to Bangladesh are sea-level rise, drought, flooding, and erosion. Overall vulnerability is high. The SPCR for Bangladesh comprises of three investment and two technical assistance projects:1. Promoting Climate Resilient Agriculture and Food Security: improve access to irrigation, introduce scress-tolerant/adaptive varieties, train farmers in adaptive water management2. Coastal Embankments Improvement and Afforestation: Rehabilitate & afforest embankments to make them more resistant to extreme events3. Coastal Climate Resilient Water Supply, Sanitation, and Infrastructure Improvement: establish water management cooperatives, improve safe access to drinking water, build roads and bridges4. Climate Change Capacity Building and Knowledge Management: Equip Ministry of Environment and Forests with knowledge and resources to foster climate resilient planning5. Feasibility Study for a Pilot Program of Climate Resilient Housing in the CoastalRegion: Requisite information base for making housing more storm/cyclone proof and affordable

responsibilities.executing_agent: Ministry of Forests and Environment, Bangladesh

evaluative_information.success_factors:
* Financial institutions must be made aware of the risks and opportunities in climate finance in order to make financing available.
* Improve coordination between government ministries and line agencies
* Effective coordination with stakeholders
evaluative_information.limiting_factors:
* Lack of secondary data on remote polders for IFC operations, restrictions on free data access.
* Political instability, unstable financial markets -> insecurity for funding and investment
* Limited capacity and CC experience executing agencies, esp. MoEF
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: improved access to drinking water, improved infrastructure (roads and bridges), increase in agricultural productivity, women's empowerment in water management

title: Strategic Program for Climate Resilience (SPCR) - Bolivia

overview.feedback: Bolivia's SPCR focuses mainly on water supply. In the past decades, rainfall has become more erratic and decreased overall. Rapidly retreating glaciers are endangering long-term water availability.The SPCR for Bolivia has three focus areas:1. Strengthening the national capacity for managing climate change: Training staff to take climate change into account and improve public information access for planning2. Climate Resilience Program for the water and sanitation systems of the metropolitan areas of La Paz and El Alto: Improving infrastructure, gather experience for water management in high mountain environments, and pilot an NRM plan.3. Strengthening the resilience to climate change in the Rio Grande basin: improving rural water management and alleviate poverty to increase resilience.

title: Strategic Program for Climate Resilience (SPCR) - Cambodia

overview.feedback: Cambodia's SPCR consists of seven projects in three key areas.1. Cambodia is exposed to climate change due to decreasing water availability and more intense flooding. Food and water security will be increased by rehabilitating irrigation systems and improving water management. Drought and flood management is improved by infrastructural measures as well as capacity development.2. Resilience of agriculture is increased by flood protection, introduction of more tolerant crop varieties, water use efficiency, and index-based insurance.3. Infrastructure is made more climate proof through Green planning and improved design standards for roads, improved sanitation infrastructure, and mainstreaming of adaptation concerns into urban planning. Community-based efforts protect infrastructure from weather extremes.

title: Strategic Program for Climate Resilience (SPCR) - Caribbean Region
country: Dominica; Grenada; Haiti; Jamaica; St Lucia; St Vincent and the Grenadines

overview.feedback: The Caribbean islands, most of them small island states, have been identified by the IPCC among the most vulnerable societies to climate change. The regional programme is designed to improve regional cooperation and knowledge sharing to overcome barriers related to scale, resources, and capacity constraints due to size. There are four components:1. Improving the quality of geospatial data crucial for understanding the impacts of climate change. This includes collection of topographic data and development of digital elevation models, analysis, and training.2. The regional climate monitoring network is consolidated in order to improve disaster management and data sharing.3. Development of regional climate models for useful precise climate projections.4. Vulnerability reduction in the food security, economic livelihoods, and human health areas.The project is designed in a staged approach, with concrete adaptation measures being taken as climate impacts can be better estimated. CCCCC members are in the process of designing country-specific SPCRs.

responsibilities.initiating_agent: Climate Investment Funds, :Caribbean Community Climate Change Centre
responsibilities.executing_agent: Caribbean Community Climate Change Centre, University of the West Indies, Caribbean Institute for Meteorology and Hydrology

evaluative_information.success_factors: not specified
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: Data availability is problematic and scientific equipment is outdated. Improving this is part of the SPCR.
evaluative_information.synergies_to_mitigation: Carbon emissions in the region are negligible in the global context, therefore mitigation is not a priority and funds are better used for adaptation.

title: Strategic Program for Climate Resilience (SPCR) - Tajikistan

overview.feedback: Tajikistan is a highly vulnerable country with many people living below the poverty line. Climate change poses risks as precipitation changes, leading to droughts as well as extreme events, flash floods, and heightened soil erosion on the slopes.The Tajik SPCR is a holistic approach. While the first phase focused on assessing investment needs, six adaptation measures are planned out for the second phase of the programme:1. Building capacity for climate resilience through strengthening institutions, awareness raising and women's empowerment2. Improvement of Weather, Climate and Hydrological Service Delivery aimed at improving the national hydro-meteorological monitoring system to provide timely warnings on dangerous events, support water management, and build the evidentiary basis for climate variability and change.3. Climate Science and Modelling Programme aimed at enhancing Tajikistan‘s capacity to conduct climate and glacier research and develop appropriate models 4. Enhancing the Climate Resilience of the Energy sector through improving the hydro power infrastructure5. Agriculture and Sustainable Land management aimed at replicating and scaling up effective, existing land management practices to ensure that climate resilience becomes an integral part of land management and agricultural production6. Building climate resilience in the Pyanj River Basin, a pilot pilot project aimed at increasing climate resilience in critical ecosystems, communities and infrastructure in major glacier-dependent river basins

responsibilities.executing_agent: not specified

evaluative_information.success_factors:
* Communicating and coordinating with stakeholders in order to address the right needs
* Identifying and cooperating with national agencies, and developing their capacity to act, is crucial for long-term effectiveness
* Ideas of what "climate resilience" means vary among stakeholders. It is important to find a consensus and avoid misunderstandings.
evaluative_information.limiting_factors:
* Central Asia's remote regions are still poorly explored, language barriers -> difficult work for international consultants and agencies
* NGOs and civil society are not directly involved in implementation and are showing dwindling interest
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: poverty alleviation, livelihood diversification, improving scientific capacity of Tajikistan, improving energy security
evaluative_information.project_evaluation:
Project implementation is ongoing and it's too early for a proper evaluation. The first detailed progress report has been published in May 2013:

title: Strategic Program for Climate Resilience (SPCR) - Yemen

overview.feedback: The Yemeni economy is highly dependent on irrigated agriculture, however groundwater sources are depleting, and recharge may be falling in the future due to climate change. Additionally, there has been damage from increased flash flooding, while erosion from sea-level rise is a hazard in the future.In accordance with the Yemeni NAPA, the Pilot Program for Climate Resilience seeks to increase resilience in four sectors: water, agriculture, coastal zones, and cross-sectoral.The Yemeni PPCR has four key components:1. Building a climate information system and training practitioniers and resource users in interpreting climate data.2. Improving capacity of water management institutions, water infrastructure, and conducting water risk analyses3. Strengthening rural livelihoods by teaching innovative soil and water conservation practices and diversification (IRLARA project)4. Climate-resilient coastal zone management entailing livelihood diversification and vulnerability/risk assessments.

title: Strengthening national capacities to respond to climate change in Viet Nam, reducing vulnerability and controlling greenhouse gases emissions

overview.feedback: The National Target Program respond to Climate Change (NTP) was issued by Government in 2008 with the main strategic objective of assessing climate change’s impacts on sectors/areas/regions and develop feasible action plan to effective respond to climate change in short-/long-term periods. Within this tight timeframe, the NTP has only proposed one strategic document but the case studies and consultation in order to formulate concrete action plans has not developed yet, while there is limited expertise within the Government Agencies for development of the strategic NTP document and detailed action plans.This project will provide support to the Government in this regard with the main objective: Frameworks, mechanisms and capacities in place to inform, guide and coordinate (i) analysis of climate change related risks and formulation of CC adaptation policy responses and investment plans; and (ii) analysis of Green House Gas emissions, and formulation of investment plans and ways to change consumer behaviour for low-carbon economic development.

responsibilities.initiating_agent: Vietnam Ministry of Natural Resources & Environment (MONRE) and United Nation Development Program (UNDP)
responsibilities.executing_agent: MONRE, Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development (MARD) and  UNDP Vietnam

evaluative_information.success_factors:
-Analysis and methodological development of the project ensure that target provinces and selected sectors are able to learn, adapt and (if appropriate) replicate this approach to develop and implement locally-appropriate provincial and sectoral adaptation frameworks.
-NTP development has been requested by the Prime Minister and therefore this project have strong government support at both central and local levels.
evaluative_information.limiting_factors:
- Three province as case studies may not be typical for all regions of Vietnam with different geographical conditions
-Consensus not reached and Ministry of Planning and Investment does not include Climate Change criteria in planning guidelines for sectors and provinces.
-Fact that learning is a ongoing process
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: Raising awareness of Vietnamese people on climate change problems
evaluative_information.project_evaluation:
The project is running and its expected outcomes are:
– Climate change policy formulated and mainstreamed into the National Target Program to respond to Climate Change, related action plans formulated, and policy and management capacities for roll out strengthened;
- Improved knowledge base and national research capacity strengthened to deliver analysis for evidence-based planning and policy development, and implementation of CC-related measures to support sectors and provinces in rolling out the NTP;
- Build capacities for regulation, guidance, local policy measures, and project management, and formulate concrete regulations, policy measures and investment plans for CC adaptation and GHG emissions control.

additional_information:
- Pilot projects in three provinces (Binh Thuan, Binh Dinh, Can Tho) was desigted to experiment with specific approaches to CCA and GHG mitigation in order to develop provincial action plans, climate change integrated in provincial plans, and capacities built of provincial CC Offices;
- IMHEN is assigned by MONRE to be the Project Focal Point who will be the lead organisation in the present project, acting for MONRE and working with various departments, offices and institutes in MONRE, MARD and selected provinces;
- Direct beneficiaries of the project are: (i) The people, especially those who live in poor rural areas within the project pilot areas; (ii) MONRE, MARD, sectors, provinces and organizations taking part in and related to the project; (iii)Women, who are one of the important target groups of the project

title: Strengthening Participatory Irrigation Management

overview.feedback: Participatory Irrigation Management (PIM) is useful in improving irrigation management along with sustainability of the system. Such a project sets up institutions such as Water User Associations (WUA) at the village level to effectively manage distribution of irrigation water, collect water user fee at the micro level and thus helps in increasing the area under effective irrigation and makes the system sustainable and equitable. A pilot project has been undertaken in two drought prone areas, Maan in district Dhar and Jobat in district Jhabua in western Madhya Pradesh through convergence of funds from different agencies to provide micro channel irrigation, awareness, capacity building and training of WUAs and exposure visits have been conducted.The PIM projects in these two areas seeks to converge financial resources from agencies such as Narmada Valley Development Authority, Madhya Pradesh Rural Livelihood Project and National Rural Employment Guarantee Scheme to support micro channel irrigation in individual farms to increase efficiency and utilisation of water by strengthening WUAs through exposure visits, capacity building and training.

responsibilities.initiating_agent: Govt. of MP: Narmada Valley Development Authority(NVDA)
responsibilities.executing_agent: NVDA, MPRLP

evaluative_information.success_factors: capacity building of the community, repair and maintenance, technical support
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: lack of insitutional support, non availability of funds for technical support
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: no regret (capacity building for accessing water for irrigation and repair and maintenance especially during dry years)
evaluative_information.project_evaluation:
There are a total of 16 WUA’s in Man & Jobat ( 10 in Man & 6 in Jobat). Rules for water sharing & distribution are common across different regions for participatory irrigation management, for the first three years it is free of cost & then the user group members have to pay a user fee. In this area, an NGO Development Suppor Center is already working for strengthening the repayment system as a reult of which they are able to recover the water charges. At present the WUA charges Rs.200 to 250 per bigha per year for irrigation which is deposited in the WUA accounts. The Chief Minister of Madhya Pradesh has awarded this project for excellent irrigation work. The tail end users are also a part of the decision making committee are benefitted. The total area in Man & Jobat is 25000 ha, 15000 ha in Man &10000 ha in Jobat. Nearly 5000 ha of area was already irrigated from before this project. From 2008 onwards through continuous efforts under this projec, now nearly 18000 ha of area has been irrigated out of which 7500 ha is in Man (before project it was only 2000 ha area)&10500 ha in Jobat(before project it was only 3000 ha). Funds are converged through the NREGA scheme. Some of the instituion building, training and awareness genaration work undertaken in the project are:

1. Motivation and awareness activities in Maan and Jobat Projects: Project/ Village levels meetings 111, PRA 25
2. Exposure visit in Maan and Jobat project:
WUA President & TC members in MP (Satak) No of programs: 2
3. WUA Membership Fee collection in Maan and Jobat project:No. of WUAs 13
Membership fee collected in Rs. 63770

4. Progress of NREGS assisted physical works:
No of Estimates 206, Funds released to the WUAs Rs 137.78 lakhs, Employment wages Rs 44.49 lakhs

5. Capacity building and strengthening of WUAs
Training 149, Project level Co-ordination 136 workshops.

title: Sub-Saharan African Cities: A Five-City Network to Pioneer Climate Adaptation through Participatory Research and Local Action

overview.feedback: This project aims to address the knowledge, resource, capacity and networking gaps of five Southern African cities by strengthening their ability to plan for, and adapt to, the impacts associated with climate change. General objectiveThe overarching objectives of this project are:- To develop 5 tailor-made adaptation frameworks for managing the increased risk to African local government and their communities due to climate change impact.- To establish a standardised approach for the collection and analyses of climatic base-line data which will assist future localised projections to assist in planning and decision making procedures.Location:The five urban centres chosen for this project are Cape Town, South Africa, Dar es Salaam, Tanzania; Maputo, Mozambique; Walvis Bay, Namibia; and Port St. Louis, Mauritius.

title: Sukhomajri - A case of forest and watershed protection in India

overview.feedback: Sukhomajri is a village in the erosion prone Shivalik hills near Chandigarh in north Indian state of Haryana where there was a severe problem of erosion in the upstream catchment area leading to silting up of the downstream Sukhna Lake. In 1977 under the guidance of  PR Mishra four tanks were built to conserve rainwater. This increased water storage and provided protective irrigation to the rainfed crops, increasing yields. This became an incentive to the villagers to stop grazing and initiate afforestation and watershed protection in the catchment, to reduce erosion and prevent sedimentation of their tanks. As many of the graziers did not own land and thus would not benefit directly from the water and increased yields, an innovative step was taken – of spliting water ownership from land ownership. The water stored was made the property of all villagers – equally shared by both land holders and landless, thus the landed bought water beyond their share from the landless folks. The project gave increased yields in agriculture, protected forest cover, and reduced erosion. The dam and catchment management was undertaken by Hill Resource Management Societies (HRMS) and HRMS were set up in scores of villages in the region.

responsibilities.executing_agent: Local community members of the HRMS

evaluative_information.success_factors: community involvement, public, private and community participation and interaction, technical support, benefits received by  the community saving the resource, equitable sharing of resources (community involvement: The measure failed initially because of the lack of concern amongst the villagers about the water woes of the Chandigarh city, public, private and community participation and interaction: the integration amongst the three parties must be transparent and no individual or personal motives should exist that may hamper the sucess of the intervention, technical support: the intervention succeeded when technical expertise was provided by Mr. P.R. Mishra (environmentalist) to build tanks for increasing water storage, benefits received by  the community saving the resource: the community recieved benefits in the form of increased water storage and increased yields which acted as an incentive for them to conserve the watershed.)
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: The measure failed initially because of the lack of concern amongst the villagers about the water woes of the Chandigarh city.
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: win-win (environmental protection and conservation, resource availability, increased income, livelihood and food security, sustainable flow of environmental services)
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: the following benefits were observed (i) savings of upto US$ 0.2 million each year in dredging and other costs to the government, (ii) increased water for irrigation leading to an increase in wheat (0.68 tonnes/ha to 1.43 tonnes/ha) and maize (0.61 tonnes/ha to 1.22 tonnes/ha) production from the year 1977 to 1986, (iii) the annual household incomes went up from Rs 2000 to Rs 3000 between 1979 to 1984, (iv) the village now earns Rs 3,50,000 and 10,000 from the sale of collective milk and bhabar grass respectively, (v) tree density increased from 13 to 1292 trees/ha between 1977 to 1986, (vi) the forest has over 0.3 million Khair trees (Acacia catechu), each tree valued at Rs 3000 (US$ 70)

title: Support for the promotion and the broadcasting of underground irrigation using buried diffusers

overview.feedback: The objective of this project is to promote an innovative irrigation technology developed by the Institute of Arid Regions in Medenine (IRA) and industrialized by the company Chahtech - the buried diffuser. Compared to drip irrigation, this technology not only allows a significant saving of water, but also avoid fewer problems commonly found in arid regions (salinity, weed growth, etc.). It’s thus, a technology with a great potential in arid zones and in the current context of climate change in order to save resources and increase the productivity of irrigated and rainfed agriculture (via supplement irrigation during long drought periods).The company involved in this project is the Chahtech company. The role of GIZ consists in bringing according to the instrument PDSP a support for this company to promote this technology as an adaptation option to climate change.

responsibilities.executing_agent: GIZ with CHAHTECH

evaluative_information.success_factors: Costs of installations, availability of components on the local market
evaluative_information.limiting_factors:
Degree of acceptance of the farmers to the new technology
Sensitivity of farmers to water saving
Recognition of the technology and its eligible consideration in the subsidy
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: not specified
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: A raising awareness campaign of farmer to this new technology is involved through  a set of demonstration parcels and a monitoring work to assess the profitability of this technology with regard to other irrigation systems in terms of economy of water.

title: Supporting the implementation of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change in Tunisia (CCC/GIZ)

overview.feedback: This project is part of the German -Tunisian bilateral cooperation and is planned for a period of 9 years (2006-2014).The project is structured in three phases:•	Phase 1: 2006 to 2008•	Phase 2: 2009 to 2011•	Phase 3: 2012 to 2014During its 3rd phase, CCC/GIZ’s objective is to support Tunisia to ensure that mitigation and adaptation to climate change at national and regional level will be managed by good governance structures.This objective is to be achieved through three main components:1.	Vulnerability and Adaptation to Climate Change that aims to initiate the implementation of sectoral strategies for adaptation to climate change on the basis of best practices and appropriate management tools,2.	Mitigation of Climate Change that aims to support policy makers to adopt and start the implementation of new policies and mitigation measures,3.	Knowledge management on climate change that aims to make the Tunisian Government and all concerned partners, profit from experiences, information and achievements capitalized during the implementation of the  3 phases-project.

responsibilities.initiating_agent: Ministry of Environment and Sustainable Development
responsibilities.executing_agent: GIZ with Ministry of Environment and Sustainable Development and other partners
responsibilities.funding_source: German Ministry for Economic Cooperation and Development (BMZ)

evaluative_information.success_factors: Political context (transition)
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: Decision makers involvement
evaluative_information.synergies_to_mitigation: In the 2 first phases, the project has been working particularly on the CDM (capacity building, development of CDM projects and promotion of CDM projects). The 3rd phase is focusing on mitigation in general with a focus on development of NAMA in different sectors (Agriculture, forests, cement sector, etc) and capacity building of the concerned partners on the topic.
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: No regret and Win-Win option are part of set of innovative adaptation options to climate change identified and proposed in the framework of the project in the different sectors concerned.
evaluative_information.project_evaluation:
The project contributed to:
- Raise awareness of politics and decision makers on the challenges of climate change on the most vulnerable sectors in Tunisia
- Support the elaboration of 3 sectoral adaptation to CC strategies (agriculture including water resources and ecosystems, tourism, health),
- Support the elaboration of a National Strategy on Climate Change involving all concerned sectors (in phase of political validation)
- Carry out many vulnerability assessments of ecosystems and agro-systems to climate change
- Mainstreaming ACC into regional, local and project levels planning (Climate Proofing)
- Integrating CCA into local development plans. Adaptation of the methodology of elaboration of community development and adaptation plans at the local level.
- Setting up a CC adaptation M&E system at the national level leaded by OTEDD. The objective is to start working on the identification of ACC indicators in the agriculture sector as a pilot example built on the existing M&E system regarding this sector
- Capacity building of different target groups in the field of CC and ACC (Decision makers, technical institutions staff, NGOs, Universities, Research institutes etc.
• Develop and update a National Portfolio on adaptation to CC projects
• Elaborate a guide for Vulnerability assessment of ecosystems to CC
• Elaborate a guide for Economic Evaluation of Ecosystem goods and services
• Elaboration of a data catalogue system for Climate services and informations

title: Sustainable Livelihoods through Organic Farming

overview.feedback: The main objective of the project is to create livelihoods through organic farming by organizing farmer’s sanghams to cultivate certified seed which are marketed as truth labeled seeds (TFL). A total of 408.57 acres have been selected for input support and crop loan schemes. In addition farmer training sessions and exposure visits are also organised. Demonstration fields have been established in 24 acres in Kancheepuram, Dindigul, Nagapattinam and Ramanathapuram districts where various organic farming technologies like preparation and application of plant growth regulators, using pheromone traps and mechanical traps for pest control, preparation of vermicompost and compost, Azolla cultivation, collection and usage of cow’s urine, using farm ponds for irrigation etc. have been implemented. Infrastructure like a seed grading and processing unit, threshing yard and a training centre have been constructed and efforts are on to set up biopesticide and vermicompost production units in the beneficiary villages.

responsibilities.initiating_agent: NGO: Centre for Indian Knowledge Systems
responsibilities.executing_agent: NGO: Centre for Indian Knowledge Systems

evaluative_information.success_factors: training programmes, exposure visits, participation in agri exhibitions and fairs, conducting food festivals, capacity building of partner NGOs, recovery of yields for farmers
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: low initial returns from agriculture after conversion, initial start up cost
evaluative_information.synergies_to_mitigation: yes: use of vermicompost and biopesticide
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: no regret: low input agriculture and enhances nutrient value of soil
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: Organic seed production is in progress in 175.38 acres in Kancheepuram, Ramanathapuram, Dindigul and Nagapattinam districts. A total of 408.57 acres have been selected for input support and crop loan schemes. Under this component of organic seed production, certified organic seeds and truthfully labeled seeds (TFL) are being produced. Inputs like quality breeder seeds and foundation seeds of paddy varieties, groundnut, blackgram and sesame, organic inputs like green manure seeds, neem cake, biofertilizers, vermicompost and mechanical traps have been distributed to the beneficiaries.

additional_information: During the period of conversion to organic farmers require support in the form of quality inputs and crop loans for conversion. Under this component, a total of 410.04 acres have been identified from all the four districts for conversion to organic farming by providing input support and crop loan. Inputs like neem cake, biofertilizers, vermicompost and mechanical traps were distributed. Crop loans have been provided for the cultivation in 199.97 acres and for establishing vermicompost production units in Nagapattinam district.

title: Sustainable Management of Coastal Forest Ecosystems

overview.feedback: The Mekong Delta is particularly affected by the impacts of climate change. Rising sea levels and storms of increasing magnitude threaten the poor rural population, Viet Nam’s rice and shrimp production, and Ho Chi Minh City with increasing regularity.These hazards can be countered by improving coastal protection. Intact coastal forests attenuate the wind and waves and safeguard the embankments needed to protect the low-lying, extensive Mekong delta against inundation.The project advises and supports the provincial Agencies in the development of protective mechanisms for the coastal zone, the management and rehabilitation of the mangrove forests, and the development of implementation mechanisms. In order to improve coastal protection, coastal forests in Bac Lieu Province are being afforested and restored. Conservation zones for mangrove forests administered jointly by the local population and the provincial government are being established. At the same time, the economic situation of coastal populations is being improved. The people thus become less dependent upon the coastal forests and can use these more sustainably. In addition, local government staffs are being trained and relevant institutions are being strengthened.

responsibilities.initiating_agent: German Federal Ministry for the Environment, Nature Conservation and Nuclear Safety (BMU)
responsibilities.executing_agent: Deutsche Gesellschaft für Technische Zusammenarbeit (GTZ), Eschborn / Hanoi, Department of Agriculture and Rural Development, Bac Lieu Province
responsibilities.funding_source: German Federal Ministry for the Environment, Nature Conservation and Nuclear Safety (BMU)

evaluative_information.success_factors: The response of the people involved and the local government.
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: The lack of cooperation mechanism for integrating sustainable management and the use of natural resources, as well as overlapping competencies among various offices and economic interests (shrimp farms).
evaluative_information.synergies_to_mitigation: Yes, through carbon sequestration by the mangroves.
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option:
Win-Win option:
- Storm surge-wave and erosion prevention
- Economic development, improve income for people
evaluative_information.project_evaluation:
The project is under running.
- The expected results are:
+ The GTZ organisation will invest 300 million VND to build the first nursery breeding trees for mangrove forests in Bac Lieu province. The trees will be planted in the bird sanctuary and coastal forests, part of the project.
+ 60 hectares of mangroves forest will be planted this year.
So far, the project has demonstrated the positive impact for adapting to climate change of the community.

additional_information: The project contributes to the conservation of climate-relevant biodiversity. A review is also under way of the extent to which restoring biodiversity in coastal zones may contribute to adapting to climate change impacts. Successful approaches may also be implemented in other provinces of the Mekong delta. The project further contributes to improving the living conditions of the rural population.

title: Sustainable management of water and soil: knowledge and tools to improve resilience to climate change and to reduce vulnerability

overview.feedback: The objective of the project is the implementation of adaptation measures along with the community, preparing their members them to climate change effects. In this sense, with financial support from the CBA, we will help the people of the communities of Moro Moro, Alto Veladero (Vallegrande Province, City of Santa Cruz), to understand, prevent and improve their ability to adapt to the impacts of climate change and reduce their vulnerability, providing to Santa Cruz valleys our protection initiatives of environmental services. The project will focus on sustainable management of forest resources to protect native species, soils, and ecosystem services (flood, erosion, and landslide protection) from climate change risks. It will compliment baseline activities by reforesting key hydrological capture zones and areas at risk from increasing erosion pressures.  The project will also directly target community awareness and adaptive capacity through an aggressive outreach and training component, while sharing lessons with neighboring municipalities.

title: Sustainable practices for the cultivation of cherimoya

overview.feedback: The project aims to reduce the vulnerability of the agriculture and fishing productive system of two communities, Oconi and Pie de la Cuesta located within the ecosystem of the xeromorphic forest of Saipina, by contributing environment’s conservation, regulation of water system and the improvement of food security.The beneficiaries of the project will be reached through a training, action, spreading of knowledge and technology development program that will try to identify the factors that affect their productive conditions. To achieve this, it is intended to improve and set up a cherimoya (a native Andes-highland fruit) garden, using agroforestry techniques that will allow for the conservation and proper use of lands, using contour lines and terraces techniques. Furthermore, it will be created several norms to regulate water use in the communities of the medium and higher sites of the basin, as well as norms on sustainable use of natural resources. These norms will be strengthened through bylaws from the two municipalities that share the basin.

responsibilities.executing_agent: NGO Fundación Amigos de la Naturaleza (FAN), local Authorities

evaluative_information.success_factors: The two communities are dependent on the volume of water of the Oconi River, to water the inhabitants’ smallholdings. Because of this, in years where the precipitation is lower than normal, the River may almost run dry (from August to September), jeopardizing the production of the inhabitants.
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: The present project will have to face a couple of obstacles, most of them domestic. They are related to working with the beneficiaries on a new subject that has still to be worked on intensively so that they come to fully understand it.
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: No regret
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: The cherimoya production system has been improved (making it more resistant to climate pressures) in the Oconi and Pie de la Cuesta communities, through the improvement and setting up of gardens with agroforestry systems. Beneficiaries conscious and trained on adaptation to climate change, through sustainable land and water use practices. The communities of the Oconi basin and the Saipina and Comarapa Municipalities have created local norms that promote adaptation to climate change.

additional_information: The beneficiaries are nine families of the Pie de la Cuesta community and four families from the Oconi community. During the meetings that were organized to the present, up to 50% of the women participated; however, when it comes to committing to the project, most of them prefer if their husbands appear as beneficiaries, because most of them await for their husband’s or companion’s support before following an initiative.

title: System of Rice Intensification in selected Madhya Pradesh Rural Livelihoods project (MPRLP) districts

overview.feedback: SRI (System of Rice Intensification) is a package of practices for cultivating rice which use less seed, water, and chemical fertilizers and more bio-fertilizers. There is more spacing between the seeds and saplings are transplanted, and flood irrigation is not practiced. This can enhancing rice productivity even under climate change.The basic concepts of SRI: • Use young seedlings to preserve mature plants growth potential.• Avoid trauma to the roots• Give plants optimally wider spacing.• Keep paddy soil sufficiently moist but not continuously flooded mostly aerobic and not saturated.• Actively aerate the soil.• Enhance soil organic matter.The total cost of production with conventional techniques comes to Rs 2695 per hectare, as compared to Rs 3065 under SRI technology.In the eastern district of Dindori under MPRLP, under SRI intervention, there has been a sharp increase in the percentage of farmers with surplus rice from 51% to 81% after introduction of SRI. There are 907 BPL households who reported to have had surplus rice to provide 3  square meals a day.

responsibilities.executing_agent: MPRLP

evaluative_information.success_factors: transplanting labor, bio fertiliser, technical advice
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: Erratic and heavy rains, labour availability, quality seeds, irrigation facility.
evaluative_information.synergies_to_mitigation: Yes: use of bio pesticides and less water demands less energy
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: Win-Win:Even in non drought years this techniques is low input
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: The SRI technique was introduced in the MPRLP in the year 2006-07 in 4 of their rice producing districts when the project felt the need for enhancing productivity in the resource poor areas. SRI was promoted on large scale through demonstrations, organizing training, field visits with active involvement of farmer’s, project facilitators and people’s representatives. Seeing the initial success farmers started adopting this technique with the help of project team. In 25 blocks in 4 districts the land cultivated under conventional method is around 1,633,329.67 acre. More than 189,594 households of 1505 villages grow paddy through conventional technique. In these 25 blocks, the SRI is practiced by 10181 households spread over 641 villages and 8924 acrea of area. An input output analysis of the conventional method of rice cultivation and SRI, the yield increase from an average of 15 to 36 quintals per ha or 140%. The gross return (@ Rs 800/quintal of paddy) is Rs 12000 under conventional practise and Rs 28800 after SRI and the cost of cultivation is Rs 2695 under conventionel method and Rs 3065 under SRI method, so the net returns are Rs 9305 and Rs 25735 respectively – an increase of over 170%

additional_information: SRI can play an important role in enhancing rice productivity, maintaining soil fertility with well ecosystem preservation . It is water saving (by 25-50%) and seed saving (by 50-80%) besides increased yield (at least 25-50% but usually over 100%). The location specific changes should be made and permitted while promotion and popularization of SRI. Theses changes would facilitate the farmers for quick adoption on larger area.

title: The Chouka System -  A soil and moisture conservation technique

overview.feedback: The chouka or square system is a soil and moisture conservation technique applied primarily in degraded pasture lands of moderate slope in Rajasthan.  The technique involves digging a checkerboard network of shallow recessed squares a few metres in length and under 1ft deep with an overall bund on the three lower sides in a U-shape  along moderate sloped plains.  A 2 km by 1.5 km area of pastureland would have choukas dug around the edge of the area with two foot high bunds creating a barrier surrounding the field. Each Choukha fills with water and excess flows to the next interconnected chaukha and so on. This system retains soil moisture beyond the monsoon to rejuvenate dry pasture lands and capture and divert rain water for ground water recharge and future use into low lying water tanks and ponds. The system is suitable for arid and semi-arid areas.  The choukas have enabled the conversion of dry wastelands to fodder rich areas and has also helped increase the diversity of medicinal herbs and avian fauna.

responsibilities.executing_agent: GMVNL (Gram Vikas Navyuvak Mandal Laporiya), Community members
responsibilities.funding_source: Community members, Self and multiple funding sources

evaluative_information.success_factors: Environmental: Topography of the region is very important, the system works well only when the land has some degree of slope
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: Extensive soil work, requires considerable labour to undertake and better suited to moderate areas with minimum slope to 4% slope. Not applicable in undulating, sand dunes and hilly areas.
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: Win-win: the system has been made keeping in mind the variability in rainfall and drought pattern of the region. It has not only provided the resources the method was sought for (fodder and water) but has also improved the economic status of the farmers, social welfare and has also helped in conservation of soil.
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: The project has been implemented in parts of Gujarat and Afghanistan based on its effectiveness to conserve water and provide fodder resources

title: The Ho Chi Minh City (HCMC) Adaptation to Climate Change

overview.feedback: This is a sub-project of Climate Change Impact and Adaptation of Coastal Cities Study. Four Asian coastal cities were selected for the study, including Ho Chi Minh City (HCMC), Bangkok, Manila and Kolkata. HCMC is located on the estuary of the Saigon – Dong Nai River system. A significant part of HCMC is regularly flooded due to a combination of tides, storm surge, rains, floods, and man-made structures. HCMC is recognized as a city at risk of the effects of climate change – it has been identified as one of the ten cities most likely to be severely affected. The study included 4 steps: 1) Baseline Information 2) Modelling of climate change and and its effect on the hydrology 3) Impact assessment 4) Adaptation options identification and proposal.The project objectives are as follows:(i)	Assessment of the current knowledge base, including historical climate information, coping strategies, and local capacity to deal with natural disasters related to floods, cyclones, and tides (ii)	Identify potential climate change scenarios (iii)	Identification of the most vulnerable coastal and urban resources (iv)	Assessment and quantification of the likely magnitude of effects on social, environmental and economic resources expected due to climate change and variability(v)	Identification and assessment of appropriate alternative intervention scenarios, and prioritization of suitable interventions (vi)	Analysis of the capacity of relevant government agencies to implement identified interventions and provide appropriate recommendations

responsibilities.initiating_agent: The  People’s Committee of Ho Chi Minh City
responsibilities.executing_agent: International Centre for Environmental Management  in collaboration with  The  People’s Committee of Ho Chi Minh City

evaluative_information.success_factors:
Successful uptake of recommendations.
Government needs to implement and mainstream on adaptation plan accordingly
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: not specified
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: Strengthening of capacities of organizations, institutions and policies to deal with climate change
evaluative_information.project_evaluation:
The project assessed the current knowledge and coping strategies for floods, storm surge, cyclones, and tides; identified potential scenarios that could affect coastal watersheds; identified vulnerable infrastructure and communities; quantified the magnitude of climate impacts on social, environmental, and economic resources; prioritized adaptive scenarios within current institutional frameworks; and looked at government capacity to manage natural disasters and climate shocks.
Policy and practice have been informed by researchers. It improved the knowledge of levels of vulnerability and policy driven opportunities of adaptability in sectors and areas that will require adaptation plans and guidance as a framework for integration.

additional_information:
The study assessed the impact and vulnerability with linking estimates of threat to potential socio-economic and environmental impacts of climate change on areas, sectors and communities in the Ho Chi Minh City by 2050; identified those which are vulnerable; undertook an economic analysis; identified adaptation options and priorities by defining what needs to be done, by whom and when to reduce the risks of climate change and recommended for integration with development planning by defining next steps for integration of adaptation measures into sector and city development plans, policies, procedures, design standards, budgets, and projects.
Research findings were communicated at stakeholder workshops.

title: The Radio and Internet Project (RANET)

overview.feedback: The Radio and Internet Project (RANET) enhanced collection and dissemination of early warning and climate information at the local level. Using a computer connected to the internet, the project provided timely information on climate and other development information for the people in the district. While the Internet is not an option in many parts of rural Africa, RANET uses wind-up or solar powered radios to deliver satellite radio broadcasts to remote areas. Not only does RANET provide access to weather and climate information, it also enables remote communities to share information with Africans in other regions. The information enabled the local population to prepare for potential droughts and to take the climate forecast into account when making decisions.

responsibilities.executing_agent: Department of Meteorology, World Vision
responsibilities.funding_source: Meteo-France, the UK Met Office, the National Meteorological Service of Spain, the French Embassy of Niger, the United States Embassy of Niger, FAO, UNDP, SNV

evaluative_information.success_factors: Needed equipment is Computer, World Space Modem, World Space Receiver and Antenna. Existing structures could be helpful to disseminate the information.
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: Specific local forecast are very difficult and requires local maximum temperatures and wind speeds. Meteorologists should take efforts to improve on the farmer’s knowledge to build their capacity to make local specific forecasts.
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: No-regret.
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: The practice succeeded in collecting and disseminating climate information to local farming communities in a timely manner. In the case of RANET project, the local communities in 17 parishes of Nakasongola district benefited from the practice. This was possible because of the easy access to weather information through the Internet, and the established local structures for interpretation and dissemination of the information. The timely dissemination of information enabled the local population to improve the state of drought preparedness and food security.

additional_information: RANET hopes to equip villagers with the technology and skills to send e-mails to it's upload site, which will then be re-broadcast as text messages to mobile devices. Similar efforts are planned in South and Southeast Asia.

title: Towards Defining the WRC Research Portfolio on Climate Change for 2008-2013

overview.feedback: The growth in awareness of global-change issues as a result of IPCC studies and reports has introduced a new and rapidly evolving focus for climate and atmosphere research in the past decade. This necessitates redefining climate-related, and particularly global climate change-related research thrusts and programmes that the Water Research Commission of South Africa (WRC) supports on behalf of the water sector. Perhaps the largest change is the need for such research to be integrated into a larger body of climate-change research nationally, which embraces a multi-sectoral, multi-level approach in order to deal with multiple stresses and enable the country to successfully face up to challenges that climate change is expected to pose over coming decades.This document sets out the background against which the development of a climate change research portfolio with a water-sector focus was initiated and pursued, with the assistance of a wide complement of stakeholders.

title: Traditional farming practices in Tunisian cork oak forests and adaptation to climate change

overview.feedback: Forest people living in the Kroumirie Mogods region experienced difficult weather conditions particularly during the years 1987-1990. To cope with this situation of long period drought, local people have adopted some practices, spontaneously. Surveys conducted in some selected areas among forest series considered vulnerable to highly vulnerable to Climate Change, showed a change in the attitude of people towards the use of natural resources: temporary migration, agricultural practices and livestock access to new information and communication technologies. This is likely to improve the adaptability of these populations to the impacts of climate change and increase their resilience. It is the same for forest ecosystems, considering the decrease of pressure on them and the services they provide will have time to recover in order to cope with the impacts of climate change.

title: Training Future Experts on Climate Change and Poverty

overview.feedback: A gender balanced group of twenty local academic and non-academic researchers and key government officials will attend an intensive four week training course. After the course, four of the most qualified participants of the training course will conduct full-time research for six months. The research topics will cover climate risk management and poverty in communities in Aceh and contribute to the overall research theme.This thorough training will enable the researchers to provide information and policy advice on climate change and poverty to the local government, as well as map the future challenges of Aceh in relation to these issues.

evaluative_information.project_evaluation: The research will provide firsthand analysis of the current poverty situation and how the local population in Aceh experience climate risks and respond to these. At the end of the project the research results will be presented in a public seminar where key-stakeholders will be invited to discuss findings. The research results will further be published in a collection of articles. Finally, the project will result in a full size technical and financial proposal for a three year research training program on climate risk management and poverty in Indonesia.
