title: Treadle Pump Programme

overview.feedback: 'Treadle Pump' is a foot operated water lifting device that can irrigate small plots of land of small holders in regions that have higher water table (not deeper than 25 feet). A low cost system, simple in design and easily manageable it appropriately answers the irrigation need for the small farmers. With an internal rate of return of 100% and a benefit cost ratio of 5, 'Treadle Pump' is an ideal investment for small land holders whose savings are as small as $12 to $15. The project is located in the Indian provinces Uttar Pradesh, Bihar, West Bengal and Orissa.IDEI has established a reliable manufacturing base for producing good quality pumps.

project_costs.maintenance_costs: yes,"The valve and washers to be replaced gbp

responsibilities.executing_agent: NGO-IDE
responsibilities.funding_source: multiple sources and user financing of product

evaluative_information.success_factors: "Institutional:reliable manufacturing base for producing good quality pumps, effort required to use should be low, wide distribution marketing and repair network, adequate demand for the pump, involvement of multiple players.
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: absence of distribution network, dip in water table would make it unusable, lack of technical support
evaluative_information.synergies_to_mitigation: low consumption of energy: foot operated water lifting device
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: win win, low energy efficient water pumping device for areas with high water table
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: The cost of a treadle pump and tube well is about Rs 1,200 to 1,300 (£14 to £15), A study has suggested that the annual income of a family has risen by Rs 11,000 (£130) on average as a result of using a treadle pump. This represents a substantial increase since the annual income for many farming families in this region is as low as Rs 7,000. Many farmers have doubled their income, and a few have seen it rise ten-fold. Farmers can easily pay back the Rs 1,200 to 1,300 cost of the pump from their increased earnings.Use of treadle pump allows farmers to cultivate all the year round thus increasing their cropping intensity to 200-300%,and never leave their land fallow.The income impact of the Treadle Pump technology varies across households and regions, but US$100 per year is the conservative estimate of the average increase in the annual net income of each household. Since inception in 1991, around 750,000 treadle pumps have been adopted by small holder farm families.

additional_information: From year 2000 IDE have embarked on a gradual phase-out programme, based on mutual trust between IDEI and its approved manufacturers to ensure quality assurance of treadle pumps. The phase-out programme involves imparting training to the manufacturers and other IDEI channel partners so that they are able to thoroughly grasp and inculcate a high degree of quality consciousness, especially in the context of strict issuance of warranty cards and instruction manual to the farmers and their empowerment for demanding quick replacement of defective pumps.

title: Van Panchayats

overview.feedback: The Van Panchayats is a Community Forest Management in Uttarakhand emerged from the conflict between the people and the Forest department over the use of the forest resources. VPs were formed after notification of the Van Panchayat Rules, in 1931 and today there a total of 12089 VPs (Uttarakhand Forest Statistics 2008-09) managing a forest area of approximately 5449.642 sq. km. These Van Panchayats help in protecting the forest area close to villages and also in the equitable sharing of the resources among the stakeholders. Projects implemented by various agencies with these VPs help strengthen these institutions and manage forest resources.

project_costs.maintenance_costs: yes, cost of management of the van panchayats gbp

responsibilities.executing_agent: local government, people and NGOs

evaluative_information.success_factors: Community cohesion to form and manage VP. Seem to work better in oak forest areas which provide leaf litter and fodder inputs into the agro-economy.
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: Areas with community conflicts make it hard to form and manange Van Panchayats. Require some financial inputs for regular forest management, which is rarely available.
evaluative_information.synergies_to_mitigation: management of local forests by VPs can improve carbon sequestration
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: win-win option, helps in sustainable management and conservation of forests by the local user groups
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: the success of this institutional arrangement can be judged by the number of van panchayats that have been formed, mostly on demand by the community, from 1931 till date, and covering 13.63% of the states' forest cover. By incentivising local communities to manage their own forest for their own long term benefits, they elicit local investment, mostly in kind, for protection, regulation of harvesting, fire fighting, etc. VPs are also involved in afforestation and reforestation activities in their forest. In recent years the FD has taken steps to re-engage with VPs and also form Joint Forest Management groups and there has been some concern about the erosion of VP autonomy.

additional_information: Various programs are being implemeted in different Van Panchayats. One such successful program is running in 15 Van Panchayats in the Almora district of Uttarakhand;Strengthening Rural Community Managed Natural Resource Institutions (Van Panchayats) for enhancing rural livelihood in Uttarakhand which aims at developing income generating activities, conserve the globally significant biodiversity, reduce women drudgery. enhancement in natural resource based rural livelihood.

title: Vietnam Coastal Zone Vulnerability Assessment and First Steps towards Integrated Coastal Zone Management

overview.feedback: This project assessed the vulnerability of the entire coastal zone of Vietnam to the effects of sea-level rise and identified and prioritised risk reduction options including legal/institutional, economic/financial, technical, biological, physical and infrastructure options and developed an approach for integrated coastal zone management in Vietnam. The focus of this project was to support, guide and strengthen Vietnamese capabilities in facing the complex technical , institutional and organizational matters involved in the effective management of the Vietnamese coastal zone.Therefore the project used GIS (Geographic information systems) analysis which determined areas of different land-use types inundated by various flood scenarios. And provided loss and risk figures for land use types, population and capital value, reviewed and implications analyzed future development trends as well as institutional, organizational arrangements for coastal zone management.The findings supported the implementation of a integrated coastal zone management project that time was being planned.

responsibilities.initiating_agent: Hydrometeorological Service of Vietnam and The General Deparment of International Cooperation of The Netherlands Ministery of Foreign Affairs
responsibilities.executing_agent: The Maria Hydrometeorological Centre of Vietnam and Frederic R Harris and Delft Hydraulics of the Netherlands

evaluative_information.success_factors: Mainstreaming the results findings to the coastal zone management planning.
evaluative_information.limiting_factors:
- Lack of awareness of climate change issues.
- The constrain of financial resources
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: not specified
evaluative_information.project_evaluation:
The project has created momentum to strengthen the cooperation between authorities on national, provincial, district and local level on coastal management. As such the project has evolved from a climate change-orientated analysis towards a broader scope of development problems in the coastal zone.
-Recommendations have been made with associated actions to strengthen local capabilities for Coastal Zone Management. It has thereby contributed to the awareness of the need for ICZM.
- Three pilot studies identified typical concrete issues and problems as bellows:
The coastal sediment deficits (Nam Dinh), sustainable aquaculture development (Thua Thien-Hue), sustainable harbour development (Ba ria Vung tau) and producing dike safety standards and design manuals for coastal defence.
- Research findings were communicated at stakeholder workshops and the project received extensive media coverage.

additional_information: Pilot studies were conducted at the three sites: Nam Dinh province (sea dyke erosion), Thua Thien-Hue province (Flooding and Lagoon management) and Ba ria-Vung tau province (Coastal Management and Planning).

title: Vulnerability and Adaptation experiences from Rajasthan and  Andhra Pradesh

overview.feedback: The program aims at strengthening the resilience of local communities to conditions of unfavorable weather, like adverse alterations in temperature and precipitation leading to more frequent occurrence of drought and to use the experiences for policy development processes at various level. The 3 specific objectives of the program were:•   To build community level capacities with regard to best practices and technologies in  the agriculture, water and energy sectors. •   To optimize the service delivery system and services at selected sites in semi-arid areas  in India. •  To promote policy dialogue and advocacy at different levels.The project in located in the Indian provinces Rajasthan and Andrah Pradesh.

responsibilities.executing_agent: NGOs and technical institutes

evaluative_information.success_factors: Institutional: Training and skill development on location specific adaptation measures and management of weather abnormalities, mainstreaming gender considerations,  and education and social mobilization, Technical support on new irrigation technologies, climate proofing
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: Weak community institutions, reluctance to change cropping pattern and type
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: No regret as the project helps in increasing the resilience of communities to the impacts of climate change
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: The project has highlighted  the need for location specific adaptation measures and for participatory research and knowledge management. The V&A interventions have also highlighted the need for mainstreaming gender considerations in all interventions. Women will suffer more from Climate Change, since they have been traditionally in charge of collecting water, fodder and fuel wood, and have been shouldering the responsibility for farm animal care and post-harvest technology. All interventions should therefore be pro-nature, pro-poor and pro-women.

title: Vulnerability Assessment and Adaptation to Climate Change-Agriculture Sector

overview.feedback: The focus of the project is primarily on agriculture sector, accounting for a large part of the income generated in the state. A vulnerability assessment will be carried out for the community in terms of important agricultural crops produced in the state. The findings will be used to develop adaptation strategies in consultation with the different stakeholders and a cost-benefit analysis of a climate change adaptation plan will be prepared for the state. The project outcomes will be the identification of agro-climatic zone specific impacts for two main crops, wheat and soyabean; the impact of climate change on production of the two crops, profile of categories of people based on their adaptive capacity; various factors that are likely to impact these categories and to what degree; draft policy goal for adaptation in agriculture sector, assessment of adaptation options and prioritising the options along with their time lines.

title: Vulnerability Assessment of Kolkata metropolitan area to increased precipitation in a Changing Climate

overview.feedback: This study aims to strengthen the understanding of the vulnerability of Kolkata from increased precipitation caused by climate change effects by developing hydrological, hydraulic, and storm drainage models to identify vulnerable areas and assessing monetary, social, and environmental impacts resulting from such climate change events. It then suggests adaptation proposals and mitigation options as well as local capacity building such that the planning process can take into account climate change threats in Calcutta

evaluative_information.limiting_factors: appropriate data, multidisciplinary team

evaluative_information.project_evaluation: The study has come out with: modeling results such as vulnerable wards to climate change, loss likely to occur, soft and hard adaptation measures such as investing in hard urban services including roads, traffic, water supply, storm water and sewage channels, electricity and telecommunications and that recognized the importance of open space, and green areas as an integral part of city development and investing in soft infrastructure such as- strengthening of disaster management and preparedness for both pre and post disaster situations.

additional_information: Among the suggested adaptation measures, a number of projects are either currently under way or are planned for future implementation in KMA under the Jawaharlal Nehru National Urban Renewal Mission (JNNURM) and the Kolkata Environmental Improvement Project (KEIP)scheme funded by ADB. title: Vulnerability of Andean Communities against climate change

overview.feedback: The assessment had two general objectives: (1) Identify all the vulnerabilities of Agricultural Producers of the watershed study in terms of how they perceive their exposures, sensitivities and adaptive capacity to climate change and water problems induced by climate. (2) Understanding the role of an organization and its processes of decision making in relation to water stress and climate, including identificatory factors that facilitate or hinder adaptation to changing conditions and how they do it (past, present, future). The methodology was a qualitative, with descriptive and interpretive approach. Strategies for data collection included individual and group interviews and participatory strategies such as discussion groups, forums, workshops, seminars and consulting experts.

responsibilities.initiating_agent: Project financed by IAI (Inter American Institute). Prior approval
responsibilities.executing_agent: Technical equipment NGO Sustainable Water
responsibilities.funding_source: Project financed by IAI (Inter American Institute).

evaluative_information.success_factors: not specified
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: not specified
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: not specified
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: The results demonstrate that the vulnerabilities of the agricultural sector in the three basins are heterogeneous, but share common themes closely linked to both climate scenarios and water availability as geographic location and topography of the communities (that determine the access or not to build artificial systems of irrigation water) and cultural resources and institutions that govern the use, access and distribution of water resources and soil. Adaptive capacities of the sector - despite facing significant challenges that are associated with climate scenarios predict further rise in average temperatures and decreased water availability - exhibit interesting social and cultural arrangements formal and informal.

additional_information: The research indicates that a higher level of development and more robust institutional frameworks, as in the cases of Argentina and Chile did not mean a greater capacity for climate adaptation in the case of Bolivia. Vulnerabilities to climate change and the resulting adaptations are mediated by processes dependent on socio-cultural context.

title: Vulnerability to Climate Change and Adaptation Assessment (VCCAA), known as KRAPI (Kajian Risiko dan Adaptasi Perubahan Iklim)

overview.feedback: Vulnerability to Climate Change and Adaptation Assessment (VCCAA), known as KRAPI (Kajian Risiko dan Adaptasi Perubahan Iklim), is a multi-hazard and multi-sector climate risk assessment, which provides the basis for developing and selecting appropriate adaption measures, and a process to mainstream these adaptation measures into existing development policies. The adaptation approach comprises a process of identifying and projecting climate risks, climate trend analysis, current and projected hazard analysis, dynamic vulnerability assessment, and baseline and future risk analysis. Identification of adaptation options is based on results of the climate risk assessment under consideration of specific features of the target area. Main outputs are risk maps as support tools for decision-makers as well as a list of adaptation options agreed upon by involved stakeholders and mainstreamed into the development policies.

responsibilities.initiating_agent: Ministry of Environment, Republic of Indonesia
responsibilities.executing_agent: Ministry of Environment in collbaoratium with the local governments

evaluative_information.success_factors:
Due to its high resource intensity, the project is especially applicable to other provinces and districts/cities if support is being provided, e.g. by the national institutions.
Support from institutions that hold climate data and vulnerability data is necessary.
Specific expertise is required for climate trend and hazard analyses
evaluative_information.limiting_factors:
The implementation of the project requires a large amount of data that may not always be available or accessible. Support from institutions that hold data is necessary.
Specific expertise is required for climate trend and hazard analyses. Experts might not be available in universities and institutions of excellence to the extent necessary
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: The project envisions long-term disaster risk reduction spatial development planning
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: The impacts depend on the willingness local governments to integrate study results into their development plan. Some local governments of the study areas, e.g. the provincial governments of Nusa Tenggara Barat (Lombo island),  already integrate the results into their sectoral development plan

additional_information: The project shows an excellent example of mainstreaming adaptation process into the local government’s development plan. However, its high resource intensity to conduct the project, and lack of experts limit its implementation.

title: Vulnerability, Coping and Adaptation within the context of climate change and HIV/ AIDS

overview.feedback: The Project looks at multiple stressors, specifically health and environment issues, and how these are impacted by changes in climatic conditions in order to identify and implement appropriate community-based adaptation practices through a social learning approach.The main objectives of the project are: - to increase the understanding of the complex inter-relationships between climate change, HIV/AIDS, vulnerability and food security, and adaptation responses within the Eastern Cape; - to support the identification and implementation of community-based adaptation practices though a social learning research process; - to develop partnerships and constituencies to help bring about relevant change to policy and practice; - to build capacity amongst multiple stakeholders, from students to municipal officials and community members, to understand the complex processes around vulnerability and the ability to cope and adapt with multiple livelihood stressors.Activities include:•Stakeholder workshops•Liaison with different stakeholders (NGOs, municipalities)•Integration of project strategies into IDPS•Research team is acting as facilitators that assist the communities in building their resilienceThe project is located in three communities near Queenstown, Eastern Cape, South Africa.

responsibilities.initiating_agent: Department of Environmental Science Rodes University South Africa) in partnership with University of Alberta (Canada)
responsibilities.executing_agent: Department of Environmental Science Rodes University South Africa) in partnership with University of Alberta (Canada)

evaluative_information.success_factors:
•Ability to engage the different stakeholder groups
•Champions in the communities
•Willingness of local government to engage with projects and communities
•Ownership by communities and local government
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: Lack of political will
evaluative_information.synergies_to_mitigation: Maybe, as the approach taken in the project is ‘mitigation for adaptation’ (e.g. promoting the use of bio gass by municipalities)
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: Measures contribute to improvment of economic development, health care, empowerment of rural communities and the strengthening of institutions.
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: Not yet possible as the project just started.

additional_information:
a)How has climate change information or climate science been considered in the design and implementation of the project?
IPCC studies and other related literature review have been considered in the design of the project and in the identification of the communities. A main challenge is that very little downscaling data for the Eastern Cape currently exist.

title: Wadi program

overview.feedback: Wadi is an integrated tribal development and poverty alleviation program initiated by BAIF- DHRUVA. The “Wadi” model of tribal development is holistic in approach addressing production, processing and marketing of the agri horti produce, and thus improving incomes.The critical inputs for the wadi programme include grafted mango saplings, vermi-compost and technical know-how for soil and water conservation and protective irrigation. The other development interventions includes required measures for soil conservation in the wadis, water resource development by digging wells, creating farm ponds, gully plugging and permanent check dams to ensure protective irrigation during the gestation period. The program began with 42 families in 1982 at Vansda, today the tribal development programme covers more than 23,000 families in three blocks of South Gujarat. Huge tracts of wastelands have been converted into orchards.

responsibilities.executing_agent: NGO:BAIF

evaluative_information.success_factors: technical know how, soil and moisture conservation, availability of fruit saplings
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: dysfunctional SHGs, absence of market linkages, no value addition
evaluative_information.synergies_to_mitigation: yes: vermi compost and organic agriculture methods
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: no regret/win win: no regret: Irrespective of climate change the livelihood options generated, protective irrigation measures will help the communities to enhance their income, win win: income from sale and procesing of fruits and irrigation measures will help cope with the impacts of climate change
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: The program began with 42 families in 1982 at Vansda, today the tribal development programme covers more than 23,000 families in three blocks of South Gujarat. Huge tracts of wastelands have been converted into orchards. Some acheivements of the program have been: livelihood prmotion and conservation of natural resources, reduction in migration, shift to commercial crops, increase in cropping intensity, processing of cashew and mango, improved health and sanitation, capacity building of women’s SHGs, adoption of Wadi model by families that were not participating earlier.

additional_information: His Excellency Dr. A.P.J. Abdul Kalam visited the tribal development cluster in Kaprada and Chonda is a significant landmark in the history of Dhruva. The President took keen interest in visiting the Wadis, food processing unit and interacting closely with the participants in our programme during this visit.

title: Waru waru

overview.feedback: Waru Waru is an agricultural technique developed in South America around 300 B.C.The project has introduced an ancient cultivation, irrigation and drainage system that made poor land productive: land with high salinity levels and poor drainage located in an area with frequent droughts and frost. The project involves the restoration of earthworks about one meter high and 10 to 15 meters wide. These are surrounded by wide, shallow canals which, when filled with water, ensure a microclimate that acts as a buffer against night-time frosts and provides moisture during droughts and drainage during the rainy season. The canals also act as barriers to keep out crawling insect pests.

responsibilities.executing_agent: Care Peru, local communities

evaluative_information.success_factors: The amount of labour initially required to restore a waru waru can be a discouraging factor. This is why the project, during the first year, offered farmers tools and seeds as an incentive.
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: not specified
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: not specified
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: The practice increases the value of unused, flood-prone lands, as well as helping to reduce the damage caused by drought and frost. Experience shows that the minimum night-time temperatures reached in waru waru areas are two to three degrees centigrade higher than those of the surrounding plains. The moisture provided by the canals lowers the impact of sporadic droughts during the cycle and, in the rainy season, prevents the subsoil from becoming waterlogged by ensuring adequate drainage. Crop yields, in particular yields of potatoes and other Andean tubers, are 50% to 100% higher than the yields obtained using traditional farming techniques.

additional_information: The results of the system could be improved if crops, including pastures, were rotated on a long-term basis.

title: Water harvesting and forest deferrer (silvopastoral)

overview.feedback: This project includes: (a) diversification of agriculture (Promotion of salt tolerant rice varieties and other crops); (b) homestead-based forestry, horticulture and vegetable cultivation; (c) promotion of integrated rice, shrimp and fish culture; (d) pro-poor brackish water aquaculture; (e) identifcation of livelihood options and activities for women and marginal groups; (f) small entrepreneurship development based on local resources such as bee-keeping; (g) rainwater harvest and sweet water conservation for drinking and domestic; (h) sweet water conservation and efficient use for irrigation to agriculture; (i) preparedness for disaster risk (cyclone, tidal surge and sea level rise) reduction to save lives, properties and household assets; and (j) promotion of coastal afforestation for protection river bank erosion, prevent cyclone damages, etc.

title: Water Management Pilot Project: Improved Management of Extreme Events Through Ecosystem-Based Adaptation in Watersheds

overview.feedback: Thailand’s water management institutions are lacking expertise and concepts to deal with increased drought and flooding from climate change, creating risk for people in catchment areas. The project introduces experiences gained from pilot projects in the Chi and Tha Di basins to national adaptation planners, and aims to improve cooperation between them and water management institutions on the national level. The goal is to foster an ecosystem-based approach in Thai adaptation to climate change.For this end, we advise resource managers in catchment areas to create integrated, basin-level information management platforms for themselves and include existing stakeholder platforms (River Basin Management Committees) in designing water resource management plans.

responsibilities.initiating_agent: Karlsruhe Institute of Technology, Germany;Khon Kaen University, Thailand;-	German Federal Ministry for the Environment, Nature Conservation and Nuclear Safety (BMU)
responsibilities.executing_agent: GIZ; Department of Water Resources of Thailand; -	Royal Irrigation Department; Khon Kaen University;Kalailak University
responsibilities.funding_source: German Federal Ministry for the Environment, Nature Conservation and Nuclear Safety (BMU); third parties

evaluative_information.success_factors:
- Political will on the Thai side to improve management of extreme events and provide funding for pilot projects
- Continued relevance of local partner institutions
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: Water governance in Thailand is being restructured and possibly more centralised, posing a risk that our current local partner institutions are weakened
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: Improvement of general education and awareness in Thailand via inclusion of two universities

title: Weather based crop Insurance Scheme

overview.feedback: Weather Based Crop Insurance (WBCI) aims to mitigate the hardship of the insured farmers against the likelihood of financial loss on account of anticipated crop loss resulting from incidence of adverse conditions of weather parameters like rainfall, temperature, frost, humidity etc.The Ministry of Agriculture has sanctioned Rs. 17.34 crores towards weather-based insurance for chilli crop in Guntur district to the losses incurred in the last Rabi season (2009-10). The expenditure, to be incurred by the government, would be entirely borne by the Agriculture Insurance Company of India Limited which is vested with the responsibility of implementing National Agricultural Insurance Scheme.

responsibilities.initiating_agent: Government: Ministry of Agriculture, Government of Andhra Pradesh
responsibilities.executing_agent: Government: Agriculture Insurance Company of India
responsibilities.funding_source: Ministry of Agriculture, Government of India

evaluative_information.success_factors: Financial: ability of farmers to pay premium, Technical: correlating weather indices with yield losses, needs upto 25 years historical weather data, accurate recording of weather phenomenon at appropriate spatial and temporal scales, simple claim process and timely payments
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: distance of the farm from the weather station, non-coverage of perils other than weather, wider sowing / planting window of the crop, differences in soil types & management practices, shift in climatic and weather patterns, etc. leading to weak correlation between the yield and the weather indices, etc.
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: Win win
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: 17,000 farmers covered, 12000 ha covered and 11.5 crores total premium received. The WBCIS has provided enormous benefits to the Chilly growers in the first season. The number of farmers receiving the benefit was 16,357 and the total amount of claims was Rs 17.34 crore. According to a press release,the number of mandals receiving the benefit was 38. The Agriculture Insurance Company of India CMD said WBCIS has been launched for Red Chilly growers in Guntur district during Kharif 2009 season on a pilot basis. The Company had conducted awareness programmes among the farmers, obtained their consent and provided a customized product as per their requirement.

additional_information: The Agriculture Insurance Company of India CMD said Weather-Based Crop Insurance Scheme (WBCIS) has been launched for Red Chilly growers in Guntur district during Kharif 2009 season on a pilot basis. The Company had conducted awareness programmes among the farmers, obtained their consent and provided a customized product as per their requirement. WBCIS, which was effectively implemented in Guntur district, has been extended to other districts also for crops like cotton, chilly, oil palm and sweet lime this year.

title: Weather Based Crop Insurance Scheme for Kharif crops  (2010)

overview.feedback: The weather based crop insurance scheme provides a financial safety net to weather induced risk of crop loss and is thus has an important climate change adaptation potential. It operates on the principle of area approach – the geographical area around a reference weather station is pre-notified by the State Level Coordination Committee on Crop Insurance (SLCCCI). The scheme is valid for crops that have been notified by SLCCCI. The sum insured is almost the same as the cost of cultivation and predeclared by AIC (Agriculture Insurance Company of India Limited) and even the crops to be insured are notified two months before a season. It currently insures crops in the Rabi (winter) and Kharif (monsoon) seasons and only those crops that have been notified by the State Government are considered for insurance.  Coverage is available for deficit rainfall (both volume and distribution ) and excess rainfall, with triggers defined for each.

responsibilities.executing_agent: Agriculture Department, Government of Rajasthan
responsibilities.funding_source: Agriculture Insurance Company of India limited, ICICI Lombard, IFFCO Tokio General Insurance

evaluative_information.success_factors: Financial: Without capital to invest the scheme will not be implemented
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: Lack of finances: Without capital to invest the scheme will not be implemented
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: no-regret: gives financial safety to farmers against weather based crop losses
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: not specified

additional_information: For a crop in the Kharif season there are two types of insurance covers (i) Deficit rainfall cover- (a) Rainfall cover Volume: This is divided into three phases, periods of which depend upon the crops being grown. In each phase there are two triggers based on amount of rainfall and for both these triggers there is a different rate (Rs./mm). The maximum payout for these phases is different for each crop but the total maximum payout under the cover is Rs. 3000 for each crop. (b) Rainfall Distribution Cover (Consecutive dry days): for this there is one trigger based on the number of dry days and the payout (maximum and for number of trigger days) varies accordingly with each crop and number of consecutive dry days. (ii) Excess Rainfall Cover (multiple crops): In this case there can be one or two phases with time periods, amount of rainfall and payout varying for different crops and for those that have different phases. The premium for each is 10% of the total sum insured. The scheme for weather based insurance is also applicable for the Rabi crops and has been initiated since the year 2007-08. For detailed information please check this weblink: http://www.rajasthankrishi.gov.in/WeatherInsuranceindex.asp.

title: Yangtze River Basin climate change vulnerability and adaptation action

overview.feedback: The action aimed at finding a way to mitigate climate change impacts on human being, forest, fresh water, urban area, etc. Detailed information is given on the adaptation methodology of agriculture to climate change: 1, It was found that with the increment of CO2 concentration and air temperature, the maize and wheat yields are expected to decrease in the Yangtze River Basin, but the rice output remains stable. Therefore, it is recommended to compress the area of maize and generally expand the rice cultivation area.2, With the increase of heat resources in the river basin, change cropping/harvesting system once per year into twice or even thrice per year to raise the food production.3, Planting the rice with longer growth period would increase the yield of about 17-23% compared to that of original crop varieties in the river basin.

responsibilities.executing_agent: CAS (Institute of Geographic Sciences and Natural Resource Research; Institute of Mountain Hazards and Environment;Institute of Applied Ecology), CMA, Fudan University

evaluative_information.success_factors: not specified
evaluative_information.limiting_factors: not specified
evaluative_information.no_regret_/_win-win_option: no-regret option
evaluative_information.project_evaluation: The project evaluates the vulnerability of water resources, agriculture, forests, grassland, wetlands and coastal city to climate change, and some general strategies and specific measures are put forward to adapt to climate change.

additional_information: This is one of the ten actions in HSBC Climate Partnership project
